Thank you also for your contributions that will help this be time totally devoted to healing for this beautiful family. Much love and gratitude.Here's Michal's Facebook post:My dear friends and family. I have some news to share. Last week I was diagnosed with a pretty substantial tumor on my vestibular nerve and pressing up against my brain stem.I went in for a basic check up, as I'd been having a sore throat on my right side, kind of on and off, for a month, only at night-- thought I was probably just fighting something, but that it was going on too long and I should address it. My primary doc checked for inflammation-- everything looked fine and so he sent me to a specialist: an ENT (ear nose throat doc), MC Chen. MC was fairly unemotional doc, who just went about checking me in a routine way, then said, "I'd like to put a scope down your nose with some local anesthetic." Sure, I said. He found nothing unusual. "Let's do a CT scan". "Could we maybe do an MRI instead - to avoid all the radiation?", and he responded firmly that a CT was the way to go, to start off and that I should do it as soon as possible. Despite the weeks out appointment prospects, I nudged my way into getting a CT scan that same day (by standing there at the front desk until there was an opening). At 5pm that evening my phone rang. MC Chen with a heavy voice I'll never forget, "so, I have some news.. I couldn't find anything in your throat, but the radiologist found an 'incidental finding'-- there is a 2x2x2cm lesion in your inner ear and on your cerebellum and brain stem. I think we need to follow this up with an MRI as soon as we can." Next day, MRI results come back and we are invited back to Chen's for an explanation. Michael and I sit there and see this image of my brain with a large white mass within it. I am shaking as the news comes in, in waves. I have a tumor on my vestibular nerve called a "Vestibular Schwannoma". These are usually benign and slow growing, but the trouble with mine is it's location. A terrible place for a person who is smitten with movement and sensation as I happen to be. It surrounds my right vestibular nerve (balance), it is on my facial nerve (facial mobility, facial strength), it's in contact with the trigeminal nerve-- responsible for facial sensation, biting, chewing, taste. It is pressed up against my cerebellum and brain stem (Bracium Pontis-- muscular control, coordination and movement, and against my Lateral Pons= my life. Control of the inhalation changing to the exhalation.I feel the terror spread into every nook and cranny of my body like a slow and tentacled poison originating at my belly, my whole body shaking. uncontrollable shaking. I'm at once visualizing the most miserable physical outcome, and then to the possibility of loosing life and not being there for my Maya, seeing her, her not having a mother, losing her mother so young, Michael and Maya losing a mother. I don't want this. I don't want this! Michael squeezes my hand. I look at his face, he is pale. Eyes on the floor.Cut to next days. HARD days. I can't seem to physically manage or contain the amount of fear that is streaming through. I want a monk to tell me what to do. I'm trying and using all my tools. Breathing, moving, yoga, showering, dancing, melatonin, calling wise elders, Netflix! Michael and I are hugging each other full bodied, like two entangled embryos, telling each other the most tender utterings. He is staying with me through every wave of anguish. Saying the most powerful words of love and commitment and level headedness and steady good old Michael medicine. Michael tells me these things are constant: he and Maya will not leave me.--- Now it's a week later, and we have seen several teams of doctors (at UW and Swedish) and are consulting on what the next steps are. All of them agree that a retrosigmoid craniotomy (eek! That word Craniotomy!) is the way to go, but comes with a whole slew of possible outcomes and side effects that will dramatically shift my quality of life. For sure- my vestibular nerve will be severed to remove the tumor. I will have to relearn balance and proprioception with one remaining verstibular nerve. Dance and yoga will hopefully help me navigate this process in more detail, perhaps more skillfully. Almost certain, I'll be deaf in my right ear. The high chance maybes: I may have partial or complete facial paralysis (facial paralysis! Floppy face! please god no. I say no thank you please no no) for a short or permanent time. Secondly, I'll have major headaches from the actual procedure, and the big ass chunk of my skull they are removing to get in and will replace with titanium, the muscles that will be moved aside, touched and manipulated, etc. The small chance: bleeding, stroke, meningitis, death.I am not a good candidate for Gama Knife radiation therapy, apparently, as with this procedure, the tumor can swell up to up to 50% larger, and with it's proximity to my brain stem, this is a no-go. It also takes away my chances to have surgery in the future if the tumor regrows, as it makes the surrounding (very important) tissues sticky, cooked, scarred and unworkable.--- So now 9 days out after receiving the news. I am doing ok. I'm actually pretty good, steady, almost content. I am trying to keep the flow of normality. I am filling my life, my time, (as usual) with a LARGE amounts of movement: ("Michael, my love-- do you mind if we ride our bike to every possible activity and errand we have despite the weather, our fatigue and the darkness?") And beautiful precious friend people who shepherd me so gorgeously into an equanimous state, and dancing and smooshing my face into Maya's pot belly. By the way, muy importante is MAYA KNOWS NOTHING. and it shall be kept that way. She thinks we're going to yoga class when we drop her off for 5 hours at a friend's house. Please hold this in the highest importance. I want her world to remain unchanged and sunshine until she needs to deal with whatever comes.I'll attempt to keep you all posted about the next steps. With much love.

title: Claire Kepsel
text: Dear Friends, our cute Claire Kepsel, daughter of Caleb and Jayne, has been sick for many weeks now.  On Monday June 2nd, Claire was taken to the hospital but this time they have found a tumor on her brain.  Claire, only being 8 years old, will be going in for surgery on Tuesday morning to remove, what the doctors believe is, medulloblastoma which is cancerous.  They are concerned that with the tumor being right on her spinal cord that it can spread very quickly down the cord to other parts of her body.  We hope that you will add Claire and her family to your prayers and if you can to donate to this fund as the family is currently without insurance.  Caleb, the father, has been marked as the beneficiary of this campaign.

title: Jamie Robertson Recovery Fund
text: On June 26, 2018, Jamie discovered the melanoma he had been diagnosed with 5 years ago had recurred and spread to other parts of his body.  He is currently undergoing radiation treatments of his brain to remove cancerous tumors before beginning treatment for the rest of his body.Originally started as a group of friends who wanted to help Jamie and Carly with their landscaping costs for the summer, this effort has grown in size leading to the creation of this page.  Anyone who would like to support Jamie and his family through this difficult time may do so by donating here.  As Jamie goes through months of treatment and hospital stays, the goal of this fund will be to assist Jamie and the family with their needs through this time.

title: #TEAMLEXI
text: In May of this year, the Shaw family received life changing news about their 14 year old daughter, Lexi.  Lexi was diagnosed with Ewing Sarcoma of the kidney.  This is an incredibly rare form of cancer which required Lexi to under surgery to remove her left kidney this week. She is presently undergoing fertility treatments while she recovers from surgery, so that she may be able to have children of her own someday .  She is scheduled to undergo 8-10 months of intense chemotherapy, missing her sophomore year of high school.  Among the many current and future sacrifices John and Debbie will make, they have decided that Debbie will have to take a leave of absence from her job to care for Lexi during this difficult time.         This GoFundMe page was created to help support Lexi and her family.  So many of you have been looking for ways to contribute and help. Please consider donating to the Shaw Family. Every donation helps, big or small.  If you are unable to donate, please consider sharing this post with family and friends.  John, Debbie, Kristina and Lexi thank everyone for all the love and support they have received and ask for your continued prayers.

title: Sylas Sandoval Slays Cancer
text: On April 7th Sylas went in for a doctors appointment to get some aches and pains checked out. That appointment turned out to be the start of many more hospital visits and tests. Sylas has now been diagnosed with Stage 4 large B cell Lymphoma. The cancer has since spread to his bones and he is now undergoing intense chemotherapy. The scheduled time right now for his first round of chemo treatment is set for 18 weeks, and will be very aggressive. The obvious situation in this case is that Sylas will be out of work during treatments and beyond that. He is the sole provider for his wife Brigette, and their two children, Little Sylas (5) and Malakai (3). Owning a construction business and not being able to work on job sites has put a major stress on the family financially, so we created this page in hopes of helping provide coverage for everyday expenses and necessities for the four of them. For anybody who knows Sylas personally you know how positive and optimistic of a person he is, and that hasn’t changed since his prognosis. Anything you can donate is greatly appreciated by the family. Please join us in helping Sylas slay cancer with lots of support and especially words of encouragement! If you would like to visit our Facebook page please click on this link: https://m.facebook.com/groups/583249418700547If you are interested in bringing a meal to the family here is the link: https://takethemameal.com/IDSQ9986

title: Alex DePriest Memorial fund
text: If anyone would have interest, were creating this as a Memorial to Alex and expense fund with contribution to the American Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation (JDRF) and I, Cary DePriest am responsible for all withdrawal and use for the campaign, as well as the delivery of any access funds to the Certified Charity named

title: Please Help Neetu
text: On March 13, 2018, we received the worst phone call any parent/sibling/fiancé/friend can imagine. Neetu was in critical condition and we needed to rush to the hospital immediately. As she was walking to work in downtown Philadelphia, she felt a shortness of breath in her chest. “It’s just my asthma,” she thought, and tried to push through, walking and losing more of her balance with each step.A good samaritan, who was driving on their way to work, saw Neetu faint and immediately stopped their car to help and call 911. The ambulance arrived right after she collapsed, and while being lifted into the ambulance, Neetu called a friend. She was crying. She was alone. She was terrified. She told her friend that she was going to a hospital, and when she realized she did not know where she would be headed to, she cried on the phone to her friend. Suddenly, everything went dark.She went into cardiac arrest. Her heart stopped beating;  blood stopped flowing; and her body shut down. It's nothing short of a miracle that she was in the ambulance, as CPR was administered immediately, which temporarily kept her blood flowing. If Neetu was not in an ambulance, she would not be here today.In the ER, doctors were able to bring our angel back to us with the aid of many machines and medications. She was immediately intubated and placed on a ventilator to help her breath. Additionally, she was placed on a machine to provide her body with oxygenated blood. Once her family arrived to the ER, Neetu was being transferred to the cardiac ICU. Hours later, they were able to find the cause of her cardiac arrest.Neetu had two major blood clots in her lungs. These clots put so much pressure that her heart stopped. From what doctors have told the family, only 4%-6% of patients survive a blood clot of this size in their lungs.Currently, Neetu is still intubated within the cardiac ICU and under the care of an amazing team for whom we are forever indebted to. Neetu just recently celebrated her 30th birthday on March 9. She was also in the midst of planning her wedding which is set for July 2018. She met the love of her life, Devin Luqman, while in law school. They have been together for 7 years and were happily planning for the next step of their lives together.We need your help. Neetu was blessed to receive medical care from one of the best hospitals in the US. However, this quality care comes with a cost. The recovery from this medical event is immense, and much more than we ever anticipated. Neetu will be placed in inpatient care for the foreseeable future. Once she exits, physical therapy, many outpatient follow ups, and other medical care awaits. Doctors have told the family that the total recovery time lies between several months to one year. She has a long road of recovery ahead of her.  Any financial help, prayers and well wishes would truly be a blessing. Thanks everyone.

title: Jillian's  Microtia Surgeries
text: Jillian Smith, a beautiful, strong-willed and courageous eight year-old  with a passion for school and sports, was born with Bilateral Microtia.  "Microtia is a congenital deformity of the outer ear where the ear does not fully develop during the first trimester of pregnancy.  Microtia ears vary in appearance, and are usually smaller in size, often only consisting of a tiny peanut-shaped lobe. Microtia occurs about 1 in 5,000 births, though rates can vary depending on ethnic background.  In 90% of cases, it affects only one ear, usually the right ear, and is more common in males. " Sited (Stanford Children's Health)Jillian however, was born with Microtia on both ears and will need three reconstructive surgeries this year.  The surgeon will suture pieces of cartilage harvested from Jillian's ribs to create the framework for the new ears and cover them with the patient's normal tissue. Recovery involves short term hospital stays and long term recuperation at home.While Jillian is able to hear, there are times where this condition hinders her hearing abilities and overall quality of life.  Safety is a major concern because when Jillian wears a helmet for sports and bike-riding, she cannot hear clearly.  During Winter time, when Jillian wears a hat, she has difficulty hearing everyday sounds such as traffic and voices like the crossing guard, teacher, friends in the playground, etc.  As Jillian gets older, this condition is beginning to affect her self confidence at school as well as in extra-curricular activities.  Already a timid child, she has become negatively impacted by situations where other children call attention to her ear deformity. Upon attending a Microtia conference in NYC, Jillian's parents selected a surgeon based out of California who specialized in only Microtia surgeries.  To their dismay, this surgeon retired three years ago due to medical reasons.  He recommended Jillian's current surgeon based out of NYC.  Although Jillian's parents have been saving for the surgeries since Jillian was born, the current surgeon does not accept any medical insurance.  With the medical fees for the doctor alone well exceeding the goal amount, I'd like to help them make up the difference.   As a dear friend of the family, I have witnessed the emotional toll that this situation has taken on them. While there is little that I can do to help minimize their worries emotionally,  I would love to help alleviate the financial burden that these surgeries impose.Any donation, big or small, will make a huge difference to Jillian's future.

title: Shiloh Cronck
text: Hello. We are friends and neighbors of the Cronck family who wanted to provide an avenue for those wishing to help them through their daughter’s latest medical crisis. It has been heartbreaking to stand by and helplessly watch the up and down roller coaster as their family has seen 5 year old Shiloh struggle through one mystery illness, endure spinal surgery to resolve it and then seem to be on the road to recovery only to end up back in the hospital in even worse circumstances. We’ve watched their lives come to a halt as they juggle caring for their other three children and straddle life between their home in Bellingham and Seattle Children’s Hospital. We’ve watched and wondered how we can support their family. We know they have asked for, and continue to ask, for positive thoughts and prayers. At this time, we’d like to offer additional support as well. There is no firm estimate as to how long they will be in the hospital. Nothing is guaranteed right now. We ask other friends, neighbors and supporters to help us raise money for whatever they need in the coming weeks and/or months. Whether it be medical bills, lodging and transportation, food, or life essentials - they can use our support. I urge you to consider a gift to this beautiful, active, sweet family. Your prayers and thoughts are welcomed as well. Thank you for taking the time to read this. We are grateful for any and all support. If you are not familiar with this situation, let us share Sommer’s words from her public Facebook page. “Shiloh is five years old and the youngest of four. In April, she got very sick and after many hospital visits it was discovered that she had an epidural infection (MSSA) and had emergency spinal surgery across five vertebrae to clear the infection. That was April 10 and she was healing beautifully and on a regimen of antibiotics to thoroughly rid of the infection. On May 9 we returned to the ER as she had high fevers, headache, sore throat, vomiting, and some alarming blood work that was part of her surgery follow up. As we were in the ER she started saying she couldn’t breathe. It is not why we brought her in but it rapidly deteriorated to the point that she was transferred to the ICU on May 10 and is now on a ventilator. The scariest part is that they simply have no idea what is causing it. She has has blood draws, MRIs, X-rays, CT scans, ultrasounds, a spinal tap, nose and throat swabs and still no answers. They do not believe it is related to the previous epidural abscess but are dumbfounded she could have two bouts of horrible bad luck in such quit succession. Her lungs have deteriorated and have fluid in and around them. They show signs of damage. We have no idea why. If they could only figure out what is causing this, perhaps they could help her. All we want are answers and to be on the path to taking our baby home. She has all the best teams working for her, and I am keeping the faith that they WILL figure this out. But my heart needs it to be soon. Please keep her in your thoughts and prayers. If you know her brothers or sister, please do not go into great detail with them. With so little information at this time we have chosen to limit what they know about the situation. Thank you.”Update: Shiloh's mother and father have created a Facebook page so we can follow the latest news about how Shiloh is doing. Here is the link to take you there.  www.facebook.com/shiloheverly. Thank you all for your gifts to help our friends and neighbors.

title: Support Carey's Fight
text: For those of you that don’t know Carey, she is the middle sister of 3 girls whose mother passed away of cancer way too young. After being diagnosed herself at 31 shortly after marrying Jon, the love of her life, Carey beat the odds. With dreams of babies, Carey and Jon moved to Hawiian paradise but struggled with fertility treatments for years until they miraculously conceived naturally not once, but twice in 13 months! With a 1 year old and 3 month old, Carey was recently diagnosed again with Stage IV metastatic breast cancer that has begun to spread. Unfortunately, some of the cancer is showing growth during chemo this time so they are exploring the best alternative solution.  They are hoping to move their family of 4 to a treatment facility in Arizona which comes with a financial burden with treatment, moving costs, housing, childcare, etc. More details on Carey’s journey is below from Stacey. Please help us pray for the Moyers!  PLEASE ALSO HELP BY KEEPING THIS FUND A SURPRISE FOR CAREY AND HER FAMILY!￼My sister Carey is one of the most intelligent, selfless, beautiful & funniest people you will ever meet.  She’s adopted more rescue animals than I can count, spent years as a Disneyland princess and can make me laugh harder than anyone I know.When Carey was first diagnosed with stage 3 breast cancer at the age of 31, we were all shocked and terrified.  Over the next two years, Carey went through multiple rounds of chemotherapy and radiation, as well as a double mastectomy.  Although it was no easy task, she is a fighter and two years later, I can still remember the moment she was officially declared cancer free. Unfortunately, Carey is up against the same battle once again.  This time she is fighting for even more - her two little baby boys, Jake & Drew. ￼When my friends first asked me if we could set up a Go Fund Me to help with Carey’s expenses, my answer was absolutely NOT! Over time though, I have realized this is a necessity. We have to get Carey well for her boys and give her the opportunity financially to explore every treatment option there is.  Also, I began thinking - how amazing would it be to SURPRISE Carey and Jon and show them how everyone they love came together to help their family.  Everyone asks us - how can I help? And I think this is it.   It would mean so much to us for you to share and spread Carey’s story and give her boys the best chance at growing up with their mom.  Side Note – Bill (my Dad) & Carey do NOT know we have set this up, please help make sure they don’t find out, so we can surprise Carey (plus Bill lives by its better to give than receive, almost to a fault!) ￼￼Carey had just married Jon when she was first diagnosed in 2009 and since they hoped to have children of their own, she went through the process of freezing her eggs before starting chemotherapy.  A few years ago, they experienced an unfortunate (and rare!) setback when they began the IVF process and none of the frozen pre-chemo embryos survived.  Looking for an alternative, Carey asked me to be an egg donor.  Inside I was nervous, but quickly said yes after seeing everything Carey had gone through.  We both went through the egg retrieval process, but her doctor was weary of her outcome because of all her body had endured.   When Carey was ready for the embryo implantation, she found out she was pregnant, NATURALLY!  Her doctors had given her less than a 1% chance to get pregnant on her own. This little baby, Jake, would be known as the “miracle baby” in our family.  When Jake was just four months old, Carey found out she was pregnant again with Jake’s little brother!! When Carey’s second baby, Drew, was only a few months old, she started experiencing extreme back pain. She hoped it was just from carrying around her two babies all day. When the pain persisted, she knew she needed to see the doctor and asked her oncologist for a scan.  The day after the scan, her home phone rang.  She was busy holding Drew and immediately began shaking when she heard the message. The doctor stated she needed her to call her back immediately. Carey had that gut feeling this was not good.  And late last year, a bone, CT and PET scan confirmed the worst.    The cancer was back and it was everywhere. My whole family and I were devastated to hear the news.  My initial reaction was that she isn’t going to make it.  How could this happen to her again?  And to our family?  Carey has been through so much and now has a husband and two small baby boys that need her.   Despite my worst fears, when you talk to Carey, you can’t help but to be positive.  True to her personality, she has the best attitude from the day she found out she said, “I’m going to fight this as hard as I can.”   God has given her so much strength!Since the beginning of this year, Carey has been battling.  They moved their family from Hawaii back to Irvine, she’s been on chemo, she’s adopted a raw vegan diet and is doing everything in her power to fight this.We just received her first set of scans since starting treatment and unfortunately it wasn’t the good news we were hoping for.  While her bones do show some healing, the tumors in her liver and lungs have shown growth.  Our options are running out.  Last week, we road tripped to Arizona to explore another path with a clinic that has a 90% success rate in healing her type of cancer.  After speaking with her doctors, we feel this is the best next step for Carey’s treatment.   The plan is for Carey and her family to relocate to Arizona in the coming week so she can seek immediate treatment with this clinic.  Her treatment in Arizona is set to begin early next month. I want to thank everyone in advanced.  We have had so many people praying for Carey and showing so much love and support thus far.  We desperately need to get Carey back to 100% healthy so she can enjoy life with her husband, raising her two baby boys.  My sisters and I lost our mom at such a young age and our biggest fear is for the same to happen to Jake and Drew. Please remember – this is a SURPRISE for Carey & Jon, so SHHHHHHH!!   Be extra careful sharing it on social media (block her from your posts).  I can’t wait to share with Carey how much we raised and ease some of their financial concerns about the next steps in treatment.   Next month, I plan to videotape the reveal and will share it with everyone.  Thank you for your prayers, donations and support.  I will keep you updated on progress. XO Stacey (Carey’s little sister)￼This fund was started by Sarah Cook and Lindsay Hornbeak with input from Carey's sisters, Stacey and Bobbi.  All funds will go directly to Carey and her family after the reveal.

title: Stewart Francke's Struggle&Strength
text: Stewart Francke's Struggles & Strength                                                     SUR * VI * VOR To beat the odds, one with great courage and strength, a true inspiration.Welcome to our Go Fund Me page, established to assist Stewart Francke and his family following a recent , very difficult 6-month health struggle.We are Stewart's sisters and the sponsors of this page, Kit and Martha. Our brother Stewart is a 20 year survivor of leukemia and a stem cell transplant, leukemia's curative treatment. Since the transplant, Stewart has regularly suffered from a variety of painful, incapacitating physical challenges related to cancer and the transplant that have limited his activities and income.Stewart Francke, Autumn 2017, before recent illness.Just before this past Christmastime, Stewart was once again blindsided by a serious and unexpected lifethreatening illness when he was rushed to the hospital after suffering two pulmonary embolisms and a lung infarction, causing excruciating pain, shortness of breath, and ultimately the tissue death of half of his left lung. It's been a very rough patch since that point. January, 2018, SF home after hospital stay in ICU.Despite many setbacks, he has pushed hard to fight his health troubles and again live life as he imagined it. Stewart was hospitalized several times after the original event, with more difficulty breathing and coping with chest pain. He's undergone batteries of tests and invasive surgical procedures while fighting infection and false hopes for recovery. His iron level has not been consistently maintained despite bi-weekly transfusions.Spring, 2018, IV Iron transfusion.Chest X-Ray showing loss of bottom half,  left lung .Most recently, he underwent  esophageal dilation surgery to repair his inability to swallow. Doctors also suspect that Stewart has continued internal bleeding, yet the source has remained undetectable since Christmas. As you can imagine, along with varying periodic new symptoms, this has become a medical nightmare. 2017 (Photo-Kathleen Galligan)We don't have a crystal ball to divine the magnitude or length of Stewart's ongoing illness, but we do know the staggering and extensive medical costs being incurred daily. This is a very difficult public request for Stewart and his family to make. It takes fortitude to go to your extended community for financial help, but as Stewart's sisters, we have no compunction asking you for a donation to help offset the mounting medical expenditures. With an immediate future involving more invasive procedures , more pulmonary breathing issues and continued cardiac edema, it's going to be a lengthy period of time before Stewart can resume an active, full schedule. The daily avalanche of bills is already overwhelming and emotionally demoralizing  to his entire family.2016 with Bruce Springsteen, Stew & Tess FranckeWith a successful career as a popular singer, songwriter, musician and author,  Stewart 's lyrics and prose hinge upon being a survivor with purpose, always persistent in trying to face adversity with strength and hope, and celebrate the beauty and promise of each new day.Your donation to this Go Fund Me campaign to help pay for medical bills and  expenses related to this health struggle will allow Stewart to continue his battle back to good health, making music, and  hopefully a full life. We thank you and deeply appreciate your donations toward the improvement of Stewart’s well-being.Gratefully,Kit Reece and Martha  HumphreysJune, 2018Stewart Francke Career Photograph Appendix:2011, Recording with production partner Bryan Reilly.(photo: Marty Rickard)Stewart singing with Jill Jack at the Ark, 2012.Undatedlive show (Photo Marty Rickard)1999  News piece on Stewart's cancer outreach.Alumni magazine, Northwood University2017 Live shot, Trinity House, Detroit .(Kathleen  Galligan)2000 with Stewart III, Northern Michigan.2016 Detroit Free Press2017 SF performing at Arts, Beats & Eats1996, SF taking notes from the Master, George Clinton.

title: Ariel's Recovery
text: Ariel is an 18 year old senior at Agoura High School. His passion is basketball, and he grew up playing club basketball for several years, as well as playing on his high school team. In December 2017, Ariel was suddenly paralyzed. One day after coming home from the gym, he gradually lost all sensation and mobility in his body from the neck down within a few hours, leaving him completely paralyzed. Ariel went from living an active life to spending several months motionless, confined to a hospital bed and undergoing countless tests. Our family has tried relentlessly to seek answers about his condition.His diagnosis is likely to be Transverse Myelitis, an inflammation of the spinal cord. Ariel is slowly regaining feeling in his body as he adjusts to life in a wheelchair. He is making small improvements each week, but not without the cost of hospital bills, physical therapy, and around-the-clock care and help. Your donations will go towards covering these costs and seeking out the appropriate treatment to help get Ariel back on his feet. Any contribution is appreciated, and our family would like to thank you for your support.Kambiz Aramnia is Ariel's father, and will be the one to withdraw the funds from the account.

title: Medical and housing
text: I've been in professional baseball for 40 years. I have type 2 diabetes which has caused kidney failure. I was to have a kidney transplant last fall but in pre transplant tests, they found a cancerous tumor. Tumor was removed but transplant put on hold to make sure cancer does not return. Also, do not have a donor at this time. Two days after surgery, I was informed by new ownership of the Miami Marlins that my contract would not be renewed. I am currently receiving dialysis three days a week and struggle with blood pressure with my medical issues. I have exhausted all of my savings and maxed out credit cards and will soon be homeless without any income.

title: TYLER TRAN CANCER WARRIOR!
text: ￼￼Strength is defined as the quality of being strong; to measure the capacity for exertion. In my eyes, my nephew Tyler Tran is the definition of strength. Tyler is a vibrant 17 year old, who is wise and compassionate beyond his years. He’s the older brother to his sister, Haley and as she puts it, “He is the coolest brother and my number one fan.”. I simply can't find a more loving sibling relationship. Tyler loves music especially listening to Imagine Dragons, Maroon 5 and Bruno Mars. Tyler loves basketball, especially the Houston Rockets and especially number 13, James Harden. He loves to indulge in his favorite foods of steak , burgers and my homemade mac & cheese with tater-tots. And as a true kung fu warrior at heart, he would love to meet his idol, Jackie Chan one day. His dream was to attend and graduate from Stanford University. I’ve never smiled more than when I’m in his presence and this kid is such a jokester. Either cracking jokes or enjoying a good laugh, he brings forth the best in everyone he meets and the love for his friends and family is immeasurable.  Unfortunately, Tyler has been battling cancer for almost a year now. In August 2017, he underwent surgery to remove a malignant brain tumor. Even though the road to recovery was treacherous and rough, Tyler was a champion throughout the rehabilitation phase. Though short-term memory loss, double vision and cognitive thinking compromised, he also underwent Chemotherapy and Radiation treatment afterwards. In May 2018, his MRI looked clear and the whole family was able to take a deep breath of relief. Just when we thought the fight was over, Tyler was rushed to the ER last week to find another tumor growing in his head. This time the germinoma tumor was super aggressive and had gone from microscopic to golf size within 6 weeks. Luckily his team at Sutter Children's center in Sacramento quickly scheduled him for surgery and was able to remove to mass. Tyler woke the next morning bouncing back with energy and strength no one predicted would happen. His optimism glowed, however the good news of the removal quickly turned bad. After several tests, the oncology team determined this was extremely rare and highly malignant aggressive yolk-sac tumor had becoming resistant to the chemo and radiation treatments he received in the past. Since there isn't a standard therapy for this rare tumor, the next plan of attack is to begin very strong regimented chemotherapy of Bleomycin and Cisplatin. At this point, Tyler’s determination in his fight has given us strength to support him through kicking cancer's butt, however I know we can do more. We are looking at other possible treatments for this rare and aggressive tumor.  He is being transferred to Stanford Hospital to further his treatments and hopefully shed some light on this terrible disease and if not a cure, then give us more time with this amazing kid. I can’t imagine the heartache of seeing your own child suffer through the pain of battling for his life, but to be left with the financial burden on top of that stress is gut wrenching. Momma Ching and Aunty Youk(Kelly) have been diligently caring for Tyler during his fight at Stanford. These amazing sisters have endured emotional and physical hardship more than anyone should for any child.  I’m reaching out on this family’s behalf to ask for your assistance. Whether it be a medical referral, spiritual or financial, your support would mean the world to Tyler and his family.On a personal note, I’ve been with Tyler since the day of his birth. Tyler is admired tremendously by his friends and family for his bravery, amazing strength, integrity and ambitious tenacity for life. To ask the questions as to why he was chosen to fight this battle is beyond any universal algorithm or even our faith can answer. The thoughtfulness and generosity of Tyler's heart is what amazes me. Even through his suffering, he continues to amaze me and reassures us that "Everything will be fine, it's OK, I'm OK." and as a mother, my heart is broken and devastated because I know the suffering my nephew has gone through and how bleak his future may be if we don't act fast. That’s why I want to raise awareness and hopefully find better treatments for aggressive brain cancers like this yolk sac germinoma tumor so that Tyler will have the best chances of being a hero to his sister, my son and pretty much everyone he meets.  As his biggest support system, we’ve decided to keep Tyler and Haley’s morale strong and optimistic with positive affirmations and a painted smile on our faces in hopes that he survives this battle with cancer. He has 1 in 100 chances. Please continue to paint this picture for Tyler and Haley, because at the end of the day, our only gift to them is hope. Thank you for listening and many blessings to you. #fuckcancer #cancersucks #tylerswarriors #tylercancerwarrior #kickcancersbutt #germinomatumor #yolksactumor #braincancer #kidswithcancer

title: Supporting Our Jimmy Cleary
text: Hi friends,Our Jimmy, my amazing partner and father to our three wonderful children, has been diagnosed with brain cancer. Jimmy and I met with two different neurosurgeons at different hospitals yesterday and we have decided to have his care at UW Hospital. Jimmy will be having a cranioscopy surgery on Wednesday, August 1st to remove as much of the tumor as possible. We feel confident in his care team and this decision we made together.This has come as a tremendous shock to our lives starting less than a week ago. The symptoms Jim exhibited came on fast over the past couple of weeks and we acted upon them quickly. Our wedding  is 10 days away, Sam is leaving for college in two weeks and Jimmy was about to start a new teaching job he was thrilled to begin. Life can sometimes be so fragile, changing in an instant. We have seen numerous doctors and continue to research and inquire about all possible avenues we can take to prolong his health and quality of life. After surgery Jimmy will be having both radiation and chemotherapy to fight remaining cancer cells. There will be many appointments, blood draws, and six weeks of radiation daily starting mid-September to name a few of our new life events. Your kind wishes of support and hope through email and text will make a huge difference for Jim and the rest of us. We look forward to visitors in the future as they will be a great distraction from the startling change in our lives. Updates will come as often as we can, but please understand that we’ll need to make our orbit much smaller for a little while so I can continue the important care Jim so deeply deserves and the love and attention our kids need. Thank you in advance for understanding we may not be able to respond to all phone calls, texts and emails and want you to know how grateful we are to ALL of you for keeping us in your thoughts. It has already buoyed us through the first rough days.We have started this GoFund Me account because Jimmy will not be able to start off his school year and may not be able to return to work or anytime soon. Since he’s starting in a new school district, it makes everything a little more difficult. We’ll be working hard to make sure his medical coverage can’t lapse between jobs, and we will be paying for his medical plan in full after his weeks of sick leave run out instead of it being covered by the school district. I plan to take time off of work as well to care for Jim as he will need daily attention. Bringing him to appointments, blood draws, radiation and advocating for him will be costly and taxing but I am beyond honored to be his best partner and advocate. Jimmy and I will need time together as well to take care of our children and connect with his family. We are turning to you, our loving community of family and friends to ask for your consideration in donating to our fund in caring for Jimmy. Every single donation is a blessing that will help put the focus on spending quality time with our kids and extended families instead of worrying about bills and payments. We will also welcome and need help along the way for those willing to assist, whether it is attending an appointment with Jimmy or making us a simple meal. We’ll leave you with knowing that even in these days of deep sadness, we have felt immense joy, just as we have over the past three years of our relationship. We are so thankful for what we have! We’ve laughed, spent precious time with our kids, retold favorite stories and dreamed. We have remained honest and understanding and look forward to each new day ahead of us, even though the path really has taken us somewhere unknown. Love to all of you, we are grateful for our community and families.

title: Ryans fight Frontotemporal Dementia
text: Please take a few minutes to read the story of the Ryan family. Kevin Ryan was recently diagnosed with Frontotemporal Dementia. We are raising funds to help with medical expenses and bills as Kevin has been unable to work for quite some time. FTD is a progressive neurological disease that has no treatments and is always fatal. Unfortunately, Kevin will progress and will need 24 hour care.  https://www.theaftd.org/what-is-ftd/ftd-disorders/behavioral-variant-ftd-bvftd/As you can image the family is devastated. Please help out this sweet family through this GoFundMe how ever you are able.Kevin and Roxana met in 7th grade at Foothill Intermediate in Walnut Creek, California. They became Best friends in High School. Roxana was attracted to Kevin's dry sense of humor and also his passion for everything and anything. Kevin was very driven and if he said he was going to climb "Mt. Everest", Roxana had no doubt he would do it. They started dating the end of Senior year and then went to different colleges for their Freshman year where Kevin played baseball for the Olympic coach at Mt. Sac. They both transferred to the University of Arizona in Tucson were they both continued to date and graduate. They were married on August 4, 1990 and will be married 28 years this year. Kevin and Roxana have two beautiful children Shane 24 and Taylor 23. During the kids childhood , Kevin was nicked named "Mr. Mom" because he did everything!!! Cooked (really good), coached most of Shane's sports, and was a calm force of reason for the kids. The Ryans moved to Texas in 2013. Kevin's health started to decline in 2016. After a year of misdiagnosis, Kevin was diagnosed with Frontotemporal Dementia in May of 2018.

title: Chris' Medical Bills
text: Anyone who knows Chris Gallagher understands what a devoted husband, father, brother, son and friend he is. For those of you that don’t know Chris, he and his wife Crystal are the loving, devoted parents to their three beautiful children- Declan, 15, Brady, 13 and Molly, 2. They are an amazing family with an unwavering faith in God, and are together facing a challenge that requires all our love and help...Chris's only desire is to get medical treatment and return to his "normal" life.  This is a simple yet complicated desire.  One that is going to require time, faith and (unfortunately) money.  Chris and Crystal ask for nothing and almost always decline assistance.  This is why we are reaching out on their behalf.(Please know that this is the abridged version of his painful journey since December.  Please reach out with any questions.)Chris has been ill since mid-December and until recently, the doctors had been unable to determine what has caused his issues.  Since December, Chris has been in intense pain, and on bed rest.  Fortunately, Chris has been seen by highly qualified specialists.  However, he has also had to endure numerous tests and hospital stays because of the sheer complexity of his medical situation.  Initial CT Scans indicated that his adrenal glands had been bleeding and had increased in size (presently to the size of soccer balls).  He is taking medication to replace the 2 hormones that his body is no longer producing.   Through all of the testing he has endured, it was found that he has tumors in both of the adrenal glands and that he has ‘dark patches’ at the bottom of both lungs.  From these findings, further testing was required.In March, Chris got the difficult news that he indeed has Stage 4 cancer in his lungs, lymph nodes, and adrenal glands. The cancer diagnosis has been difficult on many levels for the family, especially having lost Chris’ dad in February 2016 to the same disease. What we had hoped would be some minimally-invasive surgeries has now turned into something more complicated, difficult, and expensive.While the full plan and schedule of Chris’ treatment is still developing, we do know that he will be starting his treatments the week of April 2nd.  Chris is a good candidate for immunotherapy as well, and we will find that out in the coming weeks.  Currently, they are waiting for more results from two more tests from the biopsy to find out definitively.  Immunotherapy is similar to chemotherapy in procedure, it is just a different drug.  In the meantime, we are humbly asking for your financial support as Chris and his family navigate the costly world of healthcare. These funds will be used to offset medical expenses, assist with keeping a normal daily life for the kids, and help with the costs of traveling 4 hours round-trip to Johns Hopkins on a regular basis.  As you are reading and considering lending your support to Chris and his family, I ask that you bear in mind this difficult road he is on and will be facing.  He has not worked since his pain began in December.  He has had the support of his union, but as you can well imagine, it is not enough.There are many stressors that we cannot take away from Chris & Crystal at this time, but we can impact the financial burden they’re facing.We appreciate you even visiting this page and reading our story. Chris is a wonderful man who is loved by so many far and wide. Please help us in making his life a little bit easier during this time. Thank you.

title: Guy Riccardi Heart & Kidney Fund
text: Family & Friends, We’ve struggled as a family to find the words and strength to explain what has been going on with our fathers health over the past two months. We were given advice from our transplant social worker to start a gofundme ASAP, because many families waiting for a transplant simply cannot afford it.  Sometimes the hardest thing to do is to ask people for help in these situations.  We ask our loved ones to please consider donating to help us cover some of the costs that involve a heart pump, heart & kidney transplant, medicine & hospital stay. Insurance will cover a lot of these costs, but not all. We are trying to fundraise this amount to help us pay these bills. Our journey started on Sunday, April 8th.  Guy was rushed to the hospital where he went into cardiac arrest.  He was put in Lawrence Hospitals ICU unit in very critical condition where he began the fight for a second chance in life. The first 24 hours were the toughest.  Even when the doctors told us there was no hope, he beat the odds with a heart only functioning 25% and kidney at 13%.  After 3 days of being in very critical condition, he started to make progress and we believed he was "out of the woods".  We prayed and thanked God for his second chance in life.Sunday, April 15th, we celebrated Kathy & Guys 40th Wedding Anniversary together in the ICU Unit.  It was a day of laughter, tears, gratefulness and pure love.  We knew we were blessed to get through the past week together as a family. Our celebration was short lived, hours later Guy went into cardiac arrest for a second time.  After a day and a half of getting him stable enough, we transferred him to Columbia Presbyterian Hospitals CCU Unit.Every day Guy woke up, he decided it was another day to continue to fight and turn his life around.  The universe tried to take him from us twice and this was a blessing from God that it was not time for him to leave us. Unfortunately, he is very sick.  After many tests and conversations with the doctors, they have determined he will need a heart and kidney transplant.  Even with all of this difficult news, Guy is optimistic and hopeful to make a difference in this world.  As a family, we are also determine to help him make that difference.Currently in Columbias CICU unit, he is on dialysis and a lot of medication to help his heart pump.  On June 1st, he had surgery to have an LVAD pump put in as a ‘bridge to transplant’.  This will help keep his heart keep going until a donor becomes available. ( https://www.mylvad.com/content/what-lvad-how-does-it-work) If you know Guy, you know that he truly has the biggest heart in the world.  He takes care of everyone else before he even considers taking care of himself.  One of his favorite things to do is give out nicknames - he has given every nurse and doctor one already!  As the nurses wheeled him into surgery on June 1st, they gave him a standing ovation. This gofundme is to help us cover the costs of the LVAD pump surgery, heart/kidney transplant surgery, and a lifetime of medication.Lets help give the man with the biggest heart get a new healthy one. Thank you all so much!Love, The Riccardi Family Please repost and share with the hashtag #WeHeartOurGuy

title: Help for the Heusers
text: I am sure many of you have heard that Chris and Bonnie were involved in a terrible car accident while on their 25th Anniversary trip to Florida.  Chris and Bonnie incurred devastating injuries, and the recovery time is unknown at this time but will take a very large amount of time. We are sure they will be dealing with the affects of this for the years to come.  There has been such an out pouring of support and questions about what can be done to help, we decided to create this page.  Per Go Fund Me, Anything donated will go directly to Tammy Critchlow who is acting on Chris and Bonnie's behalf and wil be used to help them out in any way that she see's fit.  I hope to be able to update this as more information becomes available.

title: Help the Greg Ray Family
text: Please help us raise money for our colleague Greg Ray and his family. He is going through cancer treatments, and needs us to help lift him and his family up with our support. As small business owners we can all imagine what it must be like. We are a community, and we will always be there for each other. Let's be there for Greg and his family during this time .

title: Owenby Family
text: Sixth Grade Math teacher Amanda Owenby, her husband Ryan and 2 1/2 year old daughter Claire recently welcomed a new addition to their family seven weeks ago as baby Cate was born.  The Owenby family now is struggling as Ryan’s cancer that had been in remission has returned.  Earlier today Ryan lost his gallant fight with this terrible disease so we are now asking the Pleasant Ridge Community to assist the family with financial help in order to make the large medical bills and family expenses a bit more manageable as they cope with the loss of their husband and dad.  In times like these it becomes evident that Pleasant Ridge is more than just a school, it is a community of people who care for one another like family.  Please consider donating today to help this wonderful teacher and her family.

title: Avery Moore's Road to Recovery
text: While on their way to a sunset cruise in Long Island NY, my nephew Avery Moore, my brother-in-law Tom Moore, my sister-in-law Becky Moore & her nephew Tristan were in a serous car accident. Avery’s vertebrae was broken on impact and bone fragments went into his spinal cord causing him to not be able to move from the neck down. He underwent surgery to remove the fragments and repair the broken vertebrae. He is able to move both arms now but not fingers, legs, feet. The doctors say it can take months to see if progress will be made for him to regain function from the waist down, but we are hopeful. He is recovering in Stony Brook ICU in NY until he can be transferred to an inpatient rehabilitation center in CT. His journey is going to cost thousands and thousands of dollars to get him home and progressing. Please help with the financial burden my brother-in-law and sister-in-law now have to deal with on top of the emotional toll that they are enduring.

title: Sean's Battle w/ Stage 3 Cancer
text: Sean MacDonnell is a loving 4 year old with stage 3 Rhabdomyosarcoma,  a rare cancer found in 250 children in the USA each year.   In February 2018, Sean's parent's, Christine & George, noticed a small mass on the side of Sean's neck that first appeared as what his pediatrician thought a swollen lymph node. Although he didn't show any sign of sickness, they took the doctors advice and put him on an antibiotic to help the mass shrink. Unfortunately, the mass only grew, and rather quickly. Christine and George proceeded to take Sean to visit the radiologist for imaging, along with blood work.  The imaging showed the mass was blood fed. This news was terrifying to Sean's parents, as most cancer cells are blood-fed.  The pediatric surgeon immediately scheduled Sean for surgery to biopsy part of the mass to send off to pathology and within a few days, they received a call with the results. The mass was a tumor. Cancer. A highly aggressive form of soft tissue cancer called Rhabdomyosarcoma.  A rare cancer. Christine said, "My heart sank- I panicked. I had no words... "  Sean was immediately admitted to the hospital. The doctors performed a variety of tests- sending him in and out of anesthesia at least a handful of times- all weekend long. The doctors staged Sean’s cancer as a stage three. The location of the tumor was deemed inoperable due to its location- too close to his spine, facial nerves and major arteries.  After a week in the hospital, Sean was discharged on his 4th birthday.  Due to this rare case, the doctors felt it was necessary to transfer Sean's case to the Dana Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, a 4 hour round-trip drive, once a week.    An intense treatment plan of chemo and radiation for the next 10-12 months is the long road ahead.  Christine and George are extremely faithful and know Sean can beat this battle, "Little Sean will fight the heck out of this and kick it in the butt. We have no doubt. There is NO other way!!"Every penny of your generous donation will help offset all of the costs associated with Sean's treatment.We thank you all so much for your love and support in helping out sweet Sean and his family!! They are SO GRATEFUL!!

title: Plz Help Keep #JohnnyStrong
text: September 15, 2018, will mark 3 years since little Johnny Morris was diagnosed with stage 4 high-risk Neuroblastoma. He was just shy of 7 months old when his parents got word from the doctors that no parent should ever have to hear, “Your baby has cancer”. To say the last 1,095 days have been incredibly challenging would be a major understatement.The chemotherapy would start immediately for Johnny in order to shrink the adrenal gland tumor to a size that was safe to operate. On January 7th, 2016 little Johnny was on the operating table for almost 17 hours at Boston Children’s Hospital while the surgeon removed as much of his disease as safely possible from his tiny torso. Once he recovered from surgery, they would hit him with many more rounds of chemo, 39 rounds so far to date. He has had stem cell transplants, advanced MIBG treatments, 20 plus rounds of radiation to his chest and face. Over 150 blood and platelet transfusions. He has had a medical port in his chest every day for 3 straight years, many of them getting removed and replaced due to infections. He has been under anesthesia more than 90 times at 3 years old. His vision and hearing have both been affected, he will never be able to have children of his own. He is not talking yet, only humming and babbling. He has only had hair for about 4 months of his entire life. All of these things are a direct result of dealing with this disease. Johnny has been robbed of just about everything imaginable, yet every day he wakes up smiling and ready to fight another day. His strength and courage could literally move mountains. He is the most inspirational person I’ve ever come across.His mother Colleen who also is his best friend and lifeline has never left his side for a second. After spending hundreds of days in Children’s hospital with her baby, her new reality is anywhere from 30-50 hours per week at Dana Farber’s Jimmy Fund Clinic where Johnny is treated. Johnny’s type of childhood cancer is a very intense one that demands a lot of attention. Colleen was a successful Executive Assistant for over 20 years while always bartending at night as well. Since September 15, 2015, she has no longer been able to work due to the constant care Johnny needs every day. The financial burden that this cancer has put on the Morris family has been tremendous.There were times over the last 3 years that the outlook was not too positive. But there is a new hope! With Johnny fighting so hard each day, he has finally made enough progress to go to Helen Devos Children’s Hospital in Grand Rapids Michigan and receive what his family believes to be life-saving medicine. He’s been accepted into a DFMO program with medicine designed to keep cancer cells out of the body. Even with this amazing news, the family’s been waiting over 2.5 years to hear, it comes with the challenge of traveling halfway across the county multiple times. This will be extremely difficult for the Morris family, not only physically and emotionally, but also financially. The Morris family has exhausted all of their financial resources during this non stop fight. With this new opportunity, they’re very hopefully that Johnny will be able to live a long healthy life.Please consider helping out the Morris family as Johnny’s fight is far from over. Please share on Instagram, Facebook, and Twitter with Family & Friends.

title: Ann Knezic Medical Fund
text: On February 23, 2018, Ann underwent an emergency craniotomy to remove a 7cm colloid cyst from her brain.  The recovery has been more difficult and extensive than expected.  Ann had been in the ICU for 2+ weeks and was finally able to be moved to a rehab floor, where she will stay into April.  When she's able to be released, she will need around-the-clock, in-home healthcare services.Needless to say, this has affected the family greatly.  The stress and anxiety felt by all close to her is immense.  On top of that, there are enormous financial concerns.Insurance will not cover every expense and the loss of income only exacerbates the problem.  With the recent brain surgery, ICU stay, and impending rehab/home healthcare needs, the costs already total into the hundreds of thousands of dollars.As you all know, Pete and Ann are respected and admired by all who know them.  Pete has impacted hundreds, if not thousands of kids, not only in Wisconsin, but throughout the Midwest.  He has taught these kids important life skills, such as hard work, loyalty and discipline.  He is a mentor, involved in the community, and willing to help anyone in need.Ann is the most patient soccer spouse around.  :)  Please help them in their time of need--any amount, large or small, will be a tremendous help and greatly appreciated.Thank you for your consideration.  Please keep Ann, Pete, and the kids in your thoughts and prayers.Sincerely,Soccer Families

title: Help Carol Support Carrie
text: Help Carol support her daughter Carrie with flight and living expenses while daughter Carrie goes through a dual heart and liver transplant.  Some of you may already know that Carrie was born with congenital heart problems and has braved 3 open heart surgeries along with other procedures too numerous to count in her 37 years.  Her first open heart was at 10 days old -  to save her life.Now, there are no more surgeries that can fix her heart. Carrie has moved to Philadelphia, a requirement to be close to the transplant center where the University of Pennsylvania Hospital medical team has performed the most dual organ heart-liver transplants for congenital heart patients. She has just been placed on the transplant list. There is literally no way to predict when she will receive the donation, in 2 weeks, 2 months or 6 months.  With the uncertainty, Carol is remaining in Denver until the call comes from Philadelphia.  The potential of having only 6-8 hours from notification until the transplant surgery means that a commercial flight does not get her there in time, a private jet On-Demand flight does. Carol has never missed a surgery or procedure.  She has been there for every one of them holding Carrie’s hand, squeezing hard when the anesthesia goes into the IV and kissing her forehead as she’s being wheeled into the operating room.  This one will be the most important of all.  After the surgery, Carrie will be sedated for several days and Carol will be at her bedside, focusing on Carrie’s healing.What you probably don’t know is that Carol has been going through treatment for breast cancer for the last year.  She has endured surgery, 20 weeks of chemotherapy and 33 radiation treatments. Endured it all – pain, fatigue, nausea, worry, the days where she said “I just want my life back”.  The process is just finished and she’s recovering with a few more medical procedures to navigate.  With all of that, last year she was not able to work very much.  The few wonderful coaching clients she had and couple of great workshops was all she able to conduct did not come anywhere close to her normal income, depleting her financial resources, a worry unto itself when you’re trying to recover.Our goal is to raise $35,000 to provide support for the On-Demand flight and living expenses in Philadelphia for at least 2 months of hospitalization, no small amount.      We would be very grateful if you could support her by making a donation to her GoFundMe page and then sharing it with your social network.  Please know that even a small amount helps her get closer to her goal, and closer to being with Carrie before her surgery.

title: Celebration of Life for Len Kitzen
text: Life is so precious.To know Len and Audge is to love them. In early May, Len was diagnosed with stage IV cancer.  It's terminal. It really sucks. We are beyond words. They are going to have to face many unexpected and unwelcomed challenges in the next few months. We would like to make his remaining time on Earth the best that it can be for him, Audge, and their two kids, Zach and Gray. We're asking for your help to make this happen.They have given so much to us over the years: friendship, love, support, laughter, awesome I mean AWESOME Halloween parties. It's time for us to give something back.This terminal diagnosis is hitting them like a ton of bricks and they need your help now.  Let's give them our support and the gift of less to worry about so they can concentrate on enjoying the time they have left.A monetary gift of any amount is appreciated. Thank you from the bottom of our broken hearts.

title: Help Emel Beat Multiple Myeloma
text: Help Emel And His Family Beat Multiple Myeloma============================= On September, 2017 Emel was diagnosed with Multiple Myeloma, a form of cancer found in the blood, which then goes into the bones. First, she had a surgery on her hip (because of the tumor on her bone) then, she began chemotherapy shortly after being diagnosed (in October 2017).She is now in the hospital (UC Health, Denver, CO) and she got Bone Marrow Transplantation and need to stay the hospital until she will get good blood level.She has 3 kids [ A son and 2 daughters ->> 14 years old (son), 10 years old- (daughter) and 6 years old-(daughter) ], all they go gifted and highly talented school in CO.In the upcoming months she will continue to receive chemotherapy treatments as the doctors develop a treatment plan. Her spouse lost his job and need to take care his family. Although we are unsure of the financial burden S.... and Emel (Y...-14, A...-10 and B...-6) will have going forward, we are seeking assistance for future expenses related to medication, outpatient treatment, in home care, and other unforeseen medical bills.We appreciate & are very grateful for the prayers, thoughts & beams of light sent from all! Those who are asking how they can help? We are creating this site for help with Medical expenses as well as the income that will be lost until Emel and his family is able to get back to what they loves:) Then the journey building her body back to health will ensue, often with monies that are not covered under insurance. We are praying and trusting that God will heal Emel and S.... and provide financially for them at this time. We are thankful for all of the prayers and the support that we have and will receive. S... and Emel's husband  will be withdrawing funds from the campaign. PS >>> In behalf of the family, thank you for the donation for my wife.  May you be blessed even more. <<< Emel hanima yaklasik 11 ay once kan kanserinin bir alt turu olan (Multiple Myeloma-Kan icinde yogun/asiri/kontrolsuz PROTEIN uretimi) tanisi kondu.Bu tur kanser once kemik (vucutta herhangi kemik olabilir bu) icine kan yolu ile bulasiyor ve orada bir tumor olusturuyor.O nedenle ilk olarak bir kemik ameliyati gerceklestirildi (Ekim 2017), kalca kemiginde bu hastalik nedeni ile olusan yaklasik 3cm buyuklugunde boslugun (etrafi) temizlendi ve bosluga bir cesit kemik cimentosu eklendi, dokuldu, yerlestirildi, monte edildi.Bu operasyon ardindan Ekim 2017 ayinda ilac (kemoterapi) tedavisinde baslandi ve bu tedavi yaklasik 10 ay kadardir devam etti, kanda olunsa kanserli yapi cozulmeye calisildi, bu tedavi sonrasi Kemik iLiGi Nakli icin hastaneye yatirildi.Ve su anda hastanede yatmakta (Agustos 2018 itibari ile), yaklasik 15-20 gun kadar hastane sartlarinda kalmasi ve tedavi olmasi (baska bir kemoterapi ve ardindan iLik nakli) olmasi gerekiyor. Bu surecte hastamiza bu tedaviler yapildi, su an icin yapilan tedaviye olumlu (insa..h) cevap vermesini bekliyoruz.   Tedavi sonrasi ev bakimida aynen devam edecek olup, hastane sartlari kadar olmasa bile daha hassas, temiz, steril bir ortam bir-iki ay kadar hastamizin kendisine (vucut ve kan degerleri) gelmesi beklenecek, ve bu surecte haftada 3 gun hastaneye ornek (kan) icin gidilecektir.Sizlerden DUALARINIZI dileriz.>>> Yaptiginiz yardimlar icin hepinize ayri ayri tesekkur eder, dualariniz icinde sizlere minnettar oldugumuzu ayrica belirtmek isterim. <<<Tesekkurlerimizle

title: Medical and Foreclosure Expenses
text: My Dear Friends and former colleagues at the Exchange. Following my 35 years of service to brokers, clerks, clearing members and customers, I find myself in a financially difficult position.  I thank those of you that have lent a helping hand. My family and I appreciate your kindness and genorosity. My home is still in foreclosure and due to my wife’s battle with cancer, the medical bills are overwelming. I’ve been only able to find part time work and need your help. If you can donate anything to reach our goal, it would so helpful and so greatly appreciated, and never forgotten. Thank you in advance, Tony

title: Saving Alex - Stage 4 Cancer
text: I met my beautiful wife Alexandra, and her wonderful kids Andy and Sandy three years ago. From the moment I met her, I knew that she was a very special person. Her sincere caring  and attention for others were evident. She touched my heart like I have never experienced before.  We met, We clicked, We knew it!  We got married a year later.Alex was first diagnosed with stage II Breast Cancer in 2010. She underwent a bi-lateral mastectomy and strong chemotherapy treatment.  At that time we were told by multiple doctors that us conceiving babies was an impossibility due to her previous cancer treatments. The doctors asked if we believe in miracles because it was medically impossible for her to conceive. With  prayers and faith, we were blessed a month after our wedding with the news that she was pregnant.Not only was there one miracle...we were having twins!  Our family now consists of my wife, Alexandra, Son Andy, Daughter Sandy and our little one-year-old twin girls, Ava and Gia.Although my wife had a bi-lateral mastectomy, her body had naturally reacted to the pregnancy of our babies as we quickly found out that some breast mass was left behind during the surgery. Knowing that this had changed the makeup of her body,  we requested for a scan to be done. The doctor felt that an ultrasound of her chest was enough. The test was done and came back clear.However, as the months passed by, Alex kept having pains in her left leg and hip area, which went from being mild to excruciating. Alex is very strong, positive and always keeps a smile on her face,  so cancer returning didn't seem a possibility even to her doctors. After several visits to doctors, we finally got a doctor to order an XRay.  The findings triggered a STAT MRI Scan the very next day.  The scan revealed a lesion on her left hip. A biopsy confirmed that the breast cancer has metastasized to the bone. She is now diagnosed with Stage 4 Metastatic Breast Cancer of the bone. The cancer is triple positive, which is very aggressive in nature and growing rapidly. In a few months, the cancer mass has taken the place  of her bone causing Alex to lose most of the bone on her left hip. Unfortunately, a surgery to remove the mass or reconstruct her hip is not possible due to the amount of bone loss she has suffered. Alex is now bound to the use of a walker and wheelchair, and unable to pick up the babies due to severe pain, the the fragility of her bones and risk of bone fracture. With surgery not being a possibility, the team of doctors has recommended for my wife to go through immediate radiation in hopes to stop or slow down the growth of the cancer cells. Although no further masses have been detected, based on the pathology results, the doctors believe that cancer cells may be in other places as well, just not big enough to be detected at this time. Other than her current radiation therapies, their plan is to have her on chemo pills, shots and intravenous treatments to lower her hormones for the next year or until these medications stop working. Once the pills, shots, and IVs stop working, they would administer chemotherapy treatment for the rest of her time. The doctor is not comfortable with starting her on chemotherapy treatment now due to how much it affected her during her primary cancer treatment. Alex had to be rushed to the hospital and hospitalized with every chemotherapy treatment due to massive drops of her blood cells.The treatment plan and life expectancy we have received are very discouraging. Having our kids and little babies does not allow us to simply wait until the treatments no longer works, only to then see my wife further get killed by chemotherapy while trying to kill the cancer cells. Our goal is to help Alex survive without going through the severe side effects of treatment and chemotherapy. She is juicing, eating organic and very clean and finds it has already helped with some of the constant pain.   We have done extensive research and have found there have been excellent results with non-toxic immunotherapy, which, unfortunately, is not covered by our health insurance and is very expensive. Although we believe that there's a lot of good intention and care in traditional medicine, we can no longer only elect a treatment option with medications that cause so much harm to her body and might just give my wife another year or few months of life.  My wife and I have been doing non-stop research on the subject of alternative treatments and immunotherapy, we have educated ourselves on the different cancer treatments available and have been praying for guidance. Alex is determined to fight! We would like to give Alex the opportunity of beating this awful disease in a cancer center which offers more viable options for fighting this cancer. We have come to the conclusion that non-toxic immunotherapy and alternative treatment is a viable option that will benefit her at this time. We are aware that no treatment is 100% successful and nothing is guaranteed, but giving Alex the possibility of being here with her kids, family, friends and seeing our twin babies grow, means the world to me, my wife and our children. Many people have asked us how they can help us during this difficult time and although it is not our nature to ask for help, we must reach out so that my wife has every chance possible to beat this cancer. The life-saving treatment Alex needs does come with a cost, of approximately $45-100,000 and unfortunately, our health insurance would not assist as they would only cover traditional medicine. We have a limited amount of time to start alternative treatments and would need to get started soon.  Please be part of our journey by sharing our story as we ask for prayers for health and continuous guidance. If you feel so inclined, we would appreciate any financial help you can offer for the love of my life. If you prefer to use other means to assist and would like to reach us directly, please send an email to: ( BobbyChristiano @yahoo.com )Please keep us in your thoughts and prayers and thank you all for your prayers, kindness and supportBobby Christiano

title: Help JoeJoe Fight Leukemia
text: Imagine the joy of a family vacation quickly turn to fear and worry upon finding during that vacation that your child has leukemia.  That was exactly the nightmare that has unfolded for Louis and Jen DiNapoli and they need your help.  Joseph, lovingly known as “JoeJoe” has only just turned 3 years old.  He has a new baby sister named Alessia and he loves Marvel Action figures, especially the Hulk. He is a sweet little boy who is at the beginning of his life.  While on vacation he became sick and during a trip to the emergency room, his parents learned a truth that they never could have imagined – that he has leukemia.  A vacation which began with relaxation and fun quickly turned into a flurry of tests, transfusions and unknowns that one should have to face – especially a 3 year old.  Once JoeJoe becomes stable, his parents will fly him home where they will begin an unimaginable journey at Sloan Kettering Hospital to check if the cancer has spread to his spine and then JoeJoe will begin chemotherapy.  While fighting beside their young son to get through this while also parenting his baby sister, Louis will need to take a leave of absence from work that will result in no income until he is able to return.  Any donation provided will help support this family with their living and medical expenses while they help little JoeJoe kick cancer in the butt and be one of the super heroes that he loves so much.  Thank you so much and please keep this family in your prayers.

title: Help David Tavitian's Stroke Rehab
text: On March 22, 2018, our friend David Tavitian suffered a massive stroke which left him suddenly paralyzed on the left side of his body. Then a few days after the stroke, David needed emergency surgery to relieve swelling and bleeding in his brain. He had a large portion of his skull removed in order to save his life. David wears a helmet now, to protect his brain until the bone can be replaced.David's stroke has left him with speech, vision, and cognitive issues in addition to left side of the body paralysis, and he will need months, if not years, of exhausting rehab to maximize his ability to function.Unfortunately, insurance will pay for very little of it, leaving David and his wife Kathy with piles of bills.Before the stroke, David worked with special needs kids at North Central High School. Both he and Kathy have given so much to their community. Now they need our help. Our goal is to raise money for three essentials that will not be covered by insurance:• Structural modifications of David and Kathy’s home. This will include widening doorways, an entrance ramp, and a major remodel of their one small bathroom to install a wheelchair accessible shower, sink, and toilet. A conservative estimate of the cost of this work is about $30,000. • A wheelchair lift van to transport David to rehab. The speed and success of David’s recovery depends in large part on his ability to continue to receive therapy as frequently as possible.  A  dependable lift van will cost around $20,000. •     Costs of rehab that will exceed insurance limitations. The cost of months and months of rehab will exceed insurance limits by the tens of thousands of dollars.With gratitudeFriends of David and Kathy Tavitian

title: Pastor David's Cancer Fund
text: On January 7, 2018, I was installed as the new Lead Pastor at Newport Covenant Church in Bellevue WA (Seattle’s Eastside). I was in Washington ahead of the rest of my family, because we had decided to let our youngest son Nathaniel finish the school year in Sacramento.I made the move despite experiencing digestive symptoms since late November. As I started at Newport, the symptoms kept getting worse. I became jaundiced, and I had more and more frequent bouts with back and stomach pain.In our wildest dreams, none of us would have predicted what lay ahead. On February 7, after my second surgical procedure in three weeks, I received the news that I have Stage 3 (possibly Stage 4) pancreatic cancer.I quickly learned that pancreatic cancer is a killer and is notoriously difficult to overcome. This was an extremely trying time for Susan and me, since she was still in Sacramento, and I was in Seattle.The weekend of February 9-11, we gathered our whole immediate family (Susan, two sons Spencer and Nathaniel, and daughter Lauren and her family) to talk about the sobering realities of pancreatic cancer – but also to weep and pray with one another.Shortly thereafter I became connected with one of the foremost experts in pancreatic cancer in the world, Dr. Vince Picozzi at Virginia Mason Medical Center. He agreed to be my doctor. We were overjoyed!Dr. Picozzi explained that the tumor was mainly growing out of the head of my pancreas, but it was not only in my lymph nodes but also attached to my biliary duct and nerves running to my back and abdomen. In addition, it may have metastasized to my liver. Thus, the tumor, in its current condition, is inoperable. Dr. Picozzi is attacking the tumor with chemotherapy in hopes that we can shrink it back to the point that it might become operable. Unfortunately there are no guarantees in any of this.As I write this, I have just completed my first month-long battery of chemo. The chemo has hit my body very hard, causing fevers, extreme fatigue, digestive problems, and – as of the last two days – loss of my hair. (I let Spencer and Nathaniel shave my head, and that is the photo you see.)Susan and Nathaniel had to scrap our plans for him to finish the school year in Sacramento. He is with us and is getting ready to begin a difficult transition to a new school, 2/3 of the way through his sophomore year.Financially this is a bit of a perfect storm for us. We have lost Susan's income, which we depend on to pay a portion of our bills. And now we have additional bills in the form of medical bills. So, income has dropped dramatically, and costs have risen.
