Not a good situation.Your GoFundMe donations would enable us to pay our medical bills and provide for Susan to spend a period of 3-6 months not working so she can (a) process this cancer diagnosis emotionally and (b) tend to her husband as he fights for his life and to her kids as they walk through this crisis.There are still a great number of unknowns (what treatment will look like down the road, what to do with our house in Sacramento, how soon Susan will need to start working, etc.). The financial needs addressed by this GoFundMe are ongoing and far reaching. Looking for other ways to support us? We are receiving a tremendous amount of support from the people at Newport Covenant Church, as well as from friends and family across the country – and outside the country. We would be grateful if you would follow our story on our CaringBridge page:  www.caringbridge.org/public/davidbeck, send us your encouragement, and pray for us. This situation hit us like a car t-boning us in an intersection. It was a total shock, and in many ways we are still catching up. With chemo incapacitating me large chunks out of every week, I am not able to be much help to Susan. We trust God and are not afraid – yet we feel the urgency of this situation every day. Thank you for supporting our family!

title: Mary Huffman ALS Warrior
text:
Below is an article that Cedars Sinai is doing about Mary on their new ALS website...  It however does a good job of telling just a bit of why Mary is so special to all of us.  As does this video:

Mary Huffman faces challenges and tries to help people.Growing up very poor with neither parent having a high school diploma (but they were awesome parents).  Mary decided she wanted a different future, and so she worked hard in school and got a B.A. from UCLA and an MBA from Stanford.  In addition, she wanted to use her time to help people (her mom taught her that early on), so she started volunteering in different ways in middle school and that has really brought her a lot of pleasure.  In addition to running an online marketing company, Mary decided to start an adult coloring book publishing company after she tried coloring and realized just how calming the activity is.  But she didn't like the format of the books because you had to be at a table and hold it open with one hand, and if you used markers, it would destroy the next page.  So, she designed a beautiful and practical new version with a friend and turned it into a thriving online business. If a wall is empty, she has an inspirational quote that can go there. If someone is in need, she finds a way to help.That much has stayed the same since she was diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or ALS, in September 2017. Every day is still about how she can help someone."I wear a shirt with my philosophy on it," says Mary, 48. "It says, 'ALS Mom. I'm going to Stephen Hawking the crap out of this.’"Those are Mary’s own words as she draws inspiration from the most famous person to have ALS since Lou Gehrig. Hawking, the brilliant theoretical physicist, lived and continued to work for more than half a century with the disease. ALS affects the nerve cells of the brain and spinal cord that control muscle movement. A little more than 6,000 people in the U.S. are diagnosed with the disease each year.So far, ALS is a disease without a solution. There isn't a cure in sight. Treatment is focused on improving comfort and quality of life. Mary was diagnosed with the fast-moving form of the disease, and now must stay in bed much of the time.One of the first things she did after being diagnosed in September 2017 was set up a website–Mary’s Legacy –devoted to helping people. She shares her story, photos, and a practical list of tips and life hacks for those with ALS or mobility issues. Her "Mary's Life Tricks" section is smart and sometimes funny advice for everything from taming the "anxiety monster" to handling criticism with grace. She updates it regularly and stays active in online ALS communities from her tablet computer.Friends call Mary a joy-bringer, a cheerleader, someone who can stay positive "without being Pollyanna." Sums up her 15-year-old daughter Anna, "She's like Snow White, always  kind to everybody.”Mary met her husband, Ted Huffman, when she was 21, and their eyes met across a crowded room at a party. Within a few years, they were married and moving to Europe together. They worked and traveled there for 5 years, then came home to Southern California to start a family."He has stuck with me through hundreds of adventures, and difficulties as well," Mary says. "And he just has the greatest sense of humor."Their two children, Anna and Jonny, age 13, are a lot like their mom in many ways. As a 3rd grader, Johnny started his first charitable fundraiser to help a younger kid who had cancer. He did the same when a teacher at his middle school had a brain tumor.After learning of her mother’s diagnosis, Anna asked a question that surprised and moved her mom.  “Should I live my teen years normally, making mistakes and learning? Or should I be perfect to make you proud?" The answer came easy to Mary. "I told her that being able to articulate that makes me so proud. Learn now. Don't wait to learn later."Mary's room is lined from floor to ceiling with memories. Snapshots from her brother's recent wedding, vacation selfies, arms slung around friends and loved ones during some wonderful times. It includes new memories, too. Every visitor takes two selfies with Mary, a pretty portrait and a goofy one.Then there's a panoramic group shot of more than 60 loved ones, gathered around her at a party held last fall shortly after her diagnosis.  "This has helped me so much to stay positive," Mary says. "Just to have everyone smiling at me all day."She spreads this positivity through her coloring book business, too. She just published a coloring book with a licensed social worker that combines anxiety-busting strategies with stress-relieving coloring exercises. It has some of her favorite features–the spiral at the top makes it lay flat and easy to color, thick pages, and a heavy cardboard backing so you can even color on your lap.Her drive to give back plays a role in her treatment at Cedars-Sinai. She's donated pages from her coloring books for Cedars-Sinai to share with other ALS patients and their families. She's on a waiting list to participate in clinical trials, hoping to contribute to ALS research. She likes that her care team has so many of the traits that she values."Every single person I interact with is warm and caring and knowledgeable," she says. "They all have good senses of humor. They make me feel so well cared for that, even going through this, I have the confidence that I'm getting everything I need."

title: Sean Sweeny's Recovery
text: On Friday June 15, 2018 Sean Sweeny, 15 years of age, was at a shooting range in Mammoth with his dad. They both had experience with firearms. Sean sustained a serious gunshot wound to the head. He was rushed to Mammoth Hospital where he was stabilized and then airlifted to Reno Nevada's trauma center. He underwent 3 hours of surgery to repair the damage. He is in a coma and in critical but stable condition. Sean is going to need extended stay here at the Renown Regional Medical Center before he can come home and receive acute rehabilitation. We are asking for your support for housing, food, and daily essentials while we are at our home away from home.  Any support that is not used will be donated to a charity of our choice or Renown Regional Medical Center. PLEASE NOTE THAT IF YOU DO NOT UNCLICK THE 15% DONATION PORTION, THEN 15% OF YOUR DONATION WILL GO TO GOFUNDME.

title: Recovery for Rebecca Berenson
text: Imagine one day you are living your life, working, taking care of your family, exercising when you can because you know how important it is to take care of your health. But you haven’t been feeling that great lately. There’s always plenty of stress with balancing the special needs of your family – you are used to that, but this feels different. You are tired in a way you have never felt before. Never feeling quite right. You go to the doctor but they don’t come up with much, until a few months later when you wake up in excruciating pain with a blood clot in your spleen. You are admitted at a local hospital for several days with treatment for only the most obvious of your symptoms. After your release from the hospital your condition only gets a worse. You decide to request a second opinion at a major research hospital in Boston.  A few days later you meet with the doctor in Boston. After reviewing the results of a blood sample taken earlier that day, he asks in a matter of fact way, “Do you know why you’re here”? You recount your recent hospitalization and that fact that you haven’t been feeling well over several months. Like a hard punch in the gut, he states simply, “you have cancer”. You are admitted into the hospital immediately. A single word changes everything. Just. Like. That. Suddenly, unexpectedly, you are in the fight for your life. Since January, when my sister-in-law Rebecca and brother-in-law Chuck were given the news that she has a complicated form of AML Leukemia, it has been an unrelenting battle to ensure that she survives. After the initial diagnosis, she spent nearly a month at the Tufts Medical Center bone marrow transplant unit in Boston.  She is receiving her treatment from one of the most well-respected doctors for dealing with her specific form of leukemia. The planning for her bone marrow transplant is being mapped out in stages as the team assesses the progression of the disease and the logistics of lining up the donor. She was discharged to home but travels back and forth to Boston 2-3 times each week for testing, chemotherapy and radiation, but there have been a couple emergency hospitalizations to treat infections. Her immune system is down to zero as they prepare for the bone marrow transplant. In the meantime, she will continue to receive chemotherapy and radiation treatments. When the bone marrow transplant takes place, she will spend a month in the hospital. Once she is stable, she will be transferred to the Neely House apartments at Tufts, living in isolation in a special air filtered unit for two to four weeks more. There will be daily visits to see her doctor and someone must stay with her around the clock to assist with her care. It is a painful, brutal process, but Rebecca and Chuck are grateful for the expert care of her Tufts Medical team and hopeful that a donor will be confirmed soon. Those of you who know their family understand the challenges they face in coping with this overwhelming situation, as their youngest daughter Liza has complex special needs which require specific and intensive management with constant one to one care for all of her needs. Even though they have jobs and good medical insurance, Rebecca’s medical leave will run out in June when the school year ends. They will have to private pay for insurance through Cobra. With loss of income, co-pays, travel expenses, medical deductibles and additional specialized care and summer camp for Liza, the financial toll is real and overwhelming. It is frightening to witness how a medical diagnosis can put a family at risk for financial disaster while they are fighting to get better. In the best-case scenario, they will most likely be looking at 9 months to one year of recovery – with fingers crossed and as many prayers as can come their way. Many friends, co-workers, and neighbors have been extremely kind in sending well wishes, generous in making meals for the family and driving Rebecca to her appointments in Boston so Chuck can continue to work at least part time.  For all of this support we are truly grateful. I am starting this GoFundMe campaign as a way to allow them to concentrate on Rebecca getting well and to help relieve some of the financial stress they are dealing with in addition to everything else. So often when someone we know or love faces the unthinkable, we wish there was something, anything, we could do to help. It is my hope that those of you who know this family, and perhaps a few who don’t, will donate what you can as a way to show them your support and help them get through this. May they be fortunate enough to come out the other end of this ordeal healthy and strong. Please share this with anyone you think will want to know what Rebecca and Chuck and their family are dealing with and would want to help.With my sincere appreciation for your consideration,Paula Rosenblum

title: Urgent Help needed 4  Claudia Ghetu
text: Dear Friends,Our beloved Claudia is in urgent need of support. In June of 2018 Claudia was diagnosed with stage 4 pancreatic cancer, which had spread to her lymph nodes, lungs and liver. Pancreatic cancer is usually terminal, especially at this stage,  and requires immediate and intense treatment. Standardized medical care guarantees only a 2% recovery rate, and requires aggressive chemotherapy and radiation, which also equally guarantees a poor and debilitating quality of life. After much prayer and research, Claudia has found an outstanding alternative and integrative medical and team and clinic, known for high rate of success in healing terminal cancer, and other chronic and traditionally incurable diseases. Furthermore they provide compassionate care, and are aligned with a philosophy that is true to Claudia’s core beliefs.  They are working alongside her as a team, allowing her to use her own expertise in holistic nutrition, superfoods, and natural supplements, while supporting her with the latest state of the art integrative medical treatment. Unfortunately, her insurance will not pay for the kind of treatment she has chosen. It is all out if pocket! As you’ll see from her updates, she is making significant progress, and would have not otherwise succeeded in making it this far with traditional treatment.  The 100% standardized chemo therapy dosage, as it was recently relayed to her by her integrative oncologist, would have put her in a coma in less than a month. She is extremely sensitive, and has been practicing and writing about holistic and alternative health and nutrition for decades. Initially the money required for treatment and the goal posted was $50K, which was to cover only the first 6 weeks of treatment, however after recent new tests Claudia had, dating 8/20/18 as per her doctors’  assessments, she needs to continue with 10 more weeks of medical care. They are now targeting her lungs too, both of which have numerous lesions and suspicious masses, one of a large measurement on the left side. In addition,  the latest Pet Scan had detected that there musculoskeletal system had been affected as well, and malignant lesions in several areas are present. Claudia will also begin slowly working to try to finance herself while still undergoing medical treatment, but your continued support will be of immense help. Claudia has always believed that true healing comes from nature, a supportive and spiritual environment, and from deep within ourselves. As an Integrative Holistic Health Counselor, Nutritional Chef, and yoga and meditation teacher, she lives what she teaches  and is known to go the extra mile to empower, support,  and inspire those around her.  Even a few days before she was diagnosed, short of energy and barely able to eat, she visited someone in the hospital to give them wellness and spiritual counseling, and cooked for her clients until the day she had to go to the emergency room, making sure they wouldn’t miss out on their healthy meals. She has dedicated her life to helping others facing mental, emotional and physical challenges, and those seeking to transition to a healthier mind-body-spirit lifestyle. Now, she is the one in need of our support. She is using her own healing modalities to heal herself combined with the help of an amazing team of alternative doctors, who support her holistic choices, providing her with the compassion and motivation which she has always shown to others. She bravely turned down traditional chemotherapy and radiation treatments, which would only give her a 2% chance of survival. Those who know her well call her a warrior! She is not only fighting for her own life, but as she so often says “I am here fighting for everyone, so they can learn through me that cancer too can be overcome with the right integrative medical treatment and support, and through sheer faith, and will power!” Let’s help her achieve her goal, her medical expenses will far extend the amount we are asking. Please share this link with your various social media contacts or personal acquaintances, and kindly add a personal message to it, as this seems to make a big difference. You can read more about Claudia’s remarkable and brave story via her recent blog on her website ClaudiaGhetuWellness “How Cancer is Healing Me!” Claudia wants to live and help others by giving back. So many people like her are given a death sentence, but cancer doesn’t have to be an end, but a beginning!Claudia and her family are deeply grateful for your love, prayers and support.   With much love and gratitude.

title: The Hale Family
text: On Wednesday, May 23rd, Marlee and Jonathan Hale arrived at the hospital prepared to bring their first born into the world.  While in triage the nurses were having a difficult time finding a strong heartbeat so Marlee was taken in for an emergency c-section.  Shortly after, Beau Anderson Hale was born a solid 8lbs 6oz, however, Beau was not breathing and unable to breath on his own.  The nurses had to resuscitate Beau several times prior to rushing him to the NICU.  Beau spent the next 7 days fighting for his life in the NICU while the doctors ran tests and scans to determine if he could recover from this. After all the tests were completed and the scans had been analyzed, Marlee and Jonathan received the news that no parent wants to hear.  The oxygen deprivation Beau experienced caused brain damage that was too severe to recover from, and Beau’s time on this Earth would be short.  As you can imagine, Marlee and Jonathan are heartbroken, and this prognosis left many more questions than answers.  Despite the odds, Marlee and Jonathan wanted to make sure that they gave Beau a chance.  As long as Beau was fighting and improving they were right by his side fighting with him.  After a couple more days Beau was not improving and it became clear that God has a bigger plan for Beau. Currently, Beau is out of the NICU and on a comfort care protocol to ensure that the time he has on this Earth is pain free.  Beau is getting to spend a lot of time cuddling with his Mommy and Daddy.  Recently, Marlee and Jonathan took Beau for a walk around the hospital campus and brought their two dogs up to meet him. The amount of love Beau has brought out of all who have come in contact with him can not be overstated.  We’re all taken back by how many lives Beau has impacted in such a short amount of time. Since Beau’s birthday on 5/23, many people have been asking how they can help.  So naturally, We have been asking everyone to pray for a miracle.  When we told Marlee and Jon that we were having so many people praying for a miracle their response was simply, “We already have our miracle, and it’s BEAU.”  The resolve and the strength of the Hale family is truly remarkable.  Riddled with adversity as they start their family, however, their Faith, love for each other, and their love for Beau is unconditional. We continue to ask for prayers for Marlee, Jonathan, and Beau as each day has its challenges.

title: Mimi Dahdouh's cancer treatment
text: For those who don't know Mimi, she is a loving mother of two who has served Christ her whole life through her husband's Ministry. Mimi is 48 years old and has been battling stage 4 colorectal cancer with metastasis to her lymphatic system, skeletal system and liver for 17 months now. After 24 rounds of chemotherapy to no avail, her family decided to fly her to Houston for alternative Gene targeted therapy. Being that she is not covered by medical insurance in the United States, her family is reaching out for any financial assistance that can help pay for this very expensive yet hopeful type of treatment. After only 2 days, we have already started to see a slight improvement. This treatment is estimated to be about $30,000 a month and we are hoping she will only need to be on it for about 3 to 4 months. Please consider helping this angelic servant of the Lord as she continues to fight bravely for her life. Your love and consideration is very much appreciated. May you be rewarded abundantly.

title: Help with Anna's Spinal Surgery
text:
Our most recent family picture, Nate, Aaron, Anna, Joe and KimFUNDRAISING FOR ANNA'S SPINAL SURGERYThank you for visiting our site to support Anna (Winters) Fischer’s spinal surgery.ANNA’S STRUGGLE WITH SEVERE SCOLIOSIS
Anna has idiopathic thoracolumbar scoliosis, a disorder of the spine that causes it to progressively curve sideways.  Anna was first diagnosed at age seven, and at age eleven she was put into a brace to slow the curvature and hopefully avoid surgery.  As her curves progressed, so did her pain.  She would wear two different types of braces for the next five years until age 16, when it appeared her curves had stabilized at 37 degrees each.    EMERGENCY SITUATION  Fast forward to March of 2018 when Anna suddenly had extreme pain that went beyond anything she had experienced prior.  Her medications did nothing to alleviate the pain.  By this time, Anna was married and living in Australia with her husband, Aaron.  Anna went to specialists in Australia and it was determined that her curves had unexpectedly progressed by over ten degrees.  X-rays also showed four bulging discs, one that was impinging on her sciatic nerve, as well as a severely degenerated disc.    Once the curves start progressing to these levels, surgery becomes necessary due to the impact on the spine and potential damage to the heart and lungs.  Although fusion surgery (where your spine is fused into a solid unit) is typically recommended, Anna is not a good candidate for this surgery due to the length of her curves and other factors.    A NEW SURGICAL OPTIONAbout 20 years ago, a new surgical technique was developed called Anterior Scoliosis Correction.  (For an explanation of this procedure, please click here .)  In this procedure, a pin is drilled into the side of each vertebrae and then a flexible cord is attached to each pin.  This technique has been proven to straighten the spine, alleviate chronic and acute pain and allow flexibility.      OUR FIRST MIRACLE!We began researching doctors in the United States who perform ASC on adults and we found only two.  The one closest to our state is also the same doctor who saw Anna when she was a child being treated at Shriner’s Hospital in Philadelphia!  Kim immediately contacted this doctor and shared what was happening with Anna and our journey toward ASC surgery began.ANNA IS APPROVED FOR THIS LIFE CHANGING SURGERYWe have now completed the pre-screening process and Anna has finally been officially approved for ASC surgery – currently scheduled to take place on July 30, 2018, in New Jersey.We praise God that He led us to retain Anna on our insurance policy after she married, but because it is a rare surgery for adults, the only doctors who can perform Anna’s surgery are out of network and it is not currently clear how much of the surgical costs will be covered by our insurance.  SURGERY & RECOVERY DETAILSAnna will be tethered from T5 – L4, meaning they will be putting pins in each vertebrae from the bottom of her neck to where her hips begin.  She is in a very tiny category of people who have ever been tethered that low on the spine.  Anna’s lungs will be deflated during the procedure (one side, then the other).   Provided all goes well, Anna will be in the hospital for one full week following her surgery.  We will then stay in a hotel near the hospital for 3-4 days to make sure everything is healing properly.  We will then (Lord willing!) return to our home in Mechanicsburg for Anna’s recovery.  OUR FINANCIAL NEEDWhile our insurance has yet to verify coverage of Anna’s hospital charges, we need to send a down payment of $45,000.00 plus a promissory note for $20,000.00 by June 30, 2018 to her surgeons.  In addition to these surgical fees, insurance is still determining our initial deductible, which will range from $10,000.00-$20,000.00.   As well, we need to fly Anna to the United States from Australia and then back to Australia after her surgery via business class (lie flat seating, with a current cost estimate of $8,500.00 for a one-way ticket).  Three to four nights of nearby hotel accommodations following hospital stay are also in view; in addition to other items we need to purchase for her recuperation for months afterwards (zero gravity chair, special padded bedding, etc.).   Your contributions will go toward Anna’s out of pocket medical expenses (before, during and after surgery) and travel/lodging expenses.  So, before confirmation of what insurance will pay, and in consideration of what other families have experienced, our current estimate of out of pocket costs is $85,000.00.  PRAYER NEEDSThe surgery is complicated and carries with it a number of risks.  Please pray that all goes well for her.  Our first meeting with the surgeons will be on 7/24/18 followed by surgery on 7/30/18.  Please pray for her travel from Australia to the US on 7/20-21/18, for our meeting with surgeons and for her preparations before surgery.   Please also pray for her incisions, for when they collapse her lungs, put in her pins and connect her tethers.  Please pray that the tethers they use would never break for her entire lifetime.  As you know, Anna has a history of infection with her leg surgery, so please pray for no infection.  Anna has endured much pain since she was six years old – chronic and acute.  For many people who undergo this surgery, they leave the hospital pain free.  For some the pain returns months after surgery.  Others experience a combination.  We are of course hoping and praying for total alleviation of pain that does not return.  Anna’s husband Aaron is on the brink of going into the Royal Australian Air Force (expected departure date is in July).  Please pray for both Aaron and Anna as they wait to hear definitive plans from the RAAF and as they deal with being away from one another at this time. We will keep you posted on this site and will update you as we journey into the next several months!  Thank you so much for considering supporting us in prayer and/or with your financial support.  Your encouragement and support means the world to us.    With love and prayers,Anna, Aaron, Joseph, Nate & Kim

title: Kristen Fournier's Medical Fund
text: Dear Family, Friends, Colleagues and Supporters - Kristen was first diagnosed with Hodgkin’s Lymphoma—a rare form of blood cancer—in July 2016 after feeling ‘off’ for more than a year. At the age of 28, with an 18-month old son and husband in her corner, Kristen endured six months of chemotherapy to beat the advanced Stage IV cancer that had spread throughout her body. While this turned their world upside down, Kristen finished treatment in January 2017 and received the all clear that she had beat cancer—best news ever! With a renewed outlook, Kristen enjoyed life as healthy person again—not taking a single day of good health for granted. She celebrated her one year anniversary of being cancer free in January 2018 with friends, family and lots of champagne! Unfortunately, last month Kristen noticed swollen lymph nodes in her neck, an indicator of Hodgkin’s. Her doctor scheduled a PET scan, just to be safe, and the results indicated the worst: Kristen had relapsed. Kristen was sent to meet with a specialist at City of Hope where it was confirmed that the cancer had returned and now she must prepare to begin her second fight against Hodgkin’s Lymphoma.Kristen will be treated at City of Hope where they specialize in the advanced treatment of cancer. She will be entering a 12-week clinical trial before undergoing a stem cell transplant, a rigorous treatment that will require a month of isolation in the hospital where she will endure intensive chemotherapy followed by a transplant of her own stem cells. After the unforeseen financial consequences of fighting her first battle with cancer, we are asking for donations to help her continue her battle a second time! Any and all funds from this campaign will allow the Fournier’s to alleviate some of the financial burden that comes with a cancer diagnosis and help provide as much normalcy as possible to their son, Holden. Over the next year, Kristen, Jake and their families will be going back and forth from Orange County to City of Hope, which will require added expenses for childcare, lodging, transportation, food and healthcare costs. Every donation is sincerely appreciated as we help Kristen beat cancer once and for all so she can get back to a happy, healthy life. Please be kind enough to notify anyone who knows Kristen or has the ability to help!

title: Wyatt Boatright's Battle with ALS
text: To Friends and Family,For the past year, Wyatt Boatright has been battling a serious medical condition. In early 2017 Wyatt began experiencing problems with his fine motor skills, which made it difficult for him to do simple things such as holding a cup or catching a ball. He began to experience more serious symptoms such as fatigue, loss of strength, difficulty speaking, along with uncontrollable body tremors.In early March 2018, Wyatt’s symptoms became so severe he was forced to stop working, which affected his medical benefits through his employer.In April 2018, Wyatt and his family received the devastating news that doctors had diagnosed him with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, also known as ALS or Lou Gehrig’s Disease. Wyatt and his family were devastated by the diagnosis and are now left wondering what the future will hold.Wyatt currently lives in Corona, California with his wife, Justina, and their three boys, Landon (14), Austin (11) and Hudson (10). Wyatt’s parents, Ron and Suzanne, his brothers, Justin and Noah and their families, also live in the southern California area. The Boatright family is very strong and close-knit, but no one should be expected to go through this alone.Wyatt’s diagnosis will require serious on-going treatment and an extremely difficult road ahead. Since Wyatt can no longer work, his ability to support his family and pay medical bills will be greatly affected. He is an extremely humble person and recently told us that he didn’t want to be a burden to anyone. Wyatt would never ask for it, but he needs our help now more than ever.Thank you so much for your generosity and support.  Your outpouring of love and support has been overwhelming and gratefully appreciated by the Boatright family.  Please visit  http://www.alsa.org/about-als/ to learn more about this terrible disease.

title: We got this, Smiles
text: My sister Sarah was diagnosed with stage 4 stomach, liver and colon cancer. She is one of the best people and mother's on this planet. She has 3 young babies, and could really use some help, but is the type of person that would never ask for it. Let's help her out, thank you!

title: Bear Hovey : Medical Expenses
text: On  May 14 Theodore "Bear" Hovey was hospitalized due to a vertebral collapse that was caused by the onset of multiple myeloma tumor that attacked his spine.  He had to undergo emergency surgery on his spine, and had rods surgically placed to support the failed vertebra.  He was paralyzed in the left leg and had minimal feeling in the right leg following surgery. He stayed at Yale New Haven for two weeks  following the surgery where he received chemotherapy & physical therapy while recovering from surgery and the trauma to his spinal cord.  He was then transferred to Gaylord Hospital for rehabilitation for two weeks while being shuttled back and forth to Yale for more Cancer treatment. About a week ago he has transferred to West River Healthcare Center in Milford where he is continuing his rehabilitation, but is closer to his 7 year old son Grayson.  He is currently undergoing a two week intensive program of both chemo and radiation therapy.  He is showing significant  improvement and is currently able to walk with the aid of a walker, but it will certainly be a while before he can return to work as a rigger on large sailing yachts.Bear will undoubtedly have significant expenses from both the medical care he has and will continue to receive as well as the expenses of housing and supporting his son during his period of recovery.  Bear has shown true determination and commitment to his recovery.  It is my hope that those  of us that have had the pleasure of yacht racing, skiing or just hanging with Bear will find it in their hearts to help him out at this challenging time.  Those of us that have raced with Bear know how determined  he is to overcome whatever challenge he faces.  Please show your support for him as he faces his biggest challenge ever. Thank you for your generous support!

title: Family and Friends of John Aponas
text: John Aponas, husband, father, son, brother, & friend of so many of us, was diagnosed with kidney disease 8 years ago. Despite diet changes and medication, his disease has led to kidney failure.  To give you an idea of the seriousness of his situation; his kidneys are only operating at 13%.In the fall of 2017, John’s doctors told him he would need a kidney transplant in order to keep him off of dialysis and help him live a longer and higher quality life.  Good news … John got the news he was hoping for this year … he has a donor!!  Due to the generosity and altruism of this donor, John is on track to have his transplant soon.  As thrilled as he and his family are to have this new lease on life, it does not come without its challenges.  The recovery process will require a specialized diet, and significant life style adjustments.  John will need to travel to Boston 3 times a week for the next 2 – 6 months.   In addition, he will be out of work for 3 to 6 months.  There will be significant medical and travel expenses which will put an undue hardship on John’s family.  This Go Fund Me campaign will help John and his family during this very uncertain and difficult time.  Our goal is to raise $15,000.  This is one way you can help – give what you can and we are confident we can take the financial burden off of the Aponas family and let them focus on getting John well.Thank you in advance for your generosity!Robert Aponas, Dave Grunbeck and Diane Legg

title: Akers Family Medical Expenses
text: Andrew Akers was just recently hit by a car. He was taken to the hospital immediately and the news has come back that he is in medically induced coma and has brain bleeding as well as facial structure damaging. Andrew is also a member of Theta Chi Fraternity and is an outstanding young man, who has a bright future. This Go-Fund-Me has been set up to support him and his family through the medical expenses. Any little support that you could provide would go a very long way.Please keep him in your prayers.

title: Help Jacob Fight ALS  #GlasowStrong
text:
My name is Jacob Glasow.  I am a 36 year old, father of 5 amazing children (ages 13, 10, 8, 7 & 3) and married to the love of my life, Sheena.  

On July 12th, 2018... my wife and I received news that turned our lives upside down...  the life altering diagnosis of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), also known as Lou Gehrig’s disease.  ALS is a horrible disease, robbing its victims of the ability to walk, dress themselves, talk, swallow, and ultimately breathe. All while leaving the mind perfectly intact. 

Already, I’ve seen changes in my speech, I have twitching in my arm and leg muscles & am losing strength in my left hand and most recently, my smile has changed.   ALS has no cure and no effective treatment. 

The average lifespan from diagnosis is three to five years. I’m not sure what my journey will bring because every individual’s experience with ALS is different, meaning there are a lot of unknowns for me and my family. What I do know is that we're focused on doing everything we can to fight this disease and delay its progression into the more debilitating stages for as long as possible. As difficult and devastating as this diagnosis is, we remain positive and hopeful that through faith, hope & love, we will make it through this journey. 

A little about me: I’m an outdoors enthusiast and enjoy many activities like fishing (both open water and ice), hunting of all kinds & I especially love spending time with my family.   I am an easy-going, fun-loving guy who just enjoys the simple things in life... A cold beer, a steak on the grill hanging on the front porch with my family, watching my kids play in the yard, a bonfire with friends...    

One of my biggest fears on this journey is that my family will face extraordinary medical and incidental expenses. ALS treatment is not completely covered by insurance and estimates for medical costs alone range from $200,000-$300,000 EACH YEAR, covering ventilation, feeding tubes and in-home care. Additional large expenses may include modifying ones home for greater accessibility, wheelchairs, lifts, a specialized van, long-term clinical trials, aides/in-home nursing and technological devices to offset muscle paralysis. 

No one knows how long my fight will last, but I’m determined to  battle longer than the average person, and I plan to be in the 10% of statistics that are here for another 10+ years. Unfortunately, this could leave a tremendous financial burden on my family & I cannot bear the thought of that. 

My wife, Sheena - who is a stay at home mom, and I have dedicated our lives to raising our  5 children and love our small, tight community in Reedsville, WI.  We are the average small-town family... our kids love playing outside and adventuring, riding their bikes, making forts in the yard and on the normal weeknight, you'll find us attending their baseball/softball games and sporting events in our community.  Outside of my full time job at Miron Construction, I also serve as a volunteer firefighter for the last 12 years for the Village of Reedsville.  

For those of you who are able to donate and help us face this growing mountain of expenses, we are deeply grateful. Your contributions are helping me to face this sad and difficult disease with dignity and pride. 

With Love,  
The Glasow Family  
(Jacob, Sheena, Mya, Ella, Grady, Hunter & Knox) 


A message from Jacob's wife, Sheena: 

We do not know exactly what our future holds but we REFUSE TO GIVE UP HOPE... he is strong...he has so much to fight for... so many people standing behind him... and we will exhaust all efforts to do whatever it takes to keep him strong and fighting! The kids do know what's going on and know that we are going to fight as a family, pray and keep hope to keep Daddy here for as long as we possibly can. We know we will need to lean on friends and family (which is definitely not a skill of mine) through this journey and we thank you all from the bottom of our hearts.  We want to enjoy each day as much as we can, make amazing memories... and make the most of times with our 5 beautiful children, friends and family.  Your donations will help us to do just that...while making it possible for Jacob to explore all options to FIGHT to be here as long as possible.   

Your support, love, prayers, conversation and help is always welcome & appreciated...  #GlasowStrong

title: Sara Moss-McGinnis Children’s Fund
text: On July 19th, 2018 Sara McGinnis (Sara Moss) 36.5 weeks pregnant and suffering from a headache and nausea, was en route to the Emergency Room when she experienced a Grand Mal seizure and suffered a massive stroke in her brain stem and was called home. An emergency C-Section was performed in the ER and miraculously, the baby survived. Owen Keith progressed in the NICU while Sara was in surgery and in the ICU on life support for a number of days. Sara leaves behind her husband, Brad, her 7-year-old daughter, Aurora, and her long-awaited newborn son, Owen. Owen is still in the NICU for quite some time.Please consider donating any amount possible to help lessen the significant financial burden and stress at this catastrophic time. Sara was only 28 years old, healthy, vibrant, joyful, and beloved by everyone she met. Sara was an energetic and enthusiastic mother, not only to her sweet Rory, but also to all the children in her sphere. She created beauty and joy wherever she went. Her family and friends are stunned and shattered by her sudden death and the world will be a poorer place without her. Your help would be a welcome relief.￼￼￼

title: Support Sue Conley
text: We are coming together as a team of former parents and teachers from Park Avenue Methodist Day School to ask you for your support for Sue Conley,  a cherished friend, and wonderful teacher. Many of us have known Sue for more than 30 years and watched her over that time as a guiding light and force in the lives of small children and their parents as they were  introduced to school for the first time.  Sue has dedicated her life to helping children and families, including work  with disabled children and adults at Daniel's Music Foundation, and  co-founding a playgroup for children with developmental delays.   In March of this year Sue was diagnosed with cancer and had surgery at Sloan-Kettering to remove her spleen, a kidney, part of her pancreas and a portion of her colon. She was subsequently hospitalized on three occasions for complications requiring further surgery.    While  we are all hopeful for a good outcome  we know that Sue faces a significant and financially stressful period of recovery.  Please join us now in helping Sue defray the cost of her illness.Tina Hammond, Kit Schneider, Judith Keisman, Ellen Siesel, Megan Levantin, Lauren Wilkinson, Kathryn Carroll, Suzanne Cotton

title: Drew's Breast Cancer Fund
text: I am raising money for a wonderful mother I work with. Her daughter, Drew, who is 29 years old,  has just been diagnosed with breast cancer, and her medical bills have already depleted her savings. As she has just started treatment, she has a way to go and needs help.  So I started the GoFundMe page to help.  Drew is a beautiful girl and is trying to be positive through all this.  She has written something, so we can all get to know her and listen to her story:"Buzzzzzzz Bizzzzzzzzz Buzzzzzzippp.The sound of the clippers made a ringing in my ears, with a wicked finality. Locks of my beautiful red hair fell in clumps to the floor as my mother shaved the remaining bits of my head. She tried to keep it together as tears streamed down my face. My crowning glory, the trait that people recognized me by most, was now in a heap on the floor. Just a few short weeks prior, I was diagnosed with Stage 3 breast cancer.  A shock to my friends and family, and most especially me. I am 29 years old. But to start, you must know that I LOVE my life and I LOVE to laugh. I'm a fiery Texan, and I find humor in dry wit, fun in dressing in my vintage clothing and pin curls, and great joy in a slice of very cheesy pizza. And believe me, I enjoy all those things regularly in my now home base of New York. On top of all of those things, I love my job, a company where I am able to be my best lady-hustler self. Late last fall, the company hosted several cancer awareness events, including a bake-off where the proceeds went to Susan G. Komen. My little pink ribbon sprinkle cookies won the taste test and my company donated to Susan G. Komen in my honor! Following the bake-off, we had a young breast cancer survivor come and tell her story, a harrowing tale by a woman who's about the same age as me and my many under-30 coworkers. I consider myself fully supportive of women's issues (after all, I’m a woman myself!), but neither the bake-off nor the talk seemed to have much true weight at the time. How could they? I was happy and healthy, after all. Something from those events must have subconsciously taken hold though because a few weeks later, I did a self-examination, finding a golf ball size lump. The radiologist couldn’t look me in the face while going over the mammogram. She kept asking, “how old are you?”, in disbelief of what she was seeing on her screen. Though she hadn’t yet said the words, I knew from the look on her face that the diagnosis wasn’t in my favor. Considering the circumstances, it seemed ironic. My company had just donated money to a cause which one day I could potentially be a beneficiary. I just hadn’t known it at the time. How could I, a young woman so happy, have gotten hit by life so hard? It was surreal. Since the diagnosis, the doctors have come up with the plan for chemo first (a whopping 15 treatments!) and surgery later, hoping the chemo will shrink the tumors considerably before I go under the knife. I put on a happy face, but the truth is, the side effects of the treatment are much rougher than I lead on. There is the chronic exhaustion (which has affected my ability to walk around the city I love); I have gotten poked and prodded by more needles than I can count; I had a port implanted into my chest (which upset me to no end to have a scar in a very visible place); I have undergone a series of uncomfortable fertility treatments (who knew chemo could leave you infertile?!); I’ve had a lot of long, tough conversations about things I never thought I would discuss, and of course I’ve lost my beautiful red hair. But no matter how ill or tired I feel, I'm at the office most days, with a big smile on my face, attacking my daily goals like a ninja. Very few acquaitances or people at the office know I have cancer, and I'm proud of that, knowing I can maintain some sense of normalcy and still be perceived as the lady-hustler I always want to be! Plus, a very good auburn wig helps! And my personal life is also full of smiles, with friends and family checking in all the time, bringing over meals, and sending as many Beyonce gifs as possible (because what day isn't made better with a Beyonce gif?!). Despite my many blessings, the fact is I still have cancer, and I very simply need help. Because I have an income, I am not qualified for most financial aid. And while I do have insurance through my job, it only covers a portion of the medical bills, and those medical bills far exceed my income. I’m living a catch-22 where if I were qualified for the aid, I wouldn’t have a job. But because I do have a job, I am able to receive the insurance, which still doesn’t cover many of the bills. I am currently living in between a rock and a hard place. At the moment, I’ve depleted my savings after only the first 3 months of my treatment. With a very long road ahead, the stress of where the funds are coming from to pay the upcoming medical bills is almost as bad as the cancer itself. Thank you to all my friends and family for your love and support, and providing me the courage to speak very publicly about something so private. And thank you to those who take the time to read my story and want to help. With love and hope for a healthy future, Drew"

title: Be Kind to Andrea Hankey
text: Andrea Hankey, a young wife and mother of 2 beautiful children, 6 and 8 years old, was recently diagnosed with metastatic stage 4 liver cancer.  Andrea has already survived so much prior to this including breast cancer, which unfortunately is the cause of this horrific liver cancer.  Andrea will be undergoing chemotherapy and with this comes many travel, food,  lodging, and child care expenses.  Many community members have been touched by Andrea, through all her endless efforts in helping children, her unbelievable dedication to her family, and her continuous strength, constantly stating “I got this!”  Andrea and her husband, Andre are both social workers in school settings.  Both Andrea and Andre have given so much to our community it’s time for us to give to them.  Andrea has forever demonstrated and lived by the statement, “In a world where you can be anything, be kind.”  It’s our turn to please choose kind, and help Andrea Hankey and her family.  #BEANDREAKIND

title: Props for Aga
text: All of you who know Aga Rukaj know her as just about the strongest woman alive! I mean, the woman can do anything! She's at the dance studio lifting props, bossing around prop dads, helping her daughter's dance team, supporting her son's football team, and essentially being Wonder Woman.As if managing a daughter who dances and a son who's a graduating senior isn't enough?!?But just a few weeks ago, she went in for an X-ray for what she thought was a cold/cough and came out with a diagnosis of Stage 4 Cancer. Now this dedicated single mom of two and Prop Queen needs our help as she is in the fight of her life! Aga is always there to help EVERYONE -- now we need to help her! Aga's battle is underway, but  her testing, chemo and radiation are accompanied by so many unexpected expenses. Financial donations through this GoFundMe will be used to offset medical bills, copays, medication, and all the costs that accompany treatment and illness. This way Aga can concentrate on getting better instead of worrying about the financial aspects of this fight. Aga is fighting hard, as we all knew she would. We can fight with her through our donations. Please donate to Props for Aga. We're all with you, Aga!!

title: Baby Liam's Medical Treatment
text: *Update* Liam is fighting the good fight. Thank you all from the bottom of my heart. He is recovering from his third heart surgery. Its been devastating to find out he has been diagnosed with Multiple Sulfatase Deficiency and to date there is no known cure or treatment. We will strive and fight by Liam’s side to seek out treatment. Thank you to my family and friends. Thank you to my family in blue and tan. Fight on.  Hello everyone, my name is Benny Simonzad and our family is residing in the City of Burbank, CA. My beautiful son Liam Simonzad was born with Tetralogy of Fallot and had open heart surgery on March 8th 2018, but unfortunately his recovery had complications and he needs a life saving surgery in April, 2018. He will most likely need additional repairs in the future. I can attest that it is easier to give then to ask as I refused to burden others, but we have reached a point where we need some help.  These funds will help pay Liam’s current and future medical bills and help our family’s finances as I will be taking time off of work. To our friends and family who encouraged us and supported us, we humbly thank you.  We deeply appreciate everyone's love and concern.

title: Jim Sweeney’s Leukemia Journey
text: Dear friends, This is a picture of Jim Sweeney and his wife Mary Kay Claus with their two rescued labs on Christmas Day of 2016. Little did they know what Christmas Day 2017 had in store for them.  As the saying goes, life sure can come at you in the strangest ways.Jim, my friend, a groomsman in my wedding, and a colleague for over 30 years, was diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) on Christmas Eve 2017.  He proceeded to spend 45 days in Inova Fairfax Hospital receiving two rounds of chemotherapy treatment that, unfortunately, were not successful in getting him into remission.  He is currently receiving outpatient “maintenance” chemotherapy as he awaits a consultation at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, Maryland to determine if he is a candidate for a bone marrow transplant (necessary for a cure).As many of you know, Jim has been an independent contractor in the media industry for the majority of his career.  This means he has neither paid vacation nor sick leave accrued, and due to this debilitating disease, is currently unable to generate any income. It is highly unlikely that Jim will be able to return to work in 2018.Jim and Mary Kay need your help as they navigate through this journey.Although they do have insurance, it does not cover all expenses. We are asking for your donations to help them with the following:·      Additional Medical expenses·      Travel to/from Johns Hopkins (should he be accepted)·      Travel to/from another treatment center or clinical trial (TBD)·      Housing for out of state treatment (patients do not stay in the hospital throughout the duration of the transplant procedure, but must find near by housing)·      Home health care provider to assist Jim at the off-site housing·      Loss of Income·      Daily living expensesMany of you have already generously offered to be a bone marrow donor.  Unfortunately, it’s not like offering to donate your Type A+ blood to his. We all wish it were that easy!  Jim will have to rely on a match through the national donation bank:  www.bethematch.org.  Visit this site and you can find out more about the procedure and how you can register.Jim and Mary Kay will share updates with me (here) as they know more, and both want you to know that Jim continues to keep his positive attitude and wicked sense of humor.I thank you, and so do they.Darren Williams

title: #SawyerStrong
text: Sawyer was involved in an incident at a waterpark in which he fell more then 30ft from a platform at the water slide. We are very grateful that he is alive today. However there is a long road to recovery, with multiple surgeries and therapy and the unknown. We have launched this site to help his family cover what will be significant medical costs, so they can concentrate on Sawyers physical and mental health. The family thanks you for your prayers and support during this incredibly difficult time. This campaign has been established by Sawyer’s family,  Shari is Sawyer’s grandma.

title: Let’s help Vinny
text: I created this page as I recently found out that one of my good friend’s father, Vinny Rutigliano, was diagnosed with Pancreatic cancer. Vinny is in for the fight of his life and is currently undertaking a chemotherapy regime with the hope for curative surgery in months to come.  Unfortunately Vinny’s insurance is not taken at some of the cancer institutes needed to treat this disease and he will be out of work for quite some time. For those of you that don’t know Vinny... Vinny has been a resident of the Warwick NY area for nearly 40 years. He lives with his wife Barbara of 43 years in Sugarloaf. He just turned 64 years old and is currently the grandfather to his 7 beloved grandchildren with another one on its way in November.  Vinny has dedicated the better part of his life to helping others in the community by volunteering 20 years of service to the Brian Ahearn Children’s fund, acting as president of Warwick Litttle League and organizing many other sporting events for charitable causes.Let’s all do what we can to support Vinny and his family through this trying time so we can see that big smile and laughter of his shining for years to come.

title: Precious Parents Road to Recovery
text: Dear Friends and Family,Over the last 8 years, my mother has been the primary caregiver of my father Seymon, who is currently struggling with dementia.  Unfortunately, his mental capacity has severely declined over the last 6 months, making it more and more difficult for my mother to take care of him.  As some of you may know, my mom Lynne suffered a Hemorrhage stroke on May 16th.  When I received the phone call from the emergency room, they explained to me that the brain bleed was so deep it became too unsafe to operate on.  Having no idea if my mother would make it another day, I chose to fly home the following morning.   Praise God she is a fighter who is now in the process of recovery.  However, it will continue to be a long process as she slowly learns to walk, use her right arm, and remember words she once knew.  Even when she is discharged from rehab she will need extensive physical and occupational therapy.    Once it became clear that my mother was at least stable and on the path to recovery, I chose to fly back to California on June 12th.  On my way to the airport I received another disturbing phone call informing me that my father suffered multiple mini strokes known as “TIAs”.  Two days later, he suffered from a very large stroke called a basal ganglia. The doctors said it was about a 9/10 severity. He is now with my mom at the rehab facility trying his best to recover.  As you can imagine, his dementia has severely slowed his progress and Medicare’s coverage is coming to an end.My fathers’ strokes have resulted in a series of blood clots that have now manifested themselves in my father’s lungs. The doctors were able to dissolve some of these clots with the use of blood thinners, but he is now suffering from DVT (deep vein thrombosis) and his leg is extremely swollen, making it even more difficult to walk again. We were informed that he will probably never live at home again.Thank God my parents have some long-term health care, but as you may know, the costs are EXTREMELY high.  With the coverage we need for both of them, we will be unable to afford the costs in only a few years.  With both parents out of work, and in rehab with limited medical coverage, it has become ever more critical to pay for the recovery process.  This will most likely be for a caregiver for our mom and a nursing home for our dad.   Anything you can give would be an absolute blessing.Love you all.  Life is precious,  Emma & Dane

title: Move A Mountain with Kevin!
text: Move a Mountain with Kevin!  By Sylvia McNair, Whitney Osentoski and Ryan VanDenBoomProvidence Park Hospital is a place of wonder!  Dr. Seilesh Babu, of the Michigan Ear Institute, and his extraordinary team successfully removed an acoustic neuroma from the right side of Kevin’s head.  Kevin will have huge out-of-pocket medical expenses related to this surgery. Rise with us to give our friend Kevin another standing ovation!  Please donate here. Goal:  $50,000

title: Support for Valentina Guiulfo
text: Please read below in English and Spanish to learn more about "Valentina the Brave" and her challenging road ahead. ________________________________________________________________________________________________________________Wednesday, June 13, 2018, was a day that Marcelo and Jocy will never forget. What they thought was routine MRI as a precaution before scheduling a common surgery to correct Valentina’s lazy eye turned into their worst nightmare. Little Valentina, only 18-months old was diagnosed with a tumor on her brainstem. This one routine test and unexpected medical answer turned the Guiulfo Gamallo’s family life upside down. Instead of heading home to play with her big brother, six-year-old, Mauricio, Valentina was immediately admitted into Children’s Healthcare of Atlanta.The neurosurgeon explained that the tumor was in a very difficult area to access, as a surgery to remove it could cause devastating and irreversible damage to Valentina's vital functioning. Yet, they needed to perform an emergency surgery to release the fluid accumulating in the ventricles of her brain—causing it tremendous pressure, and they also needed to perform a biopsy of the tumor. In a little less than a month, Valentina has undergone three surgeries: the emergency surgery to release brain pressure and to autopsy the tumor, a second one to place a shunt on her brain to drain the fluid and reduce pressure, and a third to insert a port where chemotherapy will be administered. The tumor is not cancerous but it is also too dangerous to remove, so we all remain hopeful that a long-term chemotherapy treatment, beginning on July 12th, will reduce the Grade1 tumor. The tumor, or as little brother, Mauricio is calling it, “the cloud” has begun impeding Valentina’s eyesight, so she is wearing a patch for most of the day at the recommendation of her pediatric ophthalmologist. Nevertheless, Marcelo, Jocy, Mauricio, and Valentina – along with their family and friends all over the world – are ready for the fight of their lives. Valentina, meaning “healthy and strong” needs your help, love, support, and prayers as she fights for her life—she truly is “Valentina the Brave.” The Guiulfo Gamallo’s have a long road ahead of them. One that will be exhausting both physically and emotionally but also financially. They are deeply grateful to their family and friends for their continue support and willingness to help. Already in this journey, they have found wonderful people ready to give them a hand to help or a hug to comfort what they are going through. The doctors and nurses have been doing a phenomenal job and doing their very best for Valentina’s health. The prayers are coming from around the world and from different religious, which is helping this family to keep strong and faithful.Please consider helping this amazing family with a donation so they can continue to provide Valentina (and of course, big brother, Mauricio) with the love, energy, and care they deserve during this particularly challenging time. Thank you for listening to the beginning of this story – it is a journey, and they will need us all in it for the long haul. Keep up your prayers for Valentina the Brave._________________________________________________________________________________________________________________El miércoles 13 de junio de 2018 fue un día que Marcelo y Jocy nunca olvidarán. Lo que ellos pensaban que era una resonancia magnética de rutina antes de programar una cirugía común para corregir el estrabismo de Valentina, se convirtió en su peor pesadilla. A la pequeña Valentina, de sólo 18 meses, le diagnosticaron un tumor en el cerebro. Esta única prueba de rutina y una respuesta médica inesperada cambiaron la vida familiar de los Guiulfo Gamallo. En lugar de que Valentina regresara a su casa para jugar con su hermano mayor, Mauricio (de seis años), ella fue hospitalizada de inmediato en el Hospital de Niños de Atlanta.El neurocirujano les explicó que el tumor estaba en un área muy difícil de acceder,  y que una cirugía para extirparlo podría causar daños devastadores e irreversibles en el desarrollo de Valentina. Sin embargo, se necesitaba realizar una cirugía de emergencia para obtener una biopsia del tumor y liberar el líquido que se acumulaba en los ventrículos de su cerebro, causando a su vez presión en el nervio óptico.En poco menos de un mes, Valentina ha tenido tres cirugías: la cirugía de emergencia para liberar la presión en el cerebro y obtener la biopsia del tumor, una segunda para colocar una válvula en el cerebro para drenar el líquido y reducir la presión, y una tercera para insertar un puerto donde se administrará quimioterapia. El tumor no es canceroso, sin embargo, debido a su ubicación, es muy peligroso para remover, por lo que Valentina necesitará un tratamiento de quimioterapia a largo plazo, el cual comenzará el 12 de julio para reducir el tumor de Grado 1. El tumor, o como su hermano Mauricio lo llama, "una nube" ha comenzado a afectar la visión de Valentina, por lo que ella está usando un parche por recomendación de su oftalmólogo pediátrico en su ojito hasta que Valentina haya superado la quimioterapia y el tumor se haya reducido. A pesar de todo esto, Marcelo, Jocy, Mauricio y Valentina, junto con sus familiares y amigos de todo el mundo, están listos para afrontar el mayor reto de sus vidas. Valentina, que significa "saludable y fuerte", necesita de la ayuda de todos, amor, apoyo y oraciones mientras ella lucha por su vida y demuestra que ella es realmente “Valentina la Valiente". Los Guiulfo Gamallo tienen un largo camino por delante. Uno que será agotador tanto física como emocionalmente, pero también financieramente. Ellos están profundamente agradecidos con sus familiares y amigos por su continuo apoyo y voluntad de ayudar. Ya en este camino difícil, han encontrado personas maravillosas listas para darles una mano o un abrazo reconfortante para sobrellevar por todo lo que están pasando. Los doctores y enfermeras han estado haciendo un trabajo increíble y velando por el bien de Valentina. Las oraciones vienen llegando de todo el mundo y de diferentes religiones, lo que ayuda a esta familia a mantenerse fuertes y con fe para superar esta difícil travesía. Por favor, considera ayudar a esta asombrosa familia con una donación para que puedan seguir brindando a Valentina (y por supuesto, a su hermano mayor, Mauricio) el amor, la energía y la atención que merecen durante este momento particularmente difícil. Gracias por escuchar el comienzo de esta historia: es una travesía difícil, y nos necesitarán a todos en el largo plazo. Y por favor que sigan las oraciones por Valentina “la Valiente”.

title: Nathan Pinheiro Medical Expenses
text:
We create this page with heavy hearts for the Pinheiro family who are in the midst of living through something that no parent should ever have to experience. On April 19th Nathan passed away after fighting for his life for several days.The family has requested privacy during this sensitive time as they grieve. This page has been created to help support them during their time of heartache so Marissa and Jay can take their time to heal at home with their daughter Adrianna. 

All donations are greatly appreciated and are directly going to Nathan’s medical expenses and arrangements.

title: Bob- O Strong
text: Bob was the epitome of good health;  the avid bicyclist, the man who biked across the United States a few years ago, and, most recently, the one who biked through Mallorca with friends in April. Bob lived for the outdoors, his family, and most importantly, his Linda-Lou! On Friday, May 25th, everything changed. Bob was taking a short ride around his hometown of Victor, NY and was involved in a tragic bicycle accident that left him paralyzed from the chest down and dealing with many other complicating factors that came along with it.  We all know Bob is a fighter. He can do this, but he's going to need extensive rehabilitative therapy.  Unfortunately Rochester does not have the spinal cord injury facility he needs, so he was moved quite a ways from home (Sunnyview Rehabilitation Center in Schenectady) .  On top of the incurring fees for his medical care, including  daily physical therapy, occupational therapy, and speech services, there will be lots of travel involved and many nights  away from home. With the reality of everything that is going to be involved in his care, we are going to need financial help to make sure Bob gets everything he needs.  It’s going to be a long, difficult road, but Bob is tough and ready to fight!!! We appreciate your support. Please continue the prayers and positive thoughts!!From the bottom of our hearts, THANK YOU!Love,Bob & Linda's kidsMichelle, Michele, Matt, Heidi, Shannon & Erin

title: Help Ramona Fight For Her life
text: The move org. Is informing our supporters, sympathizers and all those in solidarity with the cause of revolution,that Ramona Africa,Move’s Minister of Communication, survivor of the May 13, 1985,holocaust, has been hospitalized as result of health complications coming from a condition called PTSD {post taumatic stress disorder}. A direct result of the on-going war waged on our Move Family by this government {we’ve lost 24 members to date}.  Two died in prison under suspicious circumstances termed “cancer”.  Now Ramona is diagnosed with “cancer” and she’s again battling to be a survivor.                                              If there’s any questions or concerns people want to address please contact Alberta Africa or Sue Africa at these numbers:  215-387-4107 or helpramonaafrica@gmail.com                                                             ON The Move                                                                                        Long Live John Africa!

title: Help Jason Get Out of the Woods
text: Jason was recently diagnosed with a rare form of leukemia called Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL).  This has come as a complete shock to Jason, Mindy, their two young boys Wyatt and Gunnar and to all who know and love him. For those of you who know Jason, know that he has always been a healthy and active father and husband and a ball of energy always helping others, working on projects around the house, playing with his boys or spending time with his family. Over the next few months, he will be undergoing a series of treatments that require him to stay at the hospital and not able to work. His amazing wife Mindy will also be taking time to be with him as he fights this disease. There will undoubtably be medical bills among other expenses that they will be faced with over the coming months. In an effort to help alleviate some of the financial burden, we are putting this together to help this incredible man and his family get through this hardship. No donation is too small and we appreciate all good thoughts and prayers. Let's rally together to get Jason out of the woods!

title: Gary Lopinto's Cancer Fund
text: Gary Lopinto was a 38 year veteran of the Louisiana Department of Health in the Commercial Seafood Division and was forced to abruptly retire on December 21st, 2017 due to the following events: "On December 14, 2017 while at a routine doctor visit for swelling in my left leg and foot it was discovered that I had blood clots in my left leg call DVT (deep vain thrombosis). I was placed on a blood thinner with instructions that if I had pain in my upper back an emergency room visit was required because a clot could have broken loose and traveled to my lungs. This could cause a pulmonary embolism which was potentially life threatening. On December 17, 2017 due to pain in my upper back, my wife and I visited the emergency room.  A chest X-ray and a CAT scan of my upper abdomen were taken. While there was no pulmonary embolism, the emergency room doctor said the test showed lesions in my liver and swollen lymph nodes in my chest. The emergency room doctor's opinion was that there was cancer coming from somewhere in my body. I was admitted to the hospital. Extensive testing on December 18th revealed a tumor in my pancreas, numerous lesions in my liver, and the beginning of tumors in my right lung. The doctors at EJ hospital concluded that there was a high probablity of pancreatic cancer that had spread to other oragns. I began consultaion with MD Anderson hospital in Houston on December 27, 2017. Three visits to MD Anderson between December 27th and January the 8th confirmed that it was in fact stage 4 pancreatic cancer as proven by a biopsy of my liver. The doctors at MD Anderson informed me that my condition was potentially treatable, but not curable. Because the cancer had evacuated the pancreas. The  oncologist at MD Anderson and the oncologist at EJ Hosptial agreed that the best potential treatment would be chemotherapy. Several complications arouse which delayed the beginning of my chemo therapy treatment. Finally, chemo therapy started on Valentines day of 2018. I have had a total of 3 treatments so far which last 6 and half hours per treatment, and are very difficult to recover from.  At least 4 more treatments are scheduled prior to a CAT scan. These will reveal if the chemo therapy is working on the tumor. Further treatment will be based on the result of that CAT scan."All donations are greatly appreciated during this difficult time. Treatments will be on going for the forseable future. Any dontaiton big, or small will be of great help. Thank you for your time, love, and prayers during this time.-The Lopintos

title: Cecily
text: Cecily is a beautiful, young, strong and energetic 15 year old.  Her truest passion in life is and has always been All-Star cheerleading. She has been cheering since the tender age of “5” and is currently a member of Upper Merion All Stars (UMAS) Senior X-Small Level 5 Worlds Team “The Royals”. Cecily has cheered with UMAS for the last 3 seasons and her teammates are her extended family.  Cecily is and was your typical teenager; until July 26, 2018 when she was diagnosed with the most frightening news, a Brain Tumor! Literally just days before Cecily had attended an intense cheer training camp and was practicing right up until her diagnosis where she was flying high and landing her elite tumbling passes.  Cecily had surgery on July 30, 2018 to remove her tumor but since that day and her return to recovery, Cecily has been unable to wake up. It has now been weeks of what can only be described as a Surreal Nightmare! If this was not enough tragic news, let me please share with all of you a small piece of Cecily’s life! As she is no stranger to real life pain and heartache.  Just two and a half years ago at the age of 12; Early Christmas morning Cecily lost her Father! ...and now on this very day Cecily is in a REAL LIFE FIGHT WITH REAL LIFE CONSEQUENCES!!! I know she would never look for, want for, ask for, nor need anyone’s sympathy! As she has displayed a strength of sheer determination to succeed in the face of even the most tragic of life’s obstacles! ...and a Maturity beyond Her teenage years! Thankfully Cecily has an amazing support system of family friends and teammates who have gathered in spirit to pray for her recovery! Her mother has been the rock in Her life and has taken what looks to be a permanent leave of absence from work so that she may continue her 24/7 vigil at Cecily’s side.   UMAS is trying to help alleviate just a small piece of the burden her family now endures!  So I along with Cecily’s loved ones would like to help support the ever growing accumulation of medical bills and living expenses of a seemingly endless and unknown outcome and Journey!Please Help us, Help Cecily and Her family with this most devastating occurrence! Our goal at this moment is to raise funds for Cecily’s long journey back to a full recovery.

title: Brandon Needs 2nd Liver Transplant
text: Brandon Facon has lived a life full of doctors appointments, hospital stays, countless blood draws and thousands of pills and through it all he has been my hero. He has always said, “I don’t know why I was given this challenge in life, but I will make the most of it.” That is why, after being diagnosed with Auto-Immune Hepatitis, Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis and Crohns at the age of eight, he became an advocate for the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America.  He wanted to help people and their families living with Crohns and Colitis. He became the “Face of Crohns” for the Rolf Benirschke Legacy Golf Tournament and was a speaker at their annual fundraiser for over ten years.  After eight years, Brandon’s liver deteriorated to a point where he needed a liver transplant. He was jaundice, tired and slept all the time. He had to finish high school on home hospital.   We sold our house, moved into an apartment and after graduation, he and my mom moved to Indiana because the wait time there was only weeks compared to years in California. That is when we learned that Indiana is an “opt out” state, which means that you are automatically a donor unless you “opt out.”After waiting only seven and a half weeks, Brandon received the “perfect” liver!   We now celebrate 8-10-12 as his 2nd birthday!  Brandon and my mom returned home in November, just in time for Thanksgiving. We had so much to be thankful for! While he was home recuperating from the transplant, he added Donate Life to his personal causes and began speaking to high school students about the importance of being a donor. He wants to change California to an “opt out” state, so that it will shorten the wait time for patients on the transplant waiting list. After taking the year off to recuperate from the transplant, he started college at Cal Poly San Luis Obispo studying Engineering.  Managing his health while attending school proved to be difficult. For the last three years, he has suffered with daily nausea, jaundice and extreme fatigue. His disease of Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis is back and has resulted in chronic Intrahepatic Ductopenic Rejection and Cirrhosis of the liver. Brandon needs to have a 2nd Liver Transplant.  His case will be presented April 27th  in order to get on the Transplant list.  Because it still takes about 3+ years in California, the plan is to let Brandon finish college in June and then Brandon and my mom will move to Indiana and wait for his 2nd “perfect” liver.  Brandon needs our help!  He is humble and would never ask for himself, but as his sister and as a long-time admirer of his courage, his spirit and his downright perseverance, I'm saying it.   There's no way of sugar-coating this: Brandon needs this transplant!   It's obviously a very serious surgery, and one that I know he is not looking forward to enduring, but he perseveres by staying focused on the hope of feeling better and regaining his strength and energy.  Thankfully our health insurance will cover the transplant, but there are aspects of care and recovery (including the high deductible, copays, medication, living expenses in Indiana, and much more), which are not covered by insurance.  For the first year after a transplant, a patient remains at high risk for rejection, and there are many costs associated with monitoring and guarding against this, as well as with recuperation. After-care is crucial, and it's expensive. That's where we can help.Brandon’s transplant team has advised that he should have a large contingency fund in place, which can be put towards these costs. The sums are enormous, so I'm setting up this fundraising campaign. Please give what you can and spread the word. Brandon Facon is an amazing brother and person. He is facing a very tough time ahead and we can help make it a little easier and less stressful. Thank you for reading Brandon’s story and for considering a donation. Here's a brief note from Brandon: I am proud that I have been able to make a positive contribution with my life so far and hope I have been worthy of it.  Living with chronic health issues is a challenge, but living at all can be a challenge. I have been lucky to have a mission and to know it from a very young age. People work their whole lives to leave their mark on this world with the desire to make a difference, to be remembered, to be someone’s hero. They go to school to gain knowledge so that they will achieve success, some develop their talents in athletics, music, or theater to be in the spotlight, while others choose to get married and raise families. The paths may be different, yet the desire is the same. People want to make a difference, to be remembered, to be someone’s hero. My first liver donor, Erica, didn’t know at the time, but she would become my hero just six years after she made that selfless decision and I am forever grateful. I pray now for my next liver donor and am thankful for their decision to be a donor.I want to thank you in advance for your donations, for you are making a difference in my life.  I know my health will be restored!  I have so much to accomplish and need to get busy living my life to the fullest and cherishing each and every day!  And yes, like Erica, I have that pink dot on my license too, do you?Donate Life Float at the Rose Parade back in 2013!Brandon's Neon Film Display. Cal Poly San Luis Obispo, Spring 2017.Black and white photo of Brandon's scar in 2016.

title: EMERSON THE BRAVE
text: As many of you know Emerson has been at Helen Devos childrens Hospital. She has Under gone 2 surgeries since 6/14/18.
