The latest surgery being today they were only able to remove 10 percent of mass they found.Emmy has a long road ahead of her to defeat this thing.As to be suspected this type of thing can become costly. from gas to get to and from  hospital to the bills at the house. and other unforseen expenses.any donation will helpthank youthe Francis Family

title: Fund for Russ' Standing Chair
text: Russ Hartman needs your help to fund his new electric wheelchair!  This new chair would allow him to stand up and wheel himself around electronically, aiding him as he strives to be more independent.  After testing the chair out for himself, he checked with his insurance to see if they could help.  They might be able to cover a portion of the cost, but unfortunately not enough of it.  So, now we're reaching out to all of you to see if we can raise the rest of the funds to get him in the new chair.To tell you a little about Russ, he's played a major part  in shaping Austin into the community that it is today.  As editor of the Austin Daze, he's dedicated himself to showcasing and promoting local art in all forms.  He's made it his mission to not only unite people from all walks of art, but to bring the Austin community closer together as a whole.  Most importantly, he's been a great friend and inspiration to all of us around town. Aside from his honorary band member status in so many local bands, Russ has helped a ton of great artists get their start on the roads they walk today.  With each interview conducted, issue printed, gig booked, and event covered, Russ has done everything with one major thing on his mind, building the surrounding local community and making sure everyone's having the best time that they can at the best gigs in town.Those who know Russ well, know about his addictively positive attitude that he exudes each day no matter what's thrown his way.  He's combined that attitude with a fiercely independent spirit and incredibly strong drive to create his family (every one of you!) here in Austin.We now have an opportunity to help Russ out and get him cruising in one of the most badass wheelchair's ever!  Check out the video at the top of the page to see the test drive in action.  This chair not only allows him to stand up and stretch his legs out, but he'll also become more mobile and will be able to wheel around standing up!It'd be awesome if we could all band together and help raise the funds to make this chair a reality for him! Your help mean so much and anything that you could give is very much appreciated!   There also will be a benefit show(s) coming, so be on the lookout and be sure to come out and support.  All funds raised will go directly toward Russ’s new wheelchair, allowing him to get around more easily, independently and efficiently.  You'll be seeing Russ at all of his favorite clubs around town, dancing in his new chair. Thank you to everyone for your contributions!For those of you that don't know who I am or how I fit into this whole thing,  I'm Russ' cousin, Greg.  I lived down in Austin with him for 20+ months.  I got to see firsthand what an awesome dude my cousin really is while I lived down there.  I can tell you that this wheelchair would definitely be a game changer for him.  It would make it much easier for him to do things independently and it would allow him to do so many of the daily tasks that he needs to do, wants to do, and loves to do.  Thanks for your support!

title: Sarah Salazar SF High victim
text: I am Norma Irlas. I am Sarah's aunt. Sarah was a victim of the Santa Fe shooting. After having emergency surgery, she is now in ICU.  Her shoulder was shattered. Her mandible is fractured and she also has several rib fractures.  She was shot from the neck down to her thigh. She is intubated and is recovering from the trauma to her neck vessels.  After that, she will require several surgeries. This is the beginning of a long road to recovery.  To God be the glory that she is still with us.

title: Scotty Dolan Big Fight
text: My family and I are facing the biggest challenge of my life. On Thursday August 9th I had 2 seizures and was sent to Beth Israel Deaconess for a biopsy. I have been diagnosed with stage 3  cancer (Anaplastic Astrocytoma). I will be starting chemotherapy and radiation treatment this Thursday.  I am starting this fundraiser to cover the ongoing fees and expenses not covered by my insurance. These treatments are for at least six months, unfortunately I will not be working while undergoing the healing process.Thank you on behalf of my family and myself for your support.

title: HELP ROBIN
text: July 4th, 2002. The Hannoun family departs from France to South Florida to start a new life in the United States. Even though it meant leaving the remainder of the family behind, the two young children, David and Robin, are so excited to get to a life of sunshine and rainbows (literally) and get away from all of the negative stigma that France held for them. “We’re never going back,” Robin said to David as they both saw the Independence Day fireworks streaming through the sky, something they’d never even thought about in their young days in France. Well, funny how life turns out sometimes.Fast forward to June 2018. Robin, now 21 years old, has just returned from a trip to Asia and is starting his first professional internship at an investment firm in Tampa, FL. He has a bit of a headache and is feeling nauseous, but he just shrugs it off as nerves or bad Chipotle or something like that. A week goes by, still the same feeling of nausea. He starts to seek medical attention, going to see a few different medical professionals in the South Florida area. No one is able to tell him what’s wrong with him.Rightfully worried and concerned, he decided to take matters into his own hands. Despite how the two brothers felt about France, there is one thing that is undoubtedly true – the healthcare system is miles ahead of that of the United States. So, Robin got on a flight to France, not even booking a return flight because he knew something was wrong. This was Friday, June 29th. He landed in Paris at 1:00 PM. By 3:00 PM, he found out he had a benign tumor in the left ventricle region of his brain. With his grandfather a highly regarded doctor throughout France, he was able to get in the care of Professor Parker, one of the world’s leading practitioners in neurosurgery. Robin met with him that Saturday; within a few minutes, he was scheduled for intensive brain surgery for that Tuesday, July 3rd.Everyone’s life changed. His mother, who was with his sister in New York for a dance competition, booked a flight to France immediately. His brother, who lives and works in Atlanta, did the same. His father was already in France, but now, there were no plans of returning to the States. Everyone was there for Robin when he got out of surgery, and we were all so impressed and pleased by the man we saw.Literal moments after getting out from brain surgery, when it normally takes weeks or even months to be able to move, Robin was stretching his arms and rotating his legs back and forth. He was conversing with us, he was completely conscious, and he was kicking his recovery’s ass. In fact, he was able to walk by himself within 2 days, something which usually takes several months for patients with a similar surgery. We were all so happy and pleased with how everything was going, and quite honestly, so was he.And then came the next piece of the story. Robin’s benign tumor had been sent to the lab for biological analysis just as standard procedure, and as it turns out, it actually wasn’t benign at all; in fact, it was quite the opposite. What Robin had gotten removed was a malignant medulloblastoma, a cancerous tumor which turns out had metastasized into  another region of his brain. Long story short, he had brain cancer, and needed to get treatment right away.Robin was then sat down and told the plan, the plan that would ultimately determine the most basic thing – his survival. Regular sessions of chemotherapy followed by regular sessions of radiotherapy. He would perform all of these in France over the coming months.Now, the hardest part for most cancer patients isn’t the physical symptoms and reaction to the therapy; the hardest part, by far, is the mental part. Staying positive amongst all of these negatives, keeping faith in the process even when your platelets get so low that you have to get a transfusion that doesn’t even work because you’re so depleted that your vein literally bursts when plucked with a needle, or being able to tell yourself that you’re going to get through this even when there is no indication or certainty at all. This isn’t like a common cold, or breaking a bone, or twisting an ankle. This is cancer, and nothing is certain.So how does this apply to Robin? Well, he has always been a fighter; when it comes to the physical symptoms, he’s reacting very well and he himself is not worried about them. The mental part is a different story. Remember how when he and his brother were little kids, he told David “We’re never going back.” Well, he meant it. He never wanted to go back and spend extended amounts of time in France, much less live there while getting treated for arguably the worst type of cancer known to man. So, it’s needless to say that not only is the treatment tough, but he is incurably homesick, misses his friends, his habits, his familiarity of living in the US. And while we can’t literally bring the US to him, one thing we can do is bring the next best thing – his friends.Robin has a crew, a group of several young men who all call each other best friends, and they all would be willing to do anything for one another. The goal of this fundraiser is to pay for biweekly trips to France for Robin’s best friends to come see him, to establish some sort of resemblance of home and bring some happiness and familiarity back into his life as he goes through and fights this horrible disease. As they say, even the smallest of lights shines bright if it’s in the darkest of places. Help us save Robin. Help us save my brother.David Hannoun

title: Loren and Sara Davy Family
text: Last night a good friend and colleague of ours, Loren Davy and his wife Sara Stafford Davy, were involved in a tragic vehicle accident in Monahans, Texas. This accident resulted in the passing of Loren’s beautiful wife, Sara. Both Loren and Sara are well known, loved and respected in the medical and aviation community around the Permian Basin, West Texas and beyond. Loren is one of our amazing Helicopter EMS Pilots for our MTC/AeroCare #5 Base in Odessa, Texas. Sara was a Flight Paramedic for CareStar in Odessa before becoming a Registered Nurse.  Sara was currently employed as an RN at Odessa Regional Medical Center. She previously worked at Ward Memorial Hospital in Monahans, wearing multiple hats in the ER and trauma department.  Loren and Sara have two awesome little boys, Luke who is 9 and Jake who is 6.  Loren and these boys were the center piece of love, happiness and joy to Sara.  Both Sara and Loren have dedicated much of their professional careers to helping those in need. But more importantly, they have given even more of their personal time and finances helping those in need. Now it is our turn to help their family during this terribly tragic time. This go fund me account has been established to help Loren, Luke and Jake.  Any monetary donation no matter how big or small will be appreciated. 100% of these funds will got to the Davy family. Thank you for your continued thoughts and prayers. Please help us honor Sara’s memory by assisting her beloved family.

title: Support For Danni Jo
text: She’s here! Danni Jo Napolitano was born on August 10th ~ 6 pounds 3 ounces ~ 20 inches Our beautiful little butterfly was born with a rare skin disease calledEpidermolysis Bullosa (EB). EB is a lack of K protein, which causes the first and second layer of skin to separate. The separation then causes blistering. Blisters can occur with even the slightest bit of friction to Danni Jo's skin. Danni Jo is still healing from blistering sustained during the birthing process and continues to develop new blisters daily despite the amazing 24 hour care she’s receiving from doctors, nurses, Austin, and Chris in the NICU. To combat blistering and infection, Chris and Austin must keep Danni Jo covered in Aquaphor  and work as a team to bandage her entire body from the neck down at least once a day to help protect her skin. Danni Jo is tough as nails just like both of her parents and she’s eating well and getting stronger everyday. This will be a long journey ahead for  Christopher, Austin, and Danni Jo as EB is a lifelong condition. Medical costs for people with EB can be astronomical at up to $10,000 per month for special equipment and medical supplies alone, plus doctor visits, special clothing and bedding, and more. Most insurance  companies have a cap on the amount covered for medical equipment specifically and only Chris will be able to work due to the constant care that Danni Jo will require. We are asking anyone who has it in their heart to help donate to this beautiful new family, and help our little Danni Jo on her journey ahead. Austin and Chris are both military veterans with Austin serving in the Air Force and Chris in the Army stationed with the 173rd in Bamberg Germany and Logar province Afghanistan from 2009-2012. There is so much love and good energy surrounding this beautiful little butterfly, and we hope you can be a part of that. Thank you all! - If you would like to help out in  other ways please email cjnapolitano13@gmail.com￼￼￼￼￼

title: Unidos por la salud de Marlene
text: Hola a todas y todos, En marzo de 2018, luego de batallar por varios meses con lo que se pensaba era una sinusitis bacteriana, Marlene fue diagnosticada con rhabdomyosarcoma.  Este cáncer es muy común en niños y adolescentes pero muy atípico en personas adultas (ya se imaginarán qué es lo que ella dice sobre lo de la edad). El tumor creció muy rápido,  afectó su ojo izquierdo y en cuestión de días el dolor era insoportable. Tomamos una decisión inmediata y los doctores coincidieron que el mejor curso de acción era traer a Marlene a MD Anderson Cáncer Center en Houston, Texas.  MD Anderson Cancer Center es un lugar especial. Muchos médicos boricuas trabajan acá o se preparan aquí para dar servicios de oncología en Puerto Rico.  A Marlene se le ha asignado un equipo médico con un especialista en cuello y cabeza, un oncólogo y una cirujana orbital. Todos coinciden que este tipo de sarcoma lo tienen que atacar agresivamente con quimio y radioterapia.  También, coinciden que Marlene va a ganar esta batalla contra el cancer, pero tiene que seguir su tratamiento al pie de la letra.  Marlene recibe un tratamiento de forma ambulatoria. El mismo es sumamente costoso y nos obliga a permanecer en Houston por un período de tiempo significativo.  La ayuda económica que solicitamos viene apoyar todos los gastos relacionados al proceso de curar y cuidar a Marlene.  Todo apoyo es importante, todo apoyo será para este proceso. Ayúdanos a sanar a Marlene.

title: Cancer Can't Beat Ross
text: We want to show our support and love for Ross and his family during this time. In January, he was diagnosed with Thymoma, a rare cancer that only a few hospitals around the country have experience with. They have been in New York City at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. He was also diagnosed with Thyroid cancer in May. He has undergone 3 months of chemotherapy, 2 major surgeries  in which they had to replace the lining of his heart with gore tex and remove 10% of his left lung. He is currently going through radiation. Please continue to keep Ross and his family in your prayers and give financially as you feel led. The money donated will help with medical expenses not covered by insurance, travel expenses for Ross and his family, and living expenses in NYC that have grown over the past 8 months.

title: Our Warrior Princess
text: Our Warrior PrincessAida R. Del Orbe Go Fund Me From all her loved ones especially her Husband Carlos Betancourth and daughter Raquel The life of the partyThe one who makes everyone laughThe one who can turn any situation into an adventureThe one with the loudest, rowdiest, howling laughterEveryone's best friend...that is our sister, AidaLove, Laugh, Live, Dance a lot and Pray. It’s her way of life in its simplest form. Enjoy every moment as tomorrow is not promised.  Loved fiercely by so many, she personifies what it means to live life to the fullest. Some of the hallmarks of being Aida are her sunny but caring personality, quick wit, and no filter responses to life's unpredictability. From New York City, to Arizona, to Florida she has amassed a circle of friends and loved ones who would do anything and everything for her. She is everyone's biggest cheerleader. If you ask anyone of her friends they will tell you "She is my best friend.” She makes everyone feel as if they are the most special person in her life. That is the essence of who she is. June 2016,  held the promise of  a wonderful summer to look forward to with warm sunny days, beach plans, catching up with friends and family. Little did she know it would be the beginning of a journey that was unimaginable.  After months of enduring pain that would not dissipate she finally decided to go to the doctor to determine the cause.  Like millions of women across the world, she’s diagnosed with breast cancer – Stage 3 later developing into Stage 4. After months of chemotherapy, radiation and a double mastectomy seven months later, she seemed fine. Unfortunately Aida's cancer continued to progress. The most recent diagnosis as of Saturday, Monday, May 19th is that the cancer has progressed to a brain condition called Leptomeningeal Carcinomatosis (LC). It is a rare complication of cancer which spreads to the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord. LC occurs in approximately 5% of people with cancer and is terminal. This causes blurred vision, strenuous headaches, causes the body to clamp up with no mobility, unable to speak clearly (slurring of words) where she cannot be understood and increased pressure in the brain. These episodes are increasing day-by-day. The doctors determined that a shunt surgery would stabilize the pressure that is in her brain. Monday, May 20th she will undergo this procedure. Our Princess Warrior’s hope and faith for a cure and longer life have never wavered.  She hasn’t stopped laughing and enjoying her time with family and friends. Her will to live has never diminished. God is wonderful and has blessed her with the greatest group of supporters!The doctors at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center are in search of different types of treatment to extend her life. The treatments are costly, one that will require the help of all of us coming together to relieve strenuous and costly medical bills . The situation is urgent!  We have created this Go Fund Me in hopes that collectively, all of Aida's loved ones can raise the money to pay for treatment. These funds will be a tremendous help as she explores all avenues that can lead to a potential life-saving treatment. We appreciate you taking the time to read this appeal and considering a donation to this urgent cause. As always, any amount goes a long way and we are grateful for your generous gift. Prayers go a long way, so please do not stop praying for our Warrior Princess. To help us get the word out, you may share the link to your Facebook Timeline. If you would like to stay up to date with Aida’s condition, please provide us with your email address and the team will send out updates periodically.Thank you all for your support.Team Unbeatable

title: Laura Nilson Cancer Fund
text: **When donating, you DO NOT NEED TO TIP GOFUNDME. Instead, click "Other", delete the amount in the box and type "0". If you want to help Laura Nilson fight cancer for the THIRD time, you are in the right place! Frank and Laura found out this week that after a remission of 5 years, her breast cancer has returned and aggressively metastasized to her liver and bone marrow. They are acting fast to fight it, and we can act fast to help offset the cost of treatment. All contributions will be used to pay medical bills and living expenses while Laura focuses on getting healthy.Laura has given 100% of her energy, time, and hilarious sense of humor to serve others and lift their spirits.  Her life has been dedicated to friendship and love. We are grateful to have a way to help their family during this difficult time. Thank you for your generosity!**When donating, you DO NOT NEED TO TIP GOFUNDME. Instead, click "Other", delete the amount in the box and type "0".

title: Hope for Rocky Jr.
text: This is Rocky Jr. age 9. On the night of Sunday, July 1, 2018 after a normal active summer day, Rocky suffered a severe stroke caused by a congenital condition called Arterlovenous Malformation (AVM). The stroke caused significant damage leaving him unable to walk and at first even speak. He will have to undergo at least 2 brain operations to hopefully reverse this state. But before the surgeries, Rocky Jr. will have 5+ weeks of intense rehab to hopefully regain some of his strength before the procedures. Rocky's dad, Rocky Sr., his mom, Marivel and his older sister Alison are obviously heartbroken and distraught. This is a hard working family with both parents working two jobs just to provide a normal lifestyle for lil Rock and his sister. Rocky's neurosurgeons say he is in for a very long haul from here on out but his prognosis is good. This however will involve overwhelming financial expense for the family. Please no matter what the donation, help this family through this most trying of times. Thank you.

title: "Amazing Grace that is Pam Molloy"
text: We, Pam’s friends and family, humbly request you consider donating to the “Amazing Grace that is Pam” with the same love and commitment she has given and continues to show us.Pam's StoryFifty-one years and thankfully we continue to count the days that Pam Riley Molloy graces our world.  In that time, she has proven that everything can and should be done with continual grace. As a brain cancer survivor for the past two years, she continues to show a poise and elegance while enduring the latest treatments provided by Memorial Sloan Kettering to battle this disease. At the onset of it all, Pam decided to become an active participant and survivor by joining the newly formed NJ chapter of the National Brain Tumor Society. The Molloy's Marchers have been the #1 fundraising team for the non-profit organization for the past 2 years.  Pam was raised in Glendora California by Pat and Gil Riley along with her sister Sherri. She moved to Manhattan in her 20’s, fell in love and married her soul-mate, Steve. From the beginning, this high-fashion clothing buyer exemplified style, elegance and poise. She left the work force and stayed home to raise her family. Her love for her two boys, Jack and Alec, combined with her knowledge of industry helped birth the business she called “Tickle Toes.” It was never about money and she eventually sold the business to have more time for her family and community. Pam was always active in the Colts Neck Schools and joined the PTO where she was the Fundraising Chair and eventually President for 2 years. During her time in the PTO they raised tens of thousands of dollars for the community while bringing them together to enjoy one another at the same time. Today, she is battling brain cancer and we, her friends would like to see her have that same grace and dignity she has always shown as her illness has evolved. While the cancer is in remission, Pam is suffering from Radiation Necrosis a side effect from her treatments that has affected her memory.  Now, the Molloy’s need our help as Pam requires constant supervision and care.Pam’s husband, Steve, will be the designated recipient of the funds raised during this campaign, which will be utilized for the continual care and supervision that Pam’s Necrosis requires.

title: Mac's Battle With Ewing's Sarcoma
text: On Valentine’s Day, our world came to a halt when Mac was diagnosed with a rare childhood cancer called Ewing’s Sarcoma. What had been a nagging pain in his leg turned out to be the last thing any parent wants to hear: that their child has cancer. No one wants to think that this can happen, let alone to a child that we love — our smart, funny, interesting, and creative twelve year-old Mac.        Mac has been under the care of doctors at Doernbecher's Children's Hospital at OHSU in Portland. After the diagnosis, he quickly began chemotherapy and just finished his second round. It is an excruciating schedule: he is inpatient for all his chemo which is every other week, anywhere from 2-5 days.  All totaled, he spends about half the month in the hospital.  Mac has to endure 7 rounds of chemo and then will undergo an extensive surgery in May to remove the tumor and rebuild his leg.   After surgery, Mac will be non weight-bearing for at least three months! He will be in a wheelchair and eventually on crutches if possible. He will require constant care. He only gets  a couple weeks reprieve and then begins several more months of chemotherapy after surgery.      All in all, Mac is facing nearly a year of treatment, hopefully getting his last round of chemo before Christmas. Mac’s prognosis is good, and we are all counting on a clean bill of health and a joyous return to normal life once this process is over.  However, it is a daunting year ahead. It will be filled with much worry, suffering, and demanding care — and also with strength, wisdom, love, and support. Our family has felt the love pour in from so many, and now we are asking for your support.   It is difficult to ask for help, but the year ahead will have many trials, including financial. Mac’s chemo schedule requires Laura and Kelby to join him in the hospital (there is no place they would rather be) and then at least one of them must be home to help when he’s sick. Kelby continues to work when Mac is not in the hospital, and his fire department has been unbelievably supportive with offers to cover his shifts and be flexible with his needs.    As many of you know, Laura has her own private practice and so when she doesn't work she doesn't get paid. Her schedule has already been vastly reduced, seeing clients when she can.  They have insurance, but many things are not fully covered.  Here is an idea of some things they have immediate needs for:   *  Wheelchair ramp for Mac * Bathroom remodel to accommodate wheelchair and non-weight bearing status * Laptop for Mac to video conference with his class to keep up with his schoolwork * Knee scooter, wrist crutches and other devices not covered by insurance * Supplementing Laura's loss of income for a year            This all comes at a great cost, and that is why we are asking for your support. Mac is doing the hardest work of all, and the greatest gift is enabling Laura and Kelby to have the ability to care for him during this unimaginably difficult year. By easing some of the financial stress, you would be directly helping Laura and Kelby devote all their resources to caring for Mac and helping insure that he has the best support possible for the fight ahead.        Here are some words about Mac from a dear family friend:   Mac is an incredible friend to so many. He has grown up as a Candalaria Husky and is now an exemplary student at Howard Street Charter Middle School in Salem. Mac delights in the ordinary, and extraordinary experiences that life has to offer. He is zealous about being a keeper of tradition, finding meaning and belonging in annual trips to the Polar Express with family and friends and annual Easter hunts in the back yard with neighbors. He can transform a trampoline or a dining room table into a fortress of fun and innovation. He is an encyclopedia about all things Lego, Marvel, Magic and Star Wars. He loves to create movies and animations of his own that express his interests, talents and showcase his great sense of humor. Mac has an abiding love for dogs, especially his 3 labs, Brick, Lego and Leia. It is not uncommon to find him piled up in a snuggly blanket with one or more of his canine companions. Mac finds points of connection with anyone who lends him an ear. Whether you are an adult or one of Mac's peers, you can't help but admire the way he creates an environment of inclusion wherever he goes. Mac can move from serious to silly seamlessly and has the ability to ignite contagious laughter. He is kind, brilliant, innovative, all without losing his empathic spirit. Mac knows what it is to truly walk alongside others, and often is a place of refuge for those who feel outcast. Now it is our turn to walk with Mac. For such a rare and unique individual to have such a rare form of cancer, we are afforded a rare and unique opportunity to journey alongside Mac and impart our strength to carry him through the next year of treatment.

title: For the Love of Pete
text: As many of you have heard by now, our friend and band mate, Pete Distefano has been impacted by a disease that hits so close to home for so many of us. Pete and his family have being tasked with a hefty load to take on this battle with cancer.  Hefty volume of treatments, hefty schedule of appointments, and certainly hefty level of financial burden as these treatments and appointments begin.During times like this, people are always looking for ways to help. If we can help to lighten their load by taking away some level of stress around medical bills, that will be a way to help Pete and Michelle focus their energy toward what is most important and needed right now; his health. If you've ever had the privilege of seeing and hearing Pete perform, you have been blessed.   Now it's time to give back for all those wonderful memories he's given us all.  Any little bit can help make a difference to them and can help us all feel like we are doing our part during a time where we can feel so frustrated as cancer takes its toll yet again. We thank you in advance for any donation.  No amount is too small.    Rock On!!!  We plan to!!

title: Support Brian Snyder
text: As Brian is transitioning from residency to his career in Brevard, NC he is unfortunately dealing with unexpected medical issues and unforeseen expenses. Nobody has a more humble or kind demeanor, so please join me in showing your support for him.

title: Peter Wants to Walk Again
text: Help Peter Walk Again!Dear Friends and Family,Some of you may know, on January 13, 2018 our father, Peter Montgomery, suffered a spinal stroke causing a spinal cord injury (SCI) that led him to become a T-6 Paraplegic Incomplete. This means that he is paralyzed from his mid-chest down with partial paralysis in his right leg and complete paralysis in his left leg, leaving him unable to walk. He also has sensory deprivation mid-chest down that makes him unable to distinguish between dull and sharp touch; as well as, temperature variations.Anyone who has met our dad knows what a determined and optimistic person he is. Through all of life’s uncertainty, he has maintained a positive outlook and helped others in any way possible. Although the doctor’s prognosis from his SCI is uncertain and we are still awaiting a diagnosis, he has not accepted this as his personal reality and is exemplifying the strength of his spirit by challenging himself everyday. Through this trial he has been motivated and eager to put in the hard work necessary to regain the ability to walk, something many of us take for granted, so that he too can experience the little joys life has to offer, like back packing with his children, river rafting, and dancing with his daughter at her wedding.The road to walking again will be intense, but our dad is prepared to do everything in his power to get there! Although we are currently looking at a two-year (at best) time frame for his recovery, it is crucial to have continuous physical therapy throughout this journey and to ensure that his medical needs are met.Donations will go towards medical and physical needs, such as: durable medical equipment, wheelchair costs, medications to alleviate his constant pain and muscle spasms, and various physical therapies including PT, acupuncture, swimming, cycling and massage. The most important aspect for his progress will be his acute rehab at SCIFIT, an extremely rigorous, holistic physical therapy regimen specifically customized for each individual SCI patient’s particular needs for the fullest recovery possible.Below are links to some of the organizations that have helped to inform, educate, connect and inspire our father.We would like to share these resources for people in Northern California also affected by a SCI.NOR CAL SCI: https:  https://norcalsci.org/NO LIMITS COLLABORATIVE:  http://www.nolimitscollaborative.org/BORP:  http://www.borp.org/get-involved/SCIFIT:  http://sci-fit.org We appreciate all the love, support and positive vibes we’ve received and are so thankful for your donations.  We would also like thank all the Occupational and Physical Therapists; as well as, the doctors and nurses who have and continue to help our dad.Please share, so our dad’s story can reach as many people as possible and hopefully help a few people on the way! Klaes, Jack, and Gwen   ** Spinal strokes are very rare and account for less than two percent of all stroke. A very special thanks to Teresa Montgomery whose love is like a mighty river. I love you -Peter

title: Raising Money For Our Malia
text: July 26 2018I wanted to THANK YOU for the outpoor of LOVE and SUPPORT!! THIS IS ABSOLUTELY INCREDIBLE and beyond generous! Malia is currently undergoing her treatments. The chemo is hard but we are confident that she will be healthy by the end of the process. Some friends expressed the desire to continue this fundraising campaign. All I can say is that this is already making a difference in her day to day. Sending love and blessings!----------------Je voulais vour REMERCIER TOUTES ET TOUS du fond du coeur pour votre AMOUR, SUPPORT et GENTILLESSE! Malia a commence ses traitements qui suivent leur cours. La chimio est difficile mais nous avons bon espoir qu'elle en sortira en sante. Certains amis ont exprime le desir de vouloir continuer cette campagne. Ce que je peux vous dire c'est que cela fait deja une difference dans son quotidien. Merci encore!--------------------June 2018Let's join together and support Malia in her battle again cancer. Malia got recently diagnosed with an aggressive breast cancer at only 42 y/o. She will be starting her chemotherapy treatments next week and will not be able to work for a while.  This fundraiser was created to financially help support her and her children Axel and Leola through this particularly challenging time. Malia is our light and we want to give her the space and peace to gather her strength and focus on healing and getting better over the next months. I encourage you to please share this fundraiser with Malia's network of friends and family, or others who you think may want to show their support. I know this will mean so much to her and her children. Thank you all so much in advance!-----------------Unissons-nous ensemble pour soutenir Malia dans sa bataille contre le cancer. Malia a appris recemmennt qu'elle avait un cancer du sein aggressif juste quelques jours apres son 42eme annniversaire. Elle va commencer ses traitements de chimiotehrapie la semaine prochaine et ne pourra pas travailler pendant un moment. Cette collecte de fonds a pour but de l'aider financierement elle et ses enfants Axel et Leola durant cette periode particulierement difficile.Malia est notre lumiere et nous voulons lui donner l'espace et la quietude de trouver la force de guerrir et de passer au travers de ses traitememts.Je vous encourage a partager cette collecte de fonds avec ses amis et famille ainsi que toute personne qui aimerait lui montrer son soutient. Cela fera une grande difference pour Malia et les enfants. Merci d'avance!

title: Ryan Hwang's Medical Expenses
text: Our close friend Ryan, during an afternoon on March 14, suffered a unfortunate accident by falling though an open 3rd story window onto a cement walkway. Due to the freak blizzard conditions the Boston area was experiencing, a snow layer prevented the fall from being fatal, but nevertheless Ryan was rushed to the hospital with a substantial list of injuries. Ryan suffered a skull fracture (above the ear) causing his brain to bleed in 3 separate places, 3 broken ribs, a collapsed lung, fractured right hip, and lacerated kidney and liver. A 2nd year Environmental Science major at Boston University, Ryan is a passionate, energetic, and hardworking individual. Described by many as “the life of the party,” Ryan truly embodies the Aloha Spirit. The type of upbeat character most people wish they’d meet earlier. Growing up in Honolulu, he embraced the local culture of community, where surfing, hiking, paddling, and weekends selling pineapples at the KCC Farmers Market kept him busy. There, and everywhere he ventured his infectious laugh, smile and goofy personality charmed everyone he encountered.In order to minimize the stress and anxiety on his family during such turbulent times, we ask for everyone's help to donate any amount to assist Ryan. Donations will go directly towards the extensive medical bills for his current and future procedures/tests, which already include multiple CAT scans, chest x-rays, and ICU costs. The second main hurdle that funds will cover are the rehabilitation costs, which doctors estimated could last up to a few months. While all this happens, Ryan’s single mother plans to remain by his bedside in Boston as long as she can, taking time off from her full-time job.  Ryan is a loved son, brother, cousin, nephew, and friend to to us all. We ask that you PLEASE share this page with anyone and everyone you know on any platform that you see fit. More importantly please send positive energy and prayers for the strength and recovery of Ryan Hwang. - Mahalo!

title: Road to Ben’s Recovery!
text: On June 12, 2018, my son’s best friend, Ben Mitsevich, was struck by a car, as he was crossing the street while the driver was extremely preoccupied texting away. She crushed Ben’s right leg leaving 2 of his 3 main arteries torn and unrepairable. Ben will not be able to drive hence the fact that it’s his right leg.  After multiple surgeries the doctors are not promising if Ben’s leg can be saved.Ben has been through more than one kid in his 15 years should handle, as Ben lost his father 6 years ago on his birthday. His life has changed forever all over again. The medical bills are piling up and we don’t even know how many more surgeries he will need.I ask everyone to come together and please help Ben’s mom, Lana Mitsevich give Ben the medical support that she needs to provide him with the on-going surgeries that are still ahead of Ben’s road to recovery. PLEASE PRAY FOR HIM AND PLEASE HELP!

title: Help Save Mark (Hooves)
text: This fund is set up for my son, Mark. Mark is a son, a brother, an uncle, cousin, nephew and a loyal friend to many. He has always been the one to light up a room with his outgoing personality and sense of humor. But now he is depending on his strong support system of family and friends to help him through his time of need.He is suffering from a liver disease and his condition has left him in need of an immediate liver transplant. Mark has been in the hospital for over a month now and he has been unable to work for the majority of the year. If you could support my GoFundMe by making a donation and then sharing it with your network, I would greatly appreciate it. I know that money can be tight, so please know that even $5 helps me get closer to my goal! Let me know if you have any questions and I’ll be happy to answer them.

title: BreAnn Ahara
text: With a heavy heart, we have decided to reach out to you our friends and family to help this young, struggling family in crisis.  BreAnn Ahara is a woman who, at 33, found her life as she knew it to be over.  The once vibrant, independent, business owner and mother of 3 is now essentially incapacitated with no definitive diagnosis, treatment plan, hope or end in sight.  She's seen dozens of doctors and had numerous hospital stays.  She's been living in chronic, torturous pain and growing weary.  Her husband, Rikio, has taken over caring for their 3 daughters (10, 7, 6), their household, working full time, and caring for her like a rock star.  There is still a huge financial deficit to be covered with her much-needed and life-saving medical treatments that are not covered by insurance.  Her pain is chronic and widespread and she cannot even care for herself with the simplest of tasks.  Pain medication doesn't even begin to alleviate the chronic pain.  Her body is being taken over by new and unknown sickness/disease/ailments that doctors are baffled by and referring her to specialists that her insurance won't cover.   Every time a medical professional seems to have some semblance of an answer, it ends up being a dead-end and she's left discouraged and still in chronic pain.  The life that she knew has been stripped away to where she's almost completely bedridden, relying on caregivers for help constantly.  We are 1. reaching out for emotional support for this family in a heart-breaking crisis  https://www.caringbridge.org/visit/breannahara 2. asking anyone who can, to please consider donating any amount possible to aid with the mounting medical bills and costs of trying to stay afloat as a family of 5 after losing an income and gaining medical debts.A note from Megan:  Many of you have been surprised that she's suffering so much despite "those cute pics of her on facebook".  There have been a couple of days a month - A COUPLE - here and there where she's been able to somewhat get herself out of bed and put on lipstick to feel human again and show up outside of her home and into the world around her.  These moments have been few and far between, and she's often needed to rest in bed for days afterward just to recover from attempting to walk around.  Lately, she hasn't even been able to get out of bed unassisted.  Lately her world has been closing in on her even more and leaving her bedridden and alone.  It's torturous for me (her friend) to have to write that truth down, but I think it's important that we share this harsh truth with all of you so you're aware how desperate the situation truly is.  WE NEED TO GET HER BETTER!With so much love and gratitude,Megan (friend), Coco (mother) & Melissa (sister)

title: A Fresh Start for Bill ... HALT MS
text: A Fresh Start for Bill ... HALT MSIntro:  HSCT Help & Your HelpAfter countless months of pressure, this extremely humble person finally let me put up this GoFundMe site. The reason why I’m reaching out to you is because he needs our help. Currently, there is NO cure for Multiple Sclerosis but there could be a way to HALT the progression and possibly repair the damage with a procedure called HSCT (Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplant). Sharing his MS disease has been a very difficult thing for Bill. He’s NEVER wanted to discuss this debilitating disease to anyone but there’s now … some real HOPE. Diagnosis and What IS MS?Bill was diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis in 1994, his form of MS is called Relapsing-Remitting. MS is a chronic disease of the central nervous system and is an unpredictable condition that can be relatively benign or entirely disabling. There is NO cure for MS, it damages the nerves in the spinal cord and brain, this causes the exacerbations that lead to difficulties in walking, vision, cognitive problems and other physical difficulties.  More about MS: http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/multiple-sclerosis/home/ovc-20131882 Today and Future:For the last 23 years, this disease has worsened for him. He has explained to me the exhaustive treatment options over his lifetime having MS; he’s been on countless FDA approved disease modifying drugs and advised by numerous MS Doctors, all while most of these Specialists and the MS Society have said,  “ There will be a cure SOON… just wait.” He’s been on extensive Paleo diets, physical fitness regimes, alternative vitamins, alternative therapies and alternative procedures … he is NOT getting better. Life is more difficult every year and it’s also more difficult for his family. The 20+ years of cumulative damage are now greatly affecting his ability to walk, balance, run a business, process thoughts, and just live life...let alone enjoy life. MS limits ALL of his life! He finds it difficult to imagine where he’ll be in 5, 10 and 20 years. He doesn’t want to deteriorate more but it WILL happen if the underlying disease is not stopped. MS is a persistent and relentless disease. Finding HSCT/Stem Cell Therapy: After years of researching, Bill found a procedure called HSCT. Finally something concrete…HSCT HALTS the disease for a significant number of people and it has been proven in FDA medical trials and international journals for over 15 years. In Scandinavia where MS is very prolific, as a part of their national medical care, HSCT is their standard protocol. Here are some studies looking at the efficacy of HSCT.  Click here  www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22127896/  and a second study  https://bit.ly/2IV0iTC .Unfortunately, HSCT treatment in the US, Australia and other countries are in medical trials. Unlike standard US medical trials, these trials are almost always paid for by the patient, anywhere from $200-$500K for the treatment, on top of that there is a strict criteria to even get into the study.What is HSCT?HSCT (Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplant) is an established chemotherapy treatment demonstrated to be effective for halting disease progression in autoimmune diseases such as MS. It should not be confused with Regenerative embryonic or Fat derived stem cell therapy, which have yet to prove their long-term effectiveness for MS. HSCT “reboots” the immune system back to a point before the patient ever developed the "markers" for MS. The patient's body can then, over a period of months/years begin to repair/improve itself. Some of the awful symptoms that have the potential to improve are: balance, fatigue, heat sensivity, cognitive function, and the ability to just simply walk. Although HSCT procedure is NOT FDA approved in the US, it has been done for more than 10 years in clinical trials at Northwestern Hospital in Chicago and many other hospitals around the country. These trials have shown a 90% disease stoppage success rate. These ongoing clinical trials in the US are only for qualifying patients. In countries like Canada, Mexico, Russia, Germany and Israel to name a few, the qualification for patients is broader and although the success rates aren't at the 90% level, they do far exceed the rates of current treatments used in the US.Every legitimate medical treatment available today was at one time previously not FDA approved. However, HSCT itself IS an FDA approved medical treatment for cancer and has been performed millions of times since 1967. It simply isn't currently FDA approved for the indication of an autoimmune disease, but it WILL be eventually. It just takes time for the slow-moving wheels of medicine + Government bureaucracy to complete this approval process but make no mistake about it. . . . just because HSCT is not approved on paper for autoimmune diseases does not mean that it doesn't work. The data are crystal clear today; HSCT is the most effective legitimate medical intervention so far discovered to completely and durably HALT autoimmune diseases like MS. It is not necessary for treatment to be "approved" to show this….. www.healthline.com/health-news/ms-patients-who-received-stem-cell-transplants-still-in-remission-010715%2523modal-close or this 60 Minutes newscast ... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_0hekaFdmD0&feature=youtu.be.If you only watch one video/click any hot spot on this site, please go to this site below. This is a newscast from the BBC just published on March 19th, 2018; it IS proof of ALL the studies for over a decade … HSCT does HALT Multiple Sclerosis.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TFyByMiwNNg&feature=youtu.be .Why Treatment at Clínica Ruiz in Mexico:Other countries have clinics currently treating MS with HSCT, since Bill was not accepted at the Northwestern Chicago study (Northwestern has a very narrow acceptance criteria) and because the cost there is approximately $200K, he has applied and was just approved to be treated at Clínica Ruiz in Mexico this summer. Clínica Ruiz is the largest patient volume autoimmune disease HSCT treatment center in the world. Dr. Ruiz Argüelles and Dr. Gómez-Almaguer have performed more than 2500 HSCT procedures during more than 20 years, out of which over 700 have been for MS. Their transplant related mortality is 0.22%, among the safest treatment records in the world. Positive results have been achieved in over 78% of the patients transplanted at Clínica Ruiz.Dr. Guillermo José Ruiz, namesake of this clinic, studied Internal Medicine and Hematology in Mexico and proceeded on to the Mayo Clinic in Rochester MN for his Post-doctoral research and training. As a result of the academic activity stemming from this program, he was elected Mayo Clinic’s distinguished Alumnus and elected Master of the American College of Physicians in 2013. More Information go to Clínica Ruiz’s site:  http://www.hsctmexico.com The Procedure/Recovery & Cost of Treatment :The procedure is intense; 4-6 weeks in the hospital, where T-cells (stem cells) will be harvested from his own bone marrow. He will then undergo a chemotherapy procedure to wipe out the immune system and the memory of MS. After a period of isolation, those T-cells will be reintroduced into the body. The new cells will migrate back to the bone marrow and eventually establish a new immune system that is less likely to attack the central nervous system, therefore HALTING the progression of MS; essentially its like a “FRESH START!”Here is where Bill NEEDS OUR HELP.  Unfortunately, nothing is covered by insurance. The procedure will cost $60,000, these funds would cover the cost of the treatment, travel to Mexico and a 24/7 trained out-patient staff during his time in Mexico. Bill will be there for approximately 4-6 weeks depending on various stages of the protocol and on his immune systems recovery. He will update the GoFundMe site regularly  with his progress. Appreciation:That big hearted person is still there but this disease has taken away:   The Rock Climber,  The Kayaker, The Explorer and most importantly … A Part of that Person whose Treasured things in LIFE are his FAMILY and FRIENDS.With HSCT there is finally some HOPE. The sooner HSCT is performed, the sooner this progression STOPS!~ Walking is man’s best medicine. HippocratesYOU CAN HELP BILL …1.  GIVE whatever you can. No donation is too small.2.  SHARE on Social Media3.  EMAIL this page  http://www.gofundme.com/BillSparrow to your family + friends + co-workers.Thank you for taking the time to read this and again, please SHARE.   #AFreshStart4BillSparrow

title: Shani Tsfoni's Recovery
text: Friends, family, and wider community, we reach out today with an urgent call for help. On May 31st our sister, Shani Tsfoni, was struck by a car while jogging in New York. She was taken to Jamaica Hospital where she was found to have fractures in her arm and leg as well as a head injury. In addition to emergency surgery to correct the fractures, Shani has undergone an emergency craniotomy/craniectomy in order to relieve the swelling in her brain. Currently, she is in critical but stable condition. Her treatment team has kept her intubated and sedated to minimize the stress on her body. As with most brain injuries, her prognosis is uncertain. We expect her to stay in the ICU in New York for at least two weeks. Our mother has not left her side and our father is flying from Israel to be with her in a couple of days. Our family hopes to eventually have Shani transferred to a hospital in Atlanta so as to be closer to us. She has a long road to recovery, but Shani is resilient and strong and we know she can overcome this. We are asking today for help in supporting Shani and our family through this difficult time. As anyone can imagine, the medical expenses are more than our family can manage. We need help paying for Shani’s medical treatment. Any donation can make a difference in alleviating the financial burden on our family, and allow us to focus on getting Shani back to her smiling self.Finally, in whatever version of prayer you practice, please hold Shani and our family in your hearts. With love and gratitude, Ariella & Yarden Tsfoni (All donations will be sent to our mother, Laura Wiener)

title: Team Skip
text: Skip DiStefano, at age 42 was diagnosed with stage 4 Glioblastoma (brain cancer). Skip was raised in Dedham, and graduated from the Dedham High Class of 1993.  Skip moved to Quincy in 2008 to be closer to the ocean where he worked for many years as a lobsterman and a charter boat captain. Skip and his wife Stacey have 4 beautiful children, Dylan age 8, Lyla age 6, Dominic age 4, and Julia age 2. In January Skip was hospitalized after he suffered a grand mal seizure. It was then that the doctors discovered a tumor, that began at the thalamus and radiated out to the right parietal lobe. Later that week, Skip underwent brain surgery. The doctors removed as much of the tumor as they could without causing further damage. The largest part of the remaining tumor lies deep in his brain near his thalamus and is inoperable. With Skip no longer able to work, no longer able to drive, and visually impaired, you can imagine the financial burden his family now bears. With your support, our goal is to raise over $100,000 to help cover increasing medical costs and family expenses. Thank you in advance for your support. Your donation is greatly appreciated to help ease the burden on this young family.

title: Maike's Breast Cancer Fund
text: Aloha!  My name is Maike, I am 32 years old and I was born in Hong Kong, raised in Germany and currently living in Hawaii working as a Photographer.I recently got diagnosed with breast cancer (invasive ductal carcinoma). The tumor is quite aggressive and very large in my right breast (measuring 11cm x 9cm) and has spread to several lymph nodes under my right armpit. The doctors have urged me to immediately start with chemo therapy in order to shrink the tumor enough, so they are able to perform a full mastectomy, after which we would continue with chemo therapy paired with radiation. Since my diagnosis two weeks ago, my husband and I have been driving to hospitals on a regular basis spending many hours each day with doctors and surgeons for consultations and various tests.This has immediately become a full-time job for both of us. It is a very emotional and overwhelming time but we are both staying very optimistic and motivated to win this battle! =)After hours of research and connecting with family and friends who went through similar situations, we have decided on procedures and treatments in Germany, most of which will not be covered by our insurance.My husband and I rely on both of our incomes to be able to pay for the roof over our heads, monthly bills and food. On top of all this, we will have to face the expensive bills for the treatments for my recovery, which makes it all very overwhelming.I am trying to work as much as I can during this time, but for obvious reasons I won't be able to work as much as I would like.It breaks our hearts that we need to ask for financial help since we are two very independent people, but we humbly ask for your support in helping us with the financial funds to help pay for the treatment and unexpected bills over the next several months so that we will be able to focus on becoming cancer free again!We appreciate all the help, support and love coming our way and no matter how small of a donation will be greatly appreciated!Mahalo from the bottom of our hearts!Maike & Eric

title: Help Beth Beat ALS!
text: Just months before Beth’s 57th birthday, she received a heart wrenching diagnosis. After months of countless doctor appointments, frustration and confusion about why her leg wasn’t working properly, she was diagnosed with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, well known for as ALS or Lou Gehrig’s Disease.  In a very short 6-month period, Beth went from a healthy hard working math teacher, to a strong and hopeful woman fighting a serious disease. ALS is a disease of the parts of the nervous system that control voluntary muscle movement. In ALS, motor neurons (nerve cells that control muscle cells) are gradually lost. As these motor neurons are lost, the muscles they control become weak and then nonfunctional. A number of strategies and approaches are being tested around the world, both in the laboratory and in human clinical trials. One of the most significant breakthroughs in the last decade has been the discovery of a number of genes that, when flawed, cause ALS.  In late 2017, Beth took an awful fall while playing her beloved sport of tennis (yes this super woman managed to play tennis every Wednesday with her girlfriends). She was badly bruised and decided to take a little break from the sport as she healed. Not too much later she started experiencing fatigue, lack of mobility and twinges in her feet. Walking short distances had become slightly difficult for her and Beth was starting to get concerned.  After going to the orthopedist and having numerous x-rays taken, she was diagnosed with Spinal Stenosis.  Beth began physical therapy but there was no improvement and was getting worse. She continued with this diagnosis and saw a specialist in Manhattan who had much acclaim with treating patients who had spinal stenosis.  She received a cortisone injection, however, again, there were no improvements. Beth's fears heightened, but being such a strong, prideful woman she hardly complained.  She expressed that she had an awful feeling that she may have MS but tried not to think along those lines.Winter recess was now around the corner and her walking difficulties became more pronounced.  Less than a half a block walk was extremely hard for her and this vivacious woman was having a tough time. It seemed to all be happening so fast.Fast forwarding slightly, Beth was now seeing neurologists and other doctors to see if an alternate diagnosis could be found.  Beth was then diagnosed with ALS.  This disease has moved quickly and she is now in rehab.  Her beautiful and strong family have one goal in mind and that is to get her overseas for a special treatment that has been showing hope for this dreadful disease. Beth is the sweetest, kind-hearted and most hard working mother, friend and women anyone could ask for. She has dedicated her early years to the garment industry and 20+ years to devoting her days to teaching hundreds of kids in Brooklyn, the complicated world of mathematics. Her students, parents and colleagues adore her and has always brought nothing short of smiles, positivity and friendship to her work environment. Beyond her work life, she is a magnificent wife, mother and friend. She has three beautiful children and a loving husband, Ron fighting through each day with her. Her caring, nurturing and loving personality has created a strong foundation for her family and a warm environment for success. But now, Beth needs our help. In addition to the prayers and well wishes, Beth needs financial support to assistant with significant medical expenses, including adaptive living devices, rehab, home care and medical treatments. As you can see, this is a tragic situation. Your funds will directly support Beth’s treatment, alleviate the financial burden of Beth being unable to work, and to assist with the ongoing medical costs that are yet to come. Please share this page to everyone – all the support helps! Thank you so much for your support!

title: Help Support John Bombace & Family
text: As some of you may already know,  John was recently diagnosed with cancer and will be requiring surgery and treatment.  Anyone who knows John knows he has a huge heart and would do anything for his friends.  Please show your support for John and Xakira and their children Christopher, Annalise and Madison by keeping them in your prayers and by making a donation to help them with their medical expenses.

title: Medical Expenses
text: Maureen Bole Gibbons was diagnosed with stage 4 lung cancer in May, 2018.  She and her husband Ryan were married just a few short weeks prior to her diagnosis and learned of the unfortunate news two days after returning from their honeymoon.   Both Maureen and Ryan have taken time off from their jobs for the immediate future as Maureen undergoes additional testing and treatment.The money raised here will be used for insurance premiums, deductibles, co-pays and medical expenses that insurance will not cover.  To the extent any of the funds collected are not needed by Maureen and Ryan they intend to donate the balance to a charity that supports cancer research and outreach. It’s not always easy to reach out for financial help, but this is a great and easy way for us to show our support for Maureen and Ryan as they navigate this difficult time in their life and new marriage.  All donations are very welcome through the Go Fund me site. If you are more comfortable writing a check, it can be made out to Ryan Gibbons and mailed to 916 Ormond Avenue Drexel Hill, PA 19026.Please keep Maureen, Ryan, and their families in your thoughts and prayers during this difficult time.   Send them your positive energy, love, and courage as they move mountains and make their way past this point on their life’s journey together.- Friends and Family of Ryan

title: Support For Williamson's Expenses
text: On June 5th, the Williamson's were involved in a car accident that left  Tess, Lindi and J with serious injuries that will require surgeries and rehabilitation.  Tess will need surgery to repair her leg, hip and jaw.  J, at this time, is in a coma due to head trauma from the accident.  We know that the family will need a lot of support from us, not only emotionally, but financially.  They are a wonderful family that we have been lucky to have in our lives due to Tess' love of softball.  Anything you can do to help us in raising some funds to support them is greatly appreciated.

title: Team Frankie
text: Frankie Knowles is a sweet, loving 6 year old who was recently diagnosed with a brain tumor.  He was brought to the local emergency room with a bad headache, vomiting and extreme lethargy.  They did a CT scan and determined he had a brain bleed.  He was flown to A.I. DuPont where his endocrinology and neurosurgeon team are based.  There, they did an MRI and found the brain tumor.  He had a procedure to relieve the pressure the blood was putting on his brain.  After the first test for one type of tumor was negative (yay!), a biopsy is now necessary to identify the type and also relieve continued pressure from fluid buildup.  The tumor location is compressing the connection to the pituitary gland.While he was extubated, is breathing on his own, and is starting to converse when not asleep, there are still further tests and procedures to be performed to determine the path forward.  This unfathomable situation for this sweet child bears unfortunate costs.  The funds raised here can be put toward the undesired, impending bills.  While one could only hope that the cost of this type of care would be reasonable, the reality is that unexpected healthcare bills are never reasonable.  Please join the efforts to raise funds to support Rick and Erica in this time of need.  As their focus will be on strength, love, and support to Frankie, and, their daughter Brooklyn, let's help relieve this burden from their minds.#TeamFrankie

title: John and Jen ~ Light Warriors
text: Hi, my name is Earl Teopaco. I’m the oldest child(21) of John and Jennifer Dedmon. I started this GoFundMe with a heavy heart because my mother and father were sadly involved in an ATV accident over the Father’s Day Weekend and were admitted to the ICU in Utah Valley Hospital.John and Jen and the entire family from Las Vegas were celebrating this Father’s Day Weekend at Yuba Lake State Park. On Saturday, June 16, John and Jen went out on an ATV ride. While out on the ATV there was an accident and they were thrown from the ATV and sustained serious injuries. Shortly after they were rushed to the closest hospital via helicopter.My Mother, Jen, was admitted into the hospital with a broken ulna and radius in her left forearm, a fractured rib, a fractured pelvis, a few fractured vertebrae’s of the lower spine, and lacerations/road rash all over her body.My father, John, was admitted into the hospital with a severe head injury. He has multiple facial fractures around his left orbital and is currently in a coma. The doctors are not sure when he will wake up. Doctors ran tests and have found his brain activity is almost completely normal with the acception that they have identified the bleeding in his brain to be a very minor Subarachnoid Hemorrage(SAH), so they are sort of perplexed to why he hasn’t woken up yet... The road to recovery for this type of injury is a long and winding road, so John will need all the loving support of his friends and family to help him through this tough time.John and Jennifer are two loving souls, two warriors of light, who always do their best to create a better world, a better environment for themselves and everyone around them. They find their happiness in helping those around them find their happiness. Besides me, John and Jen also have an 18yr old son, 12yr old son, and 10yr old daughter whom they love unconditionally and support financially, emotionally, mentally, and spiritually. Unfortunately, my father is the family’s main source of income while my mother is a stay at home mom which causes a little hiccup in handling the finances due to the intensive care that both my mom and dad need, the surgeries, cat scans and MRI’s, air transportation to the hospital, and regrettably not having any health insurance. Any and all donations will be going towards our family to help with medical bills and any financial hardships due to my father not being able to work. Any amount helps. If you cannot donate, we still love you. My family and I just ask you pray for John and Jen and send them as much positive, healing energy as you can.Thank you and Namaste <3￼￼

title: Help 13 year old Jack Fight Cancer
text: Hello everyone, we have decided to help raise money for a friend of ours Jack Hytner. At age 13 he has been diagnosed with stage 4 Osteosarcoma. He is an adorable, sweet kid and we are trying to help with their medical bills and expenses. With your kind donations, you can help Jack fight his battle with cancer. Any amount will help. Thank you from the bottom of our hearts and we thank you for your prayers and support.  For supporters who wish to donate over $250, please see the link below.   http://jackscavalry.com/

title: Please help Bekah and her Family!!
text: My almost 22 year old niece Bekah (Dan’s sister’s daughter who I’ve know since she was 6) was in a near fatal car accident at 1:55am early Saturday.  She is still (as of this writing on 8/27) in the ICU after an 8 hour surgery yesterday and she's in surgery again right now as I write this.  After her surgeris, and skin grafts, she still has a looooong way to recovery, as you'll read below, including at least a week in the hospital, adapting to a wheelchair for the foreseeable future, finding furniture to support her living downstairs, and dental work that will come later.She is the 2nd oldest of 7 AMAZING, humble, genuine, loving and kind children. The best family on earth I am sure of it - seriously they are amazing and I am SO LUCKY to call them MY family through marrying Bekah's mom's (Lisa) brother Dan. Bekah was not found until 5:30am, approximately 3 hours after hitting the power line and rolling around, managing to get herself off the hood of the car and out of the glass, where she then rolled around screaming in the grass and mud until someone found her on their morning run at 5am.  She quickly spun off the road and hit a power line pole head on.  She was ejected from the car (thank goodness because I don't think she'd be with us had she remained in the car because it is absolutely crushed).  God was with her for sure and she fought through because of her love for her family.  Some of the siblings went to the site of the accident and there was no blood.  Her lacertations were down to the bone and through muscle, but no blood at the scene, even though she was covered when she arrived at the hospital.  I told Lisa yesterday, if anyone doesn't believe in God, just tell them this story.Her hair was found on the pole. Her injuries are agonizingly tragic and include a fracture neck vertebrae, lacerations on her liver, lacerations on her leg in two places (almost to the bone) - all the way around her knee and a huge gash they couldn't even close during surgery yesterday right near that main artery in your leg, 5 broken ribs, a broken scapula, two strokes!!! (omgosh), and torn nerves and ligaments in her hand affecting the mobility of her two middle fingers at this point. Her arm was also completely severed and will need skin grafts and more surgeries.  All of her teeth were chipped and dental work will be expensive in the coming months once she's through the more life threatening tragedy.I know I am writing very candidly, and I don't mean to upset her friends, family, relatives or community.  But for everyone who shares this, it reaches many more people and I want them to understand the gravity of the accident.I am setting up this GoFundMe account because the family really really needs all the financial support they can get.  Bekah's dad just finished paying off the bills from his heart surgery two years ago and they support 7 children!!!, including a 2 year old who they fostered and then adopted.  Adoption runs through our family.  My goal is to raise $40,000 to cover her approximate medical costs (they have a very high out of pocket maximum because they have so many kids and do not work for large corporations).  We also need to raise money to pay for her rent while she moves back in with her parents for a while, the dental work which won't be covered and the list goes on, including her parents being out of work to take care of her, her car, etc.).The whole family really needs all the prayers and support they can get as they adjust their lives for a few months.  Bekah doesn't even realize at this point what all has happened  They are the most lovely family and I cherish them. PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE find it in your HEARTS to help them financially and through prayer.  Remember, we are a VILLAGE and it sometimes takes a village to get through something as tragic as this.  Hug your loved ones and PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE help us raise this money so they don’t have to worry about how to manage and stress over all that and can focus on getting Bekah well and back to a new normal!!  If you aren't able to donate, please PRAY and SHARE this with your network!!!!  And tag anybody and everybody who knows Bekah and her family!I promise you, this money will go toward a wonderful family, who is near and dear to me, and many others who will share this on their facebook walls.  And TRUST me, the money is truly going to what they need.  They have tons of family and community support but we can't do this without raising money.  Karma and God will pay you back, ten fold.

title: Help needed for Katia's treatment
text: "I know it's stage 4...there is always hope, and no matter my acceptance of the circumstances - my choice will always go in the direction of more life" ( Katia Bozhikova)Dear friends and strangers,For those that don't know Katia, here is a little bit of a background.Katia is my friend, a beautiful soul, the definition of kindness.  She turned 35 in May and she's been dancing with cancer for the past 8 years. In the past 6 months, the journey has not been easy. Now, the journey it's even tougher. Health Insurance slammed her with an outrageous bill and the treatment that gives HOPE is extremely expensive...On medical front - she's been having intense weeks. Spending 4-6 hours in the doctor's office, draining the energy out of her body.  HERE  you can listen to her view about cancer, death, and life.Friends, colleagues, strangers - I am asking again to step in.Please DONATE whatever you can. Remember, no amount is too large or too small.Thank you,Simona

title: Help Dan beat Cancer
text: Imagine, you're 30 years old, with a dream to be a lawyer, you have put yourself through Law School. You have so many hard earned letters after your name it's crazy. You move to LA to pursue your dream and hunt down a job.You have a neck pain, go see a Doctor and they tell you that you have Non-Hodgkin Lmmphoma, and that this cancer is such an aggressive strain, they don't think you had it three weeks ago...   You have tumors in your heart and lungs and up you neck.How would you feel...?Hey all, many of you know my friend  Dan Goldberg as the eager, helpful young chap around the Castle, an amateur magician working hard to make a new life for himself here in the US.  He's just 30 years old and a month ago was diagnosed with Non-Hodgkin lymphoma.  At 30 years old.  To say the treatment is taking a toll on him and his career dreams is an understatement.  The cancer is a aggressive and moving fast. Even with insurance he is still incurring costs that are causing great stress, and as you know that just feeds the sickness.Treatment starts with six rounds of intensive chemotherapy,  each of which requires him to be an inpatient at a hospital for 5 days. He has been fighting with his insurance company to have them cover the treatment, literally since his  diagnosis and often in the middle of treatment.It's next to impossible for him to make any kind of a living.  As his friend I can't sit here and watch the man suffer, so I've put together this little go fund me to ask for help for Dan.  Anything would be of help, as little as $5 and much as... well you know cancer treatment charges, they're astronomical.  Then there's rent (he could be evicted soon)  food, transport, medical, it all adds up.  And it's all needed as soon as ossible.  .  I have set a goal of $30,000, although I'm sure the bills will far exceed that.The type of cancer Dan has is called “Double Hit” Lymphoma, which is a very rare subtype of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma – which is already super aggressive. He is at Cedars Sinai because that is one of the few places in the world that has the required expertise on the double hit lymphoma . So if you could all do me a huge favor and help my friend Dan, I would be most grateful, and I know he would be too.Cancer can strike at any time and at any age, having friends who can help in an emergency is a wonderful thing. We can do this xxxThank you in advance.Steve

title: Bridgette Pumphrey Turner HHS1992
text: Our friend and classmate, Bridgette Pumphrey Turner, has been in the hospital since June 17. Her symptoms began with hives and a fever. She was treated for an allergic reaction in Oxford and sent home. Within 24 hours, she was not improving, so her husband, Preston, got her to Memphis. Within 72 hours of her first symptoms, her legs and arms began to show signs of discoloration  and she was in severe pain. She has been in ICU/step down units since.   The physicians are still working on an exact diagnosis.  On July 5, she was air-lifted to Vanderbilt. Her wounds are being treated similar to wounds from a severe burn.   She had surgery on July 12 to remove unhealthy tissue from her lower extremities and apply skin grafts. She will have several more surgeries as she continues to recover. Bridgette has a fourteen-year-old son, John Preston. This fund will allow her friends to get funds directly to Bridgette and her family  so that we can help cover immediate expenses that comes with extended hospital stays away from home. She is being so brave, and in true Bridgette manner is meeting this with a smile and positive outlook.  There will be a long recovery ahead but we believe she is receiving the very best care possible . One way we can help ease this transitional time is by blessing this fund with whatever you feel led to give. Let’s do as we were taught at Hernando High School and follow the golden rule. “Do unto others as you would have them do unto you” #bbstrongUpdate 7/25/18. Since the creation of this fund Bridgette has undergone several skin graft surgeries and ultimately has experienced amputation of both feet, her left hand at the wrist and a portion of her right hand. She will undergo several more surgeries throughout this journey. Prosthetics will be utilized ASAP when appropriate healing has occurred. The focus now is to keep infection at bay and for Bridgette to work with her therapists to gain skills to navigate her new normal.  This will be a long road...a costly road...  Friends, family and strangers have been so generous in blessing this fund. Please continue to share her story. Please continue to bless this fund as you feel led and most of all please continue to pray for Bridgette and her family.  Thank you for all you have done! ❤️

title: Father And Son Burn Victims
text: This father and son were in a horrible fire caused by a car explosion and are both currently suffering from 2nd and 3rd degree burns in over 70% of their bodies. They are currently fighting for their lives. They will have to be in the hospital for over two months receiving multiple surgeries. Any donation is greatly appreciated and it will help us immensely.

title: Dana's Cancer Fund
text: On April 14th, Dana was diagnosed with a very rare and aggressive form of ovarian cancer called Carcinosarcoma. Within one week it had aggressively grown which blocked her bowels. She had emergency surgery on April 22nd to remove the tumors only to find that the cancer had spread throughout her abdomen and bowels. Doctors did not remove all of the tumors during the first surgery because that would have required the complete removal of her bowel system and delayed the option of chemo.After a week of recuperating at Kaiser, she was sent home, but is unfortunately unable to eat any solid food. For the next 6 weeks she will receive her nutrition via an I.V. line called a T.P.N. In addition, Dana is also undergoing chemotherapy and will require another surgery in the near future. Dana has a great support system of family and friends to help her, but she does required around the clock in-home care. Dana is self-employed and recently took over her Father's business after he retired. She was just getting started on building her business when we were all shocked by this awful news. Unfortunately, Dana's cancer is what doctors refer to as "chronic" which means it will continue to be recurring even if she if she is able to get this into remission. Due to her major emergency surgery and chemo, Dana is currently unable to work for the foreseeable future. During this time of no income and the increasing medical expenses, we are asking her family, friends and network to donate what they can to help Dana cover ongoing medical costs and her loss of income.
