She had surgery on March 15th to remove part of her pancreas. At that point, the cancer had not metastasized and we were believing for a surgical cure. After Mrs. Tammy recovered from surgery, she began chemotherapy.  On August 8th, she had a CT scan done to see if the chemo was working. Unfortunately, the chemo is not working and there are now multiple tumors in her abdomen.Through much research and many phone calls to oncologists, medical centers and the top hospitals all over the country, Mrs. Tammy has found New Hope Medical Center. Their central office is in Arizona, and their treatment hospital is in Mexico. They offer a 12 day cancer treatment. This treatment is her next best option for a cure. Through much prayer and faith, Mr. Tim and Mrs. Tammy have concluded that this is her best option and the door that God is opening. Fortunately, they allow one person to go with her and stay with her for the duration of the treatment. Because of the aggression of the cancer, we are hopeful Mrs. Tammy gets approved to go next week (August 20th).  Our goal is to raise $35,000  to completely cover the cost of the 12 day treatment and travel to get there.  If you feel so led to give, we thank you so much! Please also join us in prayer for healing, peace, wisdom and for God's will to be done. Join us in the fight on the journey to Mrs. Tammy's recovery!A note from Tim and Tammy: "Thank you for joining us in this fight. We are so humbled by all of your love, prayers and any financial support you can offer. God bless you!"The Lord will fight for you; you need only to be still. Exodus 14:14"For I know the plans I have for you," declares the Lord, "plans to prosper you and not to harm you, plans to give you a hope and a future." Jeremiah 29:11

title: Kare for Kimball
text: KIMBALL NEEDS OUR HELP NOW!  She has just gotten results back from her MRI and not only has tumors in her brain, they are on her spinal cord and her lungs are failing as well.  We need to give as much as we are able to help her pay her monthly bills ($1100/mos) as she she explores treatment options.  It is unsure what Obamacare will cover, but it will not be cheap and not being able to work means WE NEED TO GIVE BACK TO SOMEONE WHO HAS GIVEN SO MUCH TO US.It's not all about positive thoughts and sending her healing, it is about practical help so she can focus on getting well.  You would want to have your friends come to your aid if you were in the same situation, so please GIVE NOW AS MUCH AS YOU ARE ABLE...

title: Peka Strong
text: Elikapeka Garcia is a vibrant, loving and carefree 17 year old young lady who has been dealing with stomach pain for a little over a year now.  With multiple tests, ultrasounds and blood tests all returning normal it was determined to be constipation and intense menstrual cramps.   This past February when blood started to be present in her stool we scheduled a colonoscopy.  But due to there only being one specialist on island, it could not be scheduled until April 19, 2018.The Doctor could not perform the colonoscopy because her intestines were inflamed so she recommended that we go to Kapi'olani Hospital for Women and Children on O'ahu for further tests.  We flew out that afternoon and she was admitted.  Her CT scan the next day revealed a softball size tumor in her abdomen which is applying immense pressure on her intestines.  They needed to run more tests to determine what kind of tumor it was.  On April 26, 2018 they conducted another biopsy and on May 2nd she was diagnosed with Stage 3 Ovarian Cancer.  Chemotherapy and surgery was determined to be the plan to battle this.  She was about to graduate High School from Lahainaluna and was determined to walk the line with her classmates.  Her Doctor advised since it was low grade they would wait on treatment and allowed her to finish school.  She graduated on May 27, 2018 and we celebrated this amazing achievement with her party on May 28. Her first chemotherapy treatment was on June 6, 2018 at Kapiolani Hospital.  It went well with little side affects.  She went back to Maui that same day and went about her daily happy go lucky life by going to the beach or hanging out with friends and family.  Her next scheduled treatment was on June 27.  On June 19, 2018 while at work her Mom Darice received a call that afternoon that Peka was in extreme pain from her stomach.  She called 911 and they were able to administer pain medicine immediately to give her some relief.  Maui Memorial Medical center did a CT scan and it revealed that her intestines were heavily backed up and she could not move her bowels due to the tumor blockage.  They tried a regimen of Miralax to get things moving but it just made her pain worse.  During this whole process she was undergoing fertility treatments so her eggs could be harvested and saved for her future, but that proved unsuccessful.  The plan was to try fertility again after the second or third round of chemotherapy.  But while she was in so much pain she made the heart breaking decision to not save her eggs and to perform the needed surgery and remove her ovaries now.  Her Doctor agreed and she was medevaced to Kapiolani Hospital on June 20.  Her Surgery was conducted on June 21, 2018 as she was surrounded by family and friends.  After a few hours her Doctor advised us that her cancer had spread and he was no longer able to remove the tumor and cancer from her abdomen without putting her life in danger, so he stopped.  She is at Kapiolani Hospital now recovering from surgery and has had some challenges, so recovery is longer than expected.  Plan B is to now give her a series of shots and pills to stop the estrogen production in her body which is feeding the cancer.  This will stop it from spreading while also shrinking it.  Once that is accomplished, she will go into surgery again to remove everything. At this point, insurance has not approved to cover the required shots for her treatment.  Her family plans to proceed with or without their approval to ensure she receives the needed treatment to get her back to normal.Darice has been by her side while Daddy Louis has been home taking care of her two sisters, 'Ihilani and Kolokea.  Peka has a huge support base from her family, friends and church family.  Her faith in God is strong and we believe that God has his hands on her and she will be his walking testimony to share his miracle healing upon her.  While prayers are what she needs the most, medical bills are starting to come in and as much as her family hates asking for help, there have been so many people reaching out wanting to help financially so they have decided to start this page to aslo keep everyone updated on her progress.  We Love you all and thank every one of you for your love and prayers.Peka and the Garcia OhanaPeka can do all things thru Christ who strenghthens her.  Phillipians 4:13

title: Shower Shaedyn with Love
text: Shaedyn is just 23 months old, but in her short life she has brought so much joy, love and laughter to everyone that knows her.  She has always been very active, loves to dance and even as a newborn she always wanted to be around people.  She has even enjoyed learning how to hop and how to tumble.    She began having a series of ailments in March and doctor visits without any resolution to the symptoms she was experiencing.  During this time the energetic little girl we all know and love became very lethargic.  She was having difficulty sleeping and was increasingly irritable,  began wanting to sleep most of the day away and only wanted her mom, Elizabeth, to hold her.It became so concerning that, on Sunday, March 18th her father Chris and Elizabeth decided to bring her in to be seen by a doctor yet again.  This Austin Regional Clinic doctor recommended that some blood tests be done.  The results of those tests showed that she had profound anemia.  The hematologist said that she had Pancytopenia and recommended admitting her to Dell Children's Medical Center of Central Texas.More blood tests were run that Monday, a spinal tap was done and her bone marrow was tested.  The results came back and Monday evening Shaedyn was diagnosed with B-Cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL).After receiving enough transfusions to get her blood counts to an acceptable level a procedure was performed to install a portacath  and Shaedyn received her first of a 2.5+ years long regimen of chemotherapy. The Warzecha family are some of the most warm, welcoming people you'll ever meet.  Right now they "are hard pressed on every side, but not crushed; perplexed, but not in despair."  All of us that love them and are within physical reach of them are doing all we can to try and meet whatever needs we can with our own individual, limited time and resources.  The reality is that not any one of us can do it alone and we want the Warzechas, we want Shaedyn to know that she is not in this fight for her life alone. If you are reading this story we believe you found your way to this fundraiser for a reason.  We are asking anyone who sees this to thoughtfully, prayerfully, consider donating to the cause of helping this little girl and her family pay for the long road ahead; the medical procedures and the bills that will result from them. Thank you for all of your support. Please continue to pray for our girl!

title: Bring Mav Home - MAVRIK LAXTON
text: Mavrik will be 13 years old on April 25th, 2018 and he has been fighting a heart condition since the day he was born, HLHS. Hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) is a birth defect that affects normal blood flow through the heart. As the baby develops during pregnancy, the left side of the heart does not form correctly.Throughout his life, Mavrik has had 9 open heart surgeries, 2 stokes, has survived with only 1 lung and still continues to fight but over these past few weeks his health has seriously deteriorated. He has been bed ridden and stuck in the hostpital to ride out his last few days or weeks on this earth. We are pleading for your help to raise money so we can get Mav back home to live out his last few weeks in the place he loves most and with his family around him. The insurance company will only provide coverage for 16 hours of around the clock care but Mavrik NEEDS 24 hour care. The insurance company would rather spend millions of dollars to keep him in the hospital rather than provide him with the care necessary for him to be able to come home and live comfortably surrounded by his family and enjoy his last few weeks, which would cost considerably less. Please find it in your heart to donate anything you can to grant him his last wish. Thanks so much for all the support and love you all have given thus far. #themavmovement

title: Advanced Cancer Therapy Treatment
text: A final chance to liveHello there. My name is John Bacile and I’m a Christian father of 4, and a stage 4 cancer patient with only a few months left to live (Again.)I know that some of you reading this may have also heard these words from your doctor, and if you haven’t, I can tell you, it is sobering. Your entire world comes to a stop. By the time I discovered I had bladder cancer 2 and a half years ago, it wasalmost too late. I had a very aggressive, invasive cancer that had already eaten into the muscle wall of my bladder.My options were so stark, so quickly, that I could barely breathe. I was told that unless I had a Cystectomy (surgery to remove the bladder and other nearby organs that are affected) and take Chemotherapy and Radiation for 3-6 months, I would probably only live 12 months and suffer a painful death as the cancer was obviously progressing in an unfavorable area. Even if I elected to allow the surgery, the cancer may have already grown past the point of being eradicated.I really wasn't given other choices and the Oncologists wanted to begin their operations, chemo and radiation within 2 weeks. But I consider myself fortunate that my first instinct was to pray. Seemingly out of nowhere, I remembered a book I had read the year before that discussed holistic therapies for cancer patients and it recommended ingesting overwhelming clean and raw nutrition in large doses in order to rebuild your immune system's natural weapons against disease.So I politely refused the doctor’s advice since having come to believe that destroying my immune system with chemicals and poison would greatly affect my odds of living a quality life in the few months I had left with my family. Instead, I decided to go on an all-natural, holistic, organic diet - juicing, raw organic foods, steamed vegetables, lean meats and various supplements, vitamins and enzymes, etc.That was February 2016 and we acted immediately with no hesitation. However, because the cancer was so aggresive by June it had begun to cut off urination and so I elected to have a secondary surgery called a TURP where they go in and cut out as much of the tumor as possible. The pain and the constriction were immediately relieved, but not for long. By August, I needed another operation, and by December, a third.By the time of that operation 11 months had passed and the tumor had now merged so much with my bladder that it was increasingly difficult to tell them apart in key areas like the ureters where urine drains from the kidneys to the bladder. I remember that disappointing day when I was informed that the doctors could perform no more operations; the cancer would only grow from here.The day after the December 2016 operation, my kidneys began to fail. The next morning, I needed an emergency Nephrostomy (where tubes are inserted into your kidneys through your back to drain them.)I remember being very discouraged that day as I lay in my hospital bed. Tubes in the front of me, and bags and tubes on my sides and back; the pain of back to back operations and the dreadful thoughts in my head of how quickly I was deteriorating were overwhelming. One day in the beginning when I had initially prayed to the Lord, I heard His voice tell me, “This disease is not unto death.” It was quiet; it was deep, and I daily held on to it as I fought to beat back the cancer. “But what now?” I thought. “After all this how could I possibly be saved?” Because also in June of that year, a new breakthrough in Immunotherapy for bladder cancer had been rushed to the market by the FDA, the first such advance in over 30 years. I remember thinking about how fortunate I would be if only I could take the IV therapy. However, the FDA had approved the wonder drug only for dying patients who had exhausted all other standard options - surgery, chemo, and radiation.But remember I had turned all that down.How unfortunate, I thought, that something that could possibly save me was so close and yet so far. While I was pondering our limited options, the Oncologist informed us that because I was given the emergency Nephrostomy, I was no longer a potential Chemo patient. And as of that day, I had technically exhausted all possible cures. I was now terminal, and eligible for the immunotherapy.And just like that, I was the second person in Dallas Texas to begin taking the advanced bladder cancer drug, “TECENTRIQ.” And then like magic after only 3 months, the scans showed that I had responded wonderfully to it. All the cancer outside of my bladder had disappeared and the main tumor had shrunk over 25%. What great excitement and hope we had. It happened so quickly and was such a miracle at the very last minute. But cancer is very clever and unfortunately, after only 8 months, the drug stopped working and the next scans showed that the cancer was back and worse it was growing in many other places as well. Month after month we continued with a similar bladder Immunotherapy and always taking the nutrition program as there was nothing else to do. As the months have passed, the cancer had continued to spread to my kidney and my lymph system in my throat and groin, and the main tumor has become very large. 2 weeks ago we took new scans since an additional 8 months have passed since the last, and based on them, the oncologists have again given me only months to live. Thank you for reading this far because you won't believe what happened next. Naturally our hopes and hearts were shattered and our finances had become utterly depleted. I know this is how it is for so many people with cancer, and my heart aches for those less fortunate than myself. My story up until now is the same story so many people share. It's just a devastating disease in so many ways.I am once again faced with this fact - If I do not have a miracle very, very soon, I am going to die. This was not as frightening to me as it once was though, because we have already had so many miracles during our journey that we have simply come to expect them. It seems that whatever we needed, whenever we needed it, was always there. (But this time, I must admit, I didn’t know what else there could possibly be) Are you going through a cancer trial or any other great difficulty in your life? I want to encourage you to never give up and always, always trust the Lord. He is good and merciful. With all this despair and difficulty surrounding us, our trust in the Lord was all we had left. That was when, only two days ago, two of my customers who had heard about my cancer walked into my business and sat down. They said that they are involved on the margins in one of the world’s most exciting cutting edge scientific Immunotherapy drugs, developed at Baylor Medical College in Houston Texas. They wanted to know if I’d go to a clinic in India to take treatment.And again, seemingly out of nowhere, just hours after I had been on the verge of accepting my imminent demise, my fatalism has turned into hope. For me, this is not a trial. The drug has been proven to work and is not just for bladder cancer; it has already completed a remarkable trial and it works for all solid tumor cancers.There I was, as you can imagine, stunned, speechless, and light as a feather as another timely miracle was laid at my feet.  But in order to take advantage of it I will need a lot of financial help. That's where you come in and I need your help as fast as possible - timing is essential - I must leave soon and begin the treatment that could well save me from this aggressive cancer.Having to act so quickly, we cannot take the time to first raise the funds, so we are leaving June 3rd on faith and well-placed hope because this treatment has been proven to work favorably on 40% of the first group who had been given treatment. And now the door has been opened for us to go. The cost of the medicine and travel expenses is in the neighborhood of $85,000/95,000 - and the initial part needs to be raised fairly quickly.Fighting this disease for 3 years now, has left us with virtually no money in order to take advantage of the treatment being offered to us. From a brief email this week sent to a few of our family and friends - an initial amount of cash was raised to begin the process and secure a deposit in order to be accepted into treatment.However, none of the estimated $85,000 plus is covered by insurance so we are needing to turn to the mercy and grace of anyone wishing to help. Even if you cannot help us financially, please sign up for our blog and follow our experiences as you or someone you may know could easily need this therapy in the future – hopefully as it gets less and less expensive.This is what we can share with you as of now:-            We are asking that you donate any cash amount you can via Go Fund Me. We are also asking that you donate any excess Frequent Flier points as we can use these points by giving miles in exchange for cash. -            From our initial email above, we additionally received donations from several people of over 600,000 Frequent Flyer miles. With a portion of these, we were able to purchase 3 roundtrip airfares as my two sons Kelly 19 and David 28 will be going with me. (David will only stay for 3 weeks)Here is our Itinerary:-          June 3rd through June 6th we fly from Dallas to NY to London to New Delhi India. (There were direct flights but I'm so easily fatigued we needed to factor in a couple of rest nights)-           My first injection will be June 20th. -           Second injection will be July 3rd, and the third and final injection will be July 17th.-           By the 2nd injection, I should begin to see reduction in tumor sizes. By the 3rd injection, my cancers will be a fraction of their original sizes. By August 1st, I should be in full remission. What a glorious day that will be!-          HOW DOES THE TREATMENT WORK-          The treatment is a dendritic cell immunotherapy.-           The technique is absolute cutting edge state of the art.-          It was developed at Baylor College of Medicine Houston Texas-          Cancer tissue is taken from the main tumor, and then the DNA of the patient’s white blood cells are altered to attack that specific cancer.-          It works on all solid cancers.-          Tests to date show the treatment to be extraordinarily effective.  The treatment has no side effects and results begin immediately.-          The treatment has not yet been approved in the U.S. but has been approved in India, that's why I am going there to receive the treatment.-          However, the very first United States trial will be at Baylor College of Medicine starting late next month on pancreatic cancer.  The treatment I will be receiving in India is a very similar treatment being given to the pancreatic patients here in the first American trial.I'm so excited!-          Because after looking at my 3-year medical history, my immune system, and estimated time left to live - the scientists believe that I have an excellent probability of having no discernable tumors by the end of August.-            I thank you all in advance for helping me and my family. Without help from people like you there would be no hope for us. You are our only hope.God bless you all so very much,And thank you. John Bacile and family.Dallas Texas

title: Medical Expenses - Masoud Hosseini
text: Our beloved Masoud Hosseini, dedicated husband, loving father, and generous friend has been diagnosed with Stage IV Melanoma Cancer.  It started as what was thought to be a simple strained muscle, unfortunately, tests came back with a different story. Many people have asked how they can help the family. Masoud and his family will be facing medical bills very soon, as his treatment has begun. It would help to ease their burden if we could assist them in this way.We are asking for contributions towards our goal of $100,000 to support his medical treatment without delay.   Please share his story with others because chances are someone you know also knows Masoud.Masoud and his family are grateful for your prayers and support.

title: Ella vs. Childhood Cancer
text: One day a little girl is placed in your arms.One day that little girl says her first word.One day she takes her first steps, and before you know it...One day she is off to kindergarten.Then, one day, life changes.Ella is a beautiful 6 year old. She sings and dances like it’s her job. She spends countless summer days playing at the beach, and school year afternoons with friends, family, or belting out her favorite songs like Moana’s “How Far I’ll Go.” She knows that she wants to be a singer or a princess, (or maybe even both), one day when she grows up. Ella has won the praise and acknowledgement of her teachers for being a conscientious and courteous student and an amazing friend and classmate. On Monday, February 12, 2018, Ella stayed home from school with a rash her mom, Tracy, believed to be Fifths Disease. While on the way to the pediatrician’s office for a quick check to be sure, Ella’s dad, Mike, noticed a strange lump on her lower left back. Because Ella and Tracy had attended a roller skating party 3 days prior to this visit, the pediatrician diagnosed the non-painful lump as a muscle spasm, along with her confirmation that Ella had Fifths Disease. When the lump did not change two days later, Tracy contacted the pediatrician, asking for further exploration of its cause. The pediatrician agreed, and Tracy set an appointment for an ultrasound at Hasbro Children’s Hospital in Providence, RI for 4pm on Friday, February 16. By 4:15pm on the day of the ultrasound, Tracy, Mike, and Ella were being ushered to the Emergency Room at Hasbro for further testing on what the doctors determined was a soft tissue lump. From there...that day, and the ones that immediately followed... everything became a blur. Encouraging test results came back one by one, giving the family hope, until the MRI displayed every family’s worst fear; Ella has Ewing’s Sarcoma. Through this process, a family learns a lot. They learn to take their train that until now, had encountered the same bumps and turbulence most families experience, and switch it to a track of uncertainty. A track that is often plagued with long waits and dark tunnels, much like a roller coaster at Disney World, Ella’s favorite place to visit. Parents learn to say, “My daughter has cancer,” and only cry on those days when they wonder why, and they tell people how they’ve learned that Childhood Cancer Research is devastatingly underfunded. They learn how to tell their daughter that she will lose her hair, and that she won’t be able to regularly attend school where all of her friends continue their routine. They learn how to research and explain medical procedures, while fielding questions and giving care to their child. Family members and friends learn to ask, “What can I do,” or “What do you need” before even saying “Hello.”Most importantly, a 6 year old girl learns that even though she doesn’t feel sick, there is a thing in her body called a tumor that the doctors removed...mostly...but that some sneaky cells hung around to try to make more mischief. She learns where her chemo port is, and that the awesome nurses and doctors at Hasbro treat her with gentle kindness even when performing physically difficult procedures. Ella learned that these cells she has need chemotherapy to go away for good. And that’s what they will do. They will go away for good, because no singing princess will stand for a devious disease blocking her way.Parents learn that, even with healthcare, there’s unpaid leave from work and travel expenses that add up. The doctors at Sloan Kettering in New York City are specialists in Ewing’s, and they have agreed to see Ella and help treat her. This will mean regular trips from Rhode Island to New York. Even with donated sick days, Tracy does not have enough sick time to get her through the eight plus months of chemo Ella will need to kick Ewing’s Sarcoma to the curb. Even after the chemo, there will be months of radiation, blood work, scans, and doctor’s visits to make sure our singing princess Ella remains on the road to recovery.Tracy, Ella, and Mike have a long way to go before their train can switch back to a more well-lit, less tumultuous track. Until then, they need our help so finances do not add extra bumps and worries to their already burdened travels. Because...One day, Ella and her family will celebrate new milestones.One day will be the last chemo treatment.One day will be the first of countless clear scans and tests.One day we will all join Ella and her family in celebrating a cure for everyone.Ella, Tracy, and Mike are forever grateful for the kindness of friends, family, and especially those who give without ever having met Ella. She promises to send you an autographed picture when she becomes a famous, singing princess.

title: Matt Crowe
text: Dear Friends and Family, Matt was in a very serious mountain biking accident on June 23rd  in Aspen and broke his neck. He was airlifted to Saint Anthony’s Hospital in Lakewood, Colorado where the surgeons performed a 7 hour surgery where they were able to repair his spinal column by fusing several vertebrae.  There have been some positive signs of Matt moving his arms and legs, but at this point the doctors are unable to give any definitive prognosis or timeline for his recovery. As you know, Matt and Janelle are going to need help caring for Davis and Ivy while Matt recovers. Friends of the family have set up this GoFundMe page as a gift to Matt and Janelle to help ease some of their burdens. Our hope is that we can raise enough funds to pay for a part-time nanny, cleaning services, and other household help they may need for at least the next three months.

title: Gift of Hearing for Elroi
text: We are raising funds to allow our 3-year old profoundly deaf child to have a cochlear implant surgery as soon as possible as recommended by ENT specialist. This will be Elroi’s 5th surgery in his young life, after having been diagnosed with CHARGE syndrome (explained below) not too long after birth. Every amount you can give is utterly appreciated to help us give our Elroi the gift of hearing (and consequently speech)! THANK YOU SO MUCH! Here’s a background into Elroi’s few years on God’s beautiful earth so far.Our Miracle baby Elroi was born on the 29th of January 2015. He was born without opened nostrils which impeded his ability to breathe, a condition the doctors termed as Bilateral Choanal Atresia. Since babies are obligatory nose breathers he was not able to compensate by breathing through his mouth. At only a few minutes old, he experienced his first of three pulmonary cardiac arrests and had to be resuscitated, and several pinches administered just so he could stay alive. It was scary as a parent to see the frail body of our supposed bundle of joy go through this life threatening experience; his color would turn pink when he cried, meaning he had sufficient oxygen in his body, to an eerie purple when his mouth was closed, which meant he was oxygen-deficient. Elroi was rushed to the major teaching hospital in Ghana called Korle Bu Teaching Hospital as a matter of urgency, where a life-saving operation of perforating the nasal cavity was performed. This was not to be the only time he would go under the knife. Elroi has had other operations since this first one, including removal of the stents, and a heart surgery at five months to close an open duct.To compound issues, Elroi was later diagnosed to be profoundly deaf in both ears which led to another diagnosis of CHARGE syndrome. This is known to occur only in 1 in every 10,000 births. It is a complex combination of medical conditions which includes Coloboma, heart defects, choanal atresia, growth retardation, genital abnormalities, and ear abnormalities (severe to profound sensoneural hearing loss in both ears)After several trials and speech therapy with two fitted hearing aids, the doctors in Ghana concluded that a cochlear implant would be the best solution in aiding him to hear.Unfortunately this procedure is not done in our homeland Ghana, hence our doctor suggested Nationwide Children’s Hospital (NCH) in Columbus, Ohio. NCH requested to redo all the assessments to ascertain if truly our son was eligible for the Cochlear implants. This reassessment came at a cost of $6,000 which we paid in full prior to the  tests getting done. After the various evaluations were conducted it was confirmed that Elroi is indeed a candidate for a cochlear implant in order for him to have the gift of hearing. With hearing, Elroi will be able to speak as these two essential life skills are interdependent in Elroi’s case.Now..to get the cochlear implant surgery done comes with a price tag of $50,000. The Nationwide Children’s Hospital has requested payment in full before surgery can be done, and as per the Cochlear Implant Specialist we met with, the surgery needs to be done as soon as possible…the further we delay the further Elroi’s speech development is impacted negatively. A lot has been committed so far to get us to this stage and your benevolence will be greatly appreciated to give our little miracle the needed hearing required to complete his full cycle development. Any amount will be greatly appreciated.

title: Help Christina Eat Again
text: Christina is the sweetest girl you would ever want to meet! She has an infectious smile and loves to laugh with her family and friends. Christina also loves to eat, but because of a rare disease called Chronic Intestinal Pseudo-obstruction, she can’t. Her digestive system won’t move and absorb nutrients like it should, instead food causes a great deal of pain, nausea and retching. The doctors at Cleveland Clinic have told her she is in intestinal failure and the only hope that remains is a modified multi-visceral transplant, which means she needs a stomach, duodenum, small intestine and pancreas transplant to have hope to eat - and to live. She is currently awaiting transplant.Right now Christina is receiving all of her nutrition through a surgically placed IV line that provides the nutrition her digestive system can’t (Total Parenteral Nutrition), but without the ability to eat anything she will go into liver failure, and as she knows all too well, long-term use of surgically placed IV lines brings life-threatening infections. Please join us in praying that a transplant will happen soon.During the transplant evaluation at Cleveland Clinic Christina was told the cost would be in excess of a million dollars, and although she has insurance, there are significant amounts insurance is expected not to pay. As part of the evaluation she was counseled to begin fundraising to help cover the costs of transplant, which is why this page is being created. In addition to medical costs, Christina and her mom, who will be her primary caregiver (required for transplant), will have to stay in Cleveland awaiting transplant because Christina cannot be more than three hours away when she receives the call that a donor has been found. After transplant she will be required to stay in the area for a minimum of 3-6 months. No travel or living expenses are covered by insurance.Christina is a delightful young lady with a big smile and a heart full of dreams for the future. Will you please help her raise the funds she needs to get a transplant? Asking for help is hard, but with your help, she will move forward to being able to eat again and live a life full of hope for a bright future.You can follow Christina’s journey at christinasjourney.com. Please help however you can! Please share this page! Please pray for Christina!

title: SRT Operator Justin's Recovery
text: Justin is a member of the HSI San Diego SRT team.  A piece of equipment being tested during recent training malfunctioned and resulted in major injuries to his lower extremities.  Justin has undergone 2 major surgeries since the incident, and it is anticipated that he will undergo at least one more.  The road to recovery will include months of rehabilitation both at the hospital, and will eventually transition to in-home care.The donations will be used by Justin's wife, Lyndsey,  to make necessary modifications to his home that will allow for a speedy recovery.

title: Help Jen Eccleston fight cancer
text: We come to you with heavy hearts for our sister in Christ, Jen Eccleston. We have known Jen for many  years through our church. She is a wife to Matt and mother to three beautiful children. Recently, Jen went to the ER for what she believed was a kidney stone. The CT not only confirmed the kidney stone, but also found a 13.5 cm mass in her liver, and two soft tissue masses. The natural doctor Jen has been working with the last year has specifically been working on her circulating cancer cells (a/k/a CTCs). All of this work has not been in vain as her cell count is now down to 2. Upon follow up, a PET scan has revealed that the cancer has spread.  The natural doc has a connection with a specialist in CA, Dr. Ahvie. Dr. Ahvie is an M.D. and graduated from Johns Hopkins. He takes very difficult cancer cases and offers targeted approaches with chemotherapy, as well as another therapy that acts as a cancer vaccine of sorts. (They still have more information to obtain.) The targeted therapy would be based on the RGCC testing that Jen did with her natural doc that outlined the exact chemo that gave her the highest death rate of cancer cells. Dr. Ahvie has been consulting with Jen’s natural doc and believes she would be a candidate for his therapy. He indicated how happy he is for the work that has been done to lower the CTC count, as it’s important to his therapy as well.This is where you come in. Jen and her family need prayer warriors to rally behind her. The specialized treatment from Dr. Ahvie in CA is not covered by Jen’s medical sharing company, so she also needs monetary funds to cover testing, traveling, procedures, etc. Upon her return from the initial treatment, Jen will need to keep up Dr. Ahvie’s protocol at home, which will involve costs as well.Please join kingdom forces with us to pray specifically for Jen and her family. And please consider giving a monetary gift for these mounting medical costs. God bless you, and please continue to follow Jen’s journey here as we give updates. We would be so grateful to have you share this on social media or email.Abbie Brigham and Mary Graves____________________________________________Prayer Requests by Jen:Please pray that I would have spiritual and physical strength, not fear the future, and trust in my Sovereign God completely. May He be glorified.Please pray for my dear husband, Matt, as he works tirelessly to provide working his full time job and extra side jobs to pay for medical expenses. Matt also faithfully serves the kids and me at home as I have not been operating at full speed.Pray for my children to trust in Christ and draw near to Him. They also serve our family so sweetly. Pray for their strength and for God to bless them.Of course, please pray for total healing and for us to have wisdom as we navigate the path the Lord has for us to walk.Please pray for God to provide for my medical expenses.Please pray for doctors to have wisdom for the best treatment.Please pray that I would be able to eat and sleep and hold my weight. The doctor emphasized this is very important.Thank you from our hearts. We praise God for every prayer, every kindness, and His provision.  - Jen

title: Isaac Conway and family
text: Our friend Isaac has been diagnosed with cancer.  None of us know how much time we have on this Earth, but since Isaac has touched each of us through his generosity, knowledge, compassion, humor, and leadership we want him to enjoy his time with his family. We also want to help care for his family if he becomes unable to work. The situation is not good and funds are needed now. Beyond fundraising, the Conway family might enjoy a meal or housecleaning service, donation of a family activity or getaway, or just a visit or phone call to show you care.

title: The Williamson Family
text: Jed and Chelsea have had their little six year old in the hospital for three days after she had a seizure. Lydia has led a life full of light. Her sixth birthday party she planned all the activities and made a story to share the need for Jesus with all her friends. Lydia is a big sister to a little girl named Maggie who is four. They will likely leave the hospital without Lydia, rejoicing she has gone to the Promised Land. As they transition  to a new way of life as a family they will need support and we can help them practically by donating and lifting them up in prayer, sending cards and remembering the sweet life Lydia has led.

title: The Mulhern Family
text: On January 23, 2018, following a very complicated pregnancy, Julie and Ernie welcomed twin boys Aidan and Brennan to the world 10 weeks early. Throughout Julie’s pregnancy, complications were discovered early on and the loving parents decided to undergo a procedure for the boys while in-utero in an attempt to give both little boys the best fighting chance. Later, an emergency c-section was performed and Julie gave birth to Aidan Paul weighing 1lb 3oz and Brennan Michael weighing 4lbs. Following their birth, they remained in the Yale NICU for quite some time. During their stay, they both underwent multiple medical procedures to correct complications. The family was overjoyed when they were able to bring baby Brennan home in March. Brennan is thriving at home, however still requires surgery to correct a heart condition. Unfortunately, on May 4, 2018, Julie, Ernie and the rest of the family had to say goodbye to their little fighter, baby Aidan. In their time of grieving, they should not have to also worry about how they will pay for the hospital bills and other expenses as Julie has been unable to work since the boys were born.  As many of you know, Julie and Ernie are two of the most caring and selfless people. Their friends wanted to create this fund as a way for all of us to give back to them and lessen their financial burden. We thank you for all of the outpouring of love, support and generosity.

title: Joe Zabel Family
text: On April 26th 2018, Joe was hiking with friends, while on vacation in Moab, UT. There was an accident and Joe sustained multiple critical injuries. Being outdoors is one of Joe's favorite hobbies as is being with his many friends. All those who know Joe, and his family, love them. (If you don't know them, you would love them too. They are all awesome!) He is someone that makes friends with everyone he meets. He loves life and makes the most out of every moment of it.Joe is currently in the hospital with many surgeries ahead of him.  It will most likely be a long road to recovery. Joe is a great provider for his wife and three kids  and is the main income producer. Being self employed, he will be out of work for some time. There will be many medical expenses and living expenses going forward. We would like to raise as much as we can for this great family, to help support them through this hard time.  Donate what you can, every little bit will go to a great cause and be very appreciated.Note: Edmond Holden (Joe's Brother in Law) has been selected to withdraw and deposit the funds into the appropriate account for the family. ￼￼￼￼￼￼

title: Scott VandeWalle
text: On March 20th, 2018, our family’s lives were forever changed when my brother, Scott was diagnosed with Cancer.  The original prognosis was okay, and we knew we were in for an uphill battle, however, after further testing and imaging we soon learned that our worst nightmare was now a reality.  Scott’s cancer was much much worse than what we originally thought.  He has since been diagnosed with Stage 4 Non small cell metastatic lung cancer and the cancer has spread to his bones and lymph nodes.  Further imaging also has shown small traces of cancer in other areas.  This journey and past month has been incredibly difficult on all of us, but most importantly on Scott and his loving family, especially his two beautiful daughters, Lillian (13) and Reese (9).  Scott’s wife Rebecca (Becky) has been a trooper while balancing Scott’s needs with that of his two young daughters.  While our lives are forever changed with this terrible news, we are committed to supporting Scott spiritually, mentally, and financially in any way we can.  Our family would like to thank the out pouring of love and concern that everyone has shown.  Scott is super grateful.  I have started this page for people to reach out and support him and his family in any way they can and also to keep everyone informed of Scott’s current condition.  My brother is truly one of a kind and my best friend and I will dedicate the rest of my life to helping him and his family in any way I can.  I also started this page so people can offer financial assistance with the crazy amount of medical bills, as well as an outlet for friends and family to offer words of encouragement as Scott starts the fight of his life against this terrible disease. Thanks for everyone's support! https://www.caringbridge.org/visit/scottvandewalleBrett VandeWalleAlong w/ the rest of the VandeWalle family: Becky, Lillian (13), and Reese(9) -- Tom and Sue --  Rebekah, Peyton (5), and Sydney Shaye (3)

title: Marissa Schwartz
text: Dear Family and Friends,   This site has been created to keep everyone informed of Marissa's condition.  Marissa was  admitted Sunday evening, February 18th, to the Lancaster General Hospital Intensive Care Unit (ICU).  She contracted the H1N1 and Influenza virus.  This aggressive virus attacked  suddenly and her condition deteriorated rapidly, with no warning.   A week and a half later, she was transported via chopper to Penn Presbyterian in Philadelphia.  She remains at PENN in critical condition in the ICU.   She is receiving excellent care at PENN!  We are hopeful her critical status will change soon.  The doctors have informed us that Marissa's recovery could be a very long journey.   The recovery time could take several months.  Please continue to keep her in your prayers. The incredible out-pour of concern and love is greatly appreciated.  Marissa has touched so many lives in so many beautiful ways.  This is obvious by the amount of people who are saying they will do anything to help!  Please know that the family is covered at the moment with meals, carpools and daily household needs.   A sign-up genius has been created  for meals and prayers.  You can access these links on this Caring Bridge site under "ways to help."  The reality of Marissa's prognosis brings uncertainty and concerns for the immediate future of their family.   Because of the lengthy road ahead,  additional needs are imminent.  The family is facing unexpected health costs, travel expenses and loss of income.  As some of you may know,  Marissa tutored  high school students in math and science.  After many requests from the community and careful consideration,  a "Go Fund Me" site is being  launched on behalf of the Schwartz family.  Many of you are asking for additional ways to help.  Thank you for expressing your interest in giving.  You can now donate  on the  Caring Bridge site  under "ways to help."  We greatly appreciate your interest in giving and generosity during this crisis.  Alan really struggled with the idea of a "Go Fund Me" link on the Caring Bridge site.  This was something he really felt uncomfortable doing.  He is already so humbled by the amount of help he and his family have received.  A very close friend, along with others, assured him this was the right move!  Launching the site on Caring Bridge makes the most sense  because so many visit looking for updated information and additional ways to give. Alan truly understands how helpful this will be for their family and is forever grateful to everyone.  Again, we appreciate your ongoing support and words of hope and encouragement.   Love and prayers are the most important thing now for Marissa, Alan and the kids.  Thank you all for  being so dedicated to prayer.  Please continue praying... This is what Marissa needs most....This is what Marissa is all about... THE POWER OF PRAYER!!!!

title: Help Sho Morita and his family
text: Sho Morita was hit by a drunk driver and injured his body and brain seriously.【日本語の文章は下にあります】Hi all, I’m Suguru Min, a senior at Waseda University in Japan. I have been studying at Portland State University as an exchange student since April. I’m writing this for my friend, Sho Morita, who was tragically hit by a car. Sho’s body and head were seriously injured. He was in the ICU for a month. The driver was intoxicated over the legal limit and was arrested soon after. I established this funding campaign so that he and his family can receive much needed financial help.Sho is also a  senior at Waseda University. He came to Portland in April as a member of the same International exchange program. After arriving in Portland, besides studying English, he joined the college soccer team and was spending a great time here with friends in Portland. He is bright, funny, and always friendly. He is adored by everyone who gets to know him.Sho’s family and friends were  stunned by this accident. His life was completely disrupted. I am asking our friends and the community to offer help in order to relieve the burden on his family. We would gladly appreciate anything you can offer: prayers, thoughts, and donations. 【How the accident happened and Sho’s condition】On June 25th, at midnight, Sho was hit by a car which drove through a red light while Sho was walking on the crosswalk on his way to his host family’s home. The driver was reported to be intoxicated above the legal limit. After the accident, Sho was transported to OHSU hospital. Thanks to the work of OHSU’s doctors and nurses, his life was spared. However, his body was severely injured. He sustained a severe head injury along with a broken right arm and right leg.  Because of the damage to his brain, doctors believed that he may be in a coma forever, or he might lose his life.He was in a coma for almost a month after the accident, but he woke up miraculously.  Since then he has recovered well with care from his family, friends, and the staff from OHSU. HE IS NOW FULLY CONSCIOUS and capable of communicating with us. He was then transferred from OHSU Hospital to a Japanese hospital for financial reasons. It’s still unclear when he can be discharged. Based on his condition, the doctors advise us that we should be prepared for a long stay at the hospital.【Medical expenditures and other costs】Regarding his medical expenditures, Sho bought insurance for studying abroad and his medical fees are compensated to a certain extent. However, medical fees in the U.S. are much more expensive than in Japan.His insurance coverage has reached its limit due to the U.S. medical expenses and transportation to Japan. The family will be overrun by medical costs because of his continuing care.The cost of transporting his family to the U.S. and a percentage of the medical fees in Japan are not covered by his insurance and his family had to pay for it by themselves. Furthermore we are unsure when he can leave the hospital, the total amount of medical fees is unknown. Thus I am establishing this fund and asking for your help to reduce his family’s burden even just a bit.【Goal of the fund and how to use it】All of the donations will be handed to Sho’s family and used for the transportation cost of his family and the medical fee in Japan as written above. I am setting the goal at $80,000. To be honest, the expenditures in the future vary greatly depending on how well Sho can recover, so the goal is only a guide. It is likely to cost more than that.【How you can help Sho】It goes without saying that any donation will help Sho and his family no matter how much you donate, and it would be more helpful than you think. You can donate easily by credit card and the minimum amount of donation is $5.I would appreciate it if you share this page via Facebook or Twitter as well as give a donation. Either posting this page directly on SNS or sharing someone’s post is welcome. If you can’t donate but would like to help, please share this page and this would help him and his family.I want to say again and again that both the donation and the share will help Sho and his family. Cooperation is powerful. We really need your help.Thank you for your time. Please help Sho for the sake of his future.Suguru Minはじめまして。現在大学4年生で4月からポートランド州立大学に留学していますミンスグルと申します。今回、同じ大学のプログラムで一緒に留学に来ていた友人の森田晶が不幸にも交通事故に遭い、脳を含め重傷を負って長期間の入院を余儀なくされたため、皆さんに少しでも協力していただければと思い、このクラウドファンディングを開設しました。晶は現在大学4年生で、僕と同じく4月からポートランドで留学をはじめ、大学での勉強に加えて大学のサッカーチームに所属するなど充実した留学生活を送っていました。普段から明るくて、面白くて、いつでも場を盛り上げてくれて、本当にみんなから慕われていました。今回の事故については晶に過失は一切なく、家族や友人を含め本当に悔しい思いをしています。そして何よりも悔しい思いをしているのは晶本人だと思います。晶と晶の家族のためにも少しでもみなさんに協力をしていただければ幸いです。【事故の経緯と晶の状況】6月25日深夜、晶がホストファミリーの家に帰る途中の横断歩道で、赤信号を無視した車に轢かれ大怪我を負いました。運転手は飲酒運転で、晶に過失は一切ありません。その後ポートランドの大学病院に搬送され、幸い事故直後には一命を取り留めましたが右手右足を複雑骨折し、脳へのダメージも著しかったため、当初医師からは最悪命を落とすか、よくても寝たきりの状態のままだろうと伝えられるような状況でした。その後一ヶ月弱ほどこん睡状態が続いていましたが、奇跡的に目を覚まして、今では意識もはっきりしていて会話ができるほどにまでなりました。先日アメリカから日本の病院に搬送されましたが、依然として退院のめどは立っておらず、引き続き入院が必要な状態です。それに加えて、回復した後も長いリハビリ生活を強いられることになります。【医療費やその他費用について】医療費について、晶は留学用の保険に加入しているため一定額までの入院治療費は補償されるのですが、アメリカの医療費が日本と比べて段違いに高額なため、アメリカでの入院治療費、アメリカから日本へ搬送する際の費用で保険金額の上限にほぼ達しているのが現状です。ご家族のアメリカへの渡航費や日本での治療費に関しては、留学用の保険ではカバーされずご家族自身で賄わなければなりません。また、日本での治療費やリハビリにかかる費用については退院のめども立っていないため、いくらかかるかも想定できません。そこでこのページを通じて少しでもご家族の負担を減らせればと考えています。【募金の目標金額とその用途】募金していただいた金額は全額晶の家族に引き渡され、上で述べたご家族のアメリカへの渡航費と日本での治療費に使われます。目標金額としては80,000ドル(約880万円)に設定しています。正直今後かかる費用が晶の回復状況によって大きく変動するため、目標金額はあくまで目安です。目標金額以上に費用がかかる可能性も大いにあります。その際には目標金額を変更することも考えています。【皆さんにお願いしたいこと】当たり前ですが、どんなに少額でも募金をしていただけるだけで晶とご家族のためになりますし、皆さんが考えている以上に助けになります。アメリカのWEBサイトなので英語の表記しかないのですが、クレジットカードがあれば3分ほどで募金ができるのでぜひよろしくお願いします。5ドルから募金ができます。以下のURLに募金の方法が日本語で書いてあるのでご確認ください。 http://colorguardaf3.hatenablog.com/entry/2017/01/05/173429 また、このページをFacebookやTwitterでシェアしてもらえるだけでも、募金と同じくらい助けになります。このページを引用して投稿していただくのでも、誰かの投稿をシェアをしていただくのでもどちらでもかまいません。何かしらの理由で募金ができない方、募金とまではいかなくても力になっていただける方はシェアをしていただけるだけで十二分に助かります。もちろん募金をした上でシェアをしていただければ、これ以上ないほど力になります。繰り返しにはなりますが、募金とSNSでのシェアのいずれも、皆さんが考えている以上に晶とご家族の力になります。皆さんの力を少しでもお借りできれば幸いです。ここまで長い文章を読んでいただきありがとうございます。晶とご家族のためにご協力よろしくお願いします。明　卓

title: Help Layne Berry Fight Cancer
text:
Layne Berry, Tom Berry's daughter, is currently undergoing treatment for Stage IV Lymphoma. She is a graduate of Episcopal High School and currently a student at UVA.Good news is that lymphoma is treatable, and her odds of beating the disease are high. Bad news is that her cancer is stage 4, so treatment will be aggressive.  I can't image what Layne is going through right now. Mr. Berry and his wife have a lot on their plate. It's hard to shower, get decent meals, go to work, and tend to your own needs during times like these. Not to mention the medical costs for cancer are super high! On average, the cost for lymphoma treatment is 10,000 a month. Layne will also have reoccuring medical costs at minimum for the next five years, as she will have to follow-up with her oncologist after she beats the cancer.Mr. Berry is an amazing teacher and someone who truly cares for his students. He would message me now and then after graduation, and I know he kept in touch regularly with other students. Let's help out the best BC Calculus teacher the world has ever seen. I will continue to update this page with information/wishlist items requested by the Berry family.If you want to learn more about lymphoma, here is a good overview: 

 https://www.health.harvard.edu/cancer/lymphoma-overview******************UPDATE 5/4/2018*******************GoFundMe has requested I add additional information in terms of who I am, my relationship to the Berrys, and clarification on where the money is going and how it is being withdrawn. This is to ensure total campaign transparency and for GoFundMe to be able to release the funds to the Berry family.1. My name is Barbara Bai, EHS '08, Tufts '12, currently a healthcare policy researcher at Harvard Medical School in Boston, MA.2. I am a former student of Mr. Berry's. He taught me BC Calculus at Episcopal High School in Alexandria, Virginia ("EHS"). I credit him, among other teachers, for shaping me into the person that I am today. I did not know Layne very well, as she was in elementary school when I was a student at EHS, but this family is very near and dear to my heart.3. Tom Berry is the sole beneficiary of the funds. As the organizer of the campaign, I do not have access to withdrawing any of the money that is being donated.4. All funds raised in this campaign will be used for expenses incurred during Layne's cancer treatment.  This includes but is not limited to: any or all medical bills not covered by insurance, meal delivery services, travel/lodging expenses, miscellanious gifts, etc. This money will be set aside in a separate bank account, as indicated by Tom Berry to me, the campaign organizer.5. For the purposes of this campaign, Layne's cancer treatment is defined as the five year period from May 2018-May 2023 where Layne will be receiving treatment and undergoing follow up appointments related to her Stage IV Lymphoma. 6. GoFundMe's payment processor(s) will be receiving 2.9% and $0.3 for each donation. GoFundMe does not take a cut of the donation. Instead, it requests tips from each donor. As a donor, you have the authority to request a refund from GoFundMe at any time.

title: Roman’s Emergency Fund
text: Many of you know Dr. Steven Bird DC—whether he was your peer, friend, intern, TA, or your MPI rep, he was always around to offer help to anyone who needed it, friend or stranger. He always was there, never asking for anything in return.-But Bird needs our help now. Dr. Bird recently graduated in April 2018, and is currently in the process of opening a new practice. Father of 4, it is with a heavy heart that I inform you all that his youngest, Roman, was in a terrible accident. Roman is currently in the ICU at Primary Children’s in Salt Lake City with brain swelling, seizures, and brain damage. With a new practice in the works, a big family to take care of, and a large student debt, I’m urging us all to open our hearts to send not only prayers and thoughts, but to do what we can and donate.We are well aware how incredibly ridiculous medical bills can be, and for those that know Dr. Bird, you know he was always the one to pay it forward any way he could.If you are able to donate even a few dollars, it would be more than appreciated. If you have any questions or would like to help raise more money for such a fantastic family, please feel free to reach out and contact me anytime, any day.

title: Greg & Dawn Lee: Fighting Together!
text: Dawn and Greg Lee built their life together on the foundation of faith in God, love and family. Through their unselfishness, strength and perseverance, they approach every challenge as a platform for connecting with others and for bringing God's love into our broken world. Through every trial they face, they are steadfast in putting everyone else first. Now, they need our help. Four years ago Greg Lee was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma. Then, on April 4, 2018, in the echo of three life-changing words, "you have cancer," Dawn was thrust from her role as a faithful caregiver and sole breadwinner into a fight for her own life. The process of fighting Greg's cancer the past four years has severely impacted them financially and the future costs of fighting two cancers at the same time are overwhelming. We are hoping to raise enough money to cover their ongoing medical costs and the loss of income from the inability to work fulltime, while both are being medically treated. All funds donated will go directly toward offsetting their expenses and allowing them to continue to fight. Dawn and Greg are eternally grateful for your prayers and any support you can provide.Greg's Story In 2014, Greg was shaving one morning and noticed a lump on the right side of his neck. Three physicians and two biopsies later, the diagnosis was confirmed. Squamous cell carcinoma. To make matters worse, two months after Greg's second biopsy, he began experiencing extreme vertigo, headaches and other symptoms. After seeing several doctors, the source of the problems was diagnosed as Type 1 diabetes. The healthy diet he had begun to fight the cancer was no longer healthy for him.The next eighteen months would see continued tumor growth, and a dramatic increase in fatigue. Greg was forced to cease working in March 2016 to allow his body to heal and recover from the trauma. His neck tumor was the size of a large grapefruit and was causing a tremendous amount of nerve damage and pain. In September 2016, Greg was not expected to survive long enough to see Christmas.Yet, God had other plans. Greg was referred to another radiation oncologist, who offered a new procedure: extremely high doses of radiation over a short period of time. Over the next nine months the tumor continued to shrink, far beyond everyone's expectations. One could use the word 'miracle' when describing how much better Greg's quality of life became. Not cured. Not in remission. But Greg was Greg again and life was so much better! Unfortunately, Greg’s fight is not over. On Feb. 2, 2018, a scan revealed that the tumor had doubled in size and was growing again. The limited treatment options are being explored and the future is uncertain, but Dawn and Greg aren’t giving up.  Dawn's StoryDawn is a natural caregiver. She is 100% a Mom to her kids and a Nana to her grandkids. Over the past four years, her superhero skills were called upon while serving as Greg's caregiver, supporting their family financially and caring for an untold number of women through her job as a RN at an OB-GYN clinic.Her own battle with cancer began in April 2018, when cramping and a GI bleed landed her in the ER. The CT scan showed a mass in her colon and she was kept overnight for more tests. The bleeding was so severe, Dawn lost two liters of blood the first day. The subsequent scope and biopsy revealed a large cancerous mass that needed to be removed.  Surgery went well, but the tumor was larger than anyone expected and of the 27 lymph nodes that were removed, 15 tested positive for cancer. Dawn was diagnosed with high risk, Stage 3c colon cancer. As her body recovers from the surgery, Dawn is meeting with colorectal oncologists to discuss the different options for chemotherapy. She is facing six months of intense treatment. Their Walk with GraceThroughout the past four years and even with Dawn's new diagnosis, Dawn and Greg have walked with grace, joy and dignity. Their positive spirit and giving nature is constant. Their story is not about cancer or the incredible odds facing a couple battling cancer together at the same time. Their story is about how they have used their diagnosis to inspire others in similar situations and through it all spread the love of God. Instead of letting cancer control them, they used it for good and put the needs of others over their own. But now, they need our help. Help to continue their journey, as they face long chemo treatment protocols, staggering medical bills and the inability to work fulltime as they heal. Help to know that their friends and family stand next to them during this battle. Help to know that they don't have to face this fight alone. Please help Dawn and Greg Life is precious to Dawn and Greg as they watch their children and grandchildren grow and experience the awesome world God created. God, faith and family are at the center of their lives and they would love to be able to experience as much time with family and friends as God allows. The process of fighting Greg's cancer the past four years has severely impacted them financially, and the future costs of fighting two cancers at the same time are overwhelming. We are hoping to raise enough money to cover their ongoing medical costs and the loss of income from the inability to work fulltime, while both are being medically treated. All funds donated will go directly toward offsetting their expenses and allowing them to continue to fight.We are eternally grateful for your prayers and support! May God bless you.

title: Help Ryan Hutchings Fight Cancer
text: Recently, my brother, Ryan, was informed after a medical procedure that the doctors had found a mass. While this was definitely scary news, our family was hopeful that the mass would turn out to be benign. Unfortunately, test results confirmed our worst fear...My 34-year-old brother had cancer. As devastating as this news was it was nothing compared to the news we received a week later. Stage IV with another mass found in his liver. Ryan is now in a literal fight for his life. He will begin chemo treatments this week followed by surgery soon after. As if that is not enough to worry about, he also has to worry about supporting his amazing wife, Coryne, and two beautiful children, 2 1/2 year old Preston and 10-month-old Noelle. Ryan’s treatments are going to make him extremely fatigued and weak. He will, therefore, be unable to perform at his job which is very physically demanding. Since he has not been at his new job long enough he will not be paid for time off and is not eligible for FMLA. This is where you come in. I would love to be able to help alleviate some of that financial burden for Ryan and his family. He should not have to worry about how he’s going to pay bills and feed his family while he should be focusing on beating this horrible disease. If you can give anything at all, please do. Any amount would be appreciated. If you are unable to help financially please share this page and send positive thoughts, words of encouragement, prayers, and love his way. He WILL beat this!

title: Help Travis Kick Leukemia's Butt!!
text: Travis and Jes Mulder celebrated their beautiful wedding in April. Most newlyweds get to enjoy marital bliss after the wedding festivities conclude. Unfortunately for them, this will not be the case. Less than a month into this awesome new phase of life they received some devastating news, Travis has been diagnosed with Leukemia (Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia). The road ahead for them is going to be long... really long. They will need to spend the next 4 weeks at Froedtert Hospital in Milwaukee undergoing an aggressive chemo regimen. After this 4 week period, Travis will need to return to Milwaukee 2-3 times per week for the next 5 months to continue his treatments and also do continued maintenance for the next 2-3 years. This will be a long road to recovery, and although Travis has a favorable outlook, this is still a daunting future for these newlyweds.No one knows what all this will cost, but everyone can agree that Travis and Jes should not need to be worrying about the upcoming medical bills, lost wages, travel expenses, and all the costs that come along with the road ahead. As Travis’s and Jes’s community of support, lets join together in uplifting them. We can do this in 3 ways:1.) Support the “Help Travis Kick Leukemia’s Butt” Go Fund Me2.) Share the Go Fund Me page on your social media outlets3.) And Most Importantly, Pray!!!Any way that you can support them would be much appreciated.  We serve a BIG GOD who, through us, can bless this couple in their darkest hour!

title: The Zaleski Family Fund
text: Friends and family,Some of you may know that the Zaleski family has had a setback recently. Dan had a medical scare last week when he felt numbness in his leg. Sadly, he ultimately had to have his leg amputated. He will still need further surgery in order to receive a prosthetic leg.For those of you who know the Zaleski family, you know that they have big hearts. Janet is an amazing, loving preschool teacher who sometimes can be found driving the tractor for hayrides at Westmoor Park. Dan's patience and good-naturedness has led him to work with special needs children. They are so dedicated to their family of three amazing boys.Now is the time for us to open up our hearts to them. If you are able, please contribute to this page to help offset medical expenses and lost wages. Any little bit will help Dan and his family on the road to recovery. Proceeds will go directly to the family. Thank you!

title: Crystal’s Castle of Hope
text: (This campaign was started by Crystal Jackson, RN, from Stockton, California, sister to Carlie Jackson - Crystal Castle’s partner of 7 years. Thank you for helping! The money raised for Crystal will go to medical expenses, including an air ambulance from Idaho Falls to Oakland. Crystal’s Mom, Michelle Castle, will be withdrawing any funds as the beneficiary of Crystal’s campaign. )Crystal, a healthy active 32 year old, suffered a major stroke Friday morning, May 18th, roughly 15 minutes after she arrived to work in Idaho Falls, Idaho. Any earlier she would of been driving or she could of been home where I wouldn’t of found her for hours. She was immediately taken via ambulance to the Eastern Idaho Regional Medical Center and after a 4.5 hour emergency surgery to attempt to remove a monster clot at the base of her left brain, they were unsuccessful. She was also put on a “clot buster” medicine to help break it down. We were finally able to see her hours later. She was able to lift and lower her left arm on command , squeeze our hand and tried to open her eyes. We had nothing but to believe she could hear us, feel us and that this would all be fine. Later on that evening around 1030pm her pupils changed to different sizes. They rushed her to get a CAT scan and noticed severe brain swelling that was compressing her spinal cord. At this point the neurologist recommended a craniectomy to remove the left side of her skull to relieve pressure. This would give her a chance to live with an unknown outcome of what would happen next. The doctors now believe the clot affected 90 percent of her left brain. So here we are, 5 days later. She’s now surrounded by family with more on the way. A lot of ups and downs. A lot of positives. A lot of negatives. A million unknowns. Every case is different. Every patient is different. Every outcome is different. And for those of us who know Crystal, she’s different. Strong. Stubborn. The feisty twin. And if anyone can fight, she will. I will say today wasn’t as scary as yesterday. But tomorrow has no promise. Crystal needs some help - we are asking for help! Any help. She is going to have unknown medical expenses along with a possible uninsured medical flight to get her back to CA to a hospital where we know she will get the absolute best of care. She more than likely never work again and will need years of physical and speech therapy. We moved here from Central California about 15 months ago when she accepted a new job. It’s just us out here. Shawna, her twin sister, is in Boise 4 hours away. All of our other friends and family and the biggest part of her support system are back in California and that’s our goal of where to get her. With that said, thanks for the help. It all helps. And not just the money, but the vibes, the well wishes, the prayers. We spent yesterday with some of her coworkers in ICU, reminiscing about the short time they knew her, talking about who she is, how she’s always right, how she always takes charge, how she never fails and how she isn’t going to fail this. We know she was listening to every bit of it.

title: A fight to Live and Love
text: I met Ken, my husband, four years ago in 2014. We were a surprise in each other’s lives. Loving each other has been erl we have known despite the adversaries of life. We travelled, we laughed, we married, and in 2016 brought into this world the boundless spirit of joy - our son Dylan. He’s almost two. On May 31st 2018 our world was shattered. We received the news that ken has pancreatic cancer ; metastasized to his liver and other surrounding soft tissue and vertebrae. The day before we were finalizing house plans for our new home and picking kitchen tiles with such excitement (Ken is a chef for over 20 years), our son had just recently started nursery and we’d just decided to start planning for baby  number 2.  Now we were facing the devastating possibility of worst case prognosis. We left our life in the Cayman Islands; and are now in the USA seeking treatment. We are ready to fight. We need to fight, We must fight. We believe we deserve our life together and we know that our baby deserves a life with his dad. We are uncertain of tomorrow but are certain our love can see us through-regardless. For any and all support that comes our way ; We thank you, We respect you , We are forever grateful to you. Ceili HeffernanFor all those who have graciously donated we wanted to let you know that we have made arrangements with my Aunt Gayle to receive the funds into her bank account on our behalf. She will then be able to ensure that we can then directly receive the money from her.  Because we are in the USA and this campaign was set up in the USA, only an American citizen with a bank account and residential address here can be set up to receive and withdraw from the Go fund me campaign. Of course we trust Aunt Gayle implicitly and will now be able to start using the money you have all sent us to start paying for our accommodation, food, transport, fees for our visas (to allow us to remain here for treatment), travel to obtain our visas, continued care for our son Dylan, and all the various costs arising due to Kens medical treatment. Kens doctor at Memorial Sloan Ketterin - Dr. Sharokni - has requested further scans to be done before a final decision is made on his complete treatment regime. We see him again on July 16th. This is when we will have a better picture of what's ahead. For now, Ken is doing ok. Managing symptoms with medication and we are finding moments to laugh in each day. Ken and I are both positive and are focused only on getting him better so we can get back home. Our baby boy is being flown back home tomorrow. We are distraught but know that it is the best decision for Dylan. This is no environment for him. He will be back at nursery next week and will hopefully find comfort in the familiar, even without us being there. We still do not know how long we will be here in the US, but the strain and fear of our lives being thrown into limbo, income for our family being effected during this time and the sudden increase of costs of all sorts; has been made bearable by the kindness, compassion and understanding of so many of our friends, family and even strangers. There is a lot of love in this world and its at times like these when it really shines. Much love Ceili & Ken

title: #livelikelefty
text: On March 4th 2018, Lefty-David Snyder suffered a brain aneurysm that ruptured three times, requiring three emergency surgical procedures. It is because of the swift and loving actions of his incredible family in those scary moments that Lefty made it to the hospital safely and timely, where he is now fighting hard for his life. He is a true miracle, and is defying the odds every minute. This is the beginning of a long road for the Snyder family, and this page has been set up for anyone wishing to aide them with medical costs during this extremely difficult time. #livelikelefty is more than a hashtag, it's a movement. When you live like lefty, you're creating a more selfless and compassionate place for all.Thank you deeply for your generosity.For more information and updates regarding Lefty's miraculous  progress, please follow the Facebook group #livelikelefty. https://www.facebook.com/groups/2021238414870098/#livelikelefty￼￼

title: support for Melissa
text: They say there are Angels among us on earth.  I know this to be true because Melissa Lannert is one of them.  Melissa is the most kind, loving, giving most of all selfless person I have ever met.  Always her first words would be what do you need and how can I help.  Now its our turn to show our love and appreciation of such an amazing woman.  Her family, friends and job responsibilities come first even during this extreme health battle, she still puts everyone before herself.Three months ago in a heartbeat her world was turned upside down, she was diagnosed with Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia-Philadelphia Positive .  I know for me it took my breath away that within 24hrs of "not feeling well" to a Leukemia diagnosis.  Melissa is the strongest person I know and will never ask anyone for help.  There is always a smile on her face.  Her main goal now is to fight this disease and recover.  Her bone marrow transplant will be the week of August 13th.  Her amazing sister was a perfect match!Let's work together to help remove some of the financial burden so Melissa can just concentrate on a full recovery.  Any donation will help but most important please keep Melissa and her family in your prayers.She is truly the meaning of "Life is Beautiful"

title: Fundraiser for Joe Louis Allen Jr.
text:
JOE ALLEN JR, NEEDS OUR HELP. This past Saturday night July 21, in George, Washington at the music     venue the Gorge our friend Joe was the victim of a malicious attack.    Near the end of the second set of music a man assaulted Joe with a rock to the back of his head then disappeared into the crowd.  Joe was rushed to a local medical facility where he had to have pressure relieved from the swelling in his brain.  


Luckily Joe is still with us, but his road to recovery will not be easy. Joe has nine staples in the back of his head from the wound.  Joe is still experiencing numbness in his hands and has not yet regained the ability to walk on his own. He has a fractured skull, and he needs to do a lot of rehab at a neurological facility.  As you can imagine all of this adds up and anything we can do as a community to help Joe would be greatly appreciated.  Joe is a wonderful person and loving father of four.  Its been my pleasure in life to have known him for the last 35 years and I cant wait till we are dancing together again.  Please help get our brother back on his feet.  Joe is currently recovering at Confluence Hospital in Wenatchee Wa. **-**Update Wednesday July 25 10;54 am est.**-**I spoke with Joe just moments ago as he is preparing to go into surgery this morning. They need to clear some room in his spine so that information can begin to move.  Their hope is that the pains he is feeling will subside and this will help with some of his motor functions.  I will post more when he is out of surgery and I have spoken with him again. 


Joe wanted me to thank everyone for their kindness he definitely feels the love.

title: Emma Medlin Medical Fund
text: From Nathaniel: The pediatric surgeon has been in contact with numerous doctors and the consensus is that Emma has a malignant Neuroblastoma in her abdomen. It is about 10cm by 7cm and is pressing on her major blood vessels and organs. We just found out that they will be airlifting us to St. Jude and that a biopsy is likely not even necessary as they will go straight to radiation/chemotherapy. This is the beginning of a very long process, so please continue to lift us up in prayer; especially little Emma."Please help Amy & Nathaniel with financial gifts and prayers as they go through this difficult time with Emma.If you wish to donate directly, you can contact Ronnie Medlin (go fund me will not let me post a phone number.) You can also drop off donations at Auburn Ave Presbyterian Church by contacting Mrs. Peacock at (318) three two three- three zero six one.

title: Emergency Medical Funds for Tom
text: Tom Braak is a missionary who founded the nonprofit organization Faith in Action International in Verrettes, Haiti back in 1997. On March 3rd, 2018, Tom was in a serious vehicular accident involving a Tap-Tap while transporting trees for his nursery with his 9 year old son, Ryan. He is currently in a Port-au-Prince ICU. As of right now, we know that he has suffered at least one collapsed lung, brain hematoma, a fractured pelvis and ribs, as well as a mass or hernia in his groin. He has been mostly unconscious thus far. In order to get the medical attention he needs, he will have to be transported via MedEvac to Miami, Florida, which will cost upwards of $20,000. His family and friends are doing everything they can in the given circumstances, but this is a traumatic experience for everyone involved. Please consider contributing to Tom's medical expenses as well as praying for healing and comfort for his wife Ficilta and son Ryan who will remain in Verrettes. Thank you from the bottom of our hearts.Check out  http://www.faithinactionint.org/ to learn more about Tom's nonprofit organization in Haiti.

title: Sharon Swanson Needs Our Help!
