text: As you all know, Sharon was given 6 weeks to live 18 months ago. She has fought cancer on every front like a warrior. Your generous donations have helped so much and the entire family is eternally grateful! She has run the race hard and needs our help again. She needs a procedure that is only offered in Mexico. Without our help, she won't be able to afford it because it needs to be paid for up front.  Let's rally to help this amazing, inspirational, loving, giving woman get to the finish line.Her daughter Haven wrote the following to give you more info:18 months after the initial diagnosis of my mom, she is still working 30 hour weeks at her desk, taking medications, attempting to stay healthy, visiting various doctors, and keeping a smile on her face as a walking miracle. It’s taken a toll on her body. The thing is, now her oncologist wants her to go through chemotherapy, which would have killed her last January before her 6-week prognosis. Exhaustion and pain keep her awake at night and tired during the day. She is anemic again despite blood infusions, and it’s nearly impossible to keep her on a diet that is both healthy and helps her gain weight. The next step is to achieve the goal Mom has had for a long while but never decided to pursue because of the cost—the Sanoviv clinic in Mexico. With aggressive and holistic treatments that are unavailable in the US, Sanoviv has a program to rebuild Mom and give her a future. However, that future costs $30,000, which is the same price as chemotherapy. The past year of medical bills, a college student, and regular life has left us searching for the money on trees. The donations here would be used to send my mom to the clinic in Mexico where she can taste the life we want her to have. She has come so far and I can’t stand the thought of not being able to give her this chance.  The support from our family and friends means more than I could ever convey.Sanoviv offers an abundant field of alternative, holistic and integrative breast cancer treatment options. They look at everything about a person - Mind, Body and Spirit. Their program is tailored to the individual and the objective is for the body to support its own defenses, weaken cancer cells, detoxify the body, and improve  overall well being.More info can be found at  http://www.sanoviv.com/health-concern/health-concern-alternative-breast-cancer-treatment

title: Help the Schafer Family!
text: Dennis Schafer is a long time Paramedic for AMR in Clark County Washington. Dennis has been serving his community for years and now it is time that we rally behind and support he and his family in their time of need. Dennis's 11 year old daughter, Sophia, was found to have a tumor on her kidney and it was scheduled to be removed on May 30th 2018. During the 7.5hr surgery the surgeons found that the tumor was not only attached to Sophia's kidney but had started to attach to her liver. The surgery resulted in major bleeding and the doctors have had difficulty getting her H&H and INR to appropriate levels, despite massive transfusion. Sophia, currently is at a local hospital in the ICU intubated. Once her blood levels are at a safe level she faces chemotherapy and radiation to stop the progression of the cancer.If this blow to the Schafer family was not enough they were in the process of building their dream home in Woodland. Dennis has been working full-time on the ambulance and nights building his house, on his days off from the ambulance he has spent the time working on the house. Now with Sophia's life in the hands of the surgeons, a half built house that has come to a halt, and time away from work they need our help more than ever. Please take a moment to donate any amount you can. If you are an AMR employee and can donate in the way of PTO, meals, or have experience with construction please contact me via my work email, phone or through the gofundme site. As you can imagine the Schafer Family is concentrating on the recovery of their daughter and deserves as much privacy as we can afford them. Thank you for your consideration.Thank you very much!

title: Help Gabe
text: This past year has been extremely painful for Gabe. He has traveled in and out of doctors offices, hospitals and labs trying to identify the source of the pain that has stopped him from living a normal day-to-day life.On December 29, 2017, Gabe was diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia. Since then it has been a roller coaster of emotional and medical events, as well as headaches with the insurance company. Gabe’s insurance will cover some of his treatment costs but with deductibles and non-covered costs, he desperately needs financial support in order to move forward with continuing treatment. Gabe has been through several different kinds of chemo treatments over the last six months but each time the aggressive disease has relapsed.  This cancer is so insidious and aggressive that it only takes one leukemia cell to take off like a wild fire to end his fight.His last hope is the continuing treatment of Chemotherapy and Immunotherapy and then a Stem Cell Transplant. This rigorous and persistent long-term treatment is essential for his survival. The doctors are estimating that he will need to be on this track for the next two years, but without this treatment, his cancer could kill him in matter of weeks or months. Gabe urgently needs your financial help to continue his treatment. Please help by donating now and share this Go Fund Me campaign with everyone you know.Any donation at this point, would be greatly appreciated.Thank you in advance for helping to save a life!

title: Tracey and John Pucci
text: It is much sadness that I have to report that Tracey Pucci the Wife of John Pucci lost her battle with Cancer today 6/21/2018.  John was by Tracey's side during her final hours.  Tracey was loved by so many but not as much as the Love John and their Daughters Gianna and Rayna had for a Wife and Mother.  This fund was set up to help John and Tracey finance the continued Cancer Treatment Tracey needed so much.  I'm continuing this page to now Help John and the Girls to deal with the huge financial burden that will be in their future.  I have spoke with John and all money raised will go towards helping pay for Tracey's Medical and Funeral expenses.  Anything left over will be placed in a fund to help Both girls with their future education expenses.  John wanted me to thank everyone for their Love and Support and he will be sending me a personal message from him and the Girls in the next few days that I will Post as an update.  Thank you to everyone that has showed the entire Pucci Family the Love and Support that has been so generously displayed.John, Gianna and Rayna will need everyone's continued Love and Support during this difficult time.  John wanted me to pass his thanks to everyone that has called or texted him over the past few days, and that he is sorry if he has been unable to take your call or respond to your text due to the circumstances. Again on behalf of the entire Pucci Family, his Friends and Co-Workers we thank you for all the support that has been displayed.  Let's keep John, Gianna and Rayna and their entire Family in our Thoughts and Prayers.Details for the Arrangement and Service for Tracey will be posted once they are finalized.

title: Help Tanner Get Back on his Feet
text: On Wed March 28th Tanner had a tragic Rock Climbing accident that resulted in several injuries one of which is Lower Body Paralysis. Tanners success of  becoming self sufficient and or walking again hinges on a lengthy and costly rehabilitation process. While insurance and some other alternatives may satisfy some of the cost,  it won’t nearly be enough to accomplish what needs to happen.  Tanners has the frame of mind to beat this and overcome the challenges that he faces. For those of you that know him, understand what we are talking about. He’s the strongest person we know, both mentally and physically and has a passion for being healthy and in shape. It’s because of these characteristics that we feel optimistic that a positive outcome is on our side. It may be a miracle but our biggest hope and dream is to see Tanner up on his feet again.Love the Cislaw Family

title: Stand with Officer Ron Gately
text: Thank you for coming to support Ron. Our friend and brother Officer Ron Gately has recently been diagnosed with cancer. As we all know, these types of illnesses come with hefty medical expenses and we are here to stand with Ron and his family throughout this ordeal. Ron has trained thousands of police officers throughout the Commonwealth; now is our chance to give back. Individual donations are great, but please also bring this to your departments and unions. Feel free to pass this on to as many people as you can. Thank you.

title: Join Christie's Fight
text: On March 7, 2018, our sweet Christie Alvarez found out she was about to embark in the fight of her life. Christie was diagnosed with a rare form of cancer called Adrenal Cortical Carcinoma (ACC). It is in its 4th stage of progression and we urgently need to get her to an ACC specialist in order to find out what her next steps and options are. Initial medical expenses will be in tens of thousands. This does not include follow up medical expenses such as additional tests, travel or lodging or loss of wages. These costs will add up very quickly if she needs to see more than one specialist.  We DESPERATELY need your help to raise these funds ASAP, as time is not on our side. Our goal is to raise this amount in 2 weeks so Christie can get the help she needs as soon as possible. She is a mother to a daughter and three young sons, as well as a loving wife, sister, cousin, aunt and friend to so many. Whatever you can spare, we would be so incredibly grateful...  https://www.gofundme.com/joinchristiesfightFrom the bottom of all of our hearts,THANK YOU! <3Christie's Family_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ About Adrenal cortical carcinoma (ACC):ACC is a rare disease. It is caused by a cancerous growth in the adrenal cortex, which is the outer layer of the adrenal glands. ... ACC is also known as adrenocortical carcinoma. The adrenal cortex makes hormones that regulate metabolism and blood pressure.

title: Charlie Anne Matthews Fund
text: 8/10/18Charlie is currently in the hospital but planning to go home this Saturday. As long as she has no infections she will be home till mid September. Then she will be re-admitted for her stem cell transplant and round 4 of chemo. She has been stuck in her room the past couple weeks and will be again when she has to go back....so they have had to be really creative to keep her entertained.  They also had a repeat head MRI last week and saw no tumor!!! Please keep praying!7/5/18charlie is still in the hospital. The infection is clearing and today they did the first step of her stem cell transplant. They got great news that they may be able to go home for the weekend! Next round of chemo will start Monday.Updated 6/29/18The Matthews found out today that they are going to have to stay inpatient at the hospital for the next 3-4 weeks.  Charlie is on IV antibiotics that she will need for about a week.  After that they will be harvesting her stem cells, followed by 2 more weeks of chemo.  So they will be splitting their time to be with Charlie 24/7.  How you can help over this next difficult month:1. Visit them IF YOU ARE HEALTHY!  They love visitors to break up the day!2. If you are signed up for the meal train....it would be best for them to get prepared/hot food before (or close to) 5pm.  That way one of them can pick it up and bring it back to the hospital before Charlie goes to bed (you can also text Shelly and arrange to deliver it to the hospital, or you can have uber eats deliver it there...you would just have to let shelly know when to run down to pick it up from the uber driver. 3.  Donate:)4.  Let Shelly know if you (or someone you know) has breast milk that you can donate. Updated 6/27/18charlie got admitted yesterday to treat fever and  listlessness. They gave her some blood last night and she is doing much better today. They hope to be discharged after 48 hours. Please keep your prayers up! Updated 6/20/18The Matthews are home! Charlie completed round one of chemo like a champ! Everyone at the hospital was shocked at how well she handled it.  Been a little hard  for the whole family...living at the hospital with a new born, so they are so happy to be home for a week or so with the dogs and in their own beds. When Charlie’s labs look right they will be re-admitted to collect stem cells. They collect them no to use during later chemo infusions. Updated 6/14/18Charlie was admitted to hospital this week to start her chemo treatments.  They did some more testing and confirmed that she does not have cancer cells in her spinal cord!  This was great news.  She had her first dose of chemotherapy last night and is tolerating it well.  They plan to keep her in the hospital to continue this round of chemo until the end of the week.  Then she should be able to return home and do some treatments out-patient.  The plan is that every couple of months she will have to be admitted for the more intense chemo rounds.They are still waiting on the final pathology and genome results.   It will likely be several weeks before we know more, but regardless of the results the treatments for now are the same.  Back story:In late May, Charlie became sick and appeared to have an ear infection. She was seen again by her doctors when she became unsteady on her feet. After some studies, it was found that she had a brain tumor. She was immediately transferred to Rady Children's Hospital's PICU where the doctors  quickly removed the tumor and later determined it was cancerous.  Although we still don’t have the specifics, we are sure that Charlie has a long road of chemotherapy ahead of her in which she will be admitted to the hospital on and off over the next year or so. A week after her surgery, Charlie and her parents welcomed her baby brother Noland into the world.  He was born on May 29th and was a healthy 8 pounds 1 oz.  Noland is doing well, he is a good eater and sleeper.  This fund was set up to help with medical costs, travel costs, babysitting fees, house maintenance and basically anything that will help ease the stress for the Matthews family.  Our goal is to raise enough money so that Shelly does not have to go back to work until Charlie's 9months-1 year of treatments are over.  Many people have already donated directly to the Matthews. Blake and Shelly are beyond appreciative of everyone’s generosity. They have used some of what they have gotten so far to bank the baby’s stem cells as a possible therapy for Charlie. In addition to donations, you can sign up to deliver food to them here:  https://www.mealtrain.com/trains/8dye75 Please help pass along this information to friends and family.Save

title: Let Us Help Carl Anderson
text: Our friend and leader at Delta Air Lines  is going through some significant and life threatening health issues.  Carl was admitted to the hospital in mid June after an abnormal CATH procedure that showed his heart beating at a very weak rate. His heart wasn't pumping blood through his body strong enough.  He was given a IV medication to help his heart to pump stronger.  The medication is meant to stabilize the congestive heart failure.  Carl will need to have a heart transplant due to the weak condition and function of his heart.  Carl was recently transferred from Piedmont Hospital to Emory due to their Center of Excellence status.  He had his first appointment with his new cardiologist on 7/18.  He will undergo multiple evaluations soon for the  transplant procedure.   This procedure and other miscellaneous cost will be significant as his family faces this challenge over the course of his treatments.  UHC has a great program in place that will cover the transplant procedure after his personal deductible is met.  However, there are several other out of pocket costs that his family will experience throughout this journey, and your financial assistance is certainly appreciated.   Carl is supported by his wife of 14 years Felicia and four kids: Caitlyn (13), Carl Jr. (11), Christa (9), and Camren (8).  Carl is the Manager of Employee Recognition at Delta in Atlanta.  He started his career as a Ready Reserve agent in Huntsville, Alabama, and  worked his way through 7 different cities, including managing the Norfolk, Birmingham and Cincinnati stations, before being selected to lead the employee recognition team in Atlanta.  He has directly touched many Delta employees, recognizing the many great faces of Delta and helping to make it the great place it is today.    I hope you will join with me to help a dear friend and colleague!

title: Alayne Fedewa Road to Recovery Fund
text: Four-year-old Alayne was recently diagnosed with Leukemia and now faces a long road to recovery. This diagnosis is both emotionally and financially draining for the Fedewa family. We are aiming to help ease some of this financial burden with this gofundme campaign for Alayne.For those who don’t know Alayne, she is a super-smart-almost-5-year-old that is adored by her classmates. She loves to make people laugh with her playful sense of humor and good hearted nature.The chemotherapy treatment she needs to survive this illness will weaken her immune system making it impossible to safely attend school with the other kids in her class. In order to continue to foster her love for learning and allow her parents to return to work (maintaining the income and insurance coverage necessary to provide her treatment), she will need to be homeschooled for the next 6-8 months.Our goal is to raise $35,000. Out of this amount, $25,600 will be used for Alayne’s home school expense. The remainder of the funds will help cover her parent’s unpaid time off from work. With Alayne’s frequent appointments this will be needed so that Peter or Claire could be there with Alayne. And if there are any residual funds remaining it will go towards the out of pocket medical expense that Alayne’s health insurance doesn’t cover. Please help support the Fedewa family and Alayne in this difficult time by being part of this campaign. Thank you so much for allowing Alayne to not fall behind her classmates while she is going through recovery. For the purpose of full disclosure we would like to share that Alayne, Claire and Peter are the sole beneficiaries of this campaign. Donors will not receive anything in return for their donations, this includes Brian Forstat the creator of this campaign.

title: Jan Babendererde
text: Jan  crashed his dirt bike on Sunday the 25th of March. Jan was then air lifted to Wenatchee hospital with a spinal injury. They removed the back half of c2-c5 to alleviate pressure on the spinal cord. Jan faces a long and hard recovery, with many expenses.  Jan and Kris are some of the most giving people on the planet.  It is time for us to give back.  Even the smallest amount helps, it all adds up.  Please pray and think positive for Jan's recovery. As Jan told the nurse, He is 10ft tall and bulletproof

title: CARING FOR CARSON
text: Our sweet baby Carson has brain cancer and I'm asking for your help... Carson's Story... On July 23rd 2018 we had no idea that our lives were about to change forever with my 5 month old nephew, Carson Barnhart.   On this day he woke up from his nap very irritable and vomiting. Two days later he was diagnosed with a brain tumor which was removed surgically on the 27th. He was looking amazing and recovering well, we were all extremely optimistic that this would be the end of his horrifying ordeal. Unfortunately we were very wrong, on August 1st we heard the devastating news, the pathology results came back as congenital glioblastoma, this type of brain tumor is aggressive and malignant and Carson will need to begin chemotherapy sometime in mid-August and this will be on going. I can't even comprehend how this little guy went through brain surgery and his fight has only just begun. He will be spending a lot of time in and out of the hospital trying to fight this horrible disease, but I'm hopeful that he's able to receive the best treatment necessary to help him. On behalf of our family , we are trying to give his parents, Jeff and Kelly, one less thing to worry about by providing some financial assistance during such a difficult time. Carson is going to be fighting a battle for his life and I'm asking for your support, there is no amount too small or too large and any amount will be helpful and appreciated to alleviate their worries. Kelly will be out of work during this time for the treatment of Carson. I just want them to focus on their son's health and not worry about anything else at this time...  We are tremendously grateful for all of your prayers, love, and support. Please continue, this is going to be a long road ahead of them.Thank you in advance... Lori Barnhart ￼ ￼ ￼ ￼￼￼￼￼

title: We love you, Tina!
text: Tina Kutsuma is the heart and soul of the University of Colorado Radiology residency program.  She has mothered, mentored, shepherded, and cajoled over 100 radiologists through the program.  Her dedication, kindness, and fierce loyalty to all CU Radiology residents and faculty is legendary.  As a tribute to her contributions, please consider donating generously, to help with medical costs and retirement.

title: Mark Farmer
text:
Mark is a middle school teacher who has recently been diagnosed with Metastatic Malignant Melanoma. The cancer has spread throughout his body including his bones, liver, and lungs. Mark has stopped working in order to seek treatment. We are looking to raise money for Mark and his family as travel expenses, medical bills, prescription costs, and the cost of everyday living is becoming overwhelming. Due to the severity of this disease, time is of the essence. Mark and his family should not have to worry about money, rather their efforts need to be focused on his treatment and spending time together.Mark has dedicated much of his life to teaching and working with children, whether in the classroom, as a coach or as a camp counselor at the YMCA. It is time for us to give back to Mark!In addition to this GoFundMe account, there are also local fundraising efforts taking place.

There will be a Daddy Daughter Benefit Dance on Sunday, April 29, 2018 from 4-7PM at Arcadia High School (8210 Lankford Hwy, Oak Hall, VA 23416). Tickets are $25 a couple. There will be a Grand March for all fathers and their daughters at 4:30PM. Cost to watch the Grand March is $5. Snacks and Drinks will be available.

title: Silvia's Breast Cancer Fund
text: Silvia Smith is the kindest, most loving soul you will ever be lucky enough to know.  The moment Silvia openly shared that she had been diagnosed with breast cancer stage III A, and needed a double mastectomy and ongoing treatment, I knew that her loving community of family and friends would rally around her to support her in every way possible.  Silvia needs our help now, and I ask you to please donate to this GoFundMe campaign set up for the massive medical expenses she now faces. Silvia is a Montessori teacher and has been making a difference in the lives of children for the past 25 years.   Each morning, she greets the children with a smile and a hug; she shares with them a sense of peaceful joy and a love of learning and appreciation of nature. Each parent who leaves their child in her hands, walks away knowing that child is in the safest, most loving environment in existence.  We trust Silvia with the lives of our children because of her steadfast positivity, her radiating light, and the fact that she will do anything and everything for those in her care.   And now Silvia must trust in us, her community, the ones who love her most, who are filled with gratitude for all she has done for our children,  to help her fight the battle of her life.  Please donate today. Your donations will go toward the cost of Silvia's medical care and her medications.  As you might know, cancer treatment is incredibly expensive, even with insurance coverage.  She needs our help in order to pay for the treatment she has already received, as well as the continued treatment she will need this year.  Silvia is committed to living a healthy life, and doing everything she can to continue down the road of recovery.  Silvia is facing this challenge with positivity and strength, and has the support of her wonderful children, David and Rachael, her brother Emil, her parents, and the loving Smith family. This Go Fund Me campaign in honor of Silvia, is our opportunity to support her and show her just how much she has impacted our lives, and the lives of our children.  Please donate today, and share this campaign with five other people in your life who might be able to help us create a fund for this amazing human.If you do not know Silvia, but perhaps have been sent this GoFundMe campaign from someone who loves her, I invite you to please contribute, even a small amount.  We need more angels on this earth like Silvia.  And we need your help.

title: Palm Khunsri Fund
text: In the early morning of Sunday, April 29th, Palm Khunsri was hit by a drunk driver and suffered a Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI.) Palm, his family and friends spent the next three weeks in the Trauma ICU at Loyola Medical Center. Palm did everything he was supposed to do to remain safe on the night of his accident, however, his life was still put in jeopardy. Palm went to a concert but did not drink, because he was driving. Luckily, he survived the accident but needs extensive rehabilitation. Currently, Palm is receiving medical care and starting rehabilitation at the Shirley Ryan AbilityLab (formally RIC). Between his own strong will and the undying support of his friends and family, he is slowly coming back to us.Palm is a kind, funny, incredibly insightful and spiritual 21-year-old who came to the US from Thailand ten years ago and is currently studying nursing. He is well liked and simply an extraordinary young man! We predict several months of intense work at AbilityLab. Palm's road to recovery will be long and difficult. The physical, emotional and financial burden is immense. We want to ease the burden on Palm’s mother, Neung (Sopha Khunsri), and his stepfather, Tom Rostowski, who are completely focused on Palm's full recovery.  Your donations will go to help with massive medical and rehab bills. You can help by giving Palm and his family the support they truly deserve!

title: Quadriplegic Mike needs a FES Bike
text: On New Year's Eve night Michael Cheeseman's life changed forever.  As we were ringing in 2018 with friends and family, Michael was being pulled out of the ocean after an innocent evening swim ended tragically. He shattered his C5 vertebrae and is now a quadriplegic.  The injury was complete and catastrophic and he is left with limited movement in his arms and has no movement from the chest down.This vibrant young 16 year old boy is now in the fight of his life to regain as much mobility and independence as possible.  Michael's doctors and therapists have both recommended that he have an in-home therapy system to help him achieve his goals.  The price of the FES therapy bike is not covered by insurance and will cost upwards of $30,000. The FES Bike will help keep his muscles moving and give him the hope and strength to push forward in his recovery.  https://www.fescycling.com/what-is-fescycling/My Goal is to raise $30,000 for his Mom so she can                                "Get MIKE his BIKE"please share with your friends

title: Hospital bills for Patrick
text: At 2:35AM on August 27th the van that Patrick was riding in on tour was hit,taking the life of our friend Colin and puting Patrick into a coma. Patrick is currently in a kaiser hospital and doesn’t have Insurence through them which will cost a fortune in medical bills.  we created this gofundme to help with the medical cost and support his family through this hard time. Let’s come together and do what we can to get this father of two back home.  Anything you can donate will be appreciated.  https://www.abc10.com/mobile/article/news/local/elk-grove/update-victim-in-deadly-i-5-crash-identified-woman-arrested-on-suspicion-of-dui/103-

title: Kiera’s Miracle Surgery!
text: My name is Sheena Edwick and I have created this GoFundMe campaign for my niece Kiera Ciddio. She is in need of our support and prayers. Kiera is an amazing 8 year old little girl, and overall beautiful human being. She truly touches the lives of everyone she comes across. She is the kid that can make anyone smile or laugh even on their worst day. She just has a way of drawing you in with her beautiful personality. She loves school, reading, competing in chess tournaments, Jiu Jitsu, writing books, yarn crafting and making messes! In 2011, Kiera was diagnosed with a Cerebral Cavernous Malformation (CCM). Due to a bleed in her brain, she lost feeling and the use of her lower left leg and foot overnight. At the time, surgery to remove the CCM was not an option. Based on the location of the CCM lesion, the surgery presented too many risks. After 3 months of physical therapy, hard work, and with the help of AFO braces (zoom shoes as she called them) to support her lower leg and foot, she was up and walking again. Her parents Jude and Aundrea Ciddio were blessed with several years of primarily focusing on strengthening her left leg and foot, and picking new colors for her zoom shoes of course.Unfortunately, by late 2016 she started having what she referred to as “tingles” in her left leg. By the spring of 2017 these “tingles” progressed to her leg falling asleep, and were later diagnosed as seizures. The seizures began to cause her to fall several times a day. One day at school, she experienced a seizure which caused a severe fall. She ended up with two black eyes and a huge bruise on her forehead. By the end of April 2017 and into May, she was only able to attend school for a few hours a day, and had to be escorted by mom or dad. By the end of June the seizures were increasing and nothing was helping. At the end of June, Kiera had her first overnight stay at UNM Hospital. After speaking with doctors, adjusting medication, etc., the seizures continued to get worse. They were not only happening 6-12 times during the day, but began occurring at night and disrupting her sleep. Anytime she would fall asleep she would be awoken by a seizure. After feeling helpless and scared for months, the family ended up at the ER for the 3rd time in a 10 day period. Kiera got to the point where she could not sleep without having seizure after seizure. The medication she was given was not helping with the severity or occurrence of the seizures. Kiera was finally admitted at UNM Hospital. Her seizures were so bad that an attempt for an MRI was unsuccessful. Instead, they had to do two CT scans. The results displayed signs of another bleed which was believed to be the cause of the seizures. They spent that night in the Pediatric Intensive Care Unit with little information as to why. They later found out she was so sedated there was risk and concern for respiratory issues; it was a long night to say the least. They spoke to the head of pediatric neurology, the neurosurgeon and various pediatric doctors who wanted to load her with antiepileptic drugs to try and break the seizures, while also discussing surgery to remove the CCM as well as associated risks. After 10 days at UNM, with seizures peaking at 50 per night, they finally made the decision to go home. They were not making progress at the hospital and the more drugs she was loaded with, the worse the side effects became. They were sure that surgery was going to be the only option. They prayed and hoped if they could just get home, maybe they could get her calm in her own element and get some rest before scheduling surgery. Our prayers were answered, and she was seizure free for over 5 months.At the end of December 2017, her “tingles” started to return and they tried to do all they could with medication to get ahead of it, but they are getting worse. After countless hours of research, Aundrea reached out to two neurosurgeons; one in Chicago and one in Colorado. She was able to schedule an appointment at the University of Chicago Medicine earlier this month. We have faith in this CCM specialist as he has done numerous surgeries. Kiera’s first airplane ride and out of state vacation was to fly out for advanced testing with a CCM specialist. After speaking with the doctor, it is now clear that medication is not going to be the answer and surgery is needed in order to control the seizures and give Kiera a better quality of life. So, in the next 60 days or so, Kiera will take her second plane ride to Chicago to have brain surgery and remove the CCM. Kiera, Aundrea, and Jude are expected to be in Chicago for at least two weeks. As you can imagine the cost of surgery, travel, housing, and time away from work is tremendous. At this time, they are not quite sure what kind of post-surgery rehab, medical costs, and follow-up appointments will be needed. Anyone that knows my sister and brother in-law, know that they are very private and asking for help is totally out of their element. No one wants to see their child sick or in pain, and when you add exorbitant medical costs to the mix, the situation can be extremely distressing. With that said, they need our help and prayers. I am asking from the bottom of my heart, please help my niece. She has her whole life ahead of her, and deserves a chance at a normal life. Thank you so much for your help, it is appreciated more than you know!

title: Lane Bailey Needs Our Help
text: If you know Lane Bailey, you're lucky. He's a man that truly knows no bounds to his love and nurturing.  He's loyal, he's brilliant, he's stoic, he's gentle, he's generous. Lane has dedicated his life to serving the people.  To serving the state of West Virginia.  But what you may not know, because he's kept it under wraps, is that he's dying. After struggling for almost a year+ to figure out exactly what was going on with Lane, he was finally diagnosed with MSA-C (Multiple Systems Atrophy), a rare form of Parkinson's affecting between 15,000 - 50,000 Americans. They aren't even 100% sure how to treat it as it doesn't respond to most forms of Parkinson's treatment.The list of hospital stays, procedures, treatments, and drugs is over a mile long.  He's been in ICU and on life support multiple times over the past 12 months, along with two extended stays in a rehab facility.  Lane is no longer mobile and wheelchair bound due to the MSA taking over his balance and coordination (the disease will eventually take over all motor function).  While he can get up from the chair to shuffle to another chair a few feet away, anything more will cause him to take a spill and result in injury.  The number of falls recently, resulting in blood and cuts and bruises, are too many to mention.  Lane has had to undergo a tracheotomy so that he can breath and eat normally, which comes with so many issues of its own (prone to pneumonia, fluid in the lungs, and extensive care). While he still has his voice and is finally able to breath on his own, it has been an uphill battle to get to this point.  Lane can no longer do anything on his own.  He has to have assistance for everything, and we mean EVERYTHING - from the minute he wakes up, until he goes to bed he requires assistance.  From getting dressed, to using the restroom, getting in/out of the bed, taking a shower, getting to/from the car, you name it.  All the things we take for granted, those normal everyday things, he needs help with.  If you know him, you know this is crushing his soul.  This man, this tall, wonderful, joyous man is no longer joyous.  His body is quitting on him and it is so unfair. So so unfair.  He knows he's dying, he knows there is still such a long road ahead, and he knows there isn't a thing he can do about it.  It cannot be stopped, there is no way to stop it. No treatments, no medicine, nothing.  It's just going to get worse.  The medical bills are out of control - currently ticking in at well over $50,000 not covered by any insurance.  The sheer amount of funds needed to help someone who is wheelchair bound is staggering - a new van had to be purchased, ramps for the house, retrofitting the bed and the bathroom to be handicap accessible, everything.  The cost of all of Lane's medicine is INSANE, costing he and Sharon over $2,000/month out of pocket (in addition to what is covered by Medicare).  The bills...the bills just won't stop.  His wife, who has dedicated her life to their family, must care for him 24/7, so she can't even take on work  And the system, the system he has worked so tirelessly to defend, can't help him.  So if you know Lane Bailey, you know this treasure of a human is sad.  He's defeated, he's lost, he's suffering, he's depressed, he and his wife are in a serious financial bind, and neither Lane or Sharon see light at this end of this tunnel.  Any help you could provide would be beyond generous of you and so appreciated it won't even be able to be expressed appropriately.  We don't know what else to do.  He and Sharon don't even know we're asking (and are most likely going to be mad when they find out). We don't know how to pay for all of this or even how to sustain it moving forward. It's awful, just so awful. Thank you for even taking the time to read his story and for even considering donating your hard earned money to this man. Just thank you.  All our Love,Megan (Lane's daughter-in-law), Andrew (Lane's son), Waverly & Bexley (Lane's special granddaughters).----------------------------------------For More Information on MSA: https://www.ninds.nih.gov/Disorders/Patient-Caregiver-Education/Fact-Sheets/Multiple-System-AtrophyTo Donate to the MSA Coalition:  https://www.multiplesystematrophy.org

title: Bristell Andrews
text: As many of you know 6 month old Bristell Andrews was diagnosed with Acute Myelogenous Leukemia (AML) on 4/22/18.  The Andrews family will need support as they begin this journey. Please help us in taking some stress away by helping them out with finances so that Kaylie and Russell can focus all their energy on sweet Bristell! We know that the Lord holds this precious family in the palm of his hands. Please continue to lift them, their family, and their medical team up in prayer as we join together to fight this disease!

title: Help My Dad Beat Leukemia
text: Hi, my name’s Meli Grant, and my dad, Michael, is fighting Leukemia. Basically he has cancer in his bone marrow. It’s called AML, or Acute Myeloid Leukemia. It started as MDS (Myelodysplastic Syndrome), which means that he has multiple chromosome abnormalities and as a result his bone marrow doesn’t produce cells properly. It results in a dangerously low blood count (super low energy), low platelets (he bleeds and bruises easily, and doesn’t heal well), and low white counts (most of us know what that means, but basically little things our bodies are really good at protecting us from can be a life or death situation for him). Ultimately, if untreated, it means losing my dad. Case and point, my dad spent nearly a month straight at Saint Francis Hospital on Long Island between their medical ICU and an isolated room where he’d be safe from infection after his cheek was hurting one night, and we discovered he had a fever over slices of pizza. Not exactly what we imagined life had in store for us when we ordered that night. At different intervals, he’s had a picc line in his arm, a port implanted in his chest, and the scariest one was a temporary line in the side of his neck that went straight to his heart so that he could receive blood and medicine in a timely manner. He spent multiple nights in an oxygen mask and when I wasn’t with him, I’d be home stress-drinking coffee until 5 in the morning. Happy we’re past that. Now for the good news. My dad has been very privileged to have fantastic healthcare courtesy of his job. He’s a high school teacher at Friends Academy, a Quaker private school on Long Island. He teaches stagecraft, working one on one with some amazing kids, and manages their theater. Before that he worked for over twenty years in professional theater in New York City. As a result of his great insurance, he’s had nearly everything covered thus far, and where we’ve run into unexpected bills, we’ve been able to challenge them and come out on top. The best news of all is that he’s in REMISSION!! We couldn’t be more grateful. So why is there a GoFundMe page then.Here’s the thing. He’s not cured until he’s had a stem cell transplant. This will involve another intense round of chemo, (another) full month in the hospital, and then two or three months more in a sterile environment somewhere within walking distance of the hospital (Memorial Sloan Kettering).Here’s where we’ve run into trouble.Housing is offered by MSK, but it’s very expensive. There’s a good chance we’ll have to pay up to $50,000, between housing and live-in aids. None of this is covered by insurance. This is how the numbers break down.     •       The housing option provided by the hospital works out to about $7500 a month. The social worker emphasized that some past patients have opted to rent a NYC apartment instead. ~$15000     •       He is required to have 24/7 supervision, in the event that something goes wrong, medical emergency or otherwise. This role can be filled by family members. That mostly comes down to me, but I live in Dallas and I’m already flying back and forth regularly for work. I’m going to be trying to fill as much of that time as I can. Hopefully as much as 50% of that time. Hiring an aid works out to about $25-30 an hour, 24 hours a day, which adds up in just a few months to: ~$20,000 - $30,000. If we are unable to meet this housing/supervision requirement, the hospital won’t do the procedure. We are expected to make a decision imminently, so we’re going forward with it, even if it means a lot of financial risk and instability. So the number above ($50,000) is a number that would take care of everything for us and provide us with some protection against unknowns. That would be incredible. What we are asking is if you want to donate to help us get through this, then whatever you donate would be welcome. No amount is too small. Any amount helps to reduce the financial burden and stress that it can cause my dad as he begins his new future cancer-free. If we hit our goal, we’re grateful, if we manage some of it, we’re grateful. And if we somehow wind up with more than we need, any excess will be donated to the hospitals that have taken such good care of him throughout this process, Saint Francis, Weill Cornell, Memorial Sloan Kettering. Thank you from the bottom of our hearts.

title: Stephanie Coltvet Erdmann
text: My sister in law Stephanie had been recovering at home from a routine surgery when she collapsed. After tests it was discovered that there was blockage in her hearts main artery. A stint was placed, but shortly after it became blocked again and Steph went into cardiac arrest. The amazing doctors worked to bring her back and she was placed on a heart and lung bypass machine. If this weren't enough, the CT scan showed that her fall at home had caused bleeding in the brain and this was now their first priority. The team at Abbott have been amazing, and we know Stephanie's fighting spirit will continue. Please help this family thru prayers, support or this donation page. We thank you all!

title: Caitlin Alexander Burcham
text: I'm Caitlin Alexander Burcham. I'm a married Moma of an 8 year old amazing boy, and an animation line producer, who has worked on many many wonderful animation shows for my entire 20 year career. I recently was diagnosed with Glioblastoma-a level 3-4 cancerous brain tumor. I had it surgically removed, and am now in radiation and chemo therapy, to heal from the disease. My financial goals now, are to continue to cover the insurance thats not covering all medication that I am required to take, and making sure I can receive all healing processes. I am also hoping that my 8 year old son is always taken care of- and covered through education, health and schooling for his future.My overall dream is to teach everyone about this disease. I want to let people know that I am here to recover for as long as possible, and help as many people as possible understand this new life.  I want the future to be filled with knowledge of loved ones, family members, and friends who go through things like this. Building community for everyone is so important to me, and to give back as much as possible while I am here-is my dream.

title: Thank Gene & Becky Columbus
text: Humanitarians. Benevolent. Beloved.Gene and Becky Columbus have touched us all. They have helped thousands of people personally and professionally, even responsible for some of our careers and marriages, but never asking for anything in return. Since last fall, they have been battling a tumor in Miss Becky’s brain. NOW IT IS TIME FOR ALL OF US TO HELP THEM.Healthcare coverage is complicated and expensive and sadly, their coverage does not fully cover the treatments Miss Becky needs. Contributing to this campaign with any amount, is one small way we can all say thank you. Gene & Becky humbly recognize that this is your money pledged to her treatment. To honor the intention of the GoFundMe campaign, and the commitment to their medical picture, they pledge 100% of your dollars to Dr. and hospital costs.Thank you in advance,Friends of Gene & Becky

title: Mendoza Care Fund
text: Thank you to everyone who has donated and those that are continuing to do so.  It is a huge comfort to Savannah to know that so many people loved (and still love) her husband and have wanted to contribute and support.  On Sunday evening my dear friend's husband suffered a traumatic injury affecting his brain.  He is currently on life support and hanging by a thread.  He is surrounded by his beloved family, friends, fellow coaches, players, and baseball community.  The road ahead is uncertain, but one thing to be sure is that hospital bills and all associated costs should be the last of his wife's concerns right now.  Please help by donating anything you can to offer relief.  Keep up the prayers and healing energy.

title: Help young Ukrainian with leukemia
text: I met Yarema (23) as part of one incredible smart and passionate team of developers, who never said 'no' or 'that's impossible. I had the pleasure to work with him for almost 3 years and I got to know him while visiting the team in Ukraine as well as his wife, Ievgeniia. They were and are madly in love, just got married and I have never seen such caring people, for each other as well as for all others around them....and most importantly as one of my team member, he always had my back. Now it is time for me to have his!!!I would like to share a letter, his wife (he calls her 'Wonder Women', which she truly is trying to do anything possible to save his life) send me, after I asked them how I can help.Hello,We are Ievgeniia and Yarema, a young family who got married two years ago. We had a lot of plans and dreams and one of the biggest was to become parents this year. But life had other plans: two months ago, in April 2018, Yarema was diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia.We live in Ukraine (Lviv city) and at present Yarema has a course of chemotherapy that gives good results. However, full recovery for Yarema is not possible without bone marrow transplant. Such operation cannot be done in Ukraine. We are hoping to have it in Polish clinic Maria Skłodowska-Curie Institute of Oncology in Gliwice town. The clinic has good statistics with such operations and also names lower prices comparing to other clinics in different countries. The transplant together with preparation and rehabilitation costs $200,000. This is the unaffordable sum of money for us and only your help can give us hope of recovery and returning to the normal life.I am writing this letter, because Yarema is incredibly important to me and I’m doing everything possible to save his life. I’m asking everyone who reads this to help me save my husband.Ievgeniia, Yarema’s wifeI guess no more words needed. Yarema needs all the help he can get to fight this horrible diagnosis, but all his and Ievgeniia's strength will not go anywhere if we are not able to raise the $200,000 as soon as possible.EVER $ counts....no amount is too little to too big!Thank you so much in advance ....and I would like to add a German saying I truly believe in and I teach my two little girls every day:Just as you scream into the forest it echoes back.

title: Smith/Earhart Medical Fund
text: On April 19th, Zoe was admitted to UVA hospital for emergency surgery to remove a grapefruit sized tumor from her abdomen.  What doctors initially thought was an intestinal blockage turned out to be something far more serious. Zoe was diagnosed with Rhabdoid Sarcoma, a very rare form of cancer. There are only 200 reported cases worldwide, with only 20 cases being in females.  Unfortunately, the cancer has now spread to more of Zoe's abdomen, including her liver and kidneys.  Zoe has now begun very aggressive chemotherapy to hopefully shrink the cancerous masses and prevent the spread of these cells any further. Zoe is receiving treatment at UNC - Chapel Hill and is under the care of the leading expert in this type of pediatric sarcoma, Dr. Andrea A. Hayes-Jordan.  The family felt an immediate connection with Dr. Hayes-Jordan, and are so thankful to be in her care. Kim and Greg have sought opinions from multiple doctors and hospitals across the country, battled with their insurance company (who has now dropped them), found a new insurance plan that begins July 1, and still have somehow found time to be amazing parents to both of their girls.  The financial implications illness of this are significant.  They are already looking at around $80,000 for the initial surgery and subsequent testing at UVA.  Even with insurance, they are still looking at significant costs for Zoe’s treatment, added to the fact that neither Kim nor Greg are able to work right now.  They are getting some assistance from family, but it is not enough to cover the realities of cancer treatment.  We have set up this GoFundMe account for Zoe’s medical expenses and the costs associated with frequent travel to and from Chapel Hill.  If you can make a financial gift of any size, it would be incredibly helpful.  They need all of the love and support we can offer as soon as possible.

title: Mark Hendricks
text: Our dad, Mark Hendricks, has been diagnosed with stage 4 colorectal and peritoneal cancer last father’s day 2017.  Having been one of the hardest working and healthiest men we have ever known, this was a big shock to him and us as a family.  He found great Doctors and a supportive staff to treat him through multiple rounds of chemotherapy and over 20 hours of surgery to get him to closer to cancer free.  He was working full time up to the diagnosis and was graciously looked after by his previous employer and their help though these initial treatments could not of be more appreciated from all of us.  However, insurance is soon to run out and we still have a great deal of treatment left according to his physicians.  This is difficult for us to ask for your help, many of you already do so much, but we could not think of a better person to ask on behalf of Mark Hendricks for a donation to continue his treatment to cancer free.  Many of you have known Mark through your careers to be a true friend, a mentor, and person who you can count on.  He has helped many of us in our times of need and it is with an open heart that we are asking for your support.   Please help him pursue the fight of his life and beat this horrible affliction.   With your donations and help in spreading this go fund me account you have the opportunity to help out a man that has contributed over 30 years to the health and safety of individuals in the Puget Sound and to the commercial construction business in particular.Sincerely, Hendricks' Family.

title: Medical Aid for Carlos Trevino
text: Carlos Trevino is a valued member of the IT team at Samsung Austin R&D Center (SARC).  On Sunday, July 8th he was involved in a car accident that has left him seriously injured and in need of serious medical attention.This campaign is to raise money to cover his medical bills and whatever recovery expenses may come after.  It was started by his colleagues at SARC because we would like to help in any way possible.  All of the money raised will be given to him and his family.We will post more details about his condition after getting his family's approval.  We do not want to share more information than they are comfortable with.**UPDATE #1**I have been asked to remove the details about Carlos and his family from this campaign.  I will provide as much detail as I can.  There is no update on his condition.**UPDATE #2**Update from his family:Carlos is still in critical condition so your prayers need to continue.  As of right now, he has not woken up and that is the biggest concern.  His wife went to see him and he tried to open his eyes and squeezed her hand which is the best response they have seen from him. Seeing the help from friends and colleagues has warmed their heart tremendously.  Thank you all so much for donating money to this campaign! I am increasing the goal from 10K to 50K after seeing the response from sharing this with the IT team.  We have received approval to share this with the whole company.**UPDATE #3**I was given permission from Carlos' family to share more details about his condition.Carlos, his wife (who is pregnant with their child), and her parents were involved in a serious car accident while returning from a family event in Mexico.  They were hit by someone else's car and that caused the car they were in to rollover.   Carlos and his Mother in law were severely injured in the crash and were taken to a hospital in Monterrey, Mexico.   The doctors were forced to amputate one of his legs due to injuries from the accident and he is currently unresponsive and in a coma.  His Mother in law is also in critical condition with fractures throughout her whole body.  Carlos' wife and her father thankfully were relatively unharmed.The money we are raising will be used to pay for medical bills and the inevitable physical therapy he will have to go through.  His family and friends cannot thank you enough for all the support we are getting.  I am sure Carlos would be happy to know how many people are supporting him through this tragic timeline.Please share this campaign on any social media if you have not already.  Any donation will help out his family. Thank you.**UPDATE #4**First of all I would just like to say you are all amazing and thank you so much for donating. I did not expect to be able to raise this much money and Carlos' family is eternally grateful for all of the support.I got the family's blessing to share this update with all of you:Carlos had a CT scan this morning and the doctors noticed less inflammation in the brain. The inflammation of his organs is also reducing. He will be in observation this weekend and on Monday they will determine if his breathing tube can be removed. If not, they will have to consider alternative actions. They ask for continued prayers.**UPDATE #5**I spoke to Carlos' wife, Deisy, and she is so grateful for all of the donations and support. She wanted me to tell everyone thank you from her whole family (thank you!). The donations are such a blessing as they will both be unable to work for quite some time. Here is the update about what happened on Monday:Carlos has been making good progress as the days go by. On Monday he had a tracheotomy and a gastrostomy procedure to temporarily support him until he fully gains consciousness. Both procedures went well with no complications. Please continue to keep Carlos in your prayers for a quick recovery.

title: Jordan McNair's Family Support Fund
text: There are times, when you spend just a moment with an individual and think to yourself, “What a wonderful person.”After meeting him, you quickly realize that Jordan McNair is an exceptional son, friend, teammate and human being.Last week, Jordan was airlifted to R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore, Maryland. Without disclosing all of the details of Jordan’s medical condition, he received a liver transplant and has been fighting for his life for the past week – and will continue to do so over the next several months.When friends inquired how they could help, Tonya and Marty asked only for prayers.Many of us have witnessed Tonya and Marty’s strength and faith during this experience. This is something no parent should ever have to bear.On her facebook page, one of Tonya’s favorite quotes is,“It’s not how big or heavy your load, it’s the way you carry it.”We are Jordan’s football family and want to help Tonya and Marty carry some of that heavy load.Jordan’s recovery will be long. He will be in the hospital for several months and his parents deserve to be at his side throughout his recovery.As his football family, we would like to provide Tonya and Marty financial relief so that they can remain focused on Jordan’s recovery. Our goal is $20,000. Every donation, no matter how big or small, is appreciated.

title: Help Tom Walk Again
text: My name is Maxwell Greggo. At the end of January 2017 my father, Tom, was home recovering from a routine kidney stone operation. Walking back to bed from a midnight bathroom visit he lost consciousness and fell, waking up hours later face down and unable to move. Because my mother was away visiting family and I live out of town, there was no one home to help him or hear him call for help. He laid there for hours, immobilized and alone, unable to answer the phone when messages came in from my mom asking how he was doing and if he was alright. Worried he hadn’t responded, she managed to reach two family friends to go to the house and check up on him and finally, sixteen hours after falling, paramedics were called and he was taken to the hospital.     It was determined that the fall had caused severe whiplash that resulted in a torn ligament misaligning three vertebrae in his neck and compressing his spinal cord. Emergency surgery stabilized and reinforced his spinal column, but unfortunately even after the surgery he found he was paralyzed with no feeling or control of his body from the shoulders down. After months of intense physical and occupational therapy and more recovery at home he has progressed to the point where he has regained some feeling throughout his body and some control of his shoulders and arms, but still, control of his legs, feet, and hands remains out of reach. He also suffers from constant nerve pain and frequent spasms, common to spinal cord injuries.     My dad has always been a very active man, always working on his car, fixing things around the house, running his Hi-Fi repair shop, helping his friends out with their projects, and helping me out countless times when I found myself in a jam and didn’t have the mechanical experience to handle it. His days now consist of him lying in bed, or at best being put into his manual wheelchair, and passively watching TV or listening to music. He needs constant 24 hour support to perform even basic tasks like eating.      Tom has recently been approved by The Stem Cell Institute, a world leader in their field of stem cell research and therapy, for treatment in August in Panama City, Panama. Unfortunately, this treatment isn’t yet available in the United States and requires travelling abroad. Scans taken before and after the injury as well as months into his recovery show that his spinal cord wasn’t torn or severed, only bruised and swollen. These scans were reviewed by the institute’s team of doctors before accepting him. The stem cells they use will be collected from Tom’s bone marrow and obtained from umbilical cord and placental tissue donated by mothers after normal births. The Stem Cell Institute has had success in treating similar injuries, and when performed within two years of the original trauma they show an 83% chance of significant recovery.     The initial treatment costs $37,200 and so far we estimate that we’ll need $5,000 for travel for my dad and mother along with specialized accessible medical equipment and supplies. Tom’s medical care and has put extreme financial and personal strain on our family simply maintaining the status quo. We need help. Unfortunately his insurance will not cover this treatment.     I would like to personally express my gratitude for your consideration, and especially for the wonderful help and support already given by so many of Dad’s friends and family.Thank you.Max

title: Help Jennifer Fight Cancer !
text: Hello Everyone,  I am reaching out to you because our dear friend, Jennifer Ichikawa, needs your help.  I have the privilege to work with Jennifer for the last 10 years at COBAN Technology, she is my teammate, partner and work sister.  She is selfless and always ready to lend a helping hand.  It breaks my heart to know that Jennifer was diagnosed with stage 4B Cervical Cancer, and is needing assistance with medical bills and on-going chemo treatment expenses.  It has not been easy for the family since her husband, Howard, was recently laid off.  Plus Cameron, their baby girl, is only two years old, so as you can see, the situation is quite profound.    We want to make sure Jennifer focus on recovery and not be burden with all the financial challenges.  Jennifer and Howard will receive the money directly from this Go Fund Me Campaign, the money will go towards medical bills and basic household expanses.  Please, let's HELP JENNIFER FIGHT CANCER together!

title: Fundraiser for Matt Stauder
text: This fundraiser was put together by myself and various members of the Indiana University Football team to support our equipment manager and close friend Matt Stauder. Matt has been a manager for the football team for the past 3 years and is about to finish his junior year at IU majoring in sports management and marketing. He is a positive force and a brother to us all and lives by our team motto: Love Each Other. During this past season, Matt unexpectedly lost his father to a heart attack. This loss alone has been extremely difficult, but just recently Matt was diagnosed with Hodgkins Lymphoma cancer. He will start treatments in early May and our goal is to help offset medical costs. There is a target fundraising goal set but our wish is to support Matt and his family with their financial burden as much as possible.We need your support! With the help of the community, staff, and players we can pull Matt through the fight of his life. He has supported our team everyday and now it is our turn to assist him. Thank you so much for helping. Our team, Matt and Matt's family greatly appreciates it! Please donate, share this with everyone you know and send up prayers for Matt.Sincerely,Ricky Brookins IU Football Running Back

title: Fundraiser for KC Merrill
text: My dear brother KC had a terrible accident while sleepwalking early Monday morning August 20th, 2018. KC has been a chronic sleepwalker for his entire adult life and even sometimes slept in a hammock to limit his unconscious activity. He fell from a 3rd story window to pavement and landed on the left side of his face. He was found at 3am by the paperboy; no one knows how long he was lying there. He was chilled and moaning in pain but could not respond to requests to verify control of his arms and legs.He has many fractured ribs, a punctured lung, injuries to the lower spine, spleen, and kidneys. The lumbar spine is misaligned and impinging a very small amount on his spinal cord. Worst of all, the impact was just above his left ear, smashed part of his eye orbit, and damaged his brain. The trauma team at Good Samaritan worked hard to stabilize him and warm him up before emergency surgery to address the swelling in his brain. He's had two surgeries so far. First they added a drain to relieve pressure on his brain and a plastic surgeon reattached his left ear. A few hours later they had to remove a portion of his skull and part of his temporal lobe to make room for the swelling. He is in a medically induced coma to give him rest for healing and time for the swelling to go down. It generally takes 3-5 days for that to happen. He is currently stable but in critical condition in the ICU. Treating the other injuries is secondary to stabilization and getting the swelling down.The doctors say that he has youth on his side, and we all know he's a fighter ;-) KC's dog Bella is safe at his home with me. Our mother, my husband, and I are in town from Texas to be with KC.We are starting this fund to help with KC's needs during this time. You can follow KC's story here -  https://www.caringbridge.org/visit/kcmerrill. Thank you for your generosity and please keep my brother in your thoughts and prayers.

title: Ernest's Recovery Campaign
text: In July 2018, our Ernest- famed for his heart of gold, mediocre jokes and sartorial finesse- was diagnosed with acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL). This news came as he and Lulu had recently celebrated their one-year wedding anniversary and welcomed their beautiful son, Theo.The outpour of support and well-wishes have been taken in with gratitude that they are surrounded by so many loved ones. A team of medical professionals is working hard to ensure that Ern is on track for a healthy recovery. A donation in any amount will be generous and gratefully accepted to support Ern, Lulu and Theo during this time and in the months ahead. Lulu has depleted her maternity leave, so the trio is currently being supported by Ern's disability income. 8/7/18 UPDATE- Round one. His intrepid spirit and determination have weathered one round of chemotherapy; he is currently recovering.8/14/18 UPDATE- Round two. Chemo is repeated every Monday. Side effects become milder with each administration. Blood tests show a positive response to the drugs! He essentially has no immune system and is susceptible to all sorts of infections. A very low White Cell count allows the body to regenerate itself and create new and healthy blood cells. He continues to take his morning daily dose of pills (around 10 pills with breakfast, yuck) which help combat the risk of infections and viruses.8/17/18 UPDATE- Fluctuating energy levels. Today is a low-energy day.8/18/18 UDPATE- Today is a high-energy day. Ern spotted dancing with his new partner, Barbara the IV. These two have become inseparable. 8/20/18 UPDATE- Round three. Things are going well! Ern is experiencing some nausea, but his anti-nausea meds are effective. He is off IV fluids and is no longer attached at the hip with Barbara (his IV pole). He now has more freedom to walk around the unit and visit the patio’s healing garden.  So far he’s lost about 20 pounds but his appetite remains stable. The nutritionist even added a smoothie twice a day for extra calories.  His hair is starting to shed and Ernest is actually okay with that. Instead of the usual hat/beanie cover-up, he’s considering wig options. He’s open to suggestions! I suggested a toupee, and his friend Terence suggested a blonde wig.

title: Cancer Care Support for Martin
text: Dear Friends, Family and other Benefactors - Many of you know and care for my brother Martin (Hickman).  Martin's exuberant personality has spread widely during his 34 years on this earth.  Endlessly social and animated, he has thrived on connections made through work, family and life-long friendships. After attending the North Bennet St. School in Boston, Martin established his home and business as a historical restoration carpenter in Philadelphia.  Successful and driven, as a business owner of Seneca Historic, his life has revolved around his work. Last summer, Martin began experiencing severe symptoms - the most debilitating and alarming was pain, numbness and progressive atrophying of his right arm.  After numerous tests, doctors and lost revenue (his capacity to complete contracted projects was greatly compromised) he was finally diagnosed in Jan. 2018 with a Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumor (MPNST).  By this time, Martin had almost completely lost arm function. This rare, aggressive cancer has a poor prognosis and is incredibly challenging to treat.  Scans and a surgical biopsy revealed a large (MPNST) tumor embedded deep in his chest within the brachial plexus (important network of nerves).  MPNST's have a high rate of recurrence and metastasizing to other areas (commonly lungs). His diagnosis created an emergency as Martin became unable to continue his business and lost all ability to support himself.  Without family of his own in Philly, an urgent need for immediate treatment, and housing unsuitable for a seriously ill person; our mother left her Olympia, WA home to become Martin's full-time caretaker.  She found an adequate place for them to live together while forming a team with our brothers Ethan and Thom who left their homes in Seattle and Portland to help. Martin is receiving care from a team of specialists at Penn Medicine.  He is currently in his fifth round of brutal chemo infusions - an attempt to shrink spots presenting in his lungs which doctor's believe have a high likelihood of metastasis from the primary site of origin.  Martin will soon undergo an extensive surgery to amputate his right arm and shoulder to remove as much of the tumor as possible with radiation treatment to follow. At the beginning of this crisis our family pooled together financial resources to resolve his immediate needs.  However, after months of numerous expenses necessary to support a seriously ill cancer patient - medical bills, housing costs, transportation, food - our circle of family is becoming financially depleted. On Martin's behalf, I am requesting donations to relieve the urgent financial burden on my brother and his immediate caregivers.  Your donation will be greatly appreciated and wisely managed towards providing the following: housing, utilities, caregiving expenses, groceries, transportation and medical bills not covered by insurance/other sources.  With the total cost and scope of treatment impossible to predict, we have chosen the initial amount of $50,000 in hope that will be sufficient for the next year.  As Martin progresses through this difficult journey, we will update as his needs and expenses unfold.  Best wishes and regards, Martin's sister - Emilie. Caring Bridge -  https://www.caringbridge.org/visit/martinhickman2 Before treatment - ￼Chemotherapy starting - ￼ May 7th, 2018 - starting 5th round of chemo ￼ ￼￼-

title: This One's for Ginny
text: Ginny has a very deadly form of stage IV cancer. She's going to need help paying hospital bills, chemo bills, surgery bills, and pharmacology bills. The money will at least take one less worry off her mind. Please help. If you know of any holistic treatment, it would be greatly appreciated. The situation is dire. Thank you all so much.  Guys, I know how much you all love Ms. Ballard. I love her too. Please spread the word. After all she's given, she needs us now.

title: Help Aria Overcome Neuroblastoma
text: Aria needs your help as she overcomes Stage 4 Neuroblastoma.  Please read the message below from Aria’s dad, Daniel, and consider donating.Thank You!Ryan Messer and Terri Wade(friends of the family) _______________________________________________________When Aria was born five years ago, her sister Gabriella thought she would be able to play the minute she came out of the womb.  Aria had barely been placed on her mom’s stomach before Gab was trying to give her a doll. That day will live in my memory forever, and my world was changed forever.  I think the entire world was changed forever because Aria’s personality and spark for life make the world a better place. She gives her family and everyone around her so much joy. Even in the midst of tremendous change over the last three years, Aria has been a shining star, always worried about how everyone else is doing. A few weeks ago, Aria had a sore stomach which led us to a GI specialist 3 times in one month, once to the ER and once to urgent care. They all gave us a clean bill of health but Megan and I felt something was wrong and insisted on a scan (also because I felt a weird bump on her abdomen).  We thought there might be an intestinal blockage, so were horrified when they told us there was a mass.  Over the first two weeks of March, they pieced together the shocking results that Aria has Stage 4 Neuroblastoma.   http://www.cncfhope.org/Home  There are approximately 700 cases of Neuroblastoma each year and over 100 of those are treated at Memorial Sloan Kettering in New York City.  We were referred to MSK by several sources and have now found hope and comfort.  While the cancer has spread to her bones, it has not spread to her lungs, liver or kidneys.  Aria started chemo on March 13 and, although it is hard to explain to her what is happening, she is such a brave girl.  We are in uncharted territory with this journey, but understand that it will be long, exhausting and expensive.  Our temporary second residence will be in NY since Aria’s treatment will last 8 to 12 months and she will be unable to fly home or take public transportation due to the risk of infection.  In addition to temporary housing in NY, I’ll be flying back and forth to be with Gabriella, who will stay in Georgia to minimize disruption to her life.  And I’m just beginning to get a glimpse of the many things beyond out-of-pocket medical expenses that will add up quickly – Uber/cab rides when walking is not an option, stroller, wigs, etc. We are grateful for your support and prayers!Daniel Lakier

title: Bepis Battle Fund
text: Cholangio-What?   "They do certainly give very strange, and newfangled,  names to diseases."  PlatoMy uncle Mike, who is only 46 years young, was recently diagnosed with Cholangiocarcinoma - known as bile duct cancer.  It is known as the silent disease because there are no signs or symptoms until the cancer is in the advanced stage.  Cancer - a word no one wants to hear!  That word has the ability to change your life!  Uncle Mike went from living a day to day existence of work, home, taking his daughter to school, dance lessons, Greek school, laughing and playing with her -  to one of doctor’s visits, being poked and scanned - just plain being scared, crying and feeling hopeless.   WHO IS UNCLE MIKE? Hippocrates once said, "It is more important to know what sort of person has a disease than to know what sort of disease a person has.”   So, here are a  few things about Uncle Mike:  Uncle Mike grew up on the Northside.  He attended church at Holy Trinity.  He attended school at St. Pat's.   Some of you may remember Uncle Mike as “moose” from 9Muses – and  recently you may have seen him serving up drinks at Gene and Georgetti in Rosemont!    Uncle Mike is a loving father, husband, uncle, son-in-law, brother-in-law, nouno and friend to many.  He does not have one ounce of meanness in him.  He always looks at the good in people. I have never heard him say "what about me?”   He always puts others before himself.  He is selfless.  A man that I have never seen cry has been so overwhelmed by emotions in just a few weeks - it breaks my heart!  I am proud to have Uncle Mike in my life and hope that I can be half the man he is one day.  HOW DID IT START?In September Uncle Mike noticed that his tummy was upset.  He thought it was from the stress and anxiety of losing his dad.   Then a week before Superbowl Sunday, Uncle Mike thought he had the flu because he wasn't feeling well.  It was Superbowl Sunday, although his team didn't win - he was excited that Philly won - since they never had a super bowl victory - he was even happier that the Eagles brought home a win to his family in Philly.  Anyone who knows Uncle Mike, knows that he loves sports!  You would think that he'd be jumping with joy that weekend- but uncle Mike was still not feeling well - so off he was to see the doctor on Wednesday;  he had blood work done in the morning and by the early evening, my nouna/aunt Gigi received a call from the doctor telling her to get uncle Mike to the hospital "his liver enzymes are all over the place".  Uncle Mike had CT Scans, MRIs, and blood tests to confirm that he had a tumor in the bile duct and malignant masses in the liver; more testing later revealed that the cancer had infiltrated the lymph nodes.Uncle Mike will begin chemotherapy and then radiation Y90 at University of Chicago.  Although at this point surgery is not an option for him, the goal is to hopefully have the tumor shrink so the doctor's can go in and resect - that means take it out.  We are hoping that in 3 months we see results - and results means shrinkage.  The doctors have explained that the process of chemo, radiation, scans and possible surgery could take up to 6 months!   HOW CAN YOU HELP?First and foremost PRAY!  It takes a village and I am respectfully asking that we all band together to help Uncle Mike.  Please pray and believe!  Uncle Mike has a beautiful six year old daughter who needs him around! My Aunt Gigi needs him.  My pappou needs him!  He takes such good care of my pappou!  His friends and family need him!  I need him! My Uncle Mike and Aunt Gigi are proud people - It is very difficult for them to ask for  help - but my Aunt Gigi, Uncle Mike and Cousin Gabriella are going through a difficult time.  The medical expenses, pharmacy expenses, travel expenses, nutrition expenses and just basic living expenses are becoming too much!   That is why I am asking for help on their behalf.  Please find it in your heart to show compassion, selflessness and generosity - Please help my family - the medical bills have started to come in - and although, yes, they do have insurance - it does not cover all the costs.  “Generosity consists not the sum given, but the manner in which it is bestowed.”   GandhiThank you!

title: Rally for Ryan Tadman & his family
text: Ryan “Tough Tad” Tadman was diagnosed with Osteosarcoma in the fall of his freshman year, 2015. He has now been through 4 major surgeries and spent over 135 days in the hospital for surgeries, treatments and recovery. He has maintained his school studies at Saint Mary’s High School and is on track to graduate with his class in 2019. His competitive spirit,faith and pure grit have helped Ryan and his family stay positive through it all!Ryan is a classic teenage young man who is passionate about the outdoors, hunting and fishing. He is determined not to let his illness get in the way of living his life to the fullest. Just 2 weeks after major surgery to receive a titanium knee and 8” femur, Ryan was out shooting ducks from the duck blinds. He continues to compete at a high level in shooting sports, as well as taking every opportunity to drive his truck to find the perfect fishing hole or hunting spot. Ryan’s “Tough Tad” friends would like to raise funds to help the Tadman family through this medical adventure.  It is a humble gesture to lend support to a family that helps many others. Thank you for any assistance you are able to give! Go Tough Tad!!
