title: Saeideh’s Emergency Fund
text: ￼On Wednesday February 28th, my mom Saeideh Hosseini, was admitted to the ICU...and within several short hours, mom experienced multi organ failure, ultimately leading to a double leg amputation.  That was the third time in 4 days she had been to the emergency room. Since the symptoms she was having were similar to those of a bad case of the cold or flu, she had been sent home the first two times. This time was different as her symptoms were very severe. That night the doctor told us that it wasn’t looking good and that I should go and kiss her goodbye...hearing this and seeing someone who is usually so full of life and laughter in a coma was a huge heartbreak for me, my family, friends, and loved ones who have been so supportive. We were told the multi-organ failure was due to a virus that had attacked the heart. No one has been able to tell us what strain of virus caused this, only that unfortunately for Saeideh, not only was the heart failing, but also her lungs, kidneys, and liver were failing as well. The doctors surgically placed a device called the IMPELA to help her heart continue pumping. Meanwhile, Saeideh needed dialysis machine to help with the kidney failure and also another device called  ECMO to help clean and oxygenate her blood. That’s when we got her transferred to the ICU unit at UCLA where she is still today. The team of doctors and nurses here have been working diligently to help my mom recover and  finally after days of being in a coma, she is awake. Her heart is beating on its own which is a miracle since on several occasions we were told that her chances of surviving this were 5%-10%! We were also warned that there may be brain damage and wheel chair confinement.  Mom is fully functional mentally and has no brain damage. My mom has always been and always will be a very strong independent woman. I am sure with time she will move around on her own. Unfortunately, all the medicine and medical devices used to keep her alive are not without side effects... During this time, the blood pressure medication and the devices in her groins caused poor blood flow to her lower legs which led to her having both legs amputated.Overall my mom is dealing with this better than we thought. She is stronger and braver than any of us knew, she truly is an optimist.  She keeps a smile on her face, regardless of the discomfort and pain of being in a hospital bed. The doctors and nurses are always commenting about how pleasant and nice she is. She has earned the title of the “Most Popular Patient” of the ICU. I want to thank everyone who has been supportive of us during this horrible ordeal. We are grateful for your prayers and we know that Saeideh being alive today is a divine gift and miracle!  Mom’s road to recovery is long and expensive. And she does not have much insurance coverage. So her recovery, rehab, medications will be prohibitively expensive. And thus, we ask you to be an angel and help if you can. Any amount will be appreciated and will go a long way. Please share and repost this and help spread the word.

title: Carson Frutiger Medical Fund
text: In June 2018, Carson began experiencing symptoms of pneumonia and by early July was hospitalized at Mayo Clinic Saint Marys Hospital. Doctors administered strong antibiotics and after 5 days, Carson was released back home with a prescription for daily antibiotic infusions for 4-weeks. Carson rested and received his daily infusions; however, he continued to struggle with worsening symptoms and dropping blood oxygen levels. On Friday, July 20th, Carson's parents brought him back to Saint Mary's ER where he was admitted once again. The following Monday, July 23rd, doctors determined the source of Carson's pneumonia to be a fungal infection called blastomycosis. While not uncommon, the complications Carson has experienced with this infection have been described as 1 in a million. The infection wreaked havoc on his lungs. He was eventually placed on a ventilator, but his lungs continued to fail and on Tuesday, July 24th the decision was made to place him on a heart and lung bypass machine (life support) called Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation or ECMO. This machine takes the carbon dioxide rich blood from Carson's body, removes the carbon dioxide, then oxygenates the blood and returns it to his body. Carson has been on ECMO since. His progress will be measured by weekly rather than daily progress. His mom, dad, and sister have been by his side through this journey.And, his journey will be difficult and arduous. It is not clear how long Carson will be connected to ECMO. It may be weeks or months. Since being placed on a ventilator, and eventually ECMO, Carson has been in a medically induced coma so his body can rest and heal.He has begun be to be awakened and we pray his recovery continues in this positive trajectory. Please join us in prayer for complete healing and a powerful recovery process. Pray that Carson's emotional, mental, and spiritual life will flourish even as he faces intense difficulties. Pray for strength for Carson and his family.The goal of this fundraiser is $50,000, but as you can imagine, the cost of medical care Carson requires will far exceed this mark. Our hope is that during Carson's recovery he will not have to worry about finances.  Carson has committed his life in service to others through ministry. His love for people is evident in his compassionate presence and engaging spirit. Now, it is our turn to bless Carson. Please give generously as you are able. Thank you - Team Carson

title: Help David Fight Stage IV Cancer
text:
It is with a broken heart that I have to announce David's death this week. He passed away Tuesday morning. I am grateful he is no longer in pain, and I hope he was not too frightened in the end and knows how much I loved him. Thank you and much love to everyone that has helped us over these past three months.

There are times in our lives when we need help, and, for us, this is one of those times. My husband, David, has Stage IV oral cancer. After visiting and speaking with several oncologists, we found out that traditional treatments are not an option for him. David also has an autoimmune disease (dermatomyositis) that requires him to take strong immunosuppressant drugs to keep his own immune system from destroying his muscles and connective tissues. Because of these medications, the doctors told him that chemotherapy and radiation were not an option, as these treatments would kill him quickly. Being someone who does not heal quickly and is easily prone to infection because of the medications he takes, the extreme surgery (the removal of half of his face, including bones) was also not an option. 

So, we began researching holistic alternative treatments and started them within two weeks of his diagnosis. However, insurance won’t have anything to do with these treatments and five weeks in, we are already almost $10,000 out of pocket. We have at least 8 more weeks of the protocol left and then maintenance doses to continue after he is done.

David is a strong man and a hard worker, who believes in living life to its fullest. He owns and runs his own small business, which we are trying to keep going through all of this so that he has something to focus on other than his health and so that we can continue to have some of his income coming in. Obviously, his hours have been cut way back and even in those he works, his strength and stamina is not what it usually is. He will likely lose some clients over this, but hopefully not his business. I have to constantly remind him that his life is more important. 

Outside of work, you will rarely find him sitting still. He is always working on something, helping someone out, or going out to socialize with friends. He is not one to ask for help, but always one to offer it. We have plans to travel together, and the one thing he said when he got this diagnosis was that he wants to make it long enough to go on the trip we have already planned and paid for this summer to Portugal and Spain. 

I have hopes that he will make it much longer than that, and that, maybe, once we have kicked this cancer’s butt, we can use some of these alternative treatments to cure or at least slow his autoimmune disease and get rid of some of these immunosuppressant medications that probably caused this cancer to progress so quickly that it was already a late stage cancer by the time we caught it. Mainly, I have high hopes to continue living my life with my husband and our pupsters, Chili and Toby. We have known each other since we were 9 and 10 years old. We have been together as a couple for over 20 years, and have been married for 18 of those years. We have a life full of love, laughter, and adventure, and I’m not ready to give that up. He’s not ready to give that up. So thank you for whatever help you can give. Your generosity and caring is truly humbling to us.

title: Kathleen Kowal's Cancer Battle
text: We're reaching out to family, friends and especially the volleyball community to ask for your support for our dear friend Kathleen (or Kat as she is known in the volleyball world).  You may know and love her through work, from back home in Michigan, as a beloved family member or friend, or as a super beach player and Volleyball Vacations Alumni. Kathleen has been fighting breast cancer for the past 3 years and after enduring numerous rounds of chemotherapy is still battling. After ending chemo a couple of weeks ago due to the risk to her life from horrendous side-effects she has been moved home and is now on  hospice care. Her parents Ray and Carol are by her side, having temporarily moved from Michigan to a hotel near Kathleen's home in San Jose to take care of her for an indefinite period.Aside from being a wonderful and just fabulous all-round friend and daughter- just see this link  https://youtu.be/cbcJlDcJ3x4   for a reminder of some of the most joyful moments of her life - here's looking at you Turks and Caicos- Kathleen is also a devoted mother to 5-year old Maya, who she co-parents with Maya's dad. More than anything in the world, Kathleen is determined to stay with us to be there for Maya as she grows up.She has a chance to go for treatment to the Gerson Clinic in Mexico (just over the border from San Diego). The Gerson Clinic is an alternative medical center that has saved the life of many terminally ill cancer patients who have no more conventional medical options left. To allow her to have this chance at life we are raising funds to send her there and also to help support her parents continued stay in the Bay Area. Kathleen is running out of time, so we are asking our network to step up now. Any donation is great, they all add up. And please, please share this on Facebook and other social media sites. We know there are a lot of friends out there, whose lives Kathleen has touched with her warmth and superb sense of humor, who will want to help.Thank you for being here for Kathleen and her family. Jules

title: A Single Mom’s Breast Cancer Fund
text: Please join me in raising funds for a dear friend as she courageously fights breast cancer! Recently my friend, Farokh (aka Rokhy) Emami was diagnosed with Stage II breast cancer at the age of 45. She was fortunate to find the tumor early herself and despite her doctor’s repeated assurances and even a negative mammogram, she insisted on an MRI which her insurance would not and did not cover. Thank goodness for her persistence! You see, this wasn’t the first time cancer had knocked on her door. Her only child, a daughter now a teenager, was diagnosed with retinoblastoma (a rare cancer of the eye) at the age of one. At that time, she and her daughter moved to the US and started cancer treatment at CHLA. With generous help and support from her brother, she spent months at her toddler daughter’s bedside at the hospital. Countless follow up visits, treatments, scans, ER visits, and multiple hospitalizations ensued in the next couple of years. Although, her little girl recovered, the doctors told mom that with childhood cancer, there was an increased chance of recurrence within 10 years. Dreadfully, at the age of 11, the cancer was back, this time in the form of leukemia. At that time, there was no immediate family left to help and support them. Both my friend’s parents were deceased and both siblings living were in other parts of the world. Nevertheless, this strong and extraordinary mother and daughter duo persisted as they embarked on yet another grueling round of chemotherapy treatments, prolonged hospitalizations at CHOC, countless tests, and at times devastating medical set backs until the cancer thankfully went into remission. Life continued and this mother and daughter thrived as years passed. Not too long ago, my friend posted on Facebook that her daughter had just passed her 5-year cancer free mark. A sigh of relief as this time, it had appeared that the cancer was not coming back. Little did anyone know that as the duo were preparing for high school graduation and prom, cancer was coming back into their lives for a third time, but this time for a different target - the Mom. Since this devastating diagnosis in February of this year, this amazing mother and daughter have stood strong fighting this disease with minimal help from family and friends. Chemotherapy treatments are scheduled for every other Thursday. I don’t know how, but somehow this strong woman has been undergoing her chemo treatments every other Thursday while incredibly resuming her job on the following Monday after each treatment. However, after the 3rd chemo, of the total 8 treatments, her body grew weaker and it become more difficult to gain back her energy and recuperate. After the 4th treatment recently, she developed sores on the bottom of her feet that make it painful for her to walk and drive. Needless to say, she has had to stop working until she completes the remaining 4 treatments and the recommended two months of radiation that must ensue. Meanwhile, the bills are piling up and the financial resources are almost depleted. The primary focus of anybody fighting any debilitating disease, such as cancer and alike, should be recovery and healing, but that’s difficult to do when you are burdened financially. Prayers and positive energy go along way, but reality is that she needs financial assistance as she hopefully beats the cancer and gets back on her feet, both literally and figuratively. My friend is a typical strong, prideful and resilient woman and a single mom who is used to handling all that lives throws at her on her own. This time though, it’s different and although she has somehow managed thus far, I would like to lessen her burden just a little by raising enough funds to cover at least four months of her and her daughter’s living expenses until such time that the treatments are over and she can return to work. The goal is to raise $10,000 by end of June for her remaining 4 months of treatment and recovery. Please know that every little bit helps. Please open your hearts and your pocketbooks to donate whatever amount you can spare and donate Anonymously if you’re more comfortable. For those of you who know me well, you know that I don’t hesitate to help those in need when I can. This time though, I need you to help another fellow single mother as she fights this awful disease for the third time. Thank you for taking the time to read my campaign and for your kind & thoughtful donations. Arshia Mardasi

title: Help - Blue Brother - Shawn Pardazi
text: BACK THE BLUE & Support our Brother in Blue Shawn PardaziThis past week Shawn Pardazi's wife Lillian "Lilly" Pardazi fell ill to what was believed to be pneumonia. After a visit to an area ER, Lilly was admitted immediately to the Hospital's Critical Care Unit. Since being admitted to CCU, Lilly has been fighting for her life and the prognosis is unknown.   Now is the time to rally behind our brother who has taught so many of us our trade craft and given so much to our profession over the years.Let's show Shawn and his family how much we all appreciate the lessons he has taught so many Law Enforcement Officers by giving back during his time of need.Like most Law Enforcement Families, when emergencies occur it puts an extra strain on finances. When the mother of small children falls ill it requires a whole new level of assistance. Please join me in assisting the Pardazi family as they work through these difficult  times.Please consider a donation of at least $20.00Your generous donations will assist with medical expenses, child care and lost income as a result missed work.Please continue to pray for Lilly's recovery.

title: EllenStrong
text: Please help us raise money for Ellen Delaney. Unfortunately her brain cancer has returned and she will need surgery . She is unemployed at this time as she is not feeling well enough to work . Ellen is a blessing to all who know her , and means the world to so many of us . Please keep her in your prayers . Any donation will be appreciated to help her through this financially difficult time #EllenStrong Love your friends ❤️

title: Debbie & KateLyn's Medical Expenses
text: On Tuesday, March 13, Debbie Leach was rushed to the hospital after collapsing at home. She was diagnosed with a ruptured aneurysm in her brain. After initial treatment to drain the blood from the area, Debbie underwent a successful 6 hour surgery to clamp off the aneurysm. She is not out of the woods yet. Debbie will be in Intensive Care for at least 3 weeks, with many critical steps along the way. It will be a long recovery with astronomical medical expenses. Debbie is loved by many. We ask that you please help Debbie and Kate Lyn get through this ordeal.

title: Ana Emergency surgery in Bahamas
text:
Please help Ana's family with emergency medical expenses for an appendectomy and subsequent treatment for Sepsis as a result of the ruptured appendix! There is no insurance, this is all self pay and the cost of treatment is already well over $25,000 and climbing. Unlike the US, where there are ways to walk away from medical bills, in the Bahamas you can be taken to court and will be forced to pay somehow.

Our sweet God daughter, Ana Claridge, felt stomach pain late Monday June 4th. A Doctor visit in Marsh Harbour, Abaco, Bahamas on Tuesday thought she had acute appendicitis, but no Ultra Sound machine was available on island til Thursday. Her parents attempted to fly to Florida, but there were no more available flights, so they flew to Nassau where she was admitted to the ER at Doctors Hospital. An ultra sound confirmed a ruptured appendix and she underwent  an emergency Appendectomy at 1 am.  Wednesday she felt a little better, but Thursday was not feeling well and was diagnosed with Pseudomonas, which can lead to sepsis.  She is still at Doctors Hospital on IVs awaiting blood tests and now has more pain in her stomach. As I write this, we dont know exactly what is happening in her little body. At every turn the hospital want assurance of payment, so funds are needed desperately as credit cards are being maxed out and savings are being spent to treat her. Her parents have worked very hard over the last 10 years, to start a rental management company, build a house, get out of debt, and live a happy life, these bills are crippling for anyone to absorb. Any help is greatly appreciated to get this sweet little girl back to enjoying her summertime and not lying in a hospital bed with IVs.

title: Mission Remission
text: UPDATE as of 8.9.18:Thank you so much for your support of Dana thus far. The generosity and outreach has provided a much needed source of encouragement during this immensely difficult time. The past few weeks have been challenging, and new developments have emerged as it relates to Dana's treatment. Because of this, we have increased our stretch goal to $40,000. Doctors have confirmed that Dana will need to receive a bone marrow transplant with a pre-treatment plan that includes radiation. The potential of infertility following radiation is very high. Doctors are encouraging Dana to harvest her eggs prior to the procedure, so she can still maintain the possibility of bearing children in the future. Additionally, she will need 24 hour in-home care following the transplant, for at least one month. The mounting expenses include the following:- Medical bills- A need for fresh food between treatments- A service to sterilize her apartment before she returns home from each treatment (chemo and transplant)- Fertility treatment and egg harvesting- 24 hour in-home careThank you again to those who have donated. If you are unable to contribute again, please consider sharing this link to help spread the word.  Again, your generosity and support is so encouraging. Thank you.Original post below:Our best friend, daughter, sister, niece and ray of sunshine, Dana, was diagnosed with Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia (ALL) in June of this year. She has begun a very aggressive regimen of chemotherapy, which has been difficult. The goal is for Dana to undergo a bone marrow transplant.If you’ve had the good fortune of meeting Dana, then you know Dana is an incredible person with an indomitable spirit. If you're reading this, chances are Dana has helped you or been there for you at some point in the past. Dana is a force -  she is one of a kind, she's the best friend you'll ever have, and we love her beyond belief.If you don't know Dana, you know us and our families. We wouldn't be who we are without Dana in our lives. She's extremely special to us, and by extension we hope that makes her special to you. It is not Dana’s style to ask for help, so we are asking on her behalf in the form of this fundraising effort. This is a favor for me as much as it is for her.A lot of people have reached out asking how they can help support Dana, and this is it. We'll be using the funds raised to cover medical costs and to supply healthy fresh food for Dana as she delves deeper in to treatment and prepares for her bone marrow transplant. This is the most tangible way to support Dana. Our starting goal is $20k, which will cover Dana's meals for several months. It would be an incredible start. If we can reach just 1000 friends & family who donated $20, we'd accomplish our first fundraising goal. Additional funds will continue to relieve the unexpected and certain costs that will arise throughout the remainder of her treatment and her reentry back into her normal, healthy life. Please help us make a difference in the life of a friend who brightens the soul of any person with good enough fortune to know her. More details on Dana’s diagnosis are as follows:On June 7th, 2018 Dana was diagnosed with Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia affecting her T-cells. Upon receiving her diagnosis, Dana immediately began an aggressive regimen of Chemotherapy. This specific treatment calls for a month of in-patient treatment, which Dana has completed, followed by an additional 7 months of chemotherapy. After completing the first round of chemo, Dana faced major complications and the doctors deemed a bone marrow transplant necessary. The transplant will be performed once Dana is healthy enough to receive. The biggest concern with this type of treatment is Dana’s compromised immune system, which makes her susceptible to a myriad of bacterias and viruses that our healthy bodies easily avoid. This has made her journey particularly difficult and has resulted in elongated and unexpected hospital stays. We appreciate your love and support. Thank you for your generosity.

title: Help Stephanie Stand Up to Cancer
text: Stephanie Vocell, wife of Jeffrey Vocell, and devoted mother to Atlantis, Maverick, Noah, Piper, Silas was just diagnosed with cancer earlier this week. I'd like to ask for your support by giving to the account that I've created for the Vocell Family. They will need our help outsourcing childcare, cleaning, and meals.

title: Let's Give A Big Hand To Ray!
text: Ray Paczkowski, well-known for his amazing keyboard work with bands such as Soule Monde, Vorzca, Viperhouse and the Trey Anastasio Band, recently underwent successful surgery to remove a brain tumor. Unfortunately Ray faces a lengthy period of additional treatment and recovery during which he will be unable to work. This GoFundMe drive will raise funds that will go directly into a dedicated trust account to help Ray with his living expenses and other financial needs.On March 11th , following several weeks of recurring headaches and nausea, Ray went to the UVM Medical Center in Burlington VT where a scan revealed a significant mass near his brain stem. The following day he was transferred to Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston and underwent a 12 hour surgery on March 16th. The tumor was determined to be a type called ependymoma. Follow-on treatment to reduce any chance of recurrence will be four weeks of daily radiation therapy which will begin sometime in late April. The prognosis for his full recovery is good.In addition to his musical performances, Ray also works as a carpenter to help pay the bills. It is unclear how soon Ray will be able to return to work in either of these fields; at the very least it will be several months. In addition to uncovered medical costs, he needs help with living expenses, travel costs for his radiation treatments and other costs associated with recovery and rehabilitation. Bandmates from TAB and other groups are organizing benefit shows and t-shirt sales to raise money, and local friends and neighbors are pitching in to help him. This online funding drive provides another way for folks near and far who have been touched by his music to make a contribution. Ray is looking forward to getting back out to play for everyone as soon as possible, and our financial contributions will allow him to concentrate on getting better without the added burden of financial distress. We are setting a initial goal of $30,000 to provide Ray financial security during this time. Any contribution is greatly appreciated no matter what size.About the organizer: I am a friend of Ray's and live near him in Vermont. I offered to manage this page to make it easier for people to donate to his trust account so that Ray and his family can concentrate on his recovery. All money donated will be transferred directly from GoFundMe to the trust account for Ray on a daily basis: a family member is helping Ray manage the trust account. If you wish to donate to the trust account by a method other than credit or debit card, please contact me directly for details on how to do so.

title: Dane Andersen’s Medical Funds
text: This GoFundMe is to help finance Dane and his family for what’s going to be a significantly large medical bill after suffering major burns over 75% of his body when his apartment caught fire while he was sleeping. Anything helps and all donations are greatly appreciated. Thank you to everyone that donates even if it’s a dollar. Keep your prayers going and let’s let Dane know how much we’re there for him. The beneficiary that will be receiving the donations directly is Deborah Andersen, the mother of Dane Andersen.

title: Laura Lee's Heart Transplant
text: Laura Lee will need a heart transplant within a few months. Background: On September 14th, 2017, Laura Lee gave birth to her and Ryan’s beautiful daughter. Laura Lee had an emergency C-section with breathing complications, and was immediately diagnosed with peripartum cardiomyopathy (heart failure caused by or induced by pregnancy. It’s a rare diagnosis that impacts ~1,000+ women in the US per year.) This diagnoses has led to several emergency room visits during her regular course of treatment, an ICD (implantable cardioverter defibrillator) implanted in March 2018 replacing the life vest she was temporarily wearing, and an intravenous medicine pump implanted in July 2018 to automatically distribute medicine into her body.In June 2018, it was confirmed that Laura Lee's heart failure is preexisting and was induced by her pregnancy. She was diagnosed with dilated cardiomyopathy (an enlargement of the left ventricle) with signs of noncompaction cardiomyopathy (pockets formed in the walls of the left ventricle). After further testing, signs of a leaking mitral valve was found and heart failure started to form in her right ventricle. Her condition was deemed incurable through regular medical therapy.  In the near future: In order to receive a heart sooner than later, Laura Lee will move from St Paul, Minnesota to Scottsdale, Arizona for her surgery at the Mayo Clinic. She is anticipated to be in Arizona for 4-5 months while on the waitlist and undergoing her 90-day course of treatment post-surgery. Laura Lee’s husband Ryan and her parents will rotate as her caregivers while also managing the care of her children (daughter Lindy Lu, 10 months and stepson Ezra, 8 years) who will continue to live in Minnesota. With gratefulness from Laura Lee and her family, we are asking for any donations, thoughts, prayers, and love during this time. Because of the travel expenses for her and her family flying back and forth from Minnesota and Arizona, the reduced income for Laura Lee and Ryan who will both take time off work, on top of caring and providing for their children, all support is incredibly appreciated.A note from Laura Lee:  “ ❤️Heart Transplant❤️ Many thoughts come to mind when first said: fear, danger, risk, uncertainty, death. But when it becomes your cure, the negativity subsides and beauty shines through. It becomes a miracle procedure, a chance to say ‘not yet’, to feel normal, to be able to spend more time with my husband and loved ones, to see my babies grow, to save my life.”

title: Help the Abbott family recover
text: So my friend is going through some super shitty, shit right now. Her hubby had heart surgery suddenly due to a torn aorta they found moments before it would have killed him. He's come through surgery ok bit is struggling to breathe independently. They put him onto a medically induced coma for the past 2 weeks, so he can heal. He's awake now but is still on a ventilator. Now they're not sure if he was partially paralyzed due to the lack of blood flow to his legs. They have good insurance but Emily's job doesn't have medical leave with pay. They have twin boys with Autism. So she needs to stay home for now. If you have a few extra bucks, could you send them her way to help with bills,groceries & they day to day responsibilities that are for sure going to be impacted by the loss of income so Emily and her family can make it through? Emily is a tough mom who would never ask for help but is the first to help anyone no matter what. Her husband, he's that kinda guy too. Let's surprise them & send a ray of light her way.

title: Rakefet's Breast Cancer Fund
text: Hello dearest friends and family,This is a really difficult note for our family to make.  As you may know, Rakefet (my beautiful wife) was just diagnosed with Breast Cancer (Invasive Ductal Carcinoma).  The doctors are optimistic that we have caught it in time, but this is just the beginning of a long road for us.  They are pretty certain that the cancer has not entered the lymph nodes, but they will be performing a Double Mastectomy on July 3rd.  At that point they analyze the cancer, and we will know whether she will require chemotherapy, hormone therapy and possibly radiation.  The doctors tell us that that is generally a 6-8 month process after which we can begin looking at reconstruction options.  This is all to say that this is appearing to potentially be a two year ordeal.  I imagine that most of you know that Rakefet and I work side-by-side every day to keep our Zimbabwean marimba school running.  When we met in 2012, I had been teaching out of my house for 10 years.  We moved in to a warehouse space and renovated it and created the "Rattletree School of Marimba".  Over the years, we have had close to 1000 students, friends, and family come and play music with us and we have performed for countless thousands of friends around the world.  Having the school has enabled us to support our teachers in Zimbabwe and spread this joyful music.  We both feel like we have done our best to humbly enrich the community here in Austin with our offering.  Rakefet has worked tirelessly since 2013 on so many aspects of the school: rehearsals, booking, performing, traveling, administrative work, community outreach, management....the list goes on.  She is amazing.  This cancer has much different plans for us.  Just in the last week of this ordeal, we have been driving up to the hospital in Temple, TX almost daily and spending hours each day with doctors and surgeons.  This has immediately become a full time job for both Rakefet and myself to navigate this-the bureaucracy, the confusion, the conflicting information, the overwhelm. We are so grateful and thankful that a portion of our expenses are going to be paid through Rakefet's VA healthcare program.   It is such a blessing, but with that blessing is insane amounts of paperwork, bureaucracy, constant energy being expended on making sure that they are giving Rakefet the care she needs-and not just the least expensive care possible.  We are both so afraid that this horrible situation is not only going to be the most difficult thing that we have both endured, but that it will wipe out all the work and energy that we have put in to building this community over the last 6 years.  Our fear is that-unlike a regular job where we are working for someone else-if we step away from the school, it will simply go away, and we will not be able to rebuild it.  We are asking for your support in helping us have the financial cushion over these next several months so that we will be able to take the time we need to recover from this.  Thank you, thank you, thank you, to all of you who have given so much love and support.  We strongly feel that what we have brought to Austin and the community that surrounds us is so much greater than us, and so we are asking for your support now to help us keep things going as we are in this hard time.  With so much love and gratitude,Rakefet, Joel, and Siena

title: Ray's Double Lung Transplant
text: My name is Ray O. Grosvenor Jr. I'm 42 years-young, a proud husband, brother, son and father to 6 wonderful kids. Unfortunately, for the past few years I've been battling a rare lung disease called Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis, or IPF. IPF is idiopathic meaning a condition which arises spontaneously or for which the cause is unknown. I have never smoked or done any type of illegal drugs. In 2015 I was diagnosed with IPF, sadly the survival rate from diagnosis is 3 to 5 years. From that time, I was placed on a medication used to slow the progression of the disease. There is no cure for IPF, it is terminal. I was referred to University Medical transplant center in San Antonio to be evaluated for a double lung transplant since that is my only option for survival. I have been visiting the transplant center since then to monitor the progression of my disease. On June 18, 2017 I was placed on supplemental oxygen 24 hours a day. In May on Mother’s Day I was hospitalized for a week for RSV (Respiratory Syncytial Virus) although rough I was able to recover and return to work. Then on July 1st, Heather took me to the emergency room and I was hospitalized again for a week but that time with pneumonia. Unfortunately, during that admission Heather and I were informed that I was in end-stage lung disease and we should move forward with getting listed for a double lung transplant ASAP. I have not been able to bounce back from the pneumonia and haven’t been able to return to work since the end of June. I got out of the hospital in the beginning of July and we have been traveling to San Antonio almost daily for testing, bloodwork, classes and procedures to be cleared for the transplant list. After years of battling this disease, several hospitalizations, a lung biopsy, being on oxygen for over a year and now using a wheel chair to get around we have encouraging news. As of Friday August 10th, our 11th wedding anniversary, I was officially listed for a double lung transplant. Now we wait for a phone call telling us it is time and to report to the transplant center in a matter of hours.  I take a regimen of medications and breathing treatments to attempt to give me some relief but as of my most recent spirometry appointment my lung capacity has deteriorated to just 36%.One of the many requirements in determining eligibility of a lung transplant is that I have a care provider that attends all appointments with me. Once I receive my new lungs I will be required to attend weekly transplant clinic appointments at the University Transplant Center in San Antonio to check my anti-rejection medication levels, other blood levels, to have bronchoscopies, pulmonary functions tests and doctors visits for the first 3 months following the transplant after that I will be required to attend these appointments biweekly/monthly for a year. As my caregiver Heather will be required to attend all these appointments with me. Which means we will need childcare for our 5 younger kiddos Gabi 9, Nathan 7, Maya 5, Julia 2 and Jonathan 2. I will be out of work for 6-12 months, and on and on. This is where the GO FUND ME comes into play.  All money raised will go toward travel expenses, childcare, and medical expenses related to my transplant.  Heather will not be able to work for 3 months following the transplant. She will be required to be with me 24 hours a day 7 days a week as my caregiver, this is a requirement by the transplant center. There are so many other costs associated with the surgery that don't get covered by insurance. Double Lung Transplant is not without its risks and its financial burdens.  After transplant l will be in the ICU and then later in the hospital doing rehab for up to several weeks. I am fortunate to live about 2 hours away from the University transplant center. University Transplant Center is one of the best facilities anywhere to perform the operation.  These funds will afford us the opportunity to focus on recovery, family and getting thru this tough time. I am incredibly motivated to survive this--my goal is for Heather and I to watch our 6 kids grow up and to be as active in their lives as possible. We appreciate all the prayers, good thoughts, and encouraging words from all our family, friends and church family. Thank you for reading my story and thank you for your help. I look forward to sharing my progress with you and posting pictures of me after I recover from the surgery. Thank youRay, Heather, Ray III, Gabi, Nathan, Maya, Julia and JonathanPlease feel free to ask any questions about our family or my condition. Please share this with everyone on your social media pages and ask THEM to donate and share as well--the more people who see this, the better our chances of hitting our goal.

title: Help the Capellis
text: Ryan and Lauren Capelli delivered beautiful baby girl Copeland Saturday May 12 at 3:45am but she suffered major complications. After fighting for her life in NICU for the last 5 days, the MRI revealed what they feared most. On Wednesday May 16 Copeland went to be with Jesus and is completely healed. The Capellis need prayer more than anything. However, because of a week long journey in NICU and everything they did to try to save her life, this family is about to get hit with unbelievable bills that they shouldn’t have to deal with during this time. However I know we can help if we get the word out! If you can spare, please give to our friends! Any amount will help!Update! We hit our original goal of $25000 but we’re not stopping! Let’s see if we can help pay off other things like the memorial services they have held for her, meals in the future, and other unforeseen hospital bills that may come in! They feel soooo much love and support from you guys and are blown away by your generosity and prayers! THANK YOU!

title: AIR FOR OLLIE
text: ￼￼￼￼AIR FOR OLLIE!Muscular Dystrophy has slowly taken away Oliver’s ability to walk, the use of his hands and now, his breath. Since Labor Day 2017, he has been hospitalized with several bouts of pneumonia. In February, Ollie underwent a lifesaving tracheotomy and now depends on a vent to support his lungs. While Oliver uses a vent to breathe, he also requires the use of four other devices (oxygen tank, a cough assist machine, suction and a nebulizer) for daily living.  ￼￼￼￼These machines are heavy, cumbersome, and difficult to use which makes it almost impossible to leave home or travel. This amount of equipment also requires two nurses or a nurse and respiratory therapist to manage. Although the vent has improved Oliver's ability to breathe, the equipment limitations have been effecting Oliver's quality of life.But there’s hope! The amazing people at Ventec,  www.venteclife.com have developed VOCSN, a innovative machine that incorporates all therapies into one lightweight, streamlined, portable device. A combined 55lb shrunk down to a portable 18lb! With a VOCSN, Oliver wouldn't be restrained by so much machinery and would not need to rely on so many people to navigate his world. Sounds amazing right!??? Well it is! Ollie got to trial the VOCSN on a trip to MOMA, The Museum of Modern Art and it was awesome! Oliver felt empowered with a new sense of freedom and dignity.￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼He was unencumbered by so much equipment and able to experience the museum all on his own!Here’s the caveat, though FDA approved, the VOCSN is not yet covered by Medicaid, and we can’t wait! We need to support Oliver, get him a VOCSN and get him back to living life to the fullest! With your donation he will be back to doing what he loves: ￼￼￼￼summer road trips￼￼￼￼visiting museums as his favorite superherohanging out and making music with his brother￼￼￼￼￼￼￼and expressing himself! Here's Oliver hosting his first photography show SLIMED and one of the pieces￼￼￼￼￼￼Help us change Oliver's quality of life for the better!! Thank you!

title: Help Baby Olivia Moon Zareie
text: Olivia Moon was born on April 9th, 2018 to Melanie and Cas Zareie. She suffered a traumatic birth injury and was rushed to the Gwinnett Medical Center NICU on full life support and a cooling blanket. She was diagnosed with Hypoxic Ischemic Encephalopathy, a condition with serious neurological implications. Olivia is currently still in the NICU. She is now breathing on her own but receives most of her nutrition through a feeding tube. She has severe damage to several parts of her brain and will need speech therapy, physical therapy, and occupational therapy for years to come. While she has made tremendous progress so far, she faces an uphill battle. This has been an extremely difficult time for the family emotionally and financially. In addition to the anticipated high medical costs of Olivia's current and future treatments, her parents have suffered lost wages, and have had to confront the financial burden of hotel, travel, and meal costs in order to stay close to Olivia during this difficult time. They are blessed to have friends and family nearby who have contributed their time and energy in caring for their older daughter and dogs at home. Please consider making a financial contribution to the Zareie family to assist them as they learn how to care for their new baby and her special needs. Thank you.

title: Sweet Ellie
text: Ellie's (MaryEllen) story- Ellie was born without complications and was an easy baby from birth. Ellie would smile easily, giggle and be a normal baby for mom and dad. Eating her vegetables, learning to crawl, sitting, standing, walking, using the potty chair, and blowing kisses as well as her baby talk all came natural to her.She did her first Easter egg hunt and met the Easter bunny on Sunday, March 24, 2018. She loved the Easter bunny and walked around picking up colorful plastic eggs and eating raw carrots that the Bunny's helpers had set out for children. She went down the slide with help and was practicing climbing the steps with help.On April 2, 2018 her school daycare told her mom when she was picked up that day that her left leg was "bowed" (hyper-extended) and she seemed to be dragging her left foot. Ellie saw her pediatrician on Wednesday April 4th and they wanted either a neurologist or orthopedist to take a look at her. She saw a neurologist on Monday April 9th and she did not think it was a neurological problem, so she squeezed her into the orthopedist that day. The orthopedist took an x-ray of her knee and didn't see anything and told them to come back in a week. On Wednesday April 18th, Ellie went back to a different orthopedist at that office and they said that it was probably nothing. That Ellie should come back in 6 months if she still wasn’t walking and there was no reason to waste money on PT.Ellie's parents were not satisfied with waiting 6 months and definitely thought PT would help. At this point Ellie was only walking when assisted. On Friday, April 20th, Jill took Ellie to her pediatrician and asked to get a CBC done. They also did blood work for inflammatory markers. All the blood work came back normal.  On Sunday April 22, Their neighbor Cindy who is a pediatric PT professor at MUSC came over to evaluate Ellie.  She definitely said not to wait 6 months. She may have felt some clonus in Ellie's left foot. Ellie was 17 months old.On Tuesday, April 24th, Jill and Chris called Shriners in Greenville, SC and explained Ellie's situation. Shriners called back the next day and said they would see Ellie on Friday, April 27th. Shriners did more x-rays of Ellie's spine and full right and left leg. All looked ok. They also did another CBC and lead test as well as additional bloodwork. They ordered an MRI of the brain, upper back, lumbar, etc... By the end of April, Ellie was no longer walking, standing or crawling. On May 1st Ellie started PT. On May 3rd was Ellie's MRI under general anesthesia. On May 4, 2018 at 8:30am, Shriners called and said there were spots on Ellie's brain. Chris, Jill and Ellie's lives were changed forever. Later that afternoon the neurologist from MUSC called and they heard the term Leukodystrophy for the first time.  They are waiting on the blood work from the geneticist to determine which type of leukodystrophy Ellie has.On May 14th, Ellie was fitted with braces so that she might be able to stand or maybe walk again. Ellie is also having a difficult time sitting up now. Chris, Jill and Ellie are now waiting on genetic results so they can see the best Leuko doctor in the United States at Children's Hospital of Philadelphia. They are possibly going to CHOP on June 14th, but may have to push it back to wait for the many genetic test results that they have yet to receive. This is so frustrating and sad for all as Ellie is also having symptoms in her hands and it is getting harder for her to hold her drinking cup. Ellie does not sleep well since she cannot rollover or change positions which means her mom and dad do not sleep well either. At this point there is no known cure for this disease. The possibility of Ellie continuing to regress and having a shorter life expectancy is a real possibility.  This is so devastating to Chris, Jill and everyone who loves this wonderful little girl. Ellie no longer goes to her school/daycare since it is so important for her to not get an illness with a high fever. Jill is no longer working full time hours as a dental hygienist since there are many doctor appointments and Ellie needs extra care at this time. Jill continues to work at Ravenel Family Dentistry part time and Chris continues his HVAC business. They have insurance , however there are many things that are not covered and both have missed and will continue to miss time from work as well as working fewer hours. They want the best there is for Ellie and are doing their best to do that and stop the progression of the disease.

title: Trasplante de Riñón para Francisco
text: (ENGLISH BELOW) ¿Harías cualquier cosa para salvar la vida de tu Papá? Yo también. Y con tu ayuda, yo, con todo mi amor y disposición, le estaré dando mi riñón. Mi papá, Francisco Martínez, ha dedicado gran parte de su vida a servir a los demás. Es un hombre y médico extraordinario, lleno de bondad, quien hoy necesita de tu ayuda.  Mi papa fue diagnosticado con Enfermedad Renal en Etapa Terminal (ESDR, por sus siglas en inglés). Luego de agotar las opciones en Venezuela, hace 10 días, sus hijos decidimos traerlo a Miami para verse con un Nefrólogo para una segunda opinión. En efecto, el nefrólogo confirmó que mi papá necesita un trasplante de riñón lo antes posible.  Nos remitieron al equipo de trasplantes para comenzar con los arreglos, pero al informarles que no tenemos seguro, se negaron a iniciar el proceso ya que no contamos con $275,000 dólares para cubrir la cirugía y monitoreo post-trasplante. Entre llamadas telefónicas desesperadas, reuniones, y correos electrónicos para lograr encontrar una solución... Mi papá comenzó a mostrar síntomas graves de fallo renal.  Ayer fue ingresado por emergencia en el Jackson Memorial Hospital en Miami, Florida. Sus pruebas de laboratorio arrojaron niveles muy altos de potasio, lo que coloca su corazón en peligro inminente de infarto, y su cuerpo alcanzó un estado de acidosis alarmante. En términos simples, esto es lo que sucede cuando los riñones pierden su capacidad de funcionar,  y entonces los fluidos, químicos, y desechos comienzan a acumularse en la sangre, hasta llevar a la persona a una intoxicación que puede causar la muerte.  Debido a esto, se tuvo que iniciar diálisis de emergencia para estabilizarlo. Podrías pensar que esto es bueno... Pero las estadísticas muestran que los pacientes en diálisis viven menos de la mitad del tiempo que vivirían si fuesen trasplantados. Adicionalmente, los riñones regulan la tensión, ayudan en la creación de glóbulos rojos y otras funciones importantes, cosas que la diálisis no hace. Y cada vez que lo dializan, a pesar de que su sangre es filtrada y limpiada, su función renal empeora y su oportunidad para un trasplante exitoso disminuye. Mi papá es un hombre increíble, trabajador, dedicado y bondadoso. Quien lo conoce puede dar fe de ello. Ha dedicado su vida a servir a los demás, y lo ha hecho por puro amor y pasión a su carrera. Es apreciado y amado por todos los que se cruzan en su camino, y merece una segunda oportunidad para vivir. ¡Por favor, ayúdame a dársela! Así es como puedes ayudarnos: Donar - Cualquier monto, por más pequeño que parezca, ayuda… ¡y estaremos infinitamente agradecidos!  ***Si prefieres hacer una donación directa, favor contactarme a través de GoFundMe par darte distintas opciones.Compartir - ¡Esto es tan útil como donar! Por favor, ayúdanos a difundir la palabra…nunca se sabe quién puede cambiar la vida de mi Papá. Rezar - El poder de Dios no tiene límites.  Gracias infinitasssss!!!!! La familia Martinez Arends-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-. IN ENGLISH Would you do anything to save your Dad’s life?  Me too. And with your help, I will lovingly, happily, willingly give him my kidney.  My dad, Francisco Martinez, is an extraordinary man and doctor who has dedicated most of his life to help others. Today, he needs your help. My dad was diagnosed with End Stage Renal Disease (ESDR). After running out of options in Venezuela, his 2 daughters and son, decided my dad had to be seen by a Nephrologist in Miami to get a second opinion. The nephrologist indeed confirmed he needed a kidney transplant as soon as possible.  We were referred to the transplant team, but upon letting them know my dad has no insurance, they refused to even see him without proof of having $275,000 to cover transplant surgery and post-transplant treatment, money that we don’t have.  In between phone calls, meetings, and emails trying to find a solution, my dad began to display severe symptoms of kidney failure. Yesterday, my dad was admitted by emergency to Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami, Florida. His lab tests showed very high levels of potassium, which places his heart in imminent danger for a heart attack, and his body reached a life-threatening state of acidosis. In simple terms, this is what happens when kidneys lose their ability to function correctly, so fluids, chemicals, and waste products build up in the bloodstream leading to death. Because of this condition, doctors started my dad on an emergency dialysis to stabilize him.  You’d think this is good… But statistics show that Dialysis patients live less than half as long as transplant patients (see chart above). Moreover, kidneys help regulate blood pressure, create red blood cells and other important functions, which dialysis doesn't do. And every time he is dialyzed, even though his blood is being cleansed, his kidney function actually worsens, and his shot for a successful transplant diminishes.  My Dad is an incredible man. He has devoted his life to serving others, and has done it out of pure love and passion for his profession. He is cherished and loved by all who cross his path, and deserves another shot at life. Please help me give it to him!! Here’s how you can help us:  Donate – Anything, literally ANYTHING helps, and we are DEEPLY grateful! If you prefer a direct donation, please contact me through GoFundMe for options. Share – This is as much helpful as donating! Please help us spread the word. You never know who may be able to change my Dad’s life. Pray – The power of God knows no boundaries.Thank you.The Martinez Arends Family

title: Hope for Hunter
text: The unimaginable occurred Friday morning and Hunter needs our help. Without going into too much detail, he was found under water and unresponsive. He was taken by helicopter from DMC to a Oakland Children's Hospital.He is fighting for his life! His parents Justin and Lisa Eckles, along with his sister, are by his side and need our prayers!  They also are in dire need of financial support as they have been off work due to the recent passing of Lisa's mom, Cathy. It is very costly for them to stay together at this time. There are no accommodations available for the 3 of them to stay at or near the hospital. As you can imagine they do not want to be separated. Hunter is the sweetest and most loving little baby boy!! The light of his mom and dads heart and his sisters best friend!  PLEASE donate and PRAY #hopeforhunter #prayforhunter

title: Cindy Needs Us Now
text: Our dear friend / dedicated community volunteer / Critter Sitter Extraordinaire, Cindy Albury, and her wonderful husband, Mike, need our help.  Cindy is facing some very delicate, dangerous, and expensive surgery next week.The 22+ years of dialysis, three times a week, due to Lupus, has affected Cindy’s bone density. Two soft deteriorated vertebrae need to be replaced right away.Dr Lasner and the medical team at Mt. Sinai Medical Center, Miami Beach, will perform the reconstructive surgery on Thursday, July 12th, 2018 (Cindy’s Birthday!!)After recuperating in Intensive Care and at the hospital, Cindy will remain in the halo brace (which weighs about 9 pounds and is attached to her skull to support the spine) for several months. She will also be treated with a bone stimulator for several hours per day. That is to help the bone grow around the cadaver bone replacement-vertebrae, and to stimulate hardening of the bones overall.Cindy and Mike have worked hard—and without benefit of any health insurance— paid hundreds of thousands of dollars of medical expenses over the years. It’s taken all of their life savings, and although it's not easy to ask, they need our help now.Cindy has been a tireless champion and force for good in the community. She and Mike have been virtually whinge-free, and somehow managed to keep their amazing senses of humor, throughout these health challenges.They're amazing. They rarely ask for anything, but they need our help now and any donation you can make  toward this surgery and the post-op care (and expenses related to travel back and forth to South Florida), will be deeply appreciated, to say the least! Cindy bounced back with amazing aplomb from another very serious surgery about five years ago, and we’re all cheering for an encore recovery from this tough situation.Mike Albury will keep you posted and updated here.Thank you, thank you — we all love you, Cindy!!!— On Behalf of Your Nearest & Dearest,Paula & Greg FarringtonTip BurrowsDebbie Borsetto

title: Holly Ann Hollis Will Beat This
text: Sometimes life throws a curveball. But curveballs can be knocked out of the park!Our friend, sister and daughter, Holly Ann Hollis, has been diagnosed with Stage 4 Triple Negative Breast Cancer. She is currently receiving treatment in Baton Rouge. We will provide updates when we can but ask that you please support her in any way possible. Most of all cover her in your prayers. Through Christ anything is possible! #hollyannstrong

title: A Kidney for Teagan
text: My daughter Teagan was born with a rare kidney disease called Congenital Nephrotic Syndrome of the Finnish Type.  This causes a variety of problems due to her kidneys losing essential proteins and invariably leads to total kidney failure.  Teagan has already had one kidney removed and is currently on daily peritoneal dialysis as we wait for a kidney transplant.Its been a very long road so far - Teagan was born premature at 32 weeks, she's been hospitalized dozens of times, has a compromised immune system, she's had 6 surgeries, two central lines, has a feeding tube and has an in-dwelling dialysis catheter.   She is the most remarkable little girl and has been so strong through all of it.  I am so blessed to have her in my life.The time is nearing for her transplant surgery.  She is now big enough to receive a donor kidney.  She has matched with a potential live donor who is available in the fall and she has been activated for consideration of a deceased donor as well.  We will go with whichever option presents first and is the best fit for Teagan.  We could match any time now.  This process is very expensive.  We have to be ready to travel out of state at a moments notice for the surgery and we have to live out of state near her hospital for a couple months following the surgery.I am raising money to help cover the costs of medical care, travel and living expenses.  Thank you so much for your love and support and all your help as we go through this process.

title: Antivenom Is Expensive!
text: Scot and Maggie King are both talented artists (Scot with leather, Maggie with pottery), they've helped countless people to explore their passions and have been supporting small craftsmen all over Europe bringing their craft to the states. Scot's good humor and storytelling have lit up many a campfire, and his love of history has been shared with more than we can count. On June 26, Scot was bit by a copperhead snake and went to the ER. Antivenom was administered, and while he's doing better right now, not everything is covered by insurance. They are seeking financial aid from the hospital but the bills are piling up, and he will be incapacitated for the bulkk of their high season for events and shows. For a pair of artists, this could be a devastating situation. One that could potentially prevent them from continuing to share the art and culture that they both love. Almost immediately, friends from all over reached out and wanted to help, a testament to how well-loved they are. To how much we would lose without their presence in the historical arts community. The amount being asked for is the initial estimate of just the antivenom, plus enough to cover processing and a bit more, and it may change. Anything over the amount requested will be sent to Scot and Maggie to help them get back on their feet.

title: Djordje Majkic Cancer Fight
text: Friends and Family—my brother-in-law, Djordje Majkic, was diagnosed with a rare form of cancer called Angiosarcoma of the heart which has metastasized to his lungs. Djordje is 20 years old and has been unable to work since his diagnosis due to the symptoms that he is experiencing.  Djordje’s father passed away from cancer just 11 months ago and our family is still financially strained. We are desperately trying to prolong Djordje’s life.  Djordje needs extensive treatment which is extremely expensive and financially unbearable for our family. We need all the help and support possible. Please help us by spreading the word about this action, even if you are unable to financially support the cause, so we could include as many people as possible.

title: Help Jonah fight neuroblastoma
text: Jonah is a kind, funny, and creative 3 year old from Buffalo, NY. His energy and charm bring joy and light to everyone he meets. He was also recently diagnosed with Stage IV neuroblastoma, an incredibly rare and aggressive form of pediatric cancer. Since his diagnosis, Jonah’s parents Tori and Henry have received a crash course on the harsh realities of childhood cancer. Jonah has just embarked on an aggressive 18-month treatment plan with the support of his parents and a team of doctors and experts. However, Tori and Henry are facing mounting expenses and the need to take considerable time off from their jobs, some of which may need to be unpaid leave.Jonah is going into this fight with all of the resilience and stubbornness of a 3 year old. But he will also need the support and love of his community to win this fight.Let’s provide some peace of mind for Tori and Henry as they support their little guy on this journey. Not only do they need to be able to leave work at a moment’s notice if Jonah’s hemoglobin levels drop suddenly or he gets an infection, but there are major in-patient hospital stays in his treatment plan that will require significant time off.Most importantly, we can buy them time. Tori shared with me recently that there’s a 50/50 chance Jonah will be cured, and every moment they get to spend with him is precious. They want to be there for the silly moments, to be there when Jonah wakes up and the only people he wants are Mom and Dad.Meanwhile, mortgage payments and living expenses still need to be paid, and we simply don’t have adequate social safety nets for parents of children with cancer in this country. Please join me in making it possible for Tori and Henry to have one less thing to worry about during Jonah’s treatment.With love and gratitude, Harper

title: Howard Ray Bruner
text: Turns out, humans don't have magic powers.This is Howard & Susan. These are my people. Howard is light. People want to hang with him just so some of his light transfers to them. He's the laugh track to our tribe, the all-time champion of ''quote-of-the-day' and we love him, hard.Howard has aggressive lung cancer, terrible insurance, a career where if he can't work, he doesn't get paid and they need our help.For my birthday, I want my husband's best friend and my best friend's husband to breathe a little better, literally and figuratively.Please give to/share this 'go fund me' account today for his formerly two income family.Anything you can do will make a huge difference. We cannot will someone better, but love and prayers and giving back a little of Howard's light to his family is just....Magic.

title: St. Jude Leukemia Warrior Fund
text: My nephew Brecken Owens has been diagnosed with leukemia.  Friends and family are using this platform to raise funds to support the WAR on cancer.  Moving forward  any donations will be donated in Breckens name to St. Jude Research Hospital to help others battling childhood illness. Any amount would be appreciated and will be used to help save lives.  Please feel free to share our fund with your friends and family.

title: Help Suzanne beat brain cancer
text:
Hello everyone, As some of you may have heard, our dear friend Suzanne Debold is fighting a very serious battle with brain cancer. For those of you that do not know Suzanne, she lives in Brooklyn with her husband and nine year old daughter, Sophia. She is a talented Scenic Artist with vast experience in film, television and theater. Besides being known for her talents professionally as a long standing member of Local USA 829 she is also a talented icon painter with her work commissioned by various churches in America and abroad. Suzanne's experience and creativity are surpassed only by her unique spirit, enthusiasm and strength. It was this strength that enabled her to fight breast cancer when she was diagnosed in 2015, and to be declared cancer free in 2016. Suzanne was in remission for two years, until unfortunately, her cancer returned. This time it has spread to her brain. Suzanne is determined to defeat the cancer again; she has been undergoing Radiation, Chemotherapy, Immunotherapy, and other life saving treatments. This has been taxing physically, mentally, and financially as she is unable to work. We want to do all we can in helping Suzanne get through this difficult time and overcome this horrific disease. Please keep Suzanne in your thoughts and prayers, and if at all possible, consider helping her out financially by donating to her cause. Thank you.

 

- Elina Kotler and the Scenic Artists of Local 829

 

Suzannes Instagram:  www.instagram.com/suzdebold/

Suzannes Facebook:  www.facebook.com/suzannekentdebold

Suzannes website:  http://www.silenticon.net/

text: Thursday August 9th around 10:30pm Emma was hit by a hit and run driver while riding bikes with a couple of her friends. She is in ICU with severe injuries and has a very long road to recovery ahead of her. Please help me raise money to help her family with all the expenses they will be occurring from this horrible accident. Any amount is appreciated. PLEASE SHARE

title: Support O’Dell
text: Team,A veteran, a friend, a brother, a husband and a father has been diagnosed with a health issue  and has a  fight on his hands.   He has said he will beat this but needs our support.  Please donate whatever you can.  Semper Fidels, Team Fiji

title: Kick Grant's Cancer
text: Thank you for visiting this GoFundMe to KICK GRANT'S CANCER!!!!For those of you that don't know, around the first week of April 2018, Grant was diagnosed with Large B-Cell, Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma. Grant is 21 years old and lives on the Southside of Chicago. He attended St. Cajetan’s Grade School and St. Laurence High School and prior to the diagnosis he was attending College and working at local paint shop.Grant's journey to his diagnosis started in early Winter of 2017. He wasn't feeling well and was forced to reduce his work hours and eventually stop working all together due to what he thought was severe pneumonia. Due to having no health insurance, Grant was visiting various clinics to try and get better. After a handful of visits and multiple antibiotics, one clinic suggested he get a chest X-ray. The results of the X-ray showed something more than pneumonia and they suggested he go to the Emergency Room.After arriving at the Emergency Room, Grant was quickly diagnosed with cancer and multiple scans revealed he had a large tumor located in the center of his chest cavity and one lung was completed deflated. This all contributed to Grant’s severe cough and loss of weight that led him to clinic in the first place.Due to the aggressive nature of the cancer, the doctors insisted Grant start chemotherapy immediately. Within a week, he started a 5 day, 24-hour chemo treatment in the hospital. Since his first treatment, Grant has had many complications and additional hospital visits. Although the tumor was shrinking, it caused complications by creating a hole in his esophagus. Due to the hole in the esophagus, Grant has had to endure multiple procedures and surgeries which ultimately led to the insertion of a gastrointestinal feeding tube in his stomach.Grant is currently still going through chemo treatments and managing the hole in his esophagus which makes it extremely difficult for him to breath and talk. Luckily, through all of this, Grant’s mother, Elizabeth (Lisa) Grant has had to stay with him and give him the 24-hour care that he needs, but at great sacrifice. As a single-mother, she is unable to work because Grant needs to constant care. Due to extreme weight loss and low oxygen levels, Grant is unable to care for himself even in the comfort of his own home. Even the walk from his bed to the bathroom is exhausting.We hope with this GoFundMe, we will be able to help offset some of the daily costs associated with Grant’s care. This will include medical bills, cell phone bill, gas to and from the hospital, feeding tube supplies, medical products, and just general costs to ensure that Grant always has a house to come home to after his hospital stays.Please feel free share this with family, friends, co-workers, or strangers! Any little bit will help Grant and his family conquer this challenge! On the behalf of his family, we thank you for visiting this page and thank you for your generous donation! Every little bit makes a difference.If you would like to send a special message to Grant or his Mother directly, we ask that you send it via email at egrant0168@gmail.com and we will make sure they receive it!We will share updates and photos soon!Grant and his MomGrant and his family Summer 2017

title: Ayas Fight for MS Treatment
text: “When I think of a perfect wife and friend, I cannot think of anyone better than Aya. She’s kind, patient, selfless, always willing to help, quiet at times but very sure of herself. She’s the love of my life and I don’t want anything in the world to hurt her. This disease is something she doesn’t deserve and it couldn’t have happened to a nicer, kinder person. She always puts our kids first, even during times like now when she’s struggling with fatigue, one of the many early symptoms she’s experiencing. She still finds the time to give her 100% to anyone who asks of her. All the people that know her have the utmost respect for her, I think that says a lot about a person. I love her with all my heart and want the best I can give her and we’re hoping this treatment is the best.” -Jon RapisuraWords from a husband who has so much love and determination to do anything for his wife. For those who know Aya Rapisura, Jon couldn’t be more precise; kind, patient, helpful, nicer person who loves her children. Unfortunately, today we are sharing with you some difficult news. Aya has recently been diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis. Imagine living your every day life as a wife and mother, getting yourself ready for work and the kids ready for school, drive to the market, playing at the park, making dinner. Then one day, it all stops. It disappears and may never be that way ever again. Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is an unpredictable, often disabling disease of the central nervous system that disrupts the flow of information within the brain, and between the brain and body. The progress, severity and specific symptoms of MS in any one person cannot yet be predicted. Most people with MS are diagnosed between the ages of 20 and 50. The Dealing of the Cards:January of 2018 Aya was experiencing numbness on the side of her face which spread to other areas of her face. After an appointment with her personal physician no initial flags were raised. She initially put it off as nothing serious but towards the end of January the numbness continued, and tingling started in her hands and legs with fogginess in her thoughts. She started having difficulty driving and focusing. She began to forget things. A decision was finally made to go to the ER and that was the beginning of this journey. The same day that she went to the ER, she was admitted to the Hospital. Multiple tests were performed, MRI’s, MRI’s with contrast, Spinal fluid taps, Cat Scans, countless blood work…… At the end of the 2 days in the Hospital with multiple doctors it was 99.9% confirmed as MS. The diagnosis was heart breaking and we were dealt cards which we now must play with. At that time the results were that she had one small lesion in her brain but nothing else meaning this has been caught very early and we all thought “great! Early is a good thing.” After the initial kick in the gut feeling subsided it was time to do research and let us tell you we did research. The Prescribed Fix in America:The Neuro doctor, which is the same doctor that attended to Aya in the hospital is great. She and Aya have a good connection. The initial meeting after getting out of the hospital went well. She informed us of what was going on and what steps will be taken next. Another MRI was scheduled to see if any progression was made and a follow up appointment was scheduled.  The results of the MRI were reviewed during the follow up appointment with good news, No additional brain lesions and no movement on the existing brain lesion. However, the location in the brain where this lesion is affects sensations which is why she is having symptoms of numbness, tingling and brain fogginess.  From here we will be seeing another doctor who specializes in MS who was highly recommended by the Neuro doctor.Now the meds. Currently in the United States there is no “cure” for MS, only medication to slow the progress. There is no guarantee the meds will even work and with any medication there is side effects. Your given a whole pamphlet of meds to control/slow down MS progression and are told “choose one.” The Leap of Faith HSCT/Stem Cell:The internet can be a rabbit hole, once you go down that hole be sure when you look back you can still see light. Once you start the research it gets scary fast but you can’t stop looking, almost like when there is a car accident on the side of the road and you can’t look away. Some of the stories of people and their situations with MS is heart wrenching and some are inspirational. Were hoping we are the latter of the two…From what we know…. Medication will only slow down the disease, possibly, but it cannot stop the disease. Percentage of success varies from patient to patient, progress and speed of progression of the disease varies from patient to patient. Some people live years with out any major progression, some progress in 1 year. There is no clear template of progression. They rate the progress of the disease by an Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS). -0- being no disability all the way to 9 which is bed ridden and totally dependent to 10 death. Sorry to sound morbid but this is the reality of the situation and now you can see why it strikes so much fear. After scouring the internet something interesting came up, HSCT and stem cell treatment for MS. An excerpt from  www.hsctstopsms.com “HSCT currently gaining a lot of attention in the main stream media for its huge success in giving people with MS new hope and the epic possibility of totally halting disease progression, more and more people are asking: what is hsct? HSCT stops MS!  HSCT or Hematopioetic Stem Cell Transplant, is the only existing scientifically proven treatment, currently available that completely halts disease progression of Multiple Sclerosis. It is not a new procedure as such, as it has been used to treat cancer since the 1960’s, but it is a relatively new treatment for MS. Perhaps ‘new’ is the wrong word – The first HSCT performed specifically for an autoimmune disease (uveitis) was performed in 1985 by Prof. Shimon Slavin in Israel. The patient remains cured today. The first HSCT performed specifically for MS was at George Papanicolaou General Hospital, Thessaloniki, Greece in 1995. However, there were many observational case studies before then focusing on the success of HSCT for MS patients that were transplanted for cancer who simultaneously had their MS halted, as an unanticipated side effect of the treatment. All of the early studies that followed, also clearly established the now (well understood) probability that transplantation earlier in the disease life cycle is more beneficial than transplanting later in the disease evolution, when there is a greater degree of irreversible disability. Because the procedure involves the use of chemotherapy the treatment is not the most comfortable and is unfortunately quite expensive. What cannot be denied however is that to date HSCT is the only scientifically proven treatment that STOPS underlying disease progression in all types of MS and restores normal immune self-tolerance and produces lasting curative symptomatic improvement for most MS patients. To date over 2,000 patients have been treated worldwide, and the number continues to rise daily. While this treatment is standard procedure for treating cancer patients (thousands of patients are treated annually), it is not standard treatment for people suffering from Multiple Sclerosis. There are a very small number of facilities Worldwide currently performing this procedure for MS. The hope is that more will open in the early future as the demand increasingly continues to outweigh the supply, and that the cost of being treated will reduce accordingly, as the protocol efficiency is optimized. Many who have already had HSCT say that one of the best parts of being treated is that halting the underlying disease progression of MS gives them back a future. George Goss, who had HSCT in 2009, an inspirational pioneer in promoting HSCT after he underwent the procedure in Heidelberg five years ago, describes this as “pure gold”.  (Please see his blog:   http://themscure.blogspot.co.uk/  and check out his HSCT forum on Facebook: Hematopioetic Stem Cell Transplant – MS & Autoimmune Diseases, where he has provided invaluable information and support for those seeking HSCT). Living with MS is both frightening and uncertain. Little is known about what sparks rapid disease progression with no warning. One can go 10 years with little or no symptoms and then suddenly find oneself in a wheelchair in the space of a few months. It has been described as a “Tiger that cannot be tamed”. HSCT removes this “Sword of Damocles” hanging over one’s heads and gives one the gift of hope and the luxury of planning a future with loved ones. Unless you live with MS you can have no concept of how magic this prospect can be!”The Hope is in Mexico:We guarantee everyone is saying “MEXICO?” Yes Mexico, from the research we’ve found Clinica Ruiz located in Mexico, our light at the end of this dark tunnel. If you have the chance, please look up  www.hsctmexico.com. We never had a Facebook page until now. Signing up for one has expanded our knowledge about HSCT and Mexico and is giving us hope. We’re hoping to go sooner than later, as time is not on our side and in doing so, increasing our chances of success. The percentage of success for treatment is higher the sooner you treat the disease, the percentage of success rate drops the longer you wait and the farther along the disease progresses. Once the disease progresses and the damage occurs, there is no reversal. It is not going to be easy. This is 28-days of intense treatment with tests, extraction of stem cells, chemo, re-introducing stem cells, monitoring, then heading back home for recovery anywhere from 6-12 months to prevent illness and infection. We are looking at expenses in the range of $75,000.00. Expenses include; the treatment, accommodations, flights, food and so on. This is all out of pocket as insurance will not cover this treatment.
