It is very hard to understand why HSCT is not available in the United States as a first option of treatment, but instead of complaining about it we are dealing with our situation and doing something about it which points us to Mexico. For those of you who know Aya, she never complains and she will never tell you if she’s hurting. At her worst, she will still smile, put others first and give 100% of herself. Today we are asking you to please put Aya first and help us help her fight this battle. We are humbly asking you for your support on behalf of Aya as any help is greatly appreciated.  Thank you for caring enough to take the time to read this

title: Help Gabriel Villarreal
text: English and Spanish availableEnglish:My name is Gabriel Villarreal, I'm 42 years old, father of 3 wonderful kids: Two 13-year-old twins, a boy and a girl Alejandro & Andrea (Chichi); and a 5-year-old girl Adriana and married for more than 15 years to an amazing and strong women named Fiorella.Two weeks ago I was diagnosed with a NON-KERATINIZING SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA located at my right nasal, invading my right eye and brain.As the mass is big and close to my eyes and brain, my treatment will consist of 4 to 6 chemotherapy sessions to shrink it in order to be able to proceed with surgery extraction. After surgery, I will receive both radio and chemotherapy in order to get cured.The treatment probably will take approximately from 14 to 16 weeks. Within this period of time, my working capability will be limited and our expenses will be rising due to doctor's and medicine co-payments, nutritionist, special diet, vitamins, as well as additional help at work and home.This is creating a terrible financial stress for my family, as I am self-employed and owner of my own business; and I contribute to about 60% of our household income. It will be almost impossible for me to be able to perform normally in my job, putting at risk my family's well being.For these reasons, I am kindly asking for your generosity in order to help alleviate my family for the time while I'm not able to do it. Any amount will be greatly appreciated. I don't have enough words to thank all of you who decide to help. God bless you and your family for your kindness and generosity.!Español:Mi nombre es Gabriel Villarreal, tengo 42 años,  padre de tres hijos maravillosos: un par de gemelos de 13 años, varón y hembra, Alejandro y Andrea (Chichi), y una niña de 5 años de edad Adriana. Casado por mas de 15 años con una mujer asombroza y admirable llamada Fiorella.Hace dos semanas fui diagnosticado con NO KERATINIZANTE CARCINOMA DE CELULAS ESCAMOSAS localizado en mi lado derecho de mi cara el cual está invadiendo mi ojo derecho y mi cerebro. El tumor ha venido creciendo rápidamente y el tratamiento consiste en  4 to 6 sesiones de quimioterapias para hacerlo más pequeño y entonces poder operarlo y extraerlo.  Después de la cirugía recibiré radio y quimioterapia para proseguir el proceso de curación.El tratamiento tomará probalmente entre 14 y 16 semanas, período en el cual  mi capacidad laboral se verá notablemente disminuida y limitada mientras que nuestros gastos como familia se incrementarán debido a  pagos por doctores, medicina, nutrición especial, co-pagos , vitaminas, etc. Esta situación está creando un terrible estrés financiero a mi familia, ya que trabajo en mi propio negocio y contribuyo con cerca del 60% de los ingresos del hogar. Como lo han planteado los médicos, será para mi imposible poder trabajar de la forma como siempre lo hago mientras esté en la búsqueda de mi cura.Por esta razón apelo a su generosidad en función de aliviar a mi familia en el tiempo que no voy a poder hacerlo yo. Cualquier monto es bienvenido y muy apreciado, no tengo suficientes palabras para agradecerte si decides ayudarme.¡Dios te bendiga a ti a tu familia por tu amable generosidad!

title: Help Sam's Fight To Beat Cancer
text: Welcome to Sam Bradley's GoFundMe page! Sam has been diagnosed with an aggressive form of brain cancer.  Sam is "In It To Win It" and continues to fight everyday, no matter what challenges arise.  Everyone who knows Sam knows how loving, kind and generous she is.Sam continues to battle through multiple surgeries, radiation and chemotherapy.  Sam is now struggling with basic functions like eating, breathing, speaking, and overall movement. Even with all these daily challenges, she smiles and pushes through each day, fighting to get better.Many have asked how they can help, so this page was created to help with financial needs to continue all the therapies, various medical equipment  and medicines that Sam needs to achieve the complete recovery she fights and dreams for everyday.  The therapies include physical, occupational, and speech multiples times per week; various equipment like beds and mattresses, special chairs and lifts; medicines can be anything from chemotherapy to nerve pain management.  Even to get back to basic functions like walking and eating normally, there is a long road of work and costs associated with that.  This is a marathon for Sam. We will be in it every step of the way with her and we are asking you to join us on this journey.  Thank You All greatly!James 1:2-6"Consider it pure joy, my brothers and sisters, whenever you face trials of many kinds, because you know that the testing of your faith produces perseverance. Let perseverance finish its work so that you may be mature and complete, not lacking anything. If any of you lacks wisdom, you should ask God, who gives generously to all without finding fault, and it will be given to you. But when you ask, you must believe and not doubt, because the one who doubts is like a wave of the sea, blown and tossed by the wind."

title: Alberto Benvenuto In Hospital (ICU)
text: Our good friend Alberto Benvenuto devoted husband and amazing father of three beautiful kids was in a very serious motorcycle accident (June 19th) in Ocala Florida, he’s in intensive care unit. Multiple broken ribs and punctured lungs...with no health insurance and crazy medical costs here in the US - he needs our help...Nuestro gran amigo Alberto Benvenuto tuvo un accidente muy grave en su motocicleta, se encuentra aún en cuidados intensivos con múltiples fracturas y perforación pulmonar, el no cuenta con seguro médico y como todos sabemos los gastos de hospital son exageradamente caros en este país (EEUU) y hoy necesita de nuestra ayuda, Se encuentra en el Hospital de Ocala, Fl.

title: George Ocampo's Battle with Cancer
text: George is a very loyal, kindhearted, selfless, geniune man.  He has a big heart and is a friend for life.  George is hardworking and will always go above and beyond for his family and friends.  His wife and children are his everything.  He is the most amazing husband and father. George has been a big advocate with youth sports.  He coached Little League and Hollister Heat for numerous years when his children were young.  To ensure that his children had the means to attend State Universities, he took a part time weekend job for 17 years.  Currently, he is an umpire for multiple youth baseball organizations.On April 20, 2018, George went to the hospital with the thought of possible gallstones all to find out after numerous tests he was dignosed with pancreatic cancer.  George along with his wife and children are preparing for the biggest fight of his life.  He will be having another procedure done this week which will determine if surgery is an option.  At that time, we will have a recommended treatment plan.  With the support and love from family and friends, we can help him get through this difficult time.  I am asking for donations to make this heavy load  of doctor's appointments, co-pays, deductibles, insurance preimums and the loss of income be less of a burden to the family so their main focus can be George.George has always gone out of his way for others with a huge smile on his face and has never asked for anything in return,  it is now our time to give back to him.   Most importantly,  please keep George and his family in your thoughts and prayers.

title: Cassandra's Brain Cancer Fund
text: Cassandra has been diagnosed with a very serious form of brain cancer and needs your help!“My People; Family, friends and supporters, I appreciate you more than words can express.”Your assistance and prayers are needed in this difficult time. To send Cassandra a note or good wishes, please email: liftcassandraup@gmail.com

title: Brandon's Battle
text: After weeks of illness and incredibly high fevers, we were given the devastating news on June 1st of Brandon’s diagnosis of Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia. In just a few weeks, Brandon will become a father to his first child. Our brother in law Brandon and  sister Caitlin have been busy preparing for baby Rhodes.  Within a matter of days, the aggressive cancer has completely altered Brandon and Caitlin’s life. Brandon is a man of great faith and this faith makes him incredibly strong and determined. With the support he has, from an army of friends and family, we know he will fight this and win.The next few weeks were supposed to be filled with excitement and anticipation for the arrival of their first child. Being diagnosed with a threatening disease is traumatic within itself, however, at this pivotal time in Brandon’s life, he will now need to redirect his attention to fighting Leukemia.Brandon and Caitlin need love and support more than ever. We are hoping to raise money to help support their medical bills as well as living expenses in this time of uncertainty.  Caitlin, is the most loving, devoted wife and will not leave Brandon’s side. However, she is 7 months pregnant and she owns her own business, the Kelly Academy of Irish Dance. Brandon is the primary provider but has not and will not be able to work for the foreseeable future. Caitlin is trying to keep the school operating to maintain some income through this time while being with Brandon. They too just moved into their first home two months ago and were just getting settled. It is vital that not only Brandon get necessary medical attention, but Caitlin be able to worry a little less.We hope that the love and prayers will be continuous for this grateful and growing family. We know that Brandon and Caitlin’s appreciation is endless. We thank you all for your support through this difficult time. Faith will persevere and God will guide the way. Thank you for your kindness and generosity ❤️With love,Ryan and Dana Kelly

title: Walker Family Love & Support
text: August 15th Jim and Leslie Walker were given news no parent wants to hear. Their 7 year old Drake has been diagnosed with DIPG, a terminal and very aggressive cancerous tumor on his brain stem. The Walkers are an amazing family full of love, dedication and service. Jim serves as a Sergeant with the Torrance Police Department, and Leslie serves families as a Birth and Postpartum Doula. Taryn, James and Gigi are Drake’s adorable and amazing siblings. We hope to bless them in this monitory way to ease even a tiny bit of burden they might face along their journey AND memories of fun that will last forever. All funds raised go directly to the family to help support them in any way during this difficult time.

title: Trey Richards Medical Fund
text: My sweet little six year old nephew, Trey, & his family could use all the faith, love, and support, as he is fighting for survival in late stage heart failure at Primary Children’s Hospital. He has been diagnosed with an extremely rare disease called dilated cardiac myopathy- a leading cause for Heart Transplantation. He has been in the ICU since Monday and there is no end in sight to when he can return home. Two weeks ago he seemed like every normal six year old boy, running, playing and laughing, when suddenly he lost most of his color, became extremely exhausted and wouldn’t eat for several days. When his parents took him in to their Pediatrician, something was not right and he was immediately transferred to the ER and admitted long term at Primary Children’s hospital. Trey’s parents will be taking substantial time off work, and with medical bills, hotel stays so they can be close to their son, they could use all the help they can get. Please share anything you feel that you can at this time to help raise funds for this amazing family, as they fight every minute along side Trey for a treatment that hopefully will allow him to return home.If you’d prefer donating through Venmo, you contact me and I will transfer all funds to them at the end.

title: Leah Hansen ..."STRONG LIKE A GIRL"
text: Welcome to the fundraising website/go fund me page for Ms. Leah Hansen who is "Strong like a girl"!!! Leah is one of Long Hill Township New Jerseys beloved 3rd grade softball players, along with her many other talents.   As her coach and friend, I am dedicating this page to one of the most determined, tenacious, driven "strong like a girl" nine year olds I know who also happens to share a tremendous passion for playing softball with me :)! Please join me, Leah's softball family, and my entire Long Hill Township NJ community in rooting on Leah as she battles to recover/rehab from a spinal stroke. In early March 2018, Leah became inexplicably paralyzed from the neck down and has been hospitalized on a ventilator.   After a lot of testing, they have decided they believe Leah may be one of the rare few pediatric patients who has suffered a spinal stroke.  Leah continues to improve everyday and she is fighting harder then she ever has before to regain movement in her limbs and breathe on her own. GO LEAH GO!   We all want to show Leah how much we love and support her as we start up another baseball/softball season.  As she continues in her recovery process we expect Leah and her family to have many needs.  As a community it would be awesome to be able to help them out as much as we can.Leah and her family have been extremely active in our baseball/softball community with their 4 children, Leah being the eldest (just turning 9 on March 15, 2018).  Leah has played softball all her school years pretty much all year round becoming one of the softball superstars of her town program.  Her Father, Peter Hansen has coached throughout Leahs softball career, not only helping her, but many other kids in the program.  He volunteers his time and loves every minute of it!  Both Peter and Leah have been a dynamic duo, who anyone in town will tell you, light up the softball field.  Truly inspiring to watch.  The Hansens are a wonderful family and I would love to show them how much love we all have for them.With that in mind, we would like to start off the fundraising process with a softball scrimmage in Leah's honor.  Tim Simo (a Long hill resident, town recreation baseball and softball coach and the varsity softball coach for Summit High school) was kind enough to coordinate a scrimmage with his Summit Varsity High school softball team and Watchung Hills Varsity softball team where we can kick off our fundraising scheduled for Wednesday March 28, 2018 at 3:30 at Diamond Nation 129 River Road in Flemington, NJ 08822. It will be a great way to to show support, raise money for the Hansen family and have fun simultaneously! Tee shirts have been designed and made by one of Leahs coaches for all Leah's family, friends and  teammates to wear that display one of Leah's favorite sayings on the front "Strong like a girl" and her name and softball number on the back "Hansen #1".  All Leah supporters will wear these shirts while encouraging people to donate to her cause, all while watching two rocking softball teams play in Leah's honor.   Tee shirts will be offered for purchase at the event and all proceeds will go directly to the Leah Hansen fund.  Please consider donating to Leah Hansen and the Hansen family for Leah's recovery needs.   I would love to show Leah and her family how much we support them and watch little Leah keep fighting her battle the only way she knows how... "STRONG LIKE A GIRL!"I

title: Ray Worden's Sloan Kettering Fund
text: Hello family and friends. I have started a Go Fund Me account to raise funds to help my brother, Ray Worden with medical and travel expenses. As many of you know Ray has been struggling with throat cancer that has metastasized to his hip, pelvic bone and areas surrounding. For those of you who do not know Ray, his wife Leigh Ann, his daughter Anna, and his son Jack, they have been battling this horrific disease for the past two years. Ray has received excellent medical care at Emory University of Atlanta, but his oncologist has given them the news that no one wants to hear: "We have nothing left to help you." Ray contacted Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital in NYC to see if he would qualify for experimental treatment. Ray and Leigh Ann have traveled to MSK three times for tests and advice, and they have finally been informed that Ray has qualified for a clinical trial treatment. Although truly grateful, there is ALWAYS a matter of expense that comes with cancer treatment. They are at the mercy of last minute appointments and changing schedules which becomes very expensive especially at the last minute.. This of course would eat into any family's budget, and limits their opportunities for family time together. They are trying to carry on with normal family outings and vacations to help two teenagers cope with the stress of their dad's situation. Anna will graduate in May and attend the University of Georgia in the fall and Jack is a sophomore at Marietta High School. This family's blessing and gratitude will go out to anyone that can assist with the travel and treatment costs for these much needed procedures. Thank you and God bless.

title: Julie Griffith Fights Cancer
text: As many of you know, our dear friend Julie Griffith  https://www.facebook.com/julie.l.griffith. was recently diagnosed with rectal cancer.  The good news is that it is treatable. The difficult news is that she's in for a long year of treatments including radiation and oral chemotherapy, two surgeries, and then drip chemotherapy.  She's fighting her cancer head-on but she needs our help.We'd like to make sure that her costs are covered, that she always has the best care regardless of insurance coverage, and that she has the means to take care of her bills and her health including treatments not typically covered by insurance such as Reike, therapy, and massage.  We have set up this page so that those able to support Julie financially have a place to give. All donations will be given to the Griffith family to use as they see fit for medical expenses. Any monies raised that exceed her expenses at the end of her care will be donated by Julie and Bob back to the Rocky Mountain Cancer Center to help other families in need who are struggling with this disease. We hope you will help us support our friend.  Julie is a gregarious soul who spends her days supporting all those around her.  This year she needs our help to make a full recovery and we hope you'll join our cause.  Every dollar makes a difference.Thank you!Julie's tribe

title: Joseph Mihalik Medical Fund
text: On December 7, 2017 a terrible tragedy occurred. Joe Mihalik, a longtime friend and business colleague of mine, took a fall while in the woods behind his home. The fall turned out to be catastrophic. He ended up not being discovered for over seven hours. He was barely conscious and unable to move in freezing temperatures, with his cell phone just feet away from him. Finally, after an exhaustive search by police and police dogs, they were able to locate him. He was stabilized and airlifted to the Morristown Memorial Hospital Trauma Center in Morristown, NJ.At the hospital, he spent 6 weeks in the ICU. He fractured four vertebrae in his neck, crushing the #2 vertebrae, and five vertebrae in his back causing a bruised spine. He also broke his coccyx (or tailbone), had three broken ribs, and suffered a lacerated lung. On top of that, he suffered two serious strokes. He was told that he would have paralysis in all four limbs, he would need a feeding tube because he couldn’t swallow without choking, and he was considered legally blind. It was a devastating prognosis.   Finally, on January 19, 2018 he was moved to Kessler Institute in West Orange, NJ. The therapists there are wonderful and he is very motivated to reclaim his life. He is making progress, but he can’t walk or feed himself and he gets very frustrated, as you can imagine.  He has a long road ahead of him with months of therapy, and he doesn’t know what the future holds. Unfortunately, while he is in rehab, the medical bills are piling up and he and his wife are  overwhelmed. He now has to sit back and watch everything they have worked for in life go down the drain. He is trying his best to stay focused on rehab, but it is difficult with all the financial worries. Joe is an avid outdoorsman and he has worked for Mark Patrick Seminars as a Hypnotherapist for twenty years. He and his wife, Heather, have traveled all over the country helping people to quit smoking and with weight-loss, thereby changing thousands and thousands of lives. Even after twenty years, he is passionate about his work because he lost his dad to heart disease, and he’s lost other family members to lung cancer and diabetes. Joe is a fighter, and he is already talking about getting back to helping others.  HOW THE MONEY WILL BE USED:Funds raised in this campaign will go directly to provide financial aid towards the many months of rehabilitation, transportation services to therapy, and special therapies that Joe will need.   Their insurance will not cover all of their expenses, and it can only cover a certain percentage of them. So we are asking for you to donate gracefully because this will help provide financial support towards Joe’s long recovery.  A LITTLE ABOUT ME:My name Pat Giorgio, and I have known Joe for over 33 years. If you have any questions, I can be reached at 973-768-4074.I want to thank everyone for their prayers and generosity. May every penny you donate bring blessings to you and your family.P.S. Even if you are unable to donate, please share this with the people you know. Together we can do this.

title: Support for the Pizzolato Family
text: On Tuesday, March 13th, Scotty underwent emergency surgery for an Aortic Dissection. He is currently recovering in ICU at OLOL in Baton Rouge. He is facing a long and difficult recovery with the possibility of many ups and downs. Despite his scary situation, Scotty has not lost his fighting spirit.So many of his dear friends have reached out asking how they can help Coach Pizz and his family during this trying time .  Financial support would be helpful for his medical expenses and the family's day to day needs while Scotty is unable to work for an unknown period of time. If you are unable to help support them financially, please keep Scotty, Amy, Brennan, Blake & Annie in your constant prayers.

title: Support Izzy's Fight Against Cancer
text: Family & friends, As you know, our beautiful, sweet Isabella has been diagnosed with Stage 4 Neuroblastoma.  She has a very long road ahead of her and Royce and Tierra need our  help.  Izzy will start treatment in the coming days which, as you can imagine, will be incredibly challenging for the family mentally, emotionally and financially.  Royce and T will  be limited in their ability to work as they care for Isabella, but they still have the normal expenses of everyday life, in additional to the medical expenses they've incurred and will continue to incur as Izzy's treatment progresses. A lot of people have asked what they can do to help, and this is a start.  We're asking you to contribute what you can so they can focus on caring for Izzy without worrying about how they are going to pay the rent, the utilities, the medical bills, etc.  Please share this link on your social media platforms so your friends, family, casual acquantinces, whoever- sees this post!  We need as many contributors as possible.  Our goal is high, but we are walking into the unknown and they need all the funds we can raise.  Anything helps. No donation is too small.   Helen Keller said, "Alone we can do so little;  together we can do so much."   Let's band together to help this family during this difficult time! Thank you for your love, support and prayers,#TEAM IZZY

title: Baby Aimee Higa Oshiro Ing
text: Aimee Leona Higa Ing was born on March 16, 2018 with a VSD; a common congenital heart defect in which there is a hole in the wall separating the two lower chambers of the heart. Her parents, Carolina and Brandon were informed of the VSD when Caro was still 4 months pregnant. As time progressed, it became  clear that surgery was necessary to close the hole because it was too large to close on its own. Aimee had increased complications and could not gain enough weight to receive surgery in Hawaii. Therefore, the medical decision was to fly her to San Diego where a team of pediatric heart surgeons would perform the surgery. Both Brandon and Caro had to take unpaid leave from their jobs to accommodate and care for Aimee while at Rady Children’s Hospital.  The surgery was performed on June 27th and it was successful. Aimee’s parents are very grateful that she is doing well, but is also concerned about the hospital bills and other related expenses. Aimee will need to remain in San Diego for at least 6-8 weeks or more as she recovers. Aimee’s family will humbly accept any financial assistance offered, no matter how great or small.

title: CowboysRun4Allison
text: Click here ->   PackersRun4Allison     vs    CowboysRun4Allison  <-Click hereIn support of Allison and Oral Cancer Research, Coppell MS West Assistant Principal, Bruce Hermans, will run his first marathon, the Cellcom Green Bay Marathon on May 20, 2018 in Green Bay, Wisconsin. Mr. Hermans, a die-hard Packer fan will race wearing the winning team's jersey as he crosses the finish line in famed Lambeau Field .      www.cellcomgreenbaymarathon.comTwo rival football GoFundMe accounts are accepting donations:                                   Click here ->   PackersRun4Allison    vs    CowboysRun4Allison  <-Click hereWho loves their team more? Cast your vote by donating funds to support Allison and her family with medical bills and lost income. Funds will also support the Oral Cancer Foundation.About Allison:Allison Hartzell is the 10 year accomplished choral director at Coppell Middle School West and is battling Stage 4 tongue and head and neck cancer. Only 10 months after extensive chemotherapy and radiation she has had a recurrence of squamous cell carcinoma. Since being diagnosed only a year ago, she has been fighting this devastating disease with positivity and courage. Her fighting spirit moved West to do something to help!  Inspired by runner, CMS West Assistant Principal, Bruce Hermans creative idea of Run4Allison, the West staff and learner's compassionate hearts have overflowed engaging the entire school in a Challenge Based Learning Project (CBL) to see which football team has the most dedicated fans through a friendly compitition ending in donations to support Mrs. Hartzell. *Funds raised beyond the family needs will go to Cancer Research via the  "Oral Cancer Foundation ".*Note: donations are not tax deductable under applicable 501c3 guidelines.

title: April Bennett Support/Healing Fund
text: h https://www.gofundme.com/lovefor-Aprilttps://www.gofundme.com/lovefor-April Our dear friend April Bennett is facing the journey of a lifetime. Recently diagnosed with breast cancer, April will undergo a double mastectomy and several months of aggressive cancer treatments.April is meeting all of this head-on, navigating the multiple appointments and multi- level decision-making, planning for all that is required of her logistically and physically over the next several months. And while no one can take on this part for her, we can help with the massive financial burden associated with it.Like many single parents who are small business owners, April is unable to simply stop working and continue to support her two boys Griffin and Sullivan. Yet, according to her medical team, the physical exertion required by her work as a wedding photographer may be impossible for several months following surgery and during the exhausting chemotherapy treatments. This has resulted in thousands of dollars of client refund costs and cancelled weddings.Further, bookings for summer and fall 2018 weddings are all happening now. Without a clear vision of her recovery track, April can’t, in good conscience, commit to new weddings. Therefore, she loses about half of this year’s income, and won’t be able to book any weddings until early 2019.Finally, while April does have insurance, she will be required to lay out $7400 to meet her deductible before insurance kicks in to pay for the massive cost of cancer treatment.We want April to put every ounce of energy into healing. We want her to not even consider the thought of going into credit card debt to pay for medical bills and other expenses. We know the village. We believe in its goodness. We know that April has been a part of it, carrying weight for others to ease their massive burdens. We want this care for April, in spite of her reluctance to ask for it.We are setting a fund-raising goal of $18,000, to cover that monstrous $7400 deductible, refunds, and a portion of lost living expenses, so that April can make healing her fulltime job this year. Anything raised above the amount will go toward the remaining lost wages. We deeply appreciate any support you feel moved to provide.

title: Dwight Knight Fund
text: “Therefore his sisters sent unto him, saying, Lord, behold, he whom thou lovest is sick.” John 11:3On the evening of Tuesday, May 29 Brother Dwight started exhibiting signs of a stroke. Lear and Stephane took him to the hospital where upon evaluation the doctors diagnosed him as having had a mild stroke. By the grace of God he was able to get to the hospital before any further damage was done. Dwight’s speech and right side of his body have been impacted. As it stands now he is now making steps towards recovery but is very tired and is in need of rest. Intensive rehab is planned upon discharge.Dwight and Stephane have personally ministered to many across the globe. They are now in need of our prayers and support. While some are able to minister by proximity, those that find themselves far away are encouraged  uphold them in your prayers.All funds raised here will be placed in a trust for the specific purpose to offset current and future healthcare costs as well as to cover living expenses while they are unable to continue their rigorous itinerant speaking schedule.  Shaji Varghese (CM Board Member) will be appointed the trustee, on behalf of the Challenge Ministries Board of Directors -  http://www.challenge-ministries.org/about-2/board-of-directors/) to disburse the funds accordingly.The volume of individuals who have been personally touched by this couple are enormous as expected the number of caring calls, texts, and emails have become overwhelming. Please refrain from reaching out directly. Lear will be posting regular updates in this Facebook group ( https://m.facebook.com/?_rdr#~!/groups/813461268849808?ref=bookmarks)Thank you for your generous support. Summer Trip Alumni

title: Rally for Nicholas!
text: Our friend and colleague Anna Baratelle's son Nicholes is very sick. Nicholas was originally diagnosed in 2015, when he was a freshman with disseminating oligodendroglial-like leptomeningeal tumors.  Multiple tumors surrounded his brain.  He was treated at Children's Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP) with chemo for 18 months, as well as proton beam radiation to his brain and spine for 30 treatments.  In September 2016, he finished all treatments and he just needed to get MRI scans every 3 months, just to make sure the tumors were gone.  In September, 2017, the MRI showed new tumors in his cerebellum.  New chemo treatments started, but the tumors did not respond this time.  In April, 2018, he was signed up for a clinical research trial at John's Hopkins.  Unfortunately, the MRI scans and PET scans that were required for the clinical trial, discovered that the cancer had spread in to his bones.  A bone marrow biopsy confirmed that it is in his bone marrow.  He continues to be treated at CHOP for his pain and symptoms, and also continuing the clinical trial treatment at Hopkins.  Please help us raise money to pay for medical bills and treatments. Please rally for Nicholas!

title: Caring For Courtney
text: Galatians 6:2Carry each other’s burdens, and in this way you will fulfill the law of Christ.Anyone who knows our dear sweet Courtney, knows she would move mountains to be there for you without ever needing to ask. It’s just who she is. Always caring, always willing to drop what she is doing to help, and always there to hug and pray with you.For more than the past few years, Courtney has been silently enduring so much medically. As most of us know, in 2015 Courtney had brain surgery to remove a cyst in her brain that was causing so many side effects for her. While the surgery to remove the cyst was a success, it was not without lingering complications. What we thought were just temporary symptoms from her surgery turned out to be TWO more cysts that had returned to the exact same spot she had her first removal. Her Dr. who specializes in this type of surgery and cysts had NEVER seen this happen before. Throughout it all, Courtney and Keith remained positive and steadfast in their walk with God knowing that he is her ultimate healer. In January 2017 Courtney had to go back into a second brain surgery to remove the two new cysts. The removal was a success and Courtney took her allotted 6 weeks off of work to heal and recover. All though she was still experiencing symptoms, Courtney returned to her job. The day she returned to work, she was informed she no longer had a position with the company. Courtney took this in stride and set out to find a new job. She sent in over 100 applications with no success. She is still currently unemployed and without health insurance. As of the past few months, Courtney’s symptoms since her second surgery have been progressively getting worse. One of her recent visits and scans has shown that the pressure in her brain from her spinal fluid is just too high. Her medical team has tried to treat this with multiple medications which Courtney’s body won’t tolerate. With this pressure comes intense headaches, vertigo, insomnia, loss of appetite, confusion, blurry vision, confused speech, and fatigue. It is clear to her medical team that she is in need of another surgery to place a shunt in her brain to relieve the fluid and pressure build up. This needs to be done now. There is no other option at this point. Since Courtney has lost her job, and Keith had recently started new employment, there is no health insurance at this time. They are above the income threshold to qualify for Medicaid which means this will be all out of pocket. After the hospital bringing the cost down over 50%, Courtney and Keith are looking at a $60,000.00 dollar price tag to get her through this. This money MUST be paid in full for her May 31st surgery by the 30th. We have to have all funds in by the 24th of this month to process and be able to pay the hospital. There you have it. This is the Goliath that they are facing in this moment. But we as believers know they do not face this alone. This is not a surprise to God, and it is in Him whom all our provision comes.I am asking all of our friends and family to take a moment and stop to pray. Pray first and foremost that God perform a complete healing and Courtney doesn’t need this surgery! However, if he chooses to use this medical team to give her relief and healing, pray that he can use each one of us to meet this financial need. No amount is too little.Luke 6:38 “Give, and it will be given to you. A good measure, pressed down, shaken together and running over, will be poured into your lap. For with the measure you use, it will be measured to you”Proverbs 3:27 “Do not withhold good from those to whom it is due, when it is in your power to act.”Romans 12:13 “Share with the Lord’s people who are in need. Practice hospitality.”James 2:14-17 “What good is it, my brothers and sisters, if someone claims to have faith but has no deeds? Can such faith save them? Suppose a brother or sister is without clothes and daily food. If one of you says to them, ‘Go in peace; keep warm and well fed’, but does nothing about their physical needs, what good is it? In the same way, faith by itself, if it is not accompanied by action, is dead”

title: Help Don Coufal Battle Cancer
text: In February, our Dad, Don Coufal, was diagnosed with Stage 4 Cancer - rectal cancer, that had spread to the liver. The prognosis was disheartening. While his symptoms are treatable, doctors do not believe the cancer itself is curable. And yet, throughout the experience, Dad has maintained a strong and positive outlook. He is doing his research, working hard to eat healthy, and trying to keep his mind active and engaged on other things.One issue that has been weighing on Dad is finances. The financial burden of a cancer diagnosis, coupled with the fact that he won't be able to work for the foreseeable future, has interrupted his retirement plans and placed a great deal of stress on his shoulders. We want Dad to be able to stay calm and positive so he can focus on healing. In that light, we are reaching out to Dad's friends, family, and colleagues for support. Anything we raise will help cover his living expenses so he can stay financially afloat while he is out of work.We know that anything you can contribute would mean a great deal right now and help to ease this enormous burden. Your support means the world to our family. Thank you.- Emma and Libby

title: Please Help My Mother
text: Hey, this is Mary (Nayun). For those of you who know me well, you'd know that the last thing I want to do is ask other's for help. I pride myself in being independent and self-reliant, but my mother getting sick happened all too fast and all too big for me to handle. The only thing I can do for my mom at this point in time is ask for help. (1 week before the incident)My mother, Myung Hee (Elizabeth) Park, is a parent who lives for her kids. She ran a dry cleaners by herself for 12 years, so that she could provide for my brother and me. She would hold in her urine many times because she feared to miss a customer and lose the extra dollar, the extra dollar that would go towards my brother's and my education.  She was the first one to teach me and my brother about unconditional love. My mother is the one person in the world that I love more than myself and she could've been gone in a matter of hours.  On 2/22/18, we took my mother into the ER where she was diagnosed with sepsis, which further developed into septic shock with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome. Despite giving her antibiotics, her white blood cell and procalcitonin levels kept increasing to levels that were the highest some doctors and nurses have seen in their career. Both her kidneys were failing and the liver was starting to fail as well. We were unsure that she was going to make it as septic shock has a very high mortality rate. In fact, multiple doctors have told me that it truly is a miracle she is alive. Due to the septic shock, my mother's blood pressure dropped drastically with a very irregular heart rate so we started her on multiple blood pressure medications to keep her blood pressure up. Unfortunately, her extremities have necrotized due to the minimal circulation from the blood pressure medications and her fingers and toes have resulted in gangrene (dead tissue). Currently, we are unsure how much of her hands and feet are going to to make it. We are waiting for the body to demarcate on its own and then, she will require amputations and prosthetics of both hands and feet in the future once she is stronger. There was substantial atrophy of her muscles from being strictly bedridden for weeks. My mother, once a healthy and independent woman, can no longer lift her arms to eat or sit up in a chair, let alone walk. She has a long and intense recovery with physical therapy, speech therapy (from being intubated multiple times and for long period of time), and occupational therapy.My mother almost died. No, that would be an understatement. Just looking at her blood results, symptoms, and the severity of her sepsis, she should have died. However, my mom is the strongest woman I know and her strength is what kept her alive. Recently, she told me, "It's okay if I don't have hands or feet. I'm alive. I'm grateful and happy that I will be able to see you and your brother grow." My mom's passion is cooking. She's the best cook, trust me. For my friends who've tried her food, you'll agree. So when she said that to me, I cried. A lot. For the 432489th time. By some miracle and everyone's thoughts and prayers, my mom is alive. She has a long road to recovery ahead of her and my family needs a miracle to make sure she gets there. The surgery, prosthetics, rehab centers, therapy appointments, medications, etc. will probably add up to more than 25,000, but please help my family start her recovery period. I'm still in disbelief that I find myself in a position to write this, but here I am. My mother is the sweetest, brightest, warmest and strongest woman I know and deserved none of this. She has done everything for my brother and me, so please help me do something for my mom. Thank you.

title: Rob & Maria Frischman
text: Our cherished Frisch was tragically and prematurely taken from us after a courageous fight with brain cancer.  Robert’s beloved, Maria, spent the past 18 months completely devoted to caring for him on a full-time basis, protecting and comforting him until the very end.  During this period of Robert’s illness, Maria had to forego her own job to care for him, leaving her without an income.This memorial fund is intended to help ease the financial burden for Maria and her two young daughters that comes with losing a beloved and picking back up a life. Together we can help them get back on their feet until Maria finds work. Any help, no matter how small, is greatly appreciated. We thank you with the cherished memory of Robert in our hearts.

title: Julie’s fight
text: Update from Julie7/16/18 So, my fight continues.....for the past 8 weeks I have been receiving treatment as part of a clinical trial. The immunotherapy trial worked with my immune system to fight the cancer, but I have suffered fatigue, and continued growth of the cancerous skin nodules on my left side. Also, my breathing has continued to deteriorate to the point that I now am forced to use a portable oxygen machine. The doctors have been concerned about the continued skin involvement and breathing troubles so a biopsy was performed on some skin nodules to see if my immune system had begun attacking the cancer cells. Unfortunately, my immune cells were not present in the nodules and this indicates that the treatment is not yet working.  So....my doctors decided to move on to another treatment. I started chemotherapy last Thursday. This chemotherapy is strong and works to attack the cancer. I will see more side effects from this treatment than the immunotherapy. It is likely I will suffer from fatigue, nausea, low blood counts and I will lose my hair again (this time it’s curly hair ). The doctors need to combat the cancer now, in hopes that a promising clinical trial becomes available. I will likely have to avoid a lot of crowds and germs but I will continue fighting like I have been for the past year and a half. I am so overwhelmed by the amazing support of my family, friends and community we are so thankful to know that we aren’t in this alone. After several months of telling Amy not to put this page up, I’m glad she finally got me to cave. I have been able to share my story and reconnect with so many friends from all over. My family and I feel blessed to have so many people in our corner and your generosity has been humbling. From the bottom of my heart thank you!

title: Stand Tall With Sarah
text: ￼Measuring in at just over 5 feet, Sarah may not stand tall literally speaking, but figuratievly she will stand tall during the most epic battle of her life. At 31 years old, during her prime, Sarah recently received the life changing news that she has stage 4 cancer. To those who have the pleasure of knowing her, it came as a shock to say the least.  It seems unimaginable that this could happen to a vibrant, young woman who prides herself in her work as a personal trainer and lives a healthy lifestyle. It's  hard to think that this could happen to such a good person. Sarah is a loyal friend, caring daughter, supportive sister, devoted partner to her significant other, Jacquie and of course loving dog mom to her fur baby, Wendy; she means so much to the many people in her life. She is a truly beautiful human being with a kind heart and genuine soul.  Sarah's journey in her fight against cancer is just beginning. This journey will no doubt be a challenge, but certainly one Sarah will conquer with grace and dignity. Sarah's courage thus far has been worthy of admiration; she is a true inspiration. As her medical team at Dana-Farber continues to work tirelessly to determine the primary source of her cancer, the medical bills have already started to pile up. Given that the cancer has spread to many lymph nodes throughout her body, Sarah will need aggressive chemotherapy.  She has been out of work due to debilitating nerve pain and endless medical appointments. She will continue to be unable to work for the foreseeable future. As Sarah fights hard to heal her body, we want to remove some of her financial burden so that Sarah can focus on kicking cancer's ass.HOW YOU CAN HELP SARAH:And so we ask that you to consider supporting Sarah in anyway you can. Please send her your prayers, positive vibes, and loving support. Any donation to help Sarah through this difficult time would be appreciated. For those of you who know Sarah, you know how deserving she is of all the love and support we can offer. For those of you who don't know Sarah, I hope you have the pleasure of meeting her at some point. I can assure you, you would be inspired by the courage, positive attitude and strength she has demonstrated in the face of adversity. Please follow Sarah's journey: Caring Bridge- Stand Tall with Sarah Please help us spread the word by sharing the link:Go Fund Me- Stand Tall with Sarah On behalf of Team Sarah, thank you for your support.

title: Jane Schryer support
text: After suffering from back pain and an enlarging mass for over a month, our wonderful first year anesthesiology resident Jane Schryer, was recently and unexpectedly diagnosed with a malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor. These rare tumors have been known to have a potentially devastating outcome. After her case was presented at Banner’s Neurosurgery tumor board, it was decided that Jane should be treated at UCSF, a center that specializes in Nerve Sheath tumors. She will need to have an operation to give her the best chance for long term survivability. Unfortunately, all the costs of her treatment will be out of network and she will be responsible for all travel and lodging for her family. Jane has spent most of her life caring for others. She started as an ED and ICU nurse at St Joseph Medical Center in Stockton, CA. After she got married, she worked at UC Davis Medical Center before moving to Chandler for her husband’s job. She worked as an RN in the CTICU/SICU at Scottsdale Healthcare and went back to school to complete her pre med requirements. She was accepted into The University of Arizona Medical School in 2012. While attending medical school, she also worked per diem at Northwest Medical Center in Tucson. Jane graduated from medical school in 2016 and did her transitional year at Tucson Medical Center before she started her anesthesiology residency at The University of Arizona/Banner University Medical Center. She is a loving wife and mother to 2 beautiful daughters. Jane has her first appointment at UCSF on May 8th, 2018. It is anticipated that she will have surgery that week and afterwards begin radiation and physical therapy. We’re all pulling for Jane to recover and be able to return to work and her great life.

title: Care for Geno
text: Geno is 69 years old. He was diagnosed with young onset/early stage Alzheimer's Disease at 62. He started showing symptoms 2-3 years prior, but we didn't know what was going on.Geno and I were married on June 26, 1982, 36 years ago. We have raised two sons, Ben and Owen. Our family was very thankfully formed through adoption. They both came to us through Open Adoption at birth.Geno was a Special Education teacher, firewood supplier, track coach and placer gold miner over the course of our adventuresome years together.Upon the onset of AD we were able to continue our lifestyle to a lesser degree with each passing year as he lost more and more cognitive abilities. Working was out almost immediately, but he was still able to camp, gold mine and run for a while. When all else was falling away he could still run.... So I  had him join a local running team, Sierra Gold. With a teammate at his side at every training session and in every race he was able to compete in local 5k races for 3 years! The past year even that skill began to disappear. He got lost 7 times over a period of 4 months. Fortunately for us some kind neighbor, or complete stranger would bring him home.This is a man who is in the Athletic Hall of Fame at California State University Chico and is still listed in the top 10 for both the 800 m and the mile!His time spent with caregivers increased until he was with them 5 days a week, at an out of pocket cost of over $1,500/month.On April 27, 2018, I placed him in Sierra Ridge Memory Care in Auburn, CA. It was the right timing for both of us. My health was beginning to suffer and I knew I had to trust that someone else could take over his care. Geno has adapted easily to his new living situation and is cared for with loving care "In the Moment". However, this loving care comes with a hefty price tag. Beginning August 1 my out of pocket cost will jump from an introductory fee of $3,000/month to $5,200/month because of his toileting issues (he pees in the hallways because he doesn't know where the bathrooms are AND he doesn't know how to tell anyone that he needs to go) besides needing help dressing and showering.MediCal does not kick in until someone requires skilled nursing, ie, is bedridden. Geno won't qualify for that for a long time, unless he falls and breaks a hip or gets pneumonia. Wonderful choices.So in a nutshell, within one year I will have no more money, he will still need care, and I will probably have to sell our home for his continued care, leaving me destitute. I never in my wildest dreams ever expected to be in this kind of situation. But here it is. Geno and I need financial help.Thank you for your consideration.

title: Austin's Adventure
text: Austin Fitzhugh is one of those people that impacts the lives of strangers, friends and loved ones by bringing so much happiness and light into our lives. He is selfless, kind, strong, and my favorite person in the world. In June of 2017 Austin was diagnosed with Glioblastoma, an aggressive form of brain cancer. For the last year Austin has had several brain surgeries, completed weeks of intensive radiation, many months of chemotherapy, and has worked hard every day with physical, speech and occupational therapists. Throughout all of these challenges Austin continues to be the most positive person and has acted as a pillar of strength for all of us. In the last week Austin had an MRI scan that indicated regrowth. As of right now there are plans for Austin to have alternative forms of therapy to combat cancer growth. The purpose of this page is to help fund Austin's dreams to travel the world. We have been so fortunate for him to have  great health insurance and such an incredible family and support system but I would like to raise some money for him so he can travel to all the places he has always wanted to go including Thailand, Ireland, Myanmar, Spain and more.I just want more than anything for him to find some happiness through the tough year ahead of him. Love, Lena

title: Samir Hamzabegovic's Medical Fund
text: Unfortunately, I have some sad news to share with our fellow community in regards to my best friend Samir Hamzabegovic. He is 45 years old and is a husband and father of two children. His story begins back on December 3, 2017 when he was diagnosed with stage 4 metastatic small cell lung cancer that spread to his liver and bones. He immediately began chemotherapy and completed 18 rounds. Shortly after, he completed 10 rounds of chest radiation. On April 10th 2018, Samir had three ischemic strokes and was hospitalized. Shortly after, on June 1st doctors informed him that the cancer had metastasized to his brain. He then completed 10 rounds of brain radiation in hopes of stopping the growth. July 12th 2018 after his CT scan follow-up, doctors informed him that the cancer had returned back on his right lung, spine and hips. This has been an eight month long downhill battle for Samir and his family. I would like to ask our community and anyone wanting to help to please donate however much is in their ability, as well as send prayers to him and his family to fight through this battle. Thank you in advance to anyone and everyone willing to help!Postovani prijatelji, imam veoma lose vijesti da podjelim sa vama. Nas dragi prijatelj Samir Hamzabegovic (45.god) diagnostiran je sa veoma opakom bolescu, cetvrtog stepena raka pluca koji je poceo da migrira po tijelu.U ovom teskom vremenu koje nas dragi prijatelj prolazi sa svojom porodicom, zamolio bih ljude dobre volje i ko je u mogucnosti da pomogne nasem prijatelju,  vasa donacija ce nam znaciti puno.Unaprijed, dobri ljudi,  u moje ime (Mustafa Dedić) i ime porodice Hamzabegovic zelim da vam se zahvalim.. HVALA!

title: Chris's Medical and Funeral Expense
text: We are raising money to help Christopher Masarone with any Medical Bills or Financial burdens he may have at this time. On April 17, 2018 Christopher was in a Motorcycle accident. He has sustained major trauma to his head and will have a long recovery ahead of him starting with being in the ICU for a few weeks (hopefully less). His status will be updated weekly or daily. We thank everyone for their love and support at this very tragic and fragile time.USMC Veteran, Loving father, husband, and friend.

title: Naia's Fight!
text: On Friday April 20, 2018, Naia Coltman was a passenger in a serious car accident and was ejected from the vehicle. Naia remains in critical condition in the ICU at this time. She continues to be surrounded by her family, friends and the greatest team of doctors and nurses imaginable. Naia has suffered a traumatic brain injury, along with some broken ribs and lacerated liver, among other injuries, and at this time, remains on a ventilator to assist her in breathing. Naia is going to require long-term medical assistance. Naia's longtime passion for Cheer and dedication to her Cheer Family exemplifies her dynamic personality and enthusiasm for life! We are seeking donations of any size (anything helps!) to support Naia and her family during this incredibly difficult time.  All money raised will go towards hospital expenses for Naia, ongoing long-term medical expenses and helping the family while both Marc and Shanda take time away from their job(s) to support their Daughter. This family is a family of service, with Marc serving our Country as a Marine in prior years, and continuing to serve our community still today as a Firefighter.  Please help us in returning generosity to the Coltman family by supporting Naia in her fight to recover!  Prayer is so powerful, so please keep those coming! The Coltman family is grateful beyond words for everyone’s outpouring of love and support.

title: Team Gage
text: Gage Benjamin Peters is a sweet 2 year old boy who loves his family, Mickey Mouse, and riding his golf cart. On Tuesday, 8/7/18, he was lethargic and very sleepy- only staying awake for 1-2 minutes at a time. He was taken to his pediatricians office where he was referred to the ER at UPMC. He was immediately admitted and doctors began testing. Keli and Jason’s worst nightmare was when a cat scan confirmed he had a huge mass on his brain. On Wednesday 8/8/18, Gage underwent brain surgery in hopes to remove the tumor.  8 hours and 3 blood transfusions later, the nightmare became a reality. Gage has brain cancer, and they were not able to remove the entire mass as it was so deep in his brain and removing from his brain stem was too dangerous. Pathology results could take up to 2 weeks, so we are still unsure of the type of brain cancer and how aggressive it is. I have started this page to help raise money for Gage, Keli and Jason for the medical costs, insurance bills, and other expenses resulting from this tragedy. We have a long road ahead of us and we are trying to stay positive and optimistic for our little warrior.At some point in our lives, all of us have been affected by cancer—either a personal battle or helping a loved one with the disease. Besides the physical and emotional tolls, fighting cancer can be an enormous financial burden. When you or a loved one is fighting there is never enough time or money. Your donations are greatly appreciated. Thank you for the overwhelming amount of prayer chains and kind thoughts and words.

title: Support Russ & his family!
text: Russ has been a key member of the legal team the Logitech family. Over the last 3 years (including a year at our office in Lausanne), he’s helped guide us through challenges in litigation, built a strong corporate compliance function, and guide our IP portfolio and strategy.  More important than any of the great work that he’s done here, Russ has been a great friend and colleague as well as an inspiration to many.As many of you know Russ is an active and avid outdoorsman (skiing, hiking, kayaking, mountain biking).  Unfortunately about two weeks ago, at the end of a mountain biking ride, Russ had an accident and suffered a severe spinal cord injury. He is paralyzed from the chest down and the prognosis for a full recovery is challenging at best. Russ is hard at work on recovering from and managing his various injuries.  He has a great team of doctors and specialists at Seattle’s Harborview Hospital. His wife Tamara and four grown children (Alex, Sam, Kate, and Heidi) are at his side and are supporting him through this difficult time. Tamara and their two daughters live up in Bellingham nearly a 3-hour drive away and his sons live outside of the state as well. As his friends and colleagues, we wanted to do what we can to help support Russ and his family as he fights to overcome and manage his injuries. We’re hoping to show our support with a small gesture to help them deal with travel costs, hotels, meals etc. as Russ is expected to be at Harborview Hospital until at least October 1st.  Of course, there is absolutely no obligation to help but we thought this was one simple way to do so.  We know that every little bit will help so I hope you all will join us!

title: Mark's Kidney Transplant
text: Mark has been diagnosed with end stage renal disease and is need of a kidney transplant. With 3 donor recipients currently being tested, Mark and his family are hopeful that the transplant could happen this summer. The procedure, pre-op and post-op care will be costly in both time and money, and Mark and his wife Amanda will need to reside in Houston before and after the surgery, putting a tremendous strain on their finances.  If you are able, please considering a donation to Mark's cause.

title: Estudios y terapias para Sofia
text: Hola, yo soy Sofía, tengo 3 años y medio. Cuando tenía 6 meses me diagnosticaron Hipoplasia del Cuerpo Calloso lo que hace que los hemisferios de mi cerebro no se comuniquen bien y, entre otras cosas, mi desarrollo psicomotor se ha visto bastante afectado por lo que todavía no digo palabras, no camino, no tengo mucho equilibrio, no mastico la comida y me es difícil sostener las cosas.Nací en México en donde comencé a hacer terapia desde los 6 meses. Cuando tenía 1 año y 3 meses nos mudamos a Estados Unidos, ya que mis médicos le recomendaron a mis papás que allí tendríamos más oportunidades, mejores terapias y más tecnología que me ayudarían a combatir mis fallas psicomotoras. Durante mi tiempo en Estados Unidos he tenido la fortuna de poder hacer mis terapias ocupacional, física y de lenguaje. He mejorado, pero en el trayecto le dijeron a mis padres que también tengo parálisis cerebral y mi espalda, pies, manos, ojos y oídos se han visto afectados también. Por eso he tenido que visitar a especialistas de la espalda, de los pies, de la vista y de la audición.Mi diagnóstico es complicado y por eso necesito hacerme varios estudios médicos para poder saber realmente qué sucede dentro de mi cerebro, cómo afecta mi cuerpo y entender cuáles son las mejores herramientas para ser tratada. Esos estudios incluyen resonancia magnética para ver como ha evolucionado mi cerebro desde la primera vez que diagnosticaron la malformación del cuerpo calloso, examen de la vista para saber como mi cerebro interpreta las imágenes, exámenes auditivos para saber cuanto y como escucho, exámenes de la columna vertebral ya que tengo una pequeña desviación, examen genético para determinar la causa de lo que me pasó. También necesito férulas y equipos que me den soporte para aprender a caminar, a sostener las cosas, dispositivos para ayudarme a comunicar, terapias y ejercicios en agua.Actualmente no cuento con seguro médico y mis padres tampoco cuentan con el dinero para pagar por todo esto que suma aproximadamente $21,000 USD. Mi mamá debe estar conmigo 100% de su tiempo acompañándome en terapias y mi papá trabaja mucho para cubrir los gastos. Ellos no quisieran perder la oportunidad de darme todo lo que puedan para que yo mejore y más ahora que estoy pequeña y mi cerebro, con la ayuda necesaria, puede aprender a compensar sus fallas y yo, dentro de mis capacidades, ser una niña independiente. Si no puedes ayudarme con un aporte económico no importa, igual te agradezco haberte tomado el tiempo de leer mi historia y lo que te pido es que la compartas porque también así me ayudas.De corazón muchísimas gracias!!!_______________________________________________________Hi, my name is Sofia and I´m 3 years and a half old. When I was 6 months the doctors diagnosed me with Hypoplasia Corpus Callosumwhich makes it difficult for my two sides of the brain to communicate well and, among other things, my psychomotor skills have been quite affected and because of that I cannot say word, I cannot walk, I do not have much of a balance, I cannot chew my meals and it is hard for me to grasp things.I was born in Mexico, where, when I was 6 months old, I began my therapy. We moved to the USA when I was 1 year and 3 months old because my doctors in Mexico advised my mom and daddy that here I would have more opportunities, better therapies and technologies to help me fight my psychomotor delay. Since I arrived to USA I have had the fortune to do more language, physical and occupational therapies. I have improved, but along the way my parents were informed that I also suffer from cerebral palsy and my back, feet, hands, eyes and ears have also been affected. Because of this, I have to visit back, feet, eyes and ears specialists.My diagnostic is quite complicated and I need to have several medical examinations to try to understand what is really happening inside my brain, how it affects my body and to try to determine which are the best tools for my treatment.These medical examinations include magnetic resonance scan (MRI scan) to see how my brain has responded from the first time the doctors diagnosed the malformation of my corpus callosum, eye exams to see how my brain interprets images, hearing exams to know how much and how I hear, cerebral and spine exams because I my back has a slight curvature, as well as a genetic exam to determine the cause of what happened to me. I also need splints and diverse devices that will support me while I learn to walk, grab objects with my hands, devices to help me communicate and more therapies and exercises in the therapy pool.At the moment I do not have a medical insurance and my parents do not have sufficient money to pay for what is mentioned before, which costs $21,000.00 approximately. My Mom must spend her time accompanying me to my therapies and my Dad works very hard to cover the costs. They want to give me all they can so I can get better, knowing that since I am just a kid my brain - with the appropriate help - can learn to compensate its flaws and I, within reason, may be a normal girl and lead a normal life.If you cannot help me with monetary funds, I would like to thank you for taking your time to read my story and I will kindly ask you for a very big favor: please help me by sharing my plea.I thank you from the bottom of my heart!!!

title: A 2nd Chance At Life "Stem Cells"
text: January 2, 2015 is a day I will never forget. One day can change your life. One day can change everything. It did for me. While heading to the city to pursue my dream of being a singer, I was shot by someone I had never met or even shared a word with. And for that, I lost the use of my body from a bullet that wasn’t meant for me. I am paralyzed and can’t move my legs or arms.Ever since this day, I’ve been fighting for the return and use of my body, something given to me from birth but taken from me for no reason. I’ve tried to work out, do physical therapy, but nothing is helping me recover. I’ve tried everything, and despite the lack of a drastic change, I’ve continued to fight.For the past three years I’ve prayed every day for God to not only heal me and help me but to protect my family from being put in the same predicament. I’ve cried; I’ve been angry and depressed. But one thing I have yet to do is give up. I beleive that God only gives us tests that we can succeed in. Maybe this is mine.My faith in God and the determination of my mother to find the right person to help me led us to do a lot of research. We came across a place in Panama that is doing amazing work with stem cells. The Stem Cell Institute of Panama City uses a groundbreaking method for paralysis. Now, there’s no guarantee that this treatment will fully heal me, but I’ve tried everything else, and this is my last option. I really feel deep down in my heart that this will help.Hope is so close at hand. However, my mother spent a lot to care for me and to try to get me as close to any recovery as I could. You may wonder why I am not trying stem cells in America; each one I went to turned me down due to the fact that my injury was from a bullet. It’s sad because I was just trying to reach people with my music and be a good son to my mom and support her. I live a prayer-filled life, and was studying to be a corrections officer so I can have a good salary while I work on my music. And all I needed was someone to give me a chance because I know if I would of receive stem cells I would be walking by now.That’s why I’m asking you--people I’ve never met but who may just be willing to help me fight and recover--to please donate what you can. Please, from the kindness of your hearts, help me, even if it’s just a few dollars. Every lit bit goes a long way. I will be praying for all of you and will be eternally grateful. I know it’s a lot to ask for, but I am very grateful for each and every one of you. If you read my story and were moved to donate, allow me to say thank you now. I appreciate your kindness from the bottom of my heart. If you were only able to offer up a prayer for me today, thank you, and I will be praying for you, too. May God bless you. Thank you once again.

title: CANCER TREATMENT for TRAVIS
text: Friends & Family,This past May marked three years in Travis’s battle with cancer. For the last 15 months, Travis has been on constant chemotherapy to treat his stage 4 colon cancer. That includes several port chemo’s via infusion every-other week, one phase 2 clinical trial and one phase 3 clinical trial. Non-stop therapy with the exception of a week when he had a blood clot in his lung and a week when we got married.As all of you know, Travis is a FIGHTER. He is the strongest person I have ever known. I’ve seen first hand what this chemo can do to a person. It is not pretty. It can be a daily struggle. He goes through so much on these treatments. He amazes me at how he can still beam that beautiful smile of his even on his worst days. Travis works so incredibly hard. He does his chemo treatments Friday through Sunday so that he is ready to work at UPS Tuesday through Friday the following week.We are on an uphill battle. With his tumor marker on the rise since late last year, he has challenged his doctors on finding a chemotherapy that will work for his disease. This has been difficult. We were told that Travis has DEPLETED the available medicines to treat him with. He is on the list for new clinical trials. We declined a phase 1 trial that was offered to him a few weeks ago, as it would be the first time tested on HUMANS and he would spend 8 consecutive days in Seattle getting blood draws every 15 minutes for 12 hours a day. Quality of life is very important to Travis and this was not an option.I have a dear, close friend that reached out to me demanding I watch a documentary on Amazon Prime called, ‘Cancer Can be Killed’. This is where Travis’s story of becoming cancer free will begin. I know it! Several treatments are offered in Europe, Germany in our case, that the FDA has not made available here in the U.S.One of the treatments is Hyperthermia. Simply put, cancer doesn’t like heat. Once cancer cells are heated above approximately 105 degrees Fahrenheit their metabolism starts to break down. This halts further growth and causes the cells to die. That means tumor shrinkage and slower progression of disease.While they perform hyperthermia treatment every other day, you are on therapies like; Laetrile, Thymus Therapy, herbal supplements, ozone therapy (oxygenate your blood), Autologous Stem Cell Therapy, Tri-functional antibodies, Chelation, Vitamin C, Calcium EDTA, Myers’ Cocktail, Dioxychlor, Glutathione, liver support and many more IV infusions. All while eating a complete alkaline diet with limited red meat and no refined sugars.With your immune system at its best, they then do Dendritic Cell Therapy. The laboratory will work on Travis’s blood for 8 days. They will concentrate his body’s Dendritic cells on correctly identifying his body’s cancer as a threat, then they will reintroduce those cells into his system, the ‘trained’ cells can boost his body’s capacity to work AGAINST the cancer. The idea is to have Travis’s specific cancer battled by HIS OWN enhanced or boosted self immunity---a tailored cancer treatment vaccine! You guys, this MAKES sense! No chemotherapy- that kills his good cells and lowers his immune system to a terrifying low, with side effects that are completely awful.If you have time, please read up on this! Some lucky individuals are getting T-cell immunotherapy in clinical trials with diseases like lymphoma here in the states (literally on the floor above where Travis gets his chemotherapy at Seattle Cancer Care Alliance). It is not being tried on colorectal cancer at this time, and Travis, unfortunately does not have the time to wait until it is.Travis’s friends & family CARRIED him through his first year with this disease. He could not have done it without your help. That has never left his heart & mind. It is difficult for him to ask for help, but we are at the point.Travis’s doctor said we are out of options other than clinical trial chemotherapy. In time, his cancer will spread throughout his body and to his major organs. We are desperate for this treatment and are hoping to be able to go in August or September as time is of the essence. My mom is selling her 1978 Z28 Camaro and Patty, Travis’s mom is selling her motor-home to help out.I have created this go fund me for those who can and want to help get Travis to Germany for this advanced, once in a lifetime treatment. I will blog his journey and treatments and will become an advocate for ANYONE who needs help if they consider this treatment for themselves or a loved one.Here is the breakdown of cost at Infusio in Frankfurt, Germany:Flights: $1957Integrative Dendritic Cell Therapy Program: $34,70530 day stay @ Infusio Germany: $4,465Germany Liason Fees: $3,228Stem Cell Transportation: $1,103Airport Transfer: $220Admin Fee: $1311Total: $46,989Please continue to keep Travis in your thoughts and prayers.Thank you,Danielle

title: Standing Strong with Ms. Hamy
text: For anyone who knows this lady, you know she is down right amazing!  She has, through her kind genuine nature, touched the lives of so many of us over the years.  We know her through her work with children, sports, and community activity.  On behalf of her many friends who think the world of her and have benefited time and time again from her giving nature, we wanted to reach out and request your support and well wishes for Marsha and Terry and their family.  Marsha is dealing with stage 4 lung cancer and is currently going through medical treatment in Missoula.  This has all happened very quickly.  We anticipate she will have many unexpected expenses as well as potential treatment opportunities out of state.  We would like to help defer these costs and concerns for the Hamilton family.   Any donation would be greatly appreciated and put to good use.  We also anticipate you and/or your children may want to send her something special.  Please direct these items to the following address: 12905 Severin Meadows Trail, Lolo MT 59847If you have any other inquiries or requests, please feel free to contact any one of us by responding to this page or contacting us directly.  Thank you so much for being part of this effort and helping us all stand strong with Ms. Hamy!Renee King, Lindsey Olson and Katie Fortune

title: Help for Sandra and her family
text: Let’s help Sandra Fajeraizen Mikanovsky and her Family What can you really say about a woman who embodies the words kindness, loving and true friend. She is a dedicated daughter, mother and wife. Hard working and a fighter. Our dear friend Sandra has been diagnosed with Ovarian Cancer Stage 3. She has started chemotherapy treatments and will have to undergo surgery as well and more treatments.  With all of this going on, she will have to be out of work for a while. As you can imagine, these are some very difficult times for the family emotionally and financially. For those of you who would want and are able to do something, any amount helps. Every mitzvah that you do (Shabat candles, making challah, putting on tfilim, praying) please do it in her name Chaya Bat Dvora. We are asking from the bottom of our hearts, that if you can donate any amount that you can it can make a difference. She is a true fighter. A warrior! We love you and wish you a Refua ShlemaEspañol Ayudemos a Sandra Fajeraizen Mikanovsky y su familiaQue podemos decir de una mujer que representa las palabras bondad, cariño y verdadera amiga. Sandra es una hija, madre y esposa dedicada. Trabajadora y luchadora.  Nuestra querida amiga Sandra ha sido diagnosticada con Cancer De Ovario etapa 3. Ha comenzado los tratamientos de quimioterapia, necesitará una cirugía y después más tratamientos. Con todo esto, Sandra estará fuera del trabajo por un periodo tiempo. Como se pueden imaginar, la familia esta pasando por momentos difíciles emocionales y financieros. Para todos aquellos que quieran y puedan ayudar, cualquier monto ayuda. Cada Mitzvah que hagan (encendido de velas de shabat, hacer challah, ponerse tfilim or rezar, etc) por favor háganlo en su  nombre: Chaya Bat Dvora. Les pedimos del fondo de nuestro corazón  que si pueden donar, cualquier monto puede hacer una diferencia. Ella es una luchadora, una guerrera! La queremos mucho y le deseamos Refuah Shlema

title: Christyn Pope's Recovery
text: Our beloved teacher and friend Christyn Pope has been battling melanoma for the past few years. In March 2018, Christyn was diagnosed with advanced melanoma (stage 4) and began an aggressive immunotherapy and radiation program to fight this terrible cancer.   On Saturday June 30, Christyn, who loves international travel, was with friends on vacation in the Maldives. She suffered a brain hemorrhage, a rare complication from her treatment.  She had emergency surgery in Male and is currently progressing from her surgery in the hospital there.  When she is stable, her doctor can clear her to fly back San Diego, which could be as soon as 10 days, or as long as 6 weeks.   Several friends have been at her side during this scary and complicated surgery, and her sister Carla arrived this week.  All of us remain optimistic that she will get stronger and hope that she is able to come home quickly.     We are asking loved ones and friends to donate anything they can to help offset medical expenses that may not be covered by her insurance, costs for rehabilitation or unforeseen expenses.  Our family knows that Christyn is strong, she’s brave, and she’s a fighter.  Words can not express our appreciation for your love and support.

title: Jeff & Lee Snow
text: Jeff and Lee are dancers who met 20 years ago at a South Florida Swing Dance event in 1998.  After a lifetime of excellent health, Lee has cancer.  In 22 years, she only took off one week from work for the flu, which is remarkable.   In November of 2017, Lee went to the emergency room complaining of stomach pains.  At that time, she was diagnosed with three ulcers and a small spot.  By December 29th, the cancer had spread.  Jeff's advice:  "Never get sick around the holidays." Jeff and Lee spend weeks at a time in a hospital that specializes in cancer treatment fighting to defeat this beast.  As a result, they have not worked since November, have no income, and have used up all of their savings.  They need money to help Lee keep fighting for her life and pay their living expenses (mortgage, electricity, water, food, etc).  The treatments are very expensive and we do not want them to lose their house on top of all of this.    Any donation, no matter how small, will be greatly appreciated.  It all adds up.  Please share this ‘Go Fund Me’ Campaign with your friends and family to help spread the word.We All Love Jeff and Lee and are praying for Lee’s recovery.  They are both genuinely wonderful, caring individuals who would be very grateful for any help you can provide.

title: Jens Final Fund
text: This go fund me came as a total surprise....after 4 years of battling cancer for Jens...the team told us today that Jens liver is so badly infected with cancer that too do anything more would cause more toxicity and kill him. His liver levels are severely high  to do anything more would be unsafe..with that we were told that there would be nothing more they can do to help him as chemo could potentially kill him because of the high liver numbers.
