We are all still in shock....we cant even process all of this at the moment. I am having my two oldest boys fly down tonight to spend the duration of time with him. We do not know....we were told 1 month potentially 2...but I do not foresee that. Jens birthday is September 1st and he would be turning 9....I do not know what the future holds, all I know is I am here ...we are going to be here for the duration and love him more than ever. Do anything he wants when he wants for as long as we can. While here we will need assistance for rental cars, food, gas, life....and final expenses. We are asking one last time for everyones dedication and assistance to our family . We could not have gone this far without our wonderful family of Nome and everyone coming together to help us. We are grieving right now and having a hard time processing....please just keep us all in your prayers while we are going thru this difficult time. We love all of you and our doing our best......#TEAM JENS FOREVER!!!!

title: Emmanuelle Isabella (Bella)Manfredi
text: Our Daughter, Isabella Manfredi, was struck by a car on the evening of July 27th  near her new apartment complex in Tucson, Arizona.  She and her boyfriend Connor Lehane had moved to Tucson just a week earlier from Bloomington, Indiana. Isabella was planning on finishing her PhD in Neuroscience and Psychological Brain Science at the University of Arizona. We have witnessed an outpouring of love and prayer from those familiar to us and those of total strangers. God is great and has shown his guiding love in helping Isabella survive this initial setback. She remains in critical condition, a result of a brain injury and extensive head trauma. She is just beginning the long road of recovery. We are optimistic and see daily signs of her advancement. Daily, we pray that her progress will continue. Isabella had planned to use her advanced education to help those caught in the deadly grip of drug and alcohol addiction. She was looking forward to concentrating on the next phase of her PhD program in a clinical environment to do just that. We are asking support for ongoing living, legal, and healthcare expenses that Isabella and her partner Conner Lehane are facing due to these unforeseen and catastrophic events. Her Mother -- Dawn Lushin, and Father -- Gregg Manfredi, are setting up short term housing here in Tucson to support her recovery and be with her for ongoing legal and healthcare management.Social Media is a blessing and has shown great promise in bringing us together as Human Beings. We ask for your kindness and monetary support to fund Isabella and Connor during these difficult times. Any donation will be appreciated along with your continued prayers, thoughts, and good wishes. The outpouring of love we have witnessed has increased our sometimes fragile faith in God and drives our immediate hope for a speedy recovery for our Daughter, Granddaughter, Sister, Niece, Friend, Partner and Child of God.Many thanks in advance and God’s Blessings to you and your family.

title: Dominique Crisp's Beat Cancer Fund
text: We are writing  this on behalf of Dominique Crisp. She currently resides in Italy but takes her children home every summer to see her family and friends.  Four weeks after arriving Dominique had stomach pain and went to the E.R. Within days she was diagnosed with stage 4 pancreatic cancer that has metastasized to her liver. She is here with a travel medical insurance policy that ends on Sept. 4th. We are hoping to get her into a clinical trial with the head of pancreatic oncology at UCSF. Due to her young age, and the liver not showing elevated levels she has a good chance of being chosen for a study. We are trying to raise money to cover the costs of all of the out of pocket medical expenses and living expenses for the family while they are here with her, as she will not be able to return to Italy right away and work. Any donation means the world to her and her family. Thank you so much, God bless!

title: The Burke Family Fund
text: Thank you for supporting the Burke family during this difficult time.  For those of you who are not already aware, Brian has been battling Pancreatic Cancer. Donations to this new GoFundMe will be utilized by the family to assist with immediate and future needs. Thank you for the continued love and support that you have provided for the Burke family. Brian and Tiffany are endlessly grateful for each and every one of you.

title: Help Tim S.  Beat Prostate Cancer
text: TIM’S PROSTATE CANCER DIAGNOSISHi there, I'm Jake and I've been friends with Tim and the "Schwentor Clan" for three years. They were the first family I became friends with when I moved to Maui. Tim has never asked me for anything ever... so when he called me and asked for my help with a GoFundMe, I knew I had to help. In May, 2018, after experiencing debilitating migraines and inability to urinate, and after several tests at Maui Medical Group in Kahului, Hawaii and a trip to the emergency room, Tim was diagnosed with Stage IV Metastatic Prostate Cancer. [Prostatic Adenocarcinoma & Invasive Carcinoma].As many of you know, he’s the father of four kids, Asher, 7, Oli, 10, Zach, 13 and Julia, 17, and Circe’s husband of 22 years. He’s also an active member of the Baha’i Faith and community volunteer.Tim is the sole provider financially and works construction on Maui. Circe is the sole educator to the four homeschooled children.Just before the diagnosis, Tim and his family were planning to go on a 48 state tour of the United States and travel teach between 2017 and 2019, for the bicentenary of The Bab and Baha'u'llah (the Twin Manifestations of The Baha’i Faith.)The firesides are an interactive 7-part series designed for friends of friends, communities and informal gatherings to investigate who we really are, the nature of being human and about Oneness of God, Religion and Humanity.The plan is to deal with the prostate cancer head on, and get out on the road just as soon as Tim is healthy.JULIA, 17, TIM’S DAUGHTER, WANTED TO SHARE WHY THIS IS IMPORTANT TO HER.My dad has loved me unconditionally. This is the first time in my life I’ve realized my dad isn’t invincible. For example, we can’t wrestle anymore as he’s grown weaker and barely has energy. Physical activity with dad is my main way of showing how much I love him, and so it feels like I can’t show him how much I love him anymore. The boys and I have had to adapt to show love to him in different ways. We play board games now. But it’s not the same. If he doesn’t get the treatment he needs, then he could die. It would leave me and my family struggling to live without him. We aren’t rich and my dad works hard to give us everything he can as a the sole financial provider in the household. If he doesn’t get the treatment, and if he dies, I would be devastated. I’m worried that my mom would have to do everything to support the family. I’m the oldest and that comes with the understanding that if something happens, I’m the one who is going to be strong and have to carry the family through. Without the treatment, I wouldn’t be able to be daddy’s little girl. My brothers, age 7, 10, 13, are like a pack. Dad is the leader of the pack. The boys are the heart. Without him, I imagine my brothers would feel lost. My dad gives my brothers boundaries, strong nurturing love, encourages them with their ideas and experiments. Anyone that’s met my dad knows how much he loves the boys. Without my dad, I think they would be great human beings, but I fear that the two youngest, especially Asher, 7, would grow up to only barely recollect him. I want more time with him. I want my brothers to have more time with him. If you don’t know my dad, but are considering donating, he’s why you should consider: He is loving and caring and never asks for anything of anybody ever. He selflessly gives everything he can. He teaches me and so many others about virtues and how to think about and live life. He’s funny and makes me laugh, pushes me and challenges me and everyone he comes into contact with to be the best self. He loves and gives and if you could give, we would be very grateful. NEEDED FUNDSBecause doctors have only offered palliative care, such as hormone therapy (chemical castration), and not a cure, Circe and Tim and the family have decided that alternative therapy at the CHIPSA HOSPITAL, one that has many examples of curing stage IV cancers, is the best route.Because of the nature of the cancer, and that it has spread, Tim and Circe have decided to do a rigorous 3-week program at CHIPSA headquarters, a hospital for advanced Gerson and immunotherapy work.According to the Chipsa website, “stage IV cancer is very complicated disease and there aren’t any easy answers. What we can assure you is we have the most experience with natural therapies with cutting edge immunotherapies and modern therapies than anyone else in North America.”Cost for two plane tickets from Maui to San Diego, and childcare: $1,500Cost for three weeks of therapy (plus one caregiver stay) $33,000.Because Tim is primary breadwinner, and does heavy construction, the family needs $3000 per month of living expenses for 24 months.24 months is the general time for “healing and rebuilding the body, including restoring the liver and essential organs to full function”  according to The Gerson Institute.Total needed for treatment: $34,500Total needed for 24 months of healing and on-going medications: $72,000$106,500. Currently.** Note, initial funds will be used to get Tim into treatment ASAP. Any remaining money will go towards helping living expenses. 100% of proceeds up to $33K will be used for Hospital CHIPSA and the rest will be used as described above. All funds will be transferred to Circe. TIMELINE FOR FUNDSCirce is primary educator of their four homeschooled children and therefore, we need to begin the process immediately and urgently.WHAT HAPPENS AFTER HEALING?Any remaining unused funds that are raised will be donated to other Gerson patients once Tim returns to work.We thank you for your consideration of becoming involved and supporting Tim’s recovery, the Schwentor family, and their teaching efforts.

title: Kaley Care & Expenses
text: Meet Michelle Kaley, along with her amazing family (Cameron, Alexia - 17, Devon - 16, Aubrey - 12, & Landon - 7)! Michelle was diagnosed with melanoma in October 2016 that has spread to her lungs and now her brain. She got the horribly  unfortunate news Friday the 4th that there are 13 tumors in her brain that have begun to hemorrhage. She and her family have never asked for help (and still aren't) but our community is strong and they need our help. They are the family that is ALWAYS helping others through church, school, and community. Now it's our turn to help and support them! Let's support this family through this time. Give what you can if you're able. Funds will be used for medical expenses, care for the family as well as final preparations. PLEASE USE THE CARE CALENDAR BELOW FOR MEALS AND OTHER WAYS WE CAN HELP THE KALEY'S. https://my.lotsahelpinghands.com/community/kaleycare/calendar#/cal/view/month

title: Need your Goodwill for Jill!
text: Our dear friend Jill Fernandez, who we all love with all of our hearts and souls,  has unfortunately been recently diagnosed with Stage 4 Colon cancer at the age of 38. A wife and mother of 2 , Jill has been a Vineland Elementary volunteer for many years.   You may even  recognize her friendly smile from the YMCA front desk or you've seen her on Sundays at Christ Fellowship Church. Jill will be needing help with chemotherapy, surgery, diagnostics, as well as other possible alternative treatments. As we all know how extremely costly these expenses are and how insurance coverage has changed over the years, we are asking everyone for help with this funding as soon as possible  and to please share this go-fund-me page.  As anyone who knows Jill, she has a heart of gold and would help anyone who needed it. Now it is our turn to help her.

title: Kyla's Hurdle
text: After crushing her school's 100 yard hurdle record in early May,  Kyla was diagnosed (mid May) with a cancer that affects her muscles and the surrounding tissues.   Already there have been  multiple  hospital stays and many, many tests. The family is working with Children's Hospital and Dana Farber who will administer 42 weeks of chemo with radiation coming in at some point. It is going to be a long haul but Kyla is strong and determined to get over this hurdle!  Her entire family and many friends are just as determined for her.  We are all Kyla Strong...The funds from this campaign will be used to directly benefit Kyla's ongoing medical care and associated costs to the family.   Keep those prayers and positive thoughts and healing energy coming to the McGarry family - they help more than words can say.NOTE:  it's okay to share by private messages, but not on any public Facebook posts.  Thank you for understanding and not clicking on any Facebook link.

title: HELP SAVE NATHANIEL
text: Hospitals for Humanity is currently leading in the fundraising efforts for Nathaniel Boluwatito Oyebode who is the 22 year old son of Mr. David  & Dr.(Mrs) Tinuade Oyebode.Nathaniel is promising and did well in academics and music.He got into covenant university Nigeria to study computer engineering, but tragedy struck in his 300 level when he collapsed in class and thereafter experienced repeated and frequent ill health. Sadly, actual diagnosis remained unknown until January 2018, when he was found to have a thoracic tumor diagnosed as diffuse B cell non Hodgkins lymphoma (a form of blood cancer affecting lymphocytes). This was devastating to him and the family. He suffered several complications including multiple pleural & pericardial effusions, septisaemia, low blood counts, deep vein thrombosis, hemiparesis and much more. His parents tried to provide the best available treatment for him at great financial, emotional and physical price. The location of the disease created complications necessitating prolonged hospital stay between January and June with bills and chemotherapy costing millions of naira. His family stuck by Nathaniel in this long and tasking journey, mopping up all family resources because they refuse to give up on their son. Hence this fundraising appeal to save him. Currently, he is hospitalized in the Intensive Care Unit of Emory University Hospital, Atlanta, Georgia, USA. He arrived on 28th June after the journey requiring oxygen and ambulance services to the hospital on arrival. He is currently receiving treatment for complications and the tumor is now diagnosed to be an aggressive T-Cell Lymphoblastic Lymphoma (TLBL). This warranted starting tests and treatment all over. The Emory team discovered he had clots in both lungs and his heart, fluid around his lungs and heart and a damaged left lung. He has had pulmonary and cardiac surgical procedures, suffered respiratory failure requiring life support and recommencement of new and expensive treatment. These are all associated with a growing hospital bill, currently at over $600,000 and counting as treatment continues. In spite of all, Nathaniel, in his will to live, continues fighting for his life. He looks forward to getting well and completing his studies, like youths his age. Available and hopeful treatment options for Nathaniel currently include bone marrow transplant, costing hundreds of thousands of USD. This is currently beyond the reach of his family and they seek help to save their son's life by donating to his treatment here or via His mother's bank account:Account name: Tinuade Oyebode Account number: 3004909009Bank name: First Bank Nigeria. Every bit helps, please... Thank you very much.#HELPSAVENATHANIELWebsite:  https://helpsavenathaniel.wordpress.com/

title: Rachel Roff
text: Hi friends and community of Rachel. Many of us are feeling far away from Rachel, Tory, and Camille as they navigate Rachel's care in Chiang Mai, Thailand. The coming days are unknown. Amongst the letters, videos, and messages - if you would like to support them with a financial gift, we've created this collection plate, here. We love you, Rachel!Note: We are thankful that Rachel's famly (Rick, Patsy, Adrian, Kaylee, Erik, and Jessica Delange) are together with Rachel and Tory now. Adrian Delange has informed us that these funds will assist them with the cost of plane tickets, with medical expenses, and will enable them to plan for the uncertain future. Thank you for joining together to care for our beloved Rachel in this way.

title: Rally for Randy: Battle With PSC
text: Randy JonesYou may know him as Wesley’s, Jobi’s, Mandy’s or Randall’s dad. Or maybe as Linda’s husband. Perhaps you've worked alongside him during his 30 years at Lockwood. Or you may not know him at all. Whatever the case, thank you for reading his (and our family’s) story…Randy Jones is known as a strong, hardworking and dependable man. Over the years you may have seen him at the stables feeding the horses, or in the barn working on cars, and a lot of times building something new on the farm. Building new things and tinkering are his most enjoyable hobbies. Those who know him best know that these are some of his favorite ways to spend time and that without his work, Randy wouldn’t know what to do with himself.  Throughout our lives, he has used this inherent work ethic and love for creating to build the best livable space for his family and giving us a cherished place to grow up and thrive. The beautiful homes, yards, swing sets, and patios are all things he built because he wanted his family to have them. All of these things had to be perfect in his eyes, even when we didn’t care if they were perfect or not. His undeniable desire to create these things now serve as the backdrop to so many beautiful memories. But as of late doing the work that he loves so much has been nothing short of daunting.He has always been a man of great action but very few words. Being the private person that he is, you may not have been aware that he is battling a disease that leaves him exhausted just from getting out of bed in the morning. Seven years ago, Randy was diagnosed with Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC), a rare, degenerative liver disease with no known cure. Recent months have been the toughest for him. Because of this disease, he has endured agonizing symptoms like excessive bleeding, complete loss of muscle tone, fever spouts, loss of appetite, and fluid build-up in his abdomen. There are days where he can’t reach down to tie his shoes because of the fluid build-up. He has to get his abdomen drained nearly every week now. On Wednesday, May 30th doctors drained 6.5 liters - roughly 14 lbs. He doesn’t have enough energy to do household chores. It’s almost too exhausting for him to drive to and from work. Both his body and his spirit have deteriorated. This disease, which targets the bile ducts then slowly causes the liver to fail, affects 1 in 10,000 people per year in the US. Doctors say the cause remains unclear. No one knows how or why this happened to him. With luck on his side, Randy will undergo transplant surgery at VCU in Richmond, VA in the coming months. The procedure is not without risks, but with Randy’s condition worsening each day, there is no other choice. If the months of recovery go as planned, the transplant will give him much needed strength and he will be able to regain his quality of life. Something that right now seems so distant.Sadly, coping with the disease, transplant surgery, and beginning the long road to recovery are only part of the worries weighing on him right now. So we are reaching out to ask for something that a man like Randy never could … Help. As many of you are aware, even with the blessing of a donor comes a nightmarish list of expenses: medical bills, lodging for on-site recovery, transportation to and from Richmond, farm maintenance, and lost income throughout it all.We want to see our dad doing what he loves again – but we need your help. Any donation, big or small, gets us closer to our goal and Randy closer to a calm recovery. Whether you donate because you know one of us, Linda, or Randy himself, we are forever grateful for your kindness.   In anxious wait of better days,Wesley, Jobi, Mandy, and Randall

title: Help Emily Conquer Sarcoma Cancer
text:
Together We Can Help Emily Conquer Angiosarcoma Cancer. This request is written from the hearts of so many who love, support and are praying for Emily King. Emily is a beautiful, intelligent 24-year-old young lady. Emily’s physical beauty is always striking, but it is her inner beauty that radiates more. She truly is the one to bring sunshine wherever she goes. Until approximately three weeks ago, Emily was a healthy, active Speech Pathology student, looking forward to graduate school and life with her boyfriend, Brad. Following a mammogram, she received the shocking news that she had a large, 8 cm tumor in her breast. It was not breast cancer but a rare, aggressive cancer that had settled in her breast – an Angiosarcoma. There is an estimated 200 cases a year in the world. Immediately, she was scheduled for surgery and the tumor was successfully removed. The next week, the week of August 20, 2018, Emily traveled to MD Anderson Cancer Center with her family as recommended by the physicians. They are currently at MD Anderson in Texas. Apparently, removing the tumor is just the very small tip of the iceberg and this is something that, once present, grows microscopic sized cancer cells that can travel through the blood stream to different parts of the body. The doctors determined chemo would be necessary and she began treatment Monday morning, August 27, 2018. The first round will last 4.5 months, and Emily will be required to stay in Houston the entire time. In total, everything is going to take about a year. The second and third treatments are more routine and can be given in her home town. Their lives have been turned upside down in a matter of just a few weeks. Emily will not be able to continue working and will be faced with financial difficulties. Emily does not have finances necessary to pay for this level of medical care and treatment. Please know that this petition is written and submitted by so many – Emily’s family, friends and even those who do not know them! Everyone realizes that this cannot be done alone, so please, please spread the word and contribute as much as you can. Help us help Emily so that she and her family do not have to worry about anything other than Emily getting well. In addition, prayers are much appreciated, and many are praying ceaselessly for a miracle. Please join them. Any assistance will be so appreciated. 

*Roseanne McDow - Emily's mother will be in charge of funds.

title: Teri Saben Treatment Assistance
text: Teri Saben is a long-time resident of Skagit County. Anyone who has met Teri knows that she is sweet, sharp, fun and a complete joy to be around. She adores her son Scotty and his family. Her greatest joy in life is watching her grandchildren grow and being involved in their lives. Teri is a treasured employee in the commercial loan department at Skagit Bank, where she has charmed the hearts of co-workers and customers alike.Teri and her grandsonsTeri and her granddaughterIn the Summer of 2017 Teri’s health began to decline and she could not enjoy the activities she loved, such as traveling, hiking and riding her bike with her partner, Jerry. Eventually in the Fall of 2017 she received the diagnosis that she had Stage 2 Multiple Myeloma.Teri, Jerry and her granddaughterSince the diagnosis Terri has undergone both chemo and radiation. Throughout the treatments, Teri has kept a positive outlook on things and never let her beautiful smile fade. Recently, Teri received the news she needs to have a bone marrow transplant in Seattle. Luckily, modern medical technology has advanced so the doctors can use Teri’s own bone marrow, which has a higher success rate. Her doctors are optimistic and confident the procedure will have a positive outcome. Teri's stay in Seattle will begin in mid-March and last until June.During the bone marrow treatment, Teri must stay near the Seattle Cancer Care Alliance that will be overseeing her care. She plans on residing in the Pete Gross house but she must have 24/7 care from family members as well as friends. We are raising money to help Teri in this time of need. An event like this brings about unplanned needs for expenses from taking time off work, travel costs, living costs and unforeseen medical expenses.Please help by making a donation that will go directly to Teri. We started this GoFundMe to help relieve financial stress that Teri may be facing so she can focus her energy on healing. Teri has always placed the well-being of others before herself. That is just who she is and a major part of her wonderful makeup. Teri has helped many in our community, this is our time to give back to her.Teri and friendsTeri and her son, Scotty

title: #MightyMaryn Clinical Trial Fund
text:
Thank you for reading Maryn’s story.  Maryn (aka #MightyMaryn) is my fierce 7 year-old niece battling glioblastoma, stage IV brain cancer.For those of you who have followed Maryn’s journey on Caring Bridge, you know that she is determined and resilient – she has learned to swallow pills so she could take her chemo, endured a tight mask and learned to lay still for 20 minutes at a time to avoid sedation during her 6 weeks of daily radiation treatments, attended ½ days of first grade while in treatment, embraced fashion bandanas and hats as she lost her hair, and managed the loss of vision on her right side which resulted from the brain surgery.  She also keeps all of us in better spirits with her humor and heart. Maryn is an amazing kid who loves sports, art, camping, movies with popcorn, and playing with her big sister.    Photo by: Keyana Tahmaseb    http://www.keyanatahmaseb.com/ The highlight video is from very special events with the Portland Thorns FC.  We are eternally grateful to the Thorns for these amazing events that allowed us to celebrate Maryn 7th birthday with friends and family!  It was also a celebration of the completion of the intense six weeks of travel to and from Doernbecher for 30 radiation treatments, and the completion of her daily chemo treatments.

Maryn’s family…Chrissy and Graham both work for school districts.  Chrissy is an Administrator, working with federal programs in Woodburn and Graham is on the Behavior Cadre working with high-need kids in classrooms throughout Salem. Cora, Maryn’s big sister, is an avid soccer player and will start middle school in the fall.How it began…Maryn, a normally high-spirited and lively 6 year-old, became sick and spent all day Thursday, March 15th, in a deep sleep.  The next day, Chrissy and Graham took her to the doctor, where the doctor quickly recommended Maryn go to the ER for a full work up to include a cat scan, chest x-ray and blood work.  The results showed a brain hemorrhage and the decision was made to send her via life flight to Doernbecher Children’s Hospital in Portland.  Upon arrival, things moved quickly, MRIs and CT scans were administered, and a massive tumor was detected in the left side of her brain.  The doctors performed emergency surgery (around 1am Saturday) to relieve the pressure in her brain, knowing a second brain surgery would be necessary within days.On Tuesday, March 20th, Maryn spent the day in brain surgery, where the surgical team resected about 98% of the 6 cm tennis ball sized tumor.  By the end of the week, she was released from the hospital to begin recovering and regaining her strength at home.On Thursday, March 29th, Maryn’s family received the pathology reports, and Maryn was diagnosed with Glioblastoma, Stage IV brain cancer.  This is a very aggressive form of brain cancer that creates tumors at a rapid rate, and is incredibly rare in children. While the surgeon was able to remove the visible tumor, likey some micro cells remain in her brain tissue.What followed was a course of treatment that included 6 weeks of radiation and 6 weeks of daily chemo (which she managed to complete 5 weeks before her platelets fell too low to continue). Maryn also receives occupational therapy and sees vision specialists at Casey Eye Institute.  The family is fortunate to have a world-class hospital in Doernbecher Children’s, just 45 miles away, with both Chrissy and Graham’s parents there to share in the drives to Portland for her treatments. Why are we asking for support today?There currently is no cure for glioblastoma, but there is research taking place around the world. The standard treatment typically keeps the cancer from coming back for about 15 months, but doctors have been clear that at that point this type of cancer always comes back and the options at that point are limited. There are many clinical trials providing hope, and the family has decided to participate in a clinical trial in New York City. The family will embark on a course of treatment that may span up to two years, requiring Maryn and family to travel between Salem, OR, and New York City every three weeks. The entire family will be in New York for up to four weeks to start the trial (starting July 29th), and then begin the three week travel cycle for Maryn’s one day of blood work and treatments, which also require her to be in NYC.It sounds like the clinical trial chemo has minimal side effects, so hopefully Maryn will feel good enough to play sports, go to school and play with her friends. It will be tough traveling that much, but the hope is the clinical trial is more effective than the standard treatment.The costs…Maryn’s family is fortunate to have a good health care plan that allows her top-notch care, but treatments outside of Oregon fall under out-of-network care.  During the clinical trial, the medications will be covered; however, the doctor visits and other hospital costs will fall under their out-of-network medical costs, and the travel will be the responsibility of the family as well.There will be many financial hurdles in the coming months and years, including travel and medical costs and lost wages resulting from taking time off for Family Medical Leave.  The first focus is on helping the family cover travel expenses and out-of-network medical costs.  If we exceed this goal, money will go toward helping cover lost wages Chrissy and Graham incur during the coming years.Goal -  $100,000 for travel costs and medical out-of-network deductibles for the next 24 months.  This will include the initial 3-4 week stay in NY, with 30+ additional trips over the next two years. Below are some of the key expenses the family faces.$26,000 – Out-of-network deductible - $13,000/year30+ trips to NY – $50,000 for plane tickets (30 plane tickets for Maryn, plus 50+ tickets for other family members)$12,000 for hotel rooms (The family will spend 80+ nights in NYC, staying at the Ronald McDonald when possible.  This will help cover 40+ nights of hotels if needed)$7,500 for travel between their home in Salem, OR, and the Portland airport & NYC airports and hotels/Ronald McDonald House, airport parking, and travel within NY for hospital visits (airport parking, Lyfts in NY)Additionally, Graham and Chrissy will face lost wages as their sick leave from work is depleted.  Maryn’s treatments fall mid-week, so each trip will result in about three days away from work.How you can help…We appreciate everyone following Maryn’s Caring Bridge page and supporting her journey.  Thank you for donating to Maryn’s medical journey and for sharing her story.  To help us get the word out, you can share my link on your Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, other social media or email.Some of you may have other options for support through frequent traveler programs – aka free airline tickets, hotel points – or gift cards for Lyft, etc.  I did reach out to several airlines, and there do not seem to be programs to donate miles to individuals without incurring standard transfer of mileage fees; however, the airlines recommended anyone with enough miles to purchase a ticket can purchase it for one of the family members without the transfer fees.  For any of these or other options, you can reach out to me (Stacy) personally.Here is a link to a wonderful story by the Portland Thorns FC:#MightyMaryn Thank you!Photo by: Keyana Tahmaseb  http://www.keyanatahmaseb.com/

title: Addit4Addi
text: Ashley and Charles Goff recently found out that their 9 year old daughter has a large tumor, possibly attached to her brainstem, and is having emergency surgery on Monday, April 30.  Although there are a lot of unknowns, the last thing I want my friend to worry about is finances in this difficult time.  This is a hard working family that relies on their ability to work to provide for their family.  At this time, their focus needs to be on spending time with Addi, and their other two girls, as a result, it is impossible for both of them to work right now.  The money raised will help the Goff's with medical expenses, daily expenses, groceries and help them support their family during these hard times.  I thank you in advance for your support and keep the family in your prayers.

title: Caring for Cade
text: On the night of June 13th, Candace and Chris were delivered the news that no parent ever wants to hear. They were told that their precious 2 year old who had been experiencing vomiting episodes for the previous 1-2 weeks was being diagnosed with a brain tumor. Cade was admitted to the PICU at Lutheran General Hospital that night. After an extensive MRI, it was found that Cade’s tumor had not spread and that there was only one tumor that needed to be removed which is very positive news. The type of tumor that Cade has is unknown at this time and it will be 5 days or so after it’s removed before they find out the extent of it. This diagnosis is devastating, but Cade, Chris, Candace and big brother Rylan have all been incredibly strong and brave. With this diagnosis comes a burden of financial expenses. Unfortunately, while their world has stopped, the world around them keeps moving. Please consider donating to this amazing family to help ease some of the stress that they are enduring and will continue to endure throughout this battle. Please keep praying for strength and bravery for the Winters family.

title: Vida Para Lily
text: ￼UPDATE May 5,2018It is with a very sad heart that I share the news that we had to say goodbye to Lily on May 5th.  She fought hard for her life until the very end, but tragically her infection did not clear and she was unable to get a transplant in time to save her life.We are deeply saddened, but are comforted to know that she is rejoicing in God’s glorious kingdom.Thank you to all who have supported our family  in the difficult journey with your prayers, kind words, and donations.Even though Lily was not able to get a transplant, she did stay in intensive care, and so the funds raised will go toward this hefty cost.Any additional donations will be used to continue to cover medical costs and to help her small children.Thank you again, we are truly blessed for the support from so many during this difficult time.*********************(Please scroll down for the English version)Liliana esta muy enferma y necesita un transplante inmediatamente!En espera de un milagro, y agradeciendo a Dios de antemano, con toda la fe que se puede pedimos su apoyo para darle a nuestra querida Lily una oportunidad para vivir! Nuestra querida hija, hermana, sobrina, amiga y sobre todo madre de siete adorables hijos, Liliana, ha luchado con mucha valentia contra su enfermedad en el higado por los ultimos dos anos. Lamentablemente, después de todos sus esfuerzos, la enfermedad le dano los rinones y necesita un doble transplante para sobrevivir. ￼Liliana, ha trabajado incansablemente para sacar adelande a sus hijos. A ella le apasiona ayudar a los demas, tiene un corazon tan grade y generoso que aun enferma se preocupa por todos antes que por ella. Ella da libremente de todo lo que tiene. Tan grande es su corazón que en los días que estuvo muy frío en Dallas, ella se fue a repartir comida a los que no tenían y les busco hoteles a los que no tenían  donde dormir.  Ella se pasa cada dia de accion de gracias dandoles de comer a los mas necesitados de la ciudad.Liliana tiene un corazón grandísimo y siempre busca la manera de ayudar a todos y ahora es ella quien necesita nuestra ayuda.￼Hace unas semanas todos sus planes de vida se detuvieron, y se volvio su futuro incierto y gris.  Un momento que ninguna persona de 46 anos tendria que estar pasando.  Liliana fue diagnosticada con falla de higado y rinones y con poco tiempo para seguir luchando..  Ella nunca penso en pedir ayuda, y que su vida dependeria de los demas. Pero la vida nos da muchas sorpresas. Lily está muy enferma y su única oportunidad para mejorar es un doble transplante de su hígado  y riñón.  Esta operación puede salvarle la vida y tu puedes ser parte de este milagro. Esta operacion es demasiado urgente.  Sin esta operacion, Lily no puede estar en su casa con sus hijos, sigue en el hospital, y sigue en un alto riesgo de morir.Desafortunadamente, No podremos hacerlos sin su ayuda. Cualquier apoyo es valioso. Ayudenos para recaudar los fondos necesarios para salvar su vida.Por favor done  lo que pueda hoy.  Los gastos de la operacion son immensos, y requieren cuidados intesivos no solo para Liliana, pero para los dos donantes.  De parte de toda su familia se lo agradecemos muchísimo.El alma generosa será prosperada (proverbios 11.25) Dios lo bendiga y lo proteja grandemente!Agradecemos que junto con su donación eleve su oración  a nuestro Creador.Para los que viven fueara de los Estados Unidos, pueden poner 000 para el codigo postal.*****************************************Liliana is very sick and needs a transplant immediately!We humbly ask for your support to give our beloved Lily a chance to live!  We thank God in advance for the many miracles he has shown us and wait for this precious miracle.￼Our beloved daughter, sister, niece, friend and especially a mother of seven adorable children, Liliana, has fought with great courage against her liver disease for the last two years. Unfortunately,  the liver disease has also caused damage to her kidneys and she is in need of a double transplant to survive.￼Liliana has worked tirelessly to provide the best for her children. She loves to help others, and has a heart so generous, that even while sick she worries about everyone before her.  She freely gives of everything she has. Her heart is so big that on the days when it was very cold in Dallas, she made sure to distribute food to those who do not have anything to eat and booked hotels for those who had no place to sleep. She spends every Thanksgiving giving food to the neediest in the city.  She gives selflessly always.Liliana has a generous and giving heart and always seeks a way to help everyone and now she is the one who needs our help.A few weeks ago all her life plans stopped, and her future became uncertain and gray. A moment that no 46-year-old person should have been going through-  Liliana was diagnosed with liver and kidney failure with little time to keep fighting. She never thought about asking for help, or that her life would depend on others. Lily is very sick and her only chance to improve is a double transplant of her liver and kidney.  This surgery can save her life and you can be part of this miracle.This surgery is very urgent!  Without it, Lily's life remains at a critical risk for death. During this time, she remains at the hospital and cannot be with her children.￼Unfortunately, we can not do it without your help. Any support is valuable. Help us to raise the necessary funds to save her life.  Please donate what you can today. The expenses of the surgery are immense and require intensive care not only for Liliana but also for her two donors.   On top of that, the aftercare required for her and her two donors will also be very costly.  On behalf of her family, we thank you very much. God bless you! Along with your donation, we also appreciate your prayers for Liliana!"A generous person will prosper "(Proverbs 11:25)For those who live outside the United States, you may enter 000 for the postal code.

title: Gonzalez Family Tragedy
text: This is my beautiful niece, Rylee who was supposed to graduate from high school on Thursday June 7th. Unfortunately, we lost her on Monday as she took her own life after a long battle with depression. She was intelligent, beautiful and loved by more people than she'll ever know. Her father, and my brother Richard, suffered a massive heart attack after learning that she did not make it. He is ok and managing well given the circumstances. The expenses endured from medical and funeral arrangements are extremely difficult to take care of as my brother recently lost his job. Without medical insurance or income for funeral expenses, this has put a great deal of added stress to the family. Him and his wife's biggest worry right now is figuring out how to financially cover these expenses. Please consider helping this family to pay these expenses so they can focus on trying to heal and adjust to their now very different lives. Keep our family in your prayers and thank you in advance.

title: Support Michael Hahn's Healing
text: Hello!  Meet Michael Hahn and Elizabeth RaineyThey are married and have been together for 17 years.  For 19 years they have each worked as healers in the Seattle community.  Michael is a passionate and gifted hands-on therapist working with newborns and adults and Rainey is an advanced yoga therapist working in class and private settings while also going to school for somatic psychology.   Last October Michael had a medical procedure meant to help with chronic low back pain. Unfortunately,  the following day his body began to have significant and mysterious neurological symptoms that quickly led to his inability to work. Devastatingly, his arms and legs became weak and easily pained after minimal use.  Next it became hard to swallow, muscles in his neck and shoulders became weak and muscle wasting started in his shoulders, arms, hands and feet.  A nightmare for someone who uses his body to perform precision therapy on the bodies of others.                                                                                                                                                       Michael helping mamas and their little ones                             Michael and Rainey had set aside an emergency fund, hoping they would never need it.  Luckily they had it, but that money and their other savings have been spent over the last 7 months on high deductibles, monthly bills, and seeing specialists not covered by insurance.  Michael maintained his office during this time with hopes that he would quickly return to work.  When it became clear that more time for healing was necessary, they made the tough decision to close down Michael’s office of 11 years in Fremont. Michael is seeking out traditional and holistic health care to try to get to the bottom of his medical issues. Michael’s income made up a large percentage of their combined income and they are currently unable to fully meet all of their monthly bills.  We are raising money to support Michael’s healing so that he can share his healing gifts again with the community.  These funds also support his wife Rainey (who is his main caregiver), with domestic help, health care sessions from local healers so she does not burn out, and the time needed to continue her 3 year training in somatic psychology while building this new aspect of her business. Currently they owe $7000 in medical bills; think astronomical deductibles for Sole Proprietors.  Michael continues to see both main stream and alternative practitioners on a weekly basis and Rainey is also receiving support which is costing an average of $1500 per month. Each month they require an additional $5000 to meet their living expenses. The goal is to raise enough to get them through the end of 2018 with the hope that things will be much better by then. The Go Fund Me goal is to raise $50,000

title: Health Expenses for Darryl
text: This GoFundMe campaign is for Darryl Willis. Darryl is one of the nicest people that you will ever know.  Even in the midst of his health struggles over the years, he has seemed to persevere  and remain positive through it all.Darryl was diagnosed with Ulcerative colitis nearly 30 years ago and has struggled with his digestive system ever since. Over time he was able to gain weight and feel healthier. Fast forward to five years ago, he found out that he had colon cancer, having his large intestine (colon) removed. He has since been functioning with only his small intestine after reconstruction of his intestinal tract. He has been disabled and unable to work ever since. As of three weeks ago, Darryl was hospitalized once again and diagnosed with Crohn's disease with intestinal blockage, in which a new specialist informed him that he was misdiagnosed 30 years ago. The doctors had to perform surgery once again on his intestines to clear the blockage and because of an abscess, his wounds has to remain open for him to heal from inside out. He has to wear a colostomy bag and has lost so much weight, down to a lowly 103 pounds. This is very sad to see. He is praying that he does not have to wear the colostomy bag for the rest of his life. Darryl lives in DeSoto, Texas, but for the time being has to reside with his 80+ year old parents (Jewel & Dorothy) to help care for him in Malvern, Arkansas. He is an only child. Darryl is also a member of Omega Psi Phi Fraternity, Inc., initiated Alpha Zeta Chapter, Spring 87. He has always considered his brothers and sisters in Greekdom to be the siblings he never had.Darryl does not have healthcare and the medical expenses and home care is definitely a hardship on him and his parents to maintain. He is so modest and took convincing him to allow us to start this campaign. So, this campaign is a plea to all of Darryl's friends, family and even good Samaritans to show generosity.  Please give what you can and forward to others and let Darryl know that there are people that really care about him. Prayers are always sufficient and welcome as well.Thanks in advance,- Friends of Darryl(managed by K.L. Withers)

title: Help Janet Whitehead
text: Janet is a 41 year old wife and mother of 2 little boys, Maddox 10 and Eli 7. She was recently diagnosed with colon cancer with metastasis to her liver. I am starting this page to help support her fight.     A few weeks ago, Janet had some belly pain and went to her local ER, fearing the dreaded gallbladder attack. The Er doctor performed a Ct scan of her abdomen. Gallbladder looked ok, but her liver looked abnormal. Her pain resolved and she followed up with her primary doctor. He ordered and MRI for further evaluation.  She scheduled her MRI only to find out her insurance had been canceled. She covered the cost out of pocket. The MRI led to a PET scan and  and other testing.  Janet found out that she had colon cancer and Mets to her liver. She has no family history and is otherwise very healthy.      Janet is a Nurse Practitioner and continues to work, help her patients, and care for her boys. She  is about to start chemotherapy and it will be too dangerous for her to work in the hospital. She continues to cover her cost out of pocket.      Janet is one of the most selfless people that I know. She always puts others before her self. Let’s help Janet fight and beat cancer.

title: Help fund Loren's spine surgery
text: I have been very hesitant to start a go fund me page in order to raise money for my next spine surgery, but at this point I have no choice. My physical condition has taken a turn for the worse in the past month and I am faced with yet another pressing time frame.As many of you know by my social media oversharing and venting, I have been living with chronic nerve and back pain. This started as a result of a car accident in 2008 that left me with a whole new perspective on life and physical health. In August 2016 I was then sidelined by an emergency spine surgery that racked up to $20,000. I took pride in paying my last bill in the 2017 and began building back my savings account this year. After weeks of escalating pain and nerve damage, and a decade of chronic pain and pain management, I have lost my quality of life. My job as a wellness practitioner is compromised, my happiness both in the gym and throughout life has been hampered, and my love for golf has been repressed. Turns out the necessary emergency surgery in 2016 was ultimately just a bandaid and the true fix is a Lumbar Spinal fusion (yes, like Tiger Woods).Even though I am a NYS insured individual and an independent working woman in New York City, I face the challenge of a surgery that will compromise my already compromised profession. In 2016 I lost almost 3 months of income due to surgery and rehabilitation. This next surgery will not only place my income on hold once again but will cost $35,000 for the surgeon alone. This doesn’t include any post operative care, physical therapy or household costs such as rent, utilities, and groceries. I have finally found an AMAZING spine surgeon that has deemed me an ideal candidate due to my age and physical condition for spinal fusion. With an 80% projected success rate and a reduction of most of my pain symptoms, I am hopeful to end this once and for all. I am truly thankful for any donations, food contributions, visitations or prayers you have for the success of this surgery and appreciate the time you took to read through my predicament. Regardless of donations I will be eternally grateful for your thoughts, love or well wishes and love y’all forever.

title: Marta Healing fund
text: WORDS WE NEVER THOUGHT WE’D HEAR“Your cancer has returned.”“It has metastasized.”“You have Stage 4 cancer.”The cancer that had originally started in Marta’s breasts had metastasized to her lungs, liver and bones. She has a nagging cough, walks with difficulty and with a bit of a limp on the left side, where she feels the most weakness.There have already been many treatments, scans, bloodwork, biopsies, surgeries, etc. Marta has gone through it all and is now in need for alternative treatment options; one of which is in the range of $20,000 – not including travel expenses.Loved fiercely by her 4 children, family and friends; Marta’s ready to fight this cancer like the last – but we need your help.Please consider giving to this campaign!We also ask that you keep us in your prayers for we know when three or more come together in His name, He answers prayers.Thank you so much for your consideration and God bless!*The beneficiary for this campaign will be Marta's daughter; Gabriela Bird, who will manage funds for and on behalf of her mother.*

title: Stand by Bobby
text: Hello Friends and Family of Bobby Amrhein,First of all, Bobby would kill me if he knew this page existed, but as his sister I know he is in need of our support right now.  As most of you know Bobby retired from the NYPD after 20 years of service.  He achieved his dream of buying a home and moving his wife and 5 beautiful children (ages 3-11) down to Florida.His wife Kristina has recently been diagnosed with terminal anaplastic thyroid cancer and is being treated at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in NYC.  He has selflessly been at her side leaving his job and Florida life behind - all while trying to ensure that his 5 children are getting proper care and coping with the fact that their mother is dying.Bobby has not asked for any help, but we are taking this into our own hands, because he needs us.  He has always been a selfless, kind, caring and extremely funny man.  Fatherhood has only amplified this and his compassion, love and worry for his children shines through when you see them together.  At this time we ask you to contribute whatever you can to help relieve some of his financial burden  and allow him to focus on his children and wife.  Anything is appreciated and it all will be given directly to Bobby.Thank you for your support.

title: Erica Annise CRPS Health Fund
text: Please take a moment to help me by giving, sharing, praying and believing  with me that all things are possible because Jesus lived and died for us.My big sissy Karen Brooks, sent this to me and it read perfectly for who I am, who I am trying to be and who I want to stay. Spiritual thought of the day. Be confident in Hope.Romans 12:12“Be joyful in hope, patient in affliction, faithful in prayer.”Sometimes the key to survival is simply standing on your faith and moving forward trusting that God is there helping us, despite the challenges we face.  Choosing joy through hope rather than despair, choosing patient endurance in times of affliction, and choosing faithfulness in prayer are all decisions of the will.  Trusting that the God, who raised Jesus from the dead, can also change our circumstances as well. ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️I want to live! If I am honest I really want my life back!!!!! I realize that might not happen.  So what is my purpose on this earth? What is God's reason for having here still blessed to be alive?  A lot!   I see this life,  as much as I suffer still,  as a gift that God has entrusted to me.  I believe it’s time for me to share all my stories of hope through all levels of the highs and lows with all of my illnesses.  My desire,  while I receive treatment in Italy,  is to document this journey and allow the world to see  in order to learn more about the world of chronic illness.    I haven't always shared the long painful nights, the hours of tears or the days when I thought there was nothing left for me to live for.  I want to share the gift of the power within oneself that only comes when you thrive out of the fire.   Im vowing to thrive while in and out the fire. Please help me do this! Thriving in the fire,  Erica Annise❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️Thank you for joining us on a journey that we pray will lead to lasting healing and deliverance for Erica.  Many of you will never know how devastating it is to combat a debilitating and life altering disease and I pray you never know.  However, for those who are familiar with this struggle, you know only those with strong support systems have a chance to make it through to the other side.  After much thought and prayer, we decided to ask our support system to help us  explore this treatment option in Italy for her CRPS diagnoses.  It’s not a decision taken lightly and in many ways is quite humbling, but it’s a decision that gives my wife, my friend, my partner the best chance to win this fight as she still is fighting her other illnesses.  This campaign is not simply about Erica’s treatment, but also about raising awareness and advocating for further CRPS research and advocacy here in the U.S. Again, I thank you for supporting us.  Whatever you decide to contribute, even if it’s simply your love and prayers, please know that we are eternally grateful. As my wife would say....Warmest Heartbeats, Melvin " Skip" BrazielFINANCIAL NEED LIST: Medical Treatment  in Italy$20,000 Cardiac Care in Italy$10,000 Motorized Wheelchair$2,300 Game Ready Physical Therapy Ice Machine to keep at home. $3,000 Game Ready Attachments(Back, (2) Legs, (2) Arms$435/ Each = $2175 Airbnb in  Italy- 6 weeks $10,000 Airfare- Erica DCA-Venice, Italy$10,000 Airfare to Italy- 4 people(Skip and Parents)$2,500/ Each= $10,000 Transportation in Italy$1,500 Extra Home Health Care in Italy and DC 25 hours a week at $10/hour$3,000 Documentary Team for trip to Italy and in DC$25,000 Camera/ Camera Equipment for Erica self-taping$2,500 Miscellaneous$525  Total:$100,000

title: Dismuke Family Fundraiser
text: Thank you for viewing our fundraising page for the Dismuke family.   We greatly appreciate your support of this amazing family. Eight months ago, the Dismuke family received crushing news when Jonathan was diagnosed with Stage IV Diffused Large B Cell Lymphoma.  With positivity, strength and bravery, Jonathan and his family entered into the battle of a life time.  Having just welcomed their baby boy, Jones, just three months prior, this battle took on a new and deeper meaning.  Jonathan began his treatment plan, enduring eight rounds of chemotherapy that would hopefully eradicate the cancer and allow him to continue to live his life as the great family man and friend that we all know him to be.  Amazingly, after the 8th round, his most recent scan in April came back clear.  However, the journey towards total remission continues with scans every few months to assure that the cancer has not returned.  Jonathan will not be declared officially cancer free until all scans and blood work have been clear for five years.  The past eight months have been grueling physically, emotionally, and financially.  Jonathan and family have endured countless doctors appointments, CT scans, PET scans, ER visits, biopsy's, surgeries, tests, scans, stents, ports, hospital stays, chemo, CSF injections and unwanted ailments. Additionally, they have had the added stress of dealing with insurance companies, hospital accounting and legal fees from out-of-network treatments Jonathan received early in the process. It is our hope that the amazing Denver event community will rally together to support this beloved family and ease some of this burden.  Thank you so very much for your generous support.  Sincerely, The Footers Catering Family

title: Sorensen Family Fund
text: The Sorensens are an amazing family in Southern California. Evan and Heather are loving parents to four children who are all talented scholars, musicians, dancers, athletes and are all-around fun and amazing.  The family is very active in their church and community.The Sorensens have had a series of unfortunate illnesses and events that have left them in need of some assistance.One of the boys had an athletic related concussion resulting in extensive and expensive therapy, followed by a horrifying bicycle accident and another concussion resulting in further therapy.  Meanwhile, Dad was diagnosed with Lymphoma while he was laid off.  The Lymphoma returned with a vengeance within a year of the first round of cancer, and Evan (Dad) is now having Car-T therapy treatment at City of Hope. He has been in the hospital for over a month.Heather went back to work to keep the family going while Evan has been unable to find employment because of his illness. She is a super mom, handling the four kids, working and taking care of her very ill husband. Needless to say, all the medical costs and the inability of Evan to work is sinking this family financially.  Family has been super supportive, but there are crippling medical bills, cobra insurance and a mortgage that need to be paid.  Please help this amazing family fight cancer, keep their kids afloat and stay in their home.

title: Courtney Dickson Whalen
text: Dear Friends and Family, I am reaching out to all of you to share the unfortunate news that our closest friend Courtney Dickson Whalen, has been diagnosed with throat cancer. I am at a loss for words to try and understand how a super fit, healthy, amazing mom, wife, daughter, sister and friend could now become the victim of this awful disease. It has been a tough few weeks of testing, scans, scopes, countless doctor appointments and surgery for a feeding tube. The good news is that she is in good hands at UCSF and in the care of a great oncology team. Unfortunately, the progression of the mass has intensified and we are praying that her treatment of intense radiation and chemo therapy will start without delay in the coming week. Treatment will be 5 days a week for 7 weeks. Luckily, UCSF has reasonably priced housing in SF where she can stay to avoid the back and forth driving.  Courtney is a stubborn strong willed woman that continues to fight through nausea, fatigue and extreme pain. But she cannot do this alone. It truly will take a village to support Courtney, Will and two boys, Price 12 months and Tyler 12 years. How can you help, you ask? Financial support!  For child care and UCSF housing not to mention the overwhelming amount of medical and prescription expenses. On behalf of Courtney and Will and the amazing community that they are blessed by, we greatly appreciate any and all support, positive thoughts and prayers. Big hug and lots of love,Simone

title: Tom Havens memorial for Jake
text: On August 27, our family was forever changed by the devastating loss of our beloved Tom.  In addition to being one of the kindest, gentlest are most caring human beings, Tom was also the greatest dad to two amazing young men, Ryan and Jake.  Jake is an engaging non-verbal young man with autism and Tom was his favorite person on earth.  The severity of Jake's condition will require that he receive life-long 24/7 caregiving and other support.   It would be Tom's wish that his family and specifically, his son Jake's, needs be taken care of in his absence. A special trust has been set up to help provide for Jake. For anyone who has been touched by Tom's spirit, and wishes to do something in his honor kindly consider making a donation to help support Jake and his future needs.

title: Emma Kelley’s Fight
text: As you all may have heard Emma Kelley (Brian and Kate’s 8 year old daughter) suffered a brain bleed this past Thursday evening and was med flighted to Boston Childrens Hospital. So many people have asked what they could do to help Brian, Kate, and Emma during this time. So my family and I have decided, (with Brian and Kate’s permission) to start a fundraiser for Emma and her family to help cover the uninsured astronomical costs that they will be facing now and into the future. As you may have seen from some Facebook posts Emma underwent brain surgery upon immediate arrival at Boston Childrens Hospital. They were able to remove the blood clot in the brain causing the bleed. There's a lot of unanswered questions but our Emma has cleared the first hurdle with many more to come. With all of your positive thoughts and prayers for Emma, she currently is resting in the PICU, with hopes of being moved to the neurological unit soon. Boston Children's Hospital, doctors, and its nurses have done an amazing job in saving her life. Brian and Kate have always been very supportive of all of their family, friends, and the community and have asked for nothing in return. Now is the time for us to provide Brian and Kate with any support we can. This go fund me page has been set up for them, to help with immediate incurred as well as future expenses.

title: Vinny Ruggiero's Medical Fund
text: Vinny was in San Jose on a travel gig and out to dinner with two of his Local One brothers when they were jumped and attacked by a large group two blocks from their hotel. Vinny was hit in the jaw and was sent to the hospital with a fractured jaw, plenty of bruises and many, many lost teeth. After four days in the hospital and a successful first surgery he is now home in New York recovering with his jaw wired shut for 6 weeks. Vinny has at least two months of lost work and a number of medical bills ahead of him and while the Ruggiero family is not one for handouts, we are rallying behind them to make sure this senseless act of violence does not set them back. Any money you can contribute will be greatly appreciated.

title: Help the Bensky family
text: Our beloved Dr. Norman Bensky has served this community for over 35 years. Seeing people through major illnesses, family needs, and a variety of other reasons. Often being much more than our family doctor and more like an advocate and an ally. He had a stroke on April 1st, and then experienced another stroke mid April. This has made it so he is unable to work for an indeterminate amount of time. With the support of his wife and daughters, he is working hard to rehabilitate himself. Between medical bills and various expenses incurred, it is creating a financial burden, when their focus needs to solely be on Norman’s recovery.Now is the time for our community to come forward and give back to Norman and his family in their time of need.If you are able to give, please contribute what seems right for you.Willow Creek Open Door will be collecting cards for Dr. Bensky if you would prefer to drop something off. The family very much appreciates all of the well wishes they have received from the community thus far. We thank you for your generosity and please keep sending love and light.*Check back in on this site periodically, the family will do their best to give updates on Dr. Bensky's progress.

title: Gonzalez Family
text: The Gonzalez Family needs support! This family suffered an unimaginable loss on Thursday morning when they learned that their dad and husband lost his life in an accident involving down power lines due to Wednesdays storm. This very loving family is very active in their church, community, and are always there to support others. Now they need the support. Please consider sharing and or donating to help lighten the financial load and help the family move forward as they grief their loss.

title: Support for the McLaren Family
text: On Monday morning, 7/30/18, Tom McLaren, who has been married to my friend of 16 years, sustained critical injuries in a crash on 128S between the Woburn rotary and Winn Street during rush hour.  He remains at Lahey Clinic in Burlington (the closest trauma center) unconscious with a breathing tube. Amongst other injuries, he has a broken clavicale, broken ribs, broken bones in his face and skull, and a broken humerus, This family is like family- their two kids are my kids' ages and Tom is well known and liked from his work in Newton at the Burr After School Program.  He is a kind, quiet, fun-loving, and caring man with a silly sense of humor- a great dad and a devoted husband.  Prognosis is unclear but recovery will be long,  he is still unconscious 55 hours later.   People have offered to help the family and both being teachers, they would not want the help, but they (Wanda) will graciously accept it. The Newton community I know wants to help and the Wilmington one will too.  Wanda teaches public school in Somerville and is an active member of the Lesley University alumni community and the UU Church of Reading.Please help as you are able- this is a family who has taken a grandparent in their home, too, and who have two wonderful kids with special needs.  All money will go to medical expenses and lost wages at this point.  Rehabilitation expenses, etc. may be added in the future and that use would be added here, too, as part of an "update".Here is an article about the accident:  https://patch.com/massachusetts/woburn/128-traffic-motorcycle-crash-closes-2-lanes-woburnWith our deepest thanks from a group of long term (16-30 years) family friends,-Laurel Collins (Julia, Andrew, Emily and Sarah's Mom), Educational Advocate, liasion for meals/offers of help  (781) 308-4577 collinsadvocacy@gmail.com, Friend from when our sons were in Early Intervention (2001), Educational Consultant-Johnna and Rose Huling, Educator and Librarian, Undergrad Lesley Classmates-Deb Glancy, Undergrad Lesley friend and Leila's godmother(posted with the blessing of Wanda)Posted 8/1/18

title: Kenzie Balian Treatment Fund
text: Our good friend Kenzie Nethercott Balian is suffering from a late-stage sarcoma, which metastasized from her hip to her lungs more than a year ago. After nineteen months of chemotherapy, radiation, and surgery, the family is now turning to treatments not covered by insurance. They have spent thousands of dollars along the way and have committed significant resources to this campaign, but they are at the end of their financial rope and need our help.Commitment, the Soul of LoveKenzie’s relationship with her now-husband Mikayel Balian has been an inspiring example of love and commitment. Shortly after they began dating, Kenzie was diagnosed with a rare form of sarcoma. Every time Mikayel had a chance to run, he stepped up and took more responsibility for Kenzie’s care and emotional support.In January of this year, we were honored to host their wedding at our home. It was a magical day and a much-needed break from the turmoil. Much more than this, it was a positive affirmation of their intent to fight this battle together and live life to the fullest.Rare CancerSarcomas are identified in about 1% of all cancer diagnoses – about 15,000 per year in the United States – and Kenzie’s particular form is 1% rare among sarcomas. Kenzie’s team at the City of Hope and the Huntsman Cancer Institute and most recently UCLA are among the best in the oncology community, but they have had relatively little data on which to base an effective treatment regimen.Since her initial diagnosis at the start of September 2016, Kenzie has undergone aggressive chemotherapy, radiation, complete removal of her gluteus maximus on the affected hip, and complex surgery to remove nodules in both lungs.Each treatment has well understood limits. Radiation obviously must not be overused during an individual’s lifetime. Surgically, one of the lung masses could not be removed because of its location near a critical blood vessel. Chemotherapy, which is targeted poison, wears down all systems in the body..Kenzie has exhausted the options on radiation and surgery. Chemotherapy is tricky: she has undergone and hit the limits on the most effective treatments. Technically, additional chemotherapies remain – but Kenzie feels that her body has taken all it can take, at least for now.Medical DecisionKenzie, with Mikayel and her family, has studied the options thoroughly. Because conventional medicine is reaching diminishing returns, they have made the decision for Kenzie to undergo non-toxic holistic treatments at a facility in Mexico so that she can regain her strength, continue to fight, and hopefully get healed. Insurance in the US does not cover these alternative approaches, leaving them to fund the effort themselves.We know, and the family is well aware, that these treatments are controversial. What does one do when options dwindle and time runs short? We believe that this is not the time to debate, but instead to support their decision in any way we can.A Team EffortThe costs include $30,400 for treatments, plus $22,500 for a three-week clinic stay including transportation, assessments, and supportive therapies. The family has budgeted an additional $5,000 to cover preparatory treatments, travel, and incidentals, for a campaign total of $57,900.The family will supply the first $15,000 directly to avoid paying fees, stretching their resources more than thin. They need our help to raise the incremental $42,900.About UsWe are Erika and Tom Ngo, friends of Kenzie’s family for more than twenty years. Our children have grown up together and have continued a cousin-like relationship into adulthood. We dearly love Kenzie, Mikayel, and her family.

title: Amy Resnik
text: Most people spend more time at work than they do with their immediate families. So, for us, the workplace is our family, and Amy is a huge part of that. She is someone who we miss each and every minute that we don't see her. We all can't wait to have her back so that we can laugh from the many life stories that she shares and be continually inspired by her strength and amazingly positive and tenacious attitude.Nothing gets our Amy Rez down!  So now, as she bravely and confidently embarks on her battle with ovarian cancer, it's our turn to not let our Amy down. It's our time to stand behind her with the strength, courage and fortitude that she will inevitably need to charge through this difficult time.So, we encourage you, and any family or friends, to donate whatever you are able to.  As Amy would do for us all, let's join together to ease the financial pressure that her chemo therapy regimen and other medical expenses will impose on her and her three amazing children.With gratitude for your kindness and compassion, let's be "Strong for the Strong" and show "Love for the Loved" .

title: William Harrison Medical Expense
text: This page was created by friends that care and appreciate the Will Harrison Family. Our prayer is they will feel our love and support through our offering made here. As some of you know, Will has been diagnosed with Lymphoma. This horrible journey began at Thanksgiving last year, when Will started to have pain in his back.  He assumed he had pulled a muscle and started seeing a Chiropractor. When the chiropractic visits didn’t help,he then decided to see an acupuncturist, and this helped short term. The pain elevated from November to January, to the point that Will could not get off the couch, he had no energy and had lost FORTY (40) pounds.After an appointment with an Orthopedic Surgeon, and a MRI that discovered a mass near his spine and many masses all over his organs, the doctor told Will to see an oncologist the next day. From this point, William has received multiple tests to learn he has Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma.There have been many nights at Conroe Regional and MD Anderson because his kidneys continue to shut down. This is a direct result of the Lymphoma. Will and Margaret have had numerous discussions with MD Anderson and they feel along with their team of doctors at MD Anderson that Will is an ideal candidate for a “trial therapy” drug. They have been told that this drug will give Will an 80% chance of survival. Upon learning that this “trial” was available, the Harrison’s diligently completed all the forms that their insurance company required to learn that their CLAIM WAS DENIED AND THEIR INSURANCE WOULD NOT COVER THIS TREATMENT. The MD Anderson team of doctors lowered Will’s survival rate to 40% without this “trial therapy”. Will is a father to two kids in 7th and 11th grade, and husband among the many different titles he holds. How could the Harrisons know that his chances of survival would be cut in half and NOT try to cover it on their own?The decision was made to find a way to pay for the “trial therapy” on their own. The cost of this therapy is a few dollars from $250,000.  This whopping figure does not include the numerous hospital stays or the port that was needed. To date, they have completed phase 1 of the trial and are now starting phase 2. We believe he is improving with these treatments as he has more energy and his kidneys are functioning better.  Will is making progress and we PRAY that HE WILL DEFEAT this! We ask you to please lift Will in prayer. Our God is mighty and able to Heal.Please consider donating to this GO FUND ME that was created to help the Harrisons with the financial stress of this time. James 5:15And the prayer offered in faith will restore the one who is sick, and the Lord will raise him up, and if he has committed sins, they will be forgiven him.

title: RulaRules
text: Over the years, our family member, loyal friend, role model, warrior, single mother of three, a fun-loving person to just hang out with, and a pretty great cook, Rula Abu-Rajab has supported countless people. Without any thought given, she has helped everyone around her, near and far, and it is without a doubt that what she has given to everyone embodies the word "inspiring." As many friends and family members know, our warrior was diagnosed with cancer in January and commenced chemotherapy in February which ended in late March/early April as a result of the tumor growing, despite treatment. On her birthday, April 23rd, she will undergo surgery to remove the tumor followed by can intensive round of chemotherapy, a second surgery in the fall/winter and radiation until April 2019. So far, our warrior is fighting cancer with a smile on her face and optimism that she will be able to overcome this. For those who know Rula, she is not one to ask anyone for anything - but she is the first to help everyone. With that said, understanding the nature of diseases such as cancer and the costs of medical bills for in and out of network care - this accrues quickly - and thus we are asking everyone to offer a donation to help with the high costs of her medical bills. Any and all donations will be greatly accepted and appreciated. "No one is useless in this world who lightens the burden of another." - Charles Dickens

title: Amelia: Breast Cancer and Baby
text:
What should be a season of hope and joy as the Bray Family prepares to welcome their second baby has become a period of anxiety filled with doctor appointments. At 11 weeks pregnant with Baby Bray, Amelia was diagnosed with Stage III breast cancer.Since diagnosis, Amelia has met with numerous oncologists, surgeons, and obstetricians.  She’s been scanned, biopsied, poked, and prodded. Cancer has been found in her lymph nodes in addition to her breasts and she’s tested BRCA 2 positive. While we are confident that she has a great team of medical professionals at Penn Medicine’s Abramson Cancer Center overseeing her treatment and delivery plan, we also know there is a long road ahead.Due to the nature of her cancer -- coupled with the pregnancy – Amelia will be undergoing numerous surgeries and multiple rounds of chemotherapy – both of which will be spread out over time to protect the baby. Additionally, Baby Bray will be joining the world a little earlier than the due date. Which means this new little peanut will be starting life in the Children’s Hospital of Pennsylvania’s Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU). All of this will be accompanied by extensive medical expenses for Amelia and Baby Bray’s care.Fighting breast cancer is a physical, mental, emotional, and financially draining experience. In Amelia’s case, this toll is much more acute. On top of the obvious medical and associated expenses, the Brays will lose income during the treatments and delivery, as Amelia will substantially exceed her paid time off at the small business where she works.We know how supportive her friends, family, co-workers, and past and present employers have already been as you have heard and shared this news with one another. The Brays are grateful for the love and support being shown to them each and every day.   Amelia, Derek, Avery, and Baby Bray are determined to survive this season of life and look forward to a future as a family of four thriving together, with cancer and NICU stays as a past memory.All funds received will be used to help offset expenses in Amelia’s cancer treatments, Baby Bray’s medical care, and alleviate financial stresses on the Bray family.  Please show your support for mom and baby. No donation is too small and all donations are greatly appreciated.



#BraysBeatCancer

title: Help victims of a house fire
text: On May 5th 2018, a deadly house fire broke out in my cousin Maritza and Jovani's home in Humboldt Park. The fire took two of their sons and severely injured the rest of the family including her brother, Ivan.Yohel, who just turned 8 in April and his younger brother Yadel (3) both passed away. The youngest of 18 months, Yovani is still fighting for his life.Our cousins, Maritza (mom to the boys) and her husband Jovani, as well as Maritza's brother, Ivan are in critical condition. As the entire family reels from this tragedy and prays that baby Yovanni, Maritza, Jovani and Ivan are out of immediate danger, we are also having to face the reality of arranging a funeral for young Yohel and Yadel, and to begin thinking of relocation for the family.
