Maritza and Jovani, and our family will never recover from such a loss, but we'd like to ask for your generosity to help our cousin's family with the inevitable funeral and medical expenses that come with any tragedy of this magnitude.No amount is too small and any donation would go directly to Maritza, Jovani and their family. Thank you in advance for your support. http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/ct-met-fatal-fire-20180505-story.html-----------------En español:Hoy, Mayo 5, un mortal incendio afectó la familia de mis primos Maritza y Jovani en Humboldt Park. El incendió causó la muerte de dos de sus hijos y causó lesiones a los demás incluyendo a un hermano de mi prima, Ivan.Yohel quien acababa de cumplir 8 en abril y Yadel de 3 años murieron. El más joven de 18 meses, Yovani aún está luchando por su vida en el Hospital Stroger.Maritza y Jovani nunca podrán recuperarse de esta perdida. Nos gustaría contar con apoyo económico para ayudarlos con gastos médicos y de funeraria. Favor de tocarse el corazón.Gracias por su generosidad. http://uni.vi/w09J1013W3Y  http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/ct-met-fatal-fire-20180505-story.html￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼

title: Valerie (Wild) DiMundo's Final Fight
text:
Valerie (Wild) Di Mundo is a person who comes around once in a million years.  She inspires, motivates and loves harder than most.  She is an incredible wife, mother and friend.  She has made a tremendous impact on the lives of so many during her young life.  We write with heavy hearts, that sadly, Val is losing her battle with cancer.  This leaves her husband Adam, and three young children, 6, 4 and 2, in a most difficult situation.  Let us come together and help Adam and their beautiful children. If you know Val, you know that along with her love of Hawkeyes and The Dodgers, Trader Joe's means a great deal to her.  After all, it is where she met her husband.  Adam was working towards making Trader Joe's management his career while Val was beginning to make a career teaching yoga.  Do to an unfortunate accident Adam and Val ended up having to switch things up.  Val began a career as a manager for Trader Joe's and Adam took on the immeasurable role of super dad, staying home with the kids.  They both flourished in these roles.  Val was well on her way to becoming what we call in the Trader Joe's world, a "Captain" of her own store.  Unfortunately, during this journey and at the end of her pregnancy with their third child, Val received news that NO ONE wants or is ready to hear,  Metastatic Cervical Cancer.  Val remained positive and strong staying true to her courageous self while she endured each new treatment, including; chemotherapy, radiation, immunotherapy, cyberknife and a clinical trial.  Fast forward to two years later and their family is now in the final stages; Val has received an estimated timeline.  Their burden will be heavy, let us try and help where we can.   Any and all generosity IS and WILL be greatly appreciated.  Please know that any funds received will be put towards all of their family's needs.


 "Family is not about blood.  It's about who is willing to hold your hand when you need it the most." Buddhist Saying

title: Donna's fight with leukemia
text: Our dear Leonard Neidhold passed away due to a stroke as many of you know.  What you may not know is that his sister, Donna Ingersoll, is going through chemo treatment for leukemia.  Insurance has been maxed out due to previous battles with breast cancer and leukemia.  In lieu of flowers, we ask that you please donate your money to Donna's treatment to help assist with the extraordinary expenses either through GoFundMe or at the memorial service.  Leonard loved his sister Donna so very much and it would have been meaningful to him that in his passing he helped his sister live.

title: Charlie's Angels
text: Family, friends and community know Patrick and Kate as a fun-loving, caring and supportive couple while also being loving and involved parents to Sadie, Mary Grace and little Charlie. They are all now faced with an unexpected chapter in their lives. Charlie started showing signs of illness in the beginning of March. He had seen various doctors before the last ER visit discovered what was causing his symptoms. An MRI revealed tumors and lesions in his brain and along his spine. He was admitted to Riley Children's Hospital in Indianapolis on March 25th. Two days later, the largest tumor in his brain was surgically removed. Pathology reported this to be a Medulloblastoma, and confirmed cancer. Chemotherapy treatment began April 13th. The Neuro Oncology Team at Riley have prepared the Lanes for at least six months of inpatient care, including a stem cell transplant. A CaringBridge site has been created to keep loved ones updated on Charlie's journey to healing & a full recovery.  https://www.caringbridge.org/visit/charleslane Funds received will go towards medical and rehabilitation costs, care for his big sisters, and anything that will aid in Charlie's comfort during his stay at Riley. Any additional funds will be donated to the Riley Children's Foundation.The Lane Family appreciates your prayers & support whole-heartedly.

title: Lindsay's Healthcare Fund
text: Dear Friends of Lindsay and Shawn Grain Carter, Lindsay Carter graduated from Mount Holyoke College in May 2013 and with her Master’s Degree in Public Administration from Rutgers University in May 2018.  She and her mother Shawn were reveling in her accomplishments and looking toward celebrating her bright future.  Their dreams were shattered on June 27th by the news that Lindsay has an MPNST (Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumor) Sarcoma.  This aggressive cancerous tumor in Lindsay's esophagus is interfering with her breathing and swallowing.  She is currently being fed through a feeding peg tube located in her abdomen.  The tumor is the size of an orange and is inoperable. There are no protocols for treating this type of NF1 malignant MPNST sarcoma tumor. Currently, surgery is the most common treatment. However, because of the location in her chest, Lindsay will be undergoing radiation and chemotherapy in an effort to shrink and reverse this sarcoma tumor.It’s hard to ask for help.  Mounting expenses NOT covered by health insurance include round-the-clock home medical care, medical insurance deductibles and co-pays, prescriptions, and supplies for home care.   Many of her specialists do not accept Lindsay's insurance.  In the month since her diagnosis, the bills are mounting at an astronomical rate.  If you would like to assist with their financial burden, a donation of any amount would be greatly appreciated.  Every dollar raised will go directly towards Lindsay’s health care.   The deadline for this campaign is August 24, 2018, which is Lindsay's 27th birthday. On behalf of Lindsay and Shawn, their closest friends, and the entire Carter family, we thank you for your outpouring of love, generosity, and support. We ask for your continued prayers in the weeks and months ahead. Blessings always to you and your loved ones.

title: Support for Greta and Family
text: On June 3rd, 2018, Greta and Brandon welcomed their amazing baby boy, Silas into the world. Greta experienced several complications during the delivery which eventually lead to a newly diagnosed brain tumor. She underwent partial surgical removal on June 29th at the University of Washington, and much remains uncertain regarding her treatment course. This fund was set up by friends of Greta, Brandon, and Silas to give back to Greta who has enriched our lives in so many ways.  Any money donated will be used by Greta and her family at their discretion in any way that is helpful or healing to them.

title: Dennis  F's Medical Fundraiser
text: Hello Everyone,As you may or may not know, Dennis Falvey suffered a massive stroke on November 27th which left him paralyzed in his left side.Dennis spent 3 months at a rehabilitation hospital. The cost of that stay plus his ongoing therapies and surgeries are continuing to incur additional cost of totaling over $500,000.00.  Dennis will be responsible for a significant portion of the bills and they continue to mount!Dennis is now home, and Beth will soon have to return to work. A home healthcare aide will be required during the day. His condition requires intensive and on going therapies which will incur additional out of pocket expenses. The path to recovery is long and expensive!Dennis and Beth were not only broadsided by his stroke, but also the staggering costs of his treatment. Though it takes a lot of courage to ask for help, Dennis has agreed to let us start a " Go Fund Me" to help them through this difficult and financially challenging time.They have a very long road ahead of them.  Dennis has an AMAZING network of family and friends that continue to support them. ANYTHING that you are able to contribute will be so helpful and greatly appreciated by Dennis and Beth.Let's help Dennis get the very best care we can!Please donate and also spread the word. Thank You!

title: Shrive to Drive out Cancer!
text: In July, Todd was diagnosed with throat cancer. After consulting with local doctors, he and Jennifer made the trip to Houston to meet with the best specialists. Todd has qualified for a treatment plan that he and Jen are confident about but its going to require 6-8 weeks of proton radiation along with targeted drug therapy in Houston and it will be costly. Expenses have already begun to mount up and will be coming each week for the next three months at a fast pace. We need to raise immediate funds for treatment expenses while he is out of work, so we want to share that the need is now and urgent. We also want everyone to know that with this treatment, Todd has an excellent opportunity to Drive out Cancer. Please join us in helping Todd, Jennifer, Jacob and Luke in this time. Our goal is take away the financial stress and focus on Healing!

title: Help Daniela’s Fight against Cancer
text: A parents nightmare, Daniela Conte is a vibrant 6 year old girl who continues her battle with Embryonal Rhabdomyosarcoma. Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma is a relatively common muscle and soft tissue pediatric cancer. What makes Daniela’s case extremely rare is that it's in her liver. There are only a few cases of this documented and almost none of them are in children. Upon starting kindergarten, Daniela was first diagnosed at the age of 5 and started chemotherapy immediately. Sadly, the first year of chemotherapy didn't kill it all, and now she has started another year of chemotherapy coupled with radiation therapy and immunotherapy. Radiation wasn't an option the first time because the cancer was so large and spread out. It's much smaller this time and she might be a candidate for radiation therapy in a few months.  Additionally, since this is a very rare form of rhabdomyosarcoma, her oncologists are not ruling out a liver transplant if treatment doesn't work. We need to help Daniela and her family. Insurance won't cover genetic testing for immunotherapy, immunotherapy treatment, and won't cover some imaging like mri, etc... Daniela is also the oldest of 4 children. Her mother Katia cares for Daniela full time while her father Anthony has to continue to work to support his family.   Childcare is expensive and they need to employ a full time care taker.  Please, with everyone’s love and support, let’s help the Conte family together.

title: Pitching In For Paul
text: Please join us in helping Paul and Melissa Nordquist with medical expenses. In February 2015, Paul was diagnosed with metastatic colon cancer. He has beaten the odds in large part because of treatment in New York at the Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, in combination with treatment in Tacoma, WA. While he lives in Washington, Paul has traveled monthly to New York for treatment. In the last few weeks, Paul's health has declined and Melissa took a leave of absence from work. This week, Paul entered into hospice care. Money from this fundraiser will go towards their expenses during this difficult time. Please help us in supporting them. About Paul: Anyone who knows Paul Nordquist loves him! Paul is a quiet, humble soul with a wonderful sense of humor. He's a wealth of knowledge (think encyclopedia), a sharp mind, engaging conversationalist, generous and loving friend, and accomplished athlete. With the South End Rowing Club, Paul took 1st place in the North American Open Water Rowing Challenge, rowed to and from Petaluma and China Beach numerous times, competed in many a Tahoe Regatta, and helped win the triathlon against the Dolphins for many years. Paul has donated much of his time and energy to the rowing and open water communities, serving on the South End Rowing Club board and piloting scores of swims. Paul grew up in Tacoma and he and his wife, Melissa, have made it home since 2010. See this wonderful recent video that captures their love of the area:  http://www.windermerepc.com/meettheneighbors253/melissa-paulIt’s our pleasure now to give back to Paul.Thank you.

title: Friends of Fenov
text: Our friend, our hero and the most amazing young man we've ever known has passed away at the age of 17. Fenov Pierre-Louis, known for his trademark smile, optimistic outlook and vast intellect, left this earth on Wednesday, July 18, 2018. If you had the pleasure of meeting Fenov or hearing him speak, you know that he was always the brighest light in the room.This, despite the fact that he had bravely been battling Stage 4 Nueroblastoma kancer since the age of 9. If you spent just 5 minutes talking to Fenov, you walked away feeling better about yourself. Though he had been through innumerable battles in his fight against a vile disease, he always maintained the sunniest of dispositions. He maintained the highest of grades, as evidenced by his  induction into the National Honor Society. This was accomplished despite Fenov missing a great amount of time from school due to his constant treatments. Simply put, Fenov Pierre-Louis was a brilliant and amazing young man.Together with his devoted mother Mathilda, Fenov  bravely faced many ups and downs in his battle with kancer.  Most all of Mathilda's time was devoted to caring for Fenov, ferrying him from their home in New Jersey to his treatments at Children's Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP) or other area hospitals. Like Fenov, Mathilda always cared for Fenov with a smile on her face. Through his efforts as a Jambassador for the Jam Kancer In The Kan Foundation Fund, his special friendship with New York Islanders star Anders Lee, and his efforts on behalf of Relay for Life at his school, The Academy for Information Technology, Fenov  touched and inspired many people. Videos of him speaking have been viewed hundreds of thousands of times, and so many people have benefited from his words of wisdom. and his positive message. Though he knew his time on earth was limited, he welcomed the opportunity to motivate people. In May of 2018, Fenov penned a poem that included the following words:How I could make a lasting impression upon the earth?I want to make people proud, and inspire with words,And inspire with actions, inspire with who I am,Who would’ve thought that it would start with a speech at a Kancer Jam?We are blessed that Fenov has come into our lives, and we pledge to continue his efforts and carry forth his message.We ask that you consider making a donation to assist Fenov's family in covering his funeral and other expenses they are facing.We thank you for supporting Fenov's family in memory of this amazing young man .Thank you.

title: Help Heal a Hero
text: Emily was involved in a skydiving accident on November 26th, 2017. She was an instructor on an accelerated free fall level 1 jump. The jump did not go as was planned and practiced on the ground. Emily chased the student through the student’s normal pull altitude, putting aside her safety, catching and deploying their parachute for them around 2,200 feet. Once she was clear of her student, Emily deployed her own parachute. As her main opened, her automatic activation device deployed her reserve also. At approximately 500 feet Emily had two parachutes in a biplane configuration. Between 100 and 200 feet above the ground the parachutes began to separate. She attempted to keep the parachutes above her head as much as possible. Emily impacted the ground about half a mile west-northwest of the drop zone (DZ) on a rocky hillside. Her injuries were serious, but she is still with us! Help from the DZ arrived within ten minutes of impact which included her husband. He stabilized her, addressed her injuries and coordinated life flight. About 50 minutes later she was on her way to Scripps Mercy. Emily’s injuries included: broken left femur (fixed with an IM nail), multiple pelvic fractures, five broken ribs on her left, two broken ribs on her right, a bleed in her left frontal lobe, and two small brain bruises. Emily was unconscious until December 6th when she woke up about 3:30 am and decided to try to take a selfie (with the phone Ricky had fallen asleep next to her in his hand) to see what she looked like with all the tubes in. Emily was at Scripps Mercy until Dec 10th, Navy Medical Center San Diego Balboa through Dec 14th, and finally San Diego Rehab until Dec 23rd when she finally was able to go home. While all of her fractured bones have healed, or are almost fully healed, her brain is struggling. Her traumatic brain injury has escalated to a point which is no longer manageable in the comfort of her own home with her husband taking care of her.  She is both confused and combative. We ask that everyone comes together as a community to help get her the care that her brain needs. In order for her brain to get the proper care it needs to heal, she will need to be in a 24 hour care facility which specializes in traumatic brain injuries as well as cognitive and behavioral therapies. The hope is that in 6 months to 1 year, Emily will be ready to live at home again. Casa Colina in Apply Valley is holding a bed for her. The costs for this care facility are $700-$900 per day, depending on the level of care she will require. We are setting a goal of $200,000 so that she could be covered for at least 6 months of care regardless of insurance input. Emily is a hero. She is brave, she is strong, she is fighting, and she fiercely needs our help.

title: Mary's Super Support System
text: Fighter. Mom. Genuine. Lovable. Adorable. Generous. Effervescent. Unique. Strong. Hilarious. Child of God. A straight gangsta'. Sincere. Irreplaceable.  Authentic. Selfless.  These are all words used to describe my sister, Mary, from her closest friends and family. And may I add one more, Larger than Life (you can see that just by her smile).Mary was diagnosed with colon cancer in January, 2017.  She underwent chemo for 6 months and was then declared cancer free by August 2017.  She questioned a spot that the doctors had seen on her liver that wasn't yet diagnosed as of November, 2017, and after they did a  scan to see what the spot was in February, 2018, it was revealed that she had a recurrence--metastatic Stage 4 cancer that has spread to her liver.  She has 5 tumors on her liver that are shrinking after she has been doing chemo from March to June, 2018. No more tumors are showing up and she will undergo major surgery Wednesday on her liver to section out the areas that have the tumors, followed by more chemo (undetermined amount as of now) to make sure the cancer hasn't and won't spread any further.  Needless to say, it has been a very tough journey for Mary and her family over the last 1 1/2 years and they can't seem to catch a break.  Phil is in between jobs right now and they are having health insurance issues.  We all know the exorbitant cost of healthcare and how it doesn't take much for it to become overwhelming.  Mary really didn't want me to create this page for her because she is not one to ask for anything. EVER.  I am asking on her behalf because I would really like to help her and her family to not have financial stress on top of the stress of being sick.  People are always asking in what way they can help and I thought this would be a great way to show support if you want to.  The funds that are raised will go toward their hefty COBRA insurance payments each month, travel expenses for Phil during the time Mary will be in the hospital (back and forth from CT to NY every day), hospital bills, and to supplement Mary's self-employment income since she has had to decrease her work load over the last year.Thank you so much in advance for looking out for Mary and being one of her angel's on this earth.  Please keep Mary in your thoughts and prayers for this week for a very successful surgery and quick recovery.

title: Jim Walsh
text: On August 15, 2018, Jim has had a life changing spinal cord injury as a result of an auto accident. Because of the nature of his injury, we will not know the significance of his condition for quite some time.  He suffered a broken neck at the C6, C7, and C8 vertebrae.He required emergency surgery, stayed in critical care in the hospital for several days, and was recently transferred to Marianjoy Rehabilitation Center for further recovery.We are raising money to support Jim, his wife Kathy, and children Kaleigh, McKenna, Faith and Kevin to get all of the necessary help and support they need during this difficult time.  In addition to Jim's medical bills, Faith and Kevin have ongoing medical conditions.  At a young age, Faith was misdiagnosed and just recently discovered to have epilepsy.  Kevin also has severe cognitive disabilities and will require lifelong care.Modifications to Jim's home, medical equipment, adaptive equipment for driving and helping with all the normal bills are just a few of the many things this account is designed to help with. All of the funds will directly go to Jim and his family.

title: Giselle Deserves a Fighting Chance
text: On Friday March 9, 2018 My daughter Giselle who is 10 years old, was diagnosed with Stage IV Glioblastoma which is a cancerous brain tumor. The tumor is located in the center of the brain near her brain stem which Doctors have ruled as inoperable and un-treatable. I wish to seek a second opinion and fight for my daughters life, as a Mother and any other Mother in this world would do the same and fight til' the very last breath. The money raised in this campaign will help with unforeseen expenses that may arise regarding costs that the insurance will not cover such as flying her out of state for second opinions, clinical trials, and miscellaneous expenses all in the effort to fight! I like to think that the word cancer has the word CAN in it as a statement of what we CAN do and not what we can’t do and with your help I believe we CAN fight this. If you cannot donate financially, please share and keep Giselle in your prayers.

title: Help Philip get Kidney Surgery
text: In May 2012, Philip Arinze was diagnosed with steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome, a chronic kidney disease that leads to gradual deterioration of kidney function. Unfortunately, all efforts to treat and reverse the damage were ineffective. Philip, who was then a student of Loyola Jesuit College, Abuja, Nigeria, had to be absent from school for a couple terms. Despite this, he graduated with good grades and won an award for his resilience. This was no surprise to me as Philip has always been spirited as evident in our days in primary school at St. Saviours, Ebutte Metta. Philip enrolled in Babcock University where he is studying Computer Science. His kidney function continued to worsen over time until finally in the first quarter of 2017, he reached end stage renal disease and lost all of his kidney function. He eventually commenced dialysis and was advised to plan for a kidney transplant. Due to lack of adequate funding, Philip and his family prepared for the transplant to be done in Nigeria. On the 4th of December 2017, Philip was taken in for the transplant operation but post-surgery, the transplanted kidney did not function as expected. Philip was operated on three times in a period of ten days. Due to several complications, Philip is in urgent need of another kidney transplant as his current condition is quickly deteriorating with symptoms such as muscle weakness and wasting(loss), anemia, lack of appetite, loss of weight and edema just to name a few. His family has been advised against doing the second transplant in Nigeria and is looking into The United States, Germany or India as countries where this surgery has been statistically successful. As was stated earlier, the expenses involved in doing the transplant in the above stated countries are quite difficult for Philip's family alone to bear. This is where we will need the help and support of all you kind hearted individuals who have taken the time to read this. Your generous donations will go a long way in not only financing this transplant but more importantly, granting Philip the chance to have his life back. Thank you in advance for your support. God bless you all.Necessary as per GoFundMe compliance requirements:My name is Chike Udenze and I'm a childhood friend of Philip from Lagos. We attended the same primary and secondary schools in Nigeria but I'm currently based in New York City. The entirety of the funds raised via this campaign(bar GoFundMe's transaction fees) would be sent to Philip's mum's Nigerian account.  Upon inquiring toGoFundMe into how to send these funds directly to her account, I was informed that they don't support transfer directly yo international accounts. Find attached image of email from GoFundMe. Thus, I will transfer the funds my business US account and wire it to Philip's mum's Nigerian account. These funds will go towards the cost of the transportation to the medical facility in India as well as the cost of the medical procedure.Benefactor Full Name: Philip Arinze.Person Receiving Money: Unoma Arinze (Lagos, Nigeria)Method of Transfer:  Wire

title: Baby Anchor Tanaka
text: The Tanaka's - Chris, Jenny, Kayana and Aukai were so excited to find out that their dream of having a 3rd baby was finally to be realized.  At the four month ultra sound,  the doctors became concerned with this little baby still in utero and they began to monitor Jenny and baby very closely.  By December, it was confirmed that our little baby's heart was not properly developed.  Doctors diagnosed baby Anchor with a congenital heart condition called "Tricuspid Atresia" which would require them to seek treatment in San Diego for an immediate heart operation at birth.Chris and Jenny turned to their faith and their church.  They prayed and asked for guidance and found so much peace in their relationship with God. Jenny had to fly to San Diego in March, where she was blessed with the support of the Ronald McDonald House and the amazing doctors at Rady Children's Hospital in San Diego.  This hospital is dedicated exclusively to pediatric healthcare and is a designated pediatric trauma center.  Our little baby boy made his grand entrance on April 10, 2018.  Immediately after birth, Anchor was carted away from Jenny and admitted to the Cardio Vascular Intenesive Care Unit at Rady Children’s Hospital, where he began undergoing multiple test and scans.  Along with his heart condition called “Tricuspid Atresia,”  blood results found that for no specific reason Anchor's white blood cell count is extremely low.  White blood cells are produced by the bone marrow and they are the first line of defense to fight off bacteria and infection.  Anchor has been on a medication that keeps his oxygen levels up and is buying time for the first of three heart operations. Chris and Jenny continue to put their faith in the Lord and believe that He has a plan for baby Anchor. By the Grace of God and his divine intervention and from all the love and prayers from friends and family they remain hopeful and positive during this trying time. While Jenny and Chris are far away in San Diego supporting baby Anchor, the reality of the financial commitments are setting in.  At first, they thought once baby was born they would be in San Diego for just one more month.  Unfortunately, now they are preparing for what looks like a much longer stay.  Both Jenny and Chris have extremely supportive employers, but at the moment there is no clear end in sight.  Baby Anchor will need multiple heart operations and Jenny will have to remain with him in San Diego anywhere from 6 months or longer.Both Chris and Jenny have given so much to their family, to the paddling community, the life guarding community, to friends who have become family and to their church.  Everyone who knows them, knows they are the ones who give help, not the ones who receive help.We would like to show them our love and support by helping them financially and/or simple thoughts of love and prayer.  Your donation to their GoFundMe page will not only help this beautiful family, but also they would also like to donate a portion of the funds they receive to the Ronald McDonald House Charities.Above all, your love, thoughts and prayers will be the most precious gift of all.  Mahalo e na Akua Mahalo e na kupuna la ea Mahalo me ke aloha la Mahalo me ke aloha la

title: Names Family Medical Expenses
text: This site is dedicated to help support the medical and end of life expenses for the Mitch & Nicky Names Family. As you may be well aware, Nicky’s health took a severe turn for the worst on August 3rd and she has been hospitalized since then. She is currently receiving end of life care at Mayo as her liver and kidneys have failed. Nicole was diagnosed with Neuroendocrine Cancer with Carcinoid Tumors in January of 2018. Nicky’s tumors are in her liver, which is also called Carcinoid Syndrome (carcinoid.org). Since her initial diagnosis, Nicky has undergone monthly injections with a slow release drug called Oceotride or Lanreotide. Those treatments have not been successful in stopping the growth of her tumors or liver. Nicky was preparing to undergo more intensive treatment beginning this fall.Having been with her the entire previous day, no one could have imagined the sudden, very serious onset of her current condition - but it happened. In essence, her cancer caused a very sudden internal system shutdown.Right now, Nicky is awaiting a blessed union with Jesus, and that is indeed something to celebrate!But, Mitch & their daughters are grieving and preparing for something exceptionally difficult for any family to endure. It is hard. It is emotional. It will also be very expensive. The family has medical insurance with a high deductible and out of pocket. So, while their health insurance will be helpful, a large amount of Nicky’s care will not be fully covered. In addition, the family will no doubt need to bear the costs of Nicky’s funeral and associated services.As a dual income family, the Names’ will also need to adjust to a single wage earner, while still needing to satisfy monthly obligations including a mortgage, car payments, college savings and other normal household expenses.Mitch will no doubt return to work at some point, but until he’s able to make that happen, the family will be needing financial help. That’s the purpose of this site - to ask you to please help make this horrible situation less of a financial burden for this family.Anything you would choose to give will be gratefully & humbly accepted and used to help the Names’ manage their obligations under tragic, deeply emotional circumstances.Dan & Marie LaRock would be happy to answer any questions you may have about this site or helping the Names in some way. If you would like to reach us, feel free to email us at: hillslarocks@gmail.comThank you for your consideration and most importantly, for your continued prayers for this family. God Bless.ABOUT THE CAMPAIGN:Dan & Marie are longtime friends of Mitch & Nicky & Godparents to Grace & Gretta. They live in Hills, MN. All funds donated to the family through this site will be held at the Glenwood State Bank, in a fund newly established by the Bank, for Benefit of the Names Family.

title: Let's Help Bea Fight Cancer!
text: Just 3 short months ago our beloved Bea underwent major surgery to remove her kidney, adrenal gland, part of her vena cava, and the 13cm tumor that was causing all sorts of trouble!  Since the surgery, some more tumors have popped up on her liver, and the official diagnosis is  Stage 4 Adrenal Cancer.  Bea started aggressive chemotherapy today (May 21st) and is in for a long haul with many more months of chemo and hospital visits.  As you can expect, a diagnosis like this is scary and exhausting and comes with an enormous financial burden.  We need to help this mom of 3 get better fast!!  ANY amount helps!Since Tony Colangelo is Bea’s husband and manages their finances, he is named as the beneficiary of this campaign.

title: Alex’s Recovery
text: Alex is a Captain at Allegiant Airlines and unfortunately suffered a stroke on an overnight in LAS. He has a long road to recovery and anything you can offer will help! Alex has his loving wife Heidi by his side and his best buddy Rudder cheering him on at home! I will post updates here as I get them. As of now, they are still in Las Vegas and Alex is slowly on the mend.

title: Support for Brody and the Bibeaus
text: Stephanie and Scott have just received some overwhelming news in the past couple of days. Their sweet 9 month old baby, Brody, has been diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia.  They have been trying to get to the bottom of mysterious fevers, arm pain, weakness and other concerning symptoms.  Multiple trips to the pediatrician over the past month has left them reassured. Tuesday they made a trip to Hasbro Children’s Hospital in Providence, RI for a little more follow up as Brody was having difficulty bearing weight on his legs.  They never realized that they wouldn’t be heading back to their home in CT to finish out their day with their other 3 children (Caidence 7yo, Blake 5yo and McKinley 2yo). Brody has undergone many procedures to confirm a diagnosis in the past 2 days.  He has received CT scans, biopsies, central line placement and quickly beginning intrathecal chemotherapy.  Their world has been completely flipped upside down in the blink of an eye. Stephanie has been a NICU RN for her entire nursing career. And if you have ever worked alongside Steph or had her take care of your baby, then you know that no one has a bigger heart than her.  Stephanie lost her mother, Robin to Cancer in 2017, so their family is all too familiar to the heartache and burden that his diagnosis brings along with it.  If you are able to help monetarily please donate to her family. And if you are unable to donate, please help by sharing this page. All of the proceeds will go directly to Stephanie and Scott.  For an undetermined amount of time their hearts will be split between RI and CT.

title: HSCT Stem Cell Treatment for Mommy
text: Hello. My name is Sandra (Beutler) Sidi. I am a Freshman Composition teacher in the Department of English at Texas State University. I went to Dartmouth College, Class of 2007, where I was a Kappa Kappa Gamma. I'm a mom of two boys, age five and seven and I've recently been diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis.It started six months about, when I was just so tired, dragging myself up the stairs. I couldn’t pick up my children. I was dropping cups in public. Everything hurt all the time.  Then about two months ago my left side went numb – I lost sensation in my hands, I couldn’t tell if something was hot or cold or if I was putting enough pressure around a plate to hold it. But when you're a single working mom of two little boys, who is also in graduate school, you just kind of ignore things, because who has time to be sick? I was a Division I Varsity Athlete for Dartmouth. I played volleyball, I was Middle Blocker, and I saw myself as invincible. I’d say to myself, "my right hand still works, I can still write on the board for my students."  But I was having trouble walking at all, getting shocks down my spine and then about a month and a half ago, at my son Ethan’s fifth birthday party, I could hardly stand. I was too weak even to sit. I was hospitalized and they did several MRIs and it came back that I have lesions in my spine, nerve damage.  My lumbar puncture revealed oligoclonal bands in my cerebral spinal fluid and the doctors said, you have Multiple Sclerosis.MS is a disease in which your own immune system attacks the central nervous system (of the brain and the spine) causing lesions, scars and damage to the nerves. My agility and mobility deteriorated almost immediately. The doctors said, we could try some of the immune suppressor drugs we have come out with over the past 15 years, but my aunt had died six years ago, only 11 years after being diagnosed with MS, taking all those same drugs. The doctors said, these medications will slow, not halt the disease nor will it restore disability lost. And so I was having these terrible conversations with doctors, asking “How much time? How long? How long will I be able to walk, to work?” and thinking at night, who is going to take care of my two little boys?But at Dartmouth I was in the Women in Science Program, and then later at Yale Graduate School (Class of 2012) I was a National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellow, so I just started to doing research.  As much as I could get my hands, my fingers to work, I was reading neurology journals, every study that was coming out on MS treatment, therapies, and very quickly I found out about HSCT, Hemoatopoetic Stem Cell Transplant for MS patients.Stem Cell Transplants combined with Chemo have been a standard cancer treatment for decades, but only in the last ten, fifteen years have these stem cell transplants been applied to autoimmune diseases, like MS.  In a nutshell, HSCT doctors harvest your clean, healthy bone marrow stem cells that do not contain the diseased cells attacking your nerves. They then administer chemo to wipe out the diseased immune cells. Last, they give the patient back their own clear, healthy stem cells.  The procedure essentially shuts down the immune system and then turns it back on, with no memory of dysfunction. The results of this procedure are stunning –over 86% of patients find their MS is completely halted, they go into full remission, and are gaining back disabilities that they had lost as their nerves repair themselves and grow healthy. Patients are leaving their canes and wheelchairs in the hospital, walking out, with complete halt of the disease. What’s so great is that this is not an experimental procedure. Since 1967 HSCT has been done more than two million times around the world, and is to date the most effective treatment to durably halt underlying disease activity and progression of MS.For the science-inclined, I’ve included links to the scientific journals highlighting the methods and success of this procedure:  https://www.bbc.com/news/health-35065905 https://academic.oup.com/brain/article/140/11/2776/4002732 https://www.bbc.com/news/health-36490315I've reached out to doctors doing this treatment, both in America and abroad, and it turns out I’m an excellent candidate for HSCT. Being as young as I am and newly diagnosed, if I get this HSCT treatment I have over a 90% likelihood of going into full remission, including regaining impairments that I’ve lost the last weeks.  They are doing trials on this treatment in Chicago, but it is about ten years away from being offered to the average American and unfortunately I don’t have that time. In America disability index is categorized on a scale from 0 to 10, with ten being the most disabled, and in three weeks my index went from 2 to a 5.I have found a hospital with an excellent safety profiles and over a decade of experience in providing just this treatment that is willing to do this amazing procedure on me. There is an urgency in the fact that the sooner I can get this treatment the better my odds are.  The treatment to travel to the hospital and stay for 28 days where I will have my own stem cells taken out, receive chemotherapy, and then have my stem cells put back into me will cost $89,000.  Despite the very large amount, which is so very intimidating to me as well, I want to say that no donation is too small, every little bit does help me closer.If I am fortunate to raise more, I will use the funds to hire help to make sure the boys are well cared for now, while my mobility is limited, and also when I am in the hospital getting this treatment, so the boys needs are met until I can get better.The daily pain I'm in is very, very hard, but definitely the hardest part of this has been to see the burden of my MS disease fall on the boys.  Having my seven year old joey standing on a stool to make breakfast for his five year old brother because I’m in too much pain or unable to stand long enough to toast a bagel. Telling my children I can’t pick you up, I can’t chase you, I can’t walk you to see the neighborhood cat, having to spend most of our time together laying down.  And you know, my seven-year-old especially is very aware. He’s very worried, saying things like, “Mommy what’s going to happen to us?” and that’s when I realized I can’t be embarrassed, not now, to reach out and ask for help and say I need help – I’ve recently had to go on leave from my job as an English Instructor because my health is too poor to teach. If you can help us, we are truly grateful.I want to add, that the people who know me know that I am a determined person and also a very hopeful person. I see a situation and I just see that there must be a way out. I don’t really accept that there isn’t a way out, and I do what it takes to find that way out and in my case, difficult as it is, there is a way out, this wonderful HSCT treatment for which I’m an excellent candidate and I just want to let you know that if you can help me get this treatment, I won’t let you down. I’ll be back here in 6 months, sharing a video of me back in the classroom, on the track and most importantly, taking care of these little boys that I’m so lucky to have.Thank you so much for reading and donating, or even just sharing my link. If you can send it to groups in your community or post on facebook, that helps me so much. I am so grateful, and my children are grateful.Thank you so much, God Bless.

title: RALLY FOR RUBY!
text: When you think of the words "kind," "loving," and "full of light," there is one person that comes to mind -- RUBY.This is a young lady who literally sees hearts everywhere. She brings sunshine to every corner of the world -- and she is a constant source of happiness in our office. Two weeks ago, while on a location scout in New Jersey, our dear friend was rushed to the hospital, and since then has been diagnosed with some very serious health issues, including a diagnosis of Stage 2 Endometrial Cancer. Many of the procedures she has to undergo over the next few weeks are not being covered by her insurance, which is causing her a lot more unneeded stress -- truly, the last thing anyone battling cancer needs in her life.As her work family, we want to get the word out, because this is a woman who will literally do ANYTHING for EVERYONE else. She will give you the shirt off her back; she'll work for you when everyone else has given up; and she is someone we have to rally around. Her light needs our love right now.So, please, reach into your pockets to help our dear friend out.  It doesn't matter if it's only $1. And please know, she is the kind of person who would NEVER ask anything of us. We know she's mortified that we even started this, but we want the world to know how much she means to us.

title: Lets All Help Mike Hind!
text: Hi Everyone! Lets all help our dear friend Mike Hind with his medical bills! He's been going thru hell with a second go round of a collapsed lung and needs to have emergency surgery in the US. The doctors in Bermuda could not handle the operation because of what's going on inside of him and he has to be airlifted to the US.   He is currently being flown by Medivac to John Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore from Bermuda which has already racked up an $8000 bill.     His Bermuda health insurance will only cover 60% for surgery in the USA... That leaves him and his amazing wife Christine with a huge amount of daunting medical bills!Mike has been family to us all and we all love him and want to see him recovered, back on the stage and filling our hearts with happiness and love and laughter!!! Mike has touch all of our lives in so many positive ways, lets all do our part and help this amazing man during his difficult time!( The kind folks at GFM have asked me to edit the story to add a little more information about myself and why I'm helping Mike and Christine Hind)My name is Nancy Blowers, however most of you know me as Nancy Blauers ( I use that spelling professionally so folks don't mispronounce my name)...I'm as known as "Nancy Mai Tai" because of my band, Big Tiki and the Mai Tais. I live near Orlando Florida in the small town of Geneva. I started strumming ukulele back in 2012 and not only did I fall in love with the instrument, but I also fell in love with the "family" that comes with it! I'm very active with the Tampa Bay Ukulele Society and I help them by designing artwork, logos and merchandise. I've spent the past 20 years designing art for that famous guy that sings about Cheeseburgers....I'm a very lucky lady!!!Mike and Christine Hind have become very dear friends over the past few years. We spent alot of time together at uke events, laugh and support each other. I think Mike is one of the most talented entertainers, his wit and appeal on stage are amazing, an he truly is genuinly kind! I saw an opportunity to help my friend by raising this site and asking you all for your kind donations. I'm truly overwhelmed with the response- thank you all so much! The money raised will be used to pay Mike's medical expenses since his insurance will only cover 60% of his surgery bill in the US. As soon as Christine and Mike are back in Bermuda, I will transfer the money to thier bank account and I'll also send them several thousand via Money Gram Online. It's a safe and secure way to send the funds over to them and they will be able to use your generous donations right away. They thank you all so very much- so much love- you are all amazing!!! Please give what ever you can , every bit helps!Love to you all!!!!

title: Haiti Healthy Kids
text: We are a neurosurgical team from Nicklaus Children’s Hospital in Miami, FL and we undertake pediatric neurosurgery trips to Haiti a few times a year to perform neurosurgical interventions on children suffering from neurological diseases. Since our first mission in 2003, when we performed the first surgical intervention for hydrocephalus in Haiti, we have provided care for over 1000 children suffering from hydrocephalus. We do realize that this, indeed, is a small fraction of the neurosurgical need of the children of Haiti.Our goal in Haiti is to improve awareness, train the Haitian surgeons to become self-reliant and help manage the neurosurgical needs of their children. And while we work towards that goal, we want to continue to be in Haiti and help the children and their families with their neurosurgical needs. The most common disease these children suffer from is hydrocephalus: a neurological disorder where excess brain fluid fills the cavities of the brain which in turn leads to an enlarged head. Several surgeries can be done to fix this, each taking more than a couple hours. In our short trip of 3 days, we are able to help only 18-20 of these children who need it most. However, there are many other diseases where neurosurgical interventions will be needed once the infrastructure is improved.Due to the brevity of our trips, we are able to reach out to only a small population of children who need our help. As a result, we are looking for donations to help continue our support for the children in Haiti by sending a team to Haiti at least once a month and continue to train the local Haitian surgeons. Your donation, no matter how small, would be greatly appreciated as we work towards our goal.

title: Madalyn Kate's Story
text: Madalyn Kate’s Story,On November 30th, 2017, the Rodell’s were the same healthy family of four that they had been for the past 12 and a half years; Joel, Kristin, Maddy and Miles. On December 1, 2017, a single CT scan changed everything. At just 17 years old, Maddy was diagnosed with Hodgkin’s Lymphoma. Four months of chemo would begin to shrink the tumor that had been growing around her heart from 90 cm, to 12 cm. Unfortunately, the tumor grew back to 20 cm during the following two months of chemo. This prompted a surgical procedure and a change in her treatment plan, only it hasn’t worked. Maddy’s cancer battle has now landed her at MD Anderson Hospital, in Houston TX. Doctors are now completing their final tests to confirm what they suspect to be, Primary Mediastinal Large B-Cell Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma. So many people, family and friends, have been incredible over the past 8 months, more than words could ever do any justice; so many of you also, have been asking what you can do to help. Here is where humility has become mandatory for the Rodell’s. All of Maddy’s care and treatment will now be taking place in Houston. The immediate plan has been set at 6 months, and is likely to involve a stem cell transplant. Currently, it is unknown if Maddy will have any time to come home during this time period or not; Doctors are advising at the moment that she stay in Houston. This elongated stay, along with the expected travel expenses that will follow, is quickly creating a challenge; it’s creating a challenge that we are asking you to help with. The ask is that no one would over extend themselves financially; but rather, together when we all pull in the same direction with what we can, we might eliminate this challenge and allow the Rodell’s to focus on the mountain they’ve found themselves climbing. Maddy’s Bible verse is Psalm 46:5, “God is within her, she will not fall; God will help her at break of day.” We, our entire family, are prayer warriors; we would ask you to join us. Our faith is strong and our hope is high. Maddy would tell you, “It may look like I’m surrounded, but I’m surrounded by You.” We’re praising God in the valley as He continues to bear fruit. On behalf of the Rodell’s, thank you so much, and God Bless.

title: Matt Newton-Kick Cancer to the Moon
text: Matthew Newton was diagnosed with TCell Acute Adult Lymphoblastic Leukemia.This is an extremely rare & serious type of leukemia cancer. Learn more about this cancer here Diagnosis/TreatmentMatt has been admitted to Vanderbilt Medical Center and is undergoing an intensive 6 weeks of inpatient treatment. Chemotherapy has begun, along with other drug treatments. This will be followed up by an assessment to determine if he is eligible for a stem cell transplant. We are hopeful this will be an option for him, as this is the only real way to cure this type of cancer. "Maintenance" for this type of cancer can go on for years, depending on how the body responds. He may also need more than one transplant to be successful. But these questions will only be answered with time. Brittany is in Nashville with Matt to love and serve him during his care there. This was definitely the best choice for them as Vanderbilt is uniquely equipped to handle all that Matt is facing.  His parents, Joel and Cathy, have also relocated for the weeks ahead, to be a support to Matt and Brittany any way they can.NeedThe total cost of treatment is unknown at this time but he could be facing at least three years of infusion treatments. We are grateful that Matt has insurance that is already helping with the rising costs of his care, however, there is a cap on payouts for his care. We have set a goal for $250,000 to help cover these additional costs of his cancer treatments. Matt also needs prayer for healing, as well as strength, while he goes through this process.  We give praise for what the Lord has already done and what He will continue to do as Matt moves through this. "Rejoice in hope, be patient in tribulation, be constant in prayer." - Romans 12:12GoalOur goal with this fundraiser is to take the stress and anxiety out of finances, both current and future needs, so that Matt can focus on healing and Brittany can be available to care for him throughout. This will include living expenses for the next few months, as neither of them will be working, bills/treatments that aren't covered once insurance runs out, and future treatments that are yet to be determined.  Thank YouMatt has given his life to loving others, whether through ministry, coaching track, or just being a friend. He gives to people when he has nothing to give. He’s served even when he felt depleted. We are so grateful for all the love and support Matt and Brittany have been shown thus far. We know Matt has the strength and support to beat this disease! Thank you for taking the time to read this and we thank you in advance for your desire to give, pray for and to encourage Matt at this time. "Let's kick this sh*t to the moon!" ~Joel NewtonCheck back often for updates!

title: Mom's Advanced-Stage Cancer Battle
text: March 8, 2018 Our dearest Anna and her family are dealing with a very difficult situation. Her cancer has made a comeback in a BIG way. It has spread into her lungs and liver, and mostly into her bones. She is currently in the hospital and is hoping to be released soon. However, she is unable to walk (the cancer has all but obliterated the left side of her pelvis). She hopes to be going home in a motorized wheelchair. As you know, she has battled and beat cancer before. She is very positive she will do it again, but it is going to be a long, suffering battle this time around. But, if ANYBODY can do it, ANNA CAN!!!! Only a week ago, Anna was walking with a limp and a dull pain in her hip. This has escalated so fast, that she can no longer bear any weight on her left side - AND she can no longer move her left leg without excruciating pain. This is what has rendered her immobile. And this is what she hopes to treat and to, somehow, find a way to become mobile again. Anna is seriously considering traveling to the Hope4Cancer clinic in Mexico ( https://hope4cancer.com/) to treat her condition in a holistic way. They have a shuttle from the San Diego airport directly to the clinic 30 minutes away. But, due to her limitations, she may not be able to get there at this time. She is hoping to get stronger and for her bone to regenerate so she can get mobile and get healthy again. Life is going to be looking very different for the Parrs for the forseeable future. For now, Anna is at Longmont United Hospital, running more tests and working with an orthopedist to stabilize her bones. After that, she would like to move to a rehab facility before going home. Any donated funds will help the family with Anna's mounting medical bills and day-to-day life for their family. We have also set up a meal train ( https://mealtrain.com/eyq3wy) if anybody wants to bring them a meal and/or send over gift cards for take-out and the like. Most of all, please PRAY for Anna and the rest of her family. She and her husband Shannon (Eric Shannon Parr) are so very thankful for any generosity (monetary or not), including your prayers.  Their daughters Anika (11), Mikayla (9) and Justine (7) just want to see their mom get better so they can continue their nightly dance parties under the disco ball. Let's shower the Parr family with our love and generosity. Thank you all very much in advance for your consideration and love. - Cheryl Swanson (friend and neighbor)

title: Fight For Mike
text: On Sunday May 27th, Mike was involved in a freak bicycle accident. He hit his brakes too hard and flew off his bike hitting his head on a tree. He was life flighted from Ten Mile Lake to Minneapolis where he underwent a 5 hour surgery to repair a fracture in his T1 vertebrae. His spinal cord was also compressed during the accident which has left him currently paralyzed from the chest down. He has started his recovery but will be starting rehabilitation once he leaves the hospital.  We are asking for any donations to help with unforeseen medical costs associated with this type of injury. We appreciate all of the calls, comments, and prayers. Please keep them coming.

title: Gabrielle Richmond Needs Our Help
text: GABRIELLE'S (KIND OF TERRIFYING) STORY:(Gabrielle, Myself and my Husband, Leif)My sister Gabrielle is one of the most charitable people I know. I remember when Hurricane Katrina hit New Orleans; my sister, who was 10 at the time, went around our neighborhood with a wagon knocking on doors and asking for food donations. She was just so desperate to help anyway she could.Gabrielle has always been that way. As a kid she would ask for donations instead of birthday presents. She would host blanket-making parties as a teenager to provide warmth for patients in hospice homes. Today you can find her dressing up as a Disney princess to bring smiles to the faces of sick children in the Orlando area.  When someone needs help, she will move mountains to help them. Well, now she needs our help.(Gabrielle dressed as Rapunzel for the Runway  to Hope charity event)On Tuesday, June 12th Gabrielle was working at a trade show when at about 3:00pm Orlando time she had stomach cramps and went off to the bathroom. She was alarmed to find a significant amount of blood in her stool. She immediately left work and went home where she had several severe bouts of the same bloody stools and eventually became unconscious on the bathroom floor.Luckily, Gabrielle regained consciousness and called a friend to take her to the hospital.  However, as they tried to get her to the car, Gabrielle passed out again in the driveway. Unable to get her into the car and noticing she was losing a lot of blood, her friend made the choice to call an ambulance. She was taken to the nearest hospital and was admitted into the ICU being treated for significant blood loss (her hemoglobin was only 5 g/dl) via three blood transfusions. The doctors focused on getting her stabilized as they tried to figure out what was happening. The preliminary diagnosis was a bleeding stomach ulcer, but that was just an early guess.At 5:00am  on Wednesday, June 13th Gabrielle went into surgery. The doctors did an endoscopy and found not an ulcer but an enlargement of the connecting area between two blood vessels in her upper intestines which had hemorrhaged and bled into her intestines, causing the bloody stools and blood loss.  The surgeons stopped the bleeding by cauterization endoscopically.This is a condition called Arteriovenous malformation. This condition is not caused by external things like NSAID use as ulcers are, but rather is something someone is born with.  The doctors said many people have it and live their whole lives without a hemorrhage happening, while some experience ruptures throughout their lives. We pray this is a one time rupture.We are so thankful that Gabrielle was able to get to the hospital and get the help she needed; without it she would have bled out and the unthinkable would have happened. But with all hospital visits comes a bill, and unfortunately Gabrielle does not have health insurance.Gabrielle moved from Minnesota to Orlando shortly after high school to fulfill her dream of working for Disney and performing. As any artist knows, the life of a performer is not glamorous or easy, but she has the drive to achieve greatness. She is a hard worker and works many different oddball jobs, often working over 40 hours a week in total. She lives modestly, and is completely financially independent. (Gabrielle working her favorite job, a D.J. for Disney's Animal Kingdom) (Gabrielle working as a blackjack dealer for an event company)Even with her many jobs, Gabrielle struggles  to make ends meet and can't afford health insurance. Even with the Affordable Care Act raising the age a child can be covered by a parent's plan, my parents health insurance does not cover anything in Florida, so she is on her own. ( The whole clan! Thank goodness mom was able to get to FL to be with her when we couldn't be )Nobody expects to be in the hospital for an emergency like this, especially not a 24 year-old healthy woman. Between the ambulance trip, the blood transfusions, and the surgery; she is going to have many hospital bills she will not be able to pay on her own. This is just the tip of the iceberg as well, for we don't know how long she will be in the hospital or how much work she will miss. Her employment is all contract work with no sick pay or workman’s compensation. Financially, there could not be a worse situation for her, but you can help her. This is where I ask you to please donate. If I could give her my insurance I would. If I could sell an arm to get the money I would (anybody want to buy an arm...?) But this might be our best and only option. Any amount you can give to help her would be greatly appreciated. The more you give, the more she can rest stress-free and heal faster. She gives so much of herself to other people, it's about time she sees that generosity returned.I will continue to post updates as we learn more information. For now it looks like she will be in the hospital for at least 3 days, keep checking to see her progress. Thank you for reading and for caring about my baby sister.- Victoria Sundberg(Gabrielle graciously volunteering to come see my students as Elsa. I was the coolest teacher around for personally knowing Elsa.)

title: Jackie's Nanoknife Procedure
text: We are asking your support of our beloved mother, sister, aunt and friend-Jackie Parker. In August of 2017, Jackie woke up on what seemed like a typical day, headed to the doctor for a pre-op visit for another minor medical procedure. However, what happened in the days following the visit to the doctor was not typical at all. After noticing a discoloration in her eyes, Jackie proceeded to the doctor and was immediately admitted to the hospital.  After several tests we received the news that rocked our family. Jackie was diagnosed with Pancreatic Cancer-one of the most aggressive forms of cancer that exist. Her only son, wanting the best for his mom, immediately went into action and located the best doctor in Miami and placed her under his care. Since her diagnosis she has undergone chemo therapy and been hospitalized with numerous medical issues related to the cancer and chemo treatment, and with God's healing touch the tumor has started to shrink. Because of where the tumor is located on her pancreas (encasing a major blood vessel) she is not able to undergo traditional surgery to have it removed. Her doctor recently recommended that she see a specialist that performs a cutting-edge procedure called NanoKnife. It is a minimally invasive treatment procedure for inoperable tumors such as hers. Our family has been praying without ceasing that she would be eligible for the procedure-for we know that God truly answers prayers!! In April, our prayers were answered!!! Jackie found out that her insurance will cover most of the hospital bills and medications but will not cover the physician fee. So we held our breath.... and we were told that the uncovered fee is $25,000. This fee must be paid in full before the procedure can be scheduled and performed. As you can imagine, with this unforeseen medical diagnosis, Jackie's current medical bills are growing and she has had to retire from her job at Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines International after 26 ½ years.  The family has been working together to help financially, physically, and spiritually throughout the last 8 months. And it is with a humble heart that we are reaching out to our family and friends to help us raise the $25,000 needed to cover this procedure.To know Jackie is to love Jackie.  She is always willing to help others; whether it is taking the time to visit others when they are sick or sending a thoughtful gift for special occasions, she loves doing for others.  During basketball season, you can always find Jackie cheering and couch-coaching her favorite team, the Miami Heat. She loves to bake and is an all-around fun spirited person.  She needs our support now and we can't help but want to do all we can to help her fight this horrible disease. If you find it in your heart and are able to assist in any fashion with our fundraising efforts, please know that you will be helping one of God’s children continue to be a blessing to others as she always has. Our family thanks you for any assistance that you may provide. Please feel free to pass this page on to anyone or organization that you feel may be interested in helping Jackie. All funds raised will be going towards Jackie's procedure and medical expenses.

title: Steve Herren
text: On June 14, 2018, Steve Herren passed away after a year-long battle with colon cancer.  The loss of such an extraordinary person, husband, father, brother, son, and friend so early in his life is an unimaginable tragedy.Other than the obvious physical signs, one would never know he was in the midst of an arduous journey. Steve had the ability to make everyone around him feel good with his humor and sarcasm, despite the odds he was facing.A few days earlier, in the presence of the chaplain and social worker, Steve’s family and friends surrounded his bed at what they thought were their final moments together. Everyone held hands as they held back tears while saying their heartbreaking good-bye’s. Then, in the middle of a somber prayer lead by the chaplain, Steve slowly opened his eyes and said, “NOPE!”This is the kind of person Steve has been throughout his life. He always had an optimistic attitude and was armed with quick-witted one liners to make light of even the most impossible situations.Steve’s unwavering commitment to family, his passion for sports, and love for his sons Jackson and Carson were evident to everyone who knew him. For as long as his body let him and up to his final days, he was still showing up at their games come rain or shine. His positive attitude, kindness, and fierce fighting spirit are traits that we can all try to emulate and remember. We can honor his legacy through support of his family as they navigate the next phase of their journey.Steve was a blessing to all who knew him.  His smile and laughter will live on with his amazing boys Carson and Jackson. 100% of the proceeds from this campaign will be donated to them and his loving wife, Lisa. Thank you in advance for your generosity. #HerrenStrong #coloncancer #cancersucks

title: Brett Ploessel Medical Fundraiser
text: In 2015, Brett Ploessel was diagnosed with Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis, otherwise known as IPF.  IPF is an incurable chronic lung disease which results in a progressive and irreversible decline in lung function.  In 2015,  they were told that eventually Brett would need a double lung transplant.  Well, that time has arrived and thus the reason for reaching out and asking for your prayers, positive thoughts and support.Brett has officially been listed as a candidate for a double lung transplant and our goal is to transplant at the Norton Thoracic Institute at St. Joseph’s Hospital in Phoenix, AZ.   This hospital has the busiest lung transplant program in the United States with 117 transplants in 2016.  It also has one of the highest one-year survival rates (90%) and has a shorter wait time (15 days) as compared to our local Denver based hospital.  Brett will need to take a medic plane to Phoenix, as his oxygen needs are too great for a commercial flight.  The “one way ticket” alone is $15,000.  In addition to the air travel, he will be required to remain in Phoenix for 90 days post transplant which will require accommodation and care outside of the hospital.  We hope to be breathing a sigh of relief and have Brett transplanted and home by Christmas. Our goal is to raise $25,000 within the next few weeks, as time is critical!On behalf of Brett, Jennifer, and their 2 adorable boys, Jack and Michael, thank you for your time and consideration in supporting the Ploessel family during this life changing event.  Your generosity will play a critical role in assuring Brett can beat this life challenge and enjoy the many years ahead with his loving family that he so deserves!

title: Help for Justin 2B564
text: Aloha all. My name is Tyler and I created this gofund me account for my good friend and beat partner Justin. Justin and I are police officers with the Honolulu Police Department, District 5 Kalihi, Second Watch. Justin is married and has a daughter and son that are in elementary school. Justin was just diagnosed with Adenocarcinoma, type of cancer, in his intestines, liver, and possibly right lung. Justin is the type of person who doesn't want help because he doesn't want people to worry about him. We're setting this up for him regardless because he's concerned with the medical expenses.  He's a hard worker, a great officer, and an even better friend and brother in blue.Justin will be seeking medical treatment in the mainland.

title: Leslie Crisp kicks cancer's ass
text: http://yt.vu/UyMlnH3Y1t4 I am Dominique Crisp. My family and I are raising funds to cover treatment costs for our mother Leslie Crisp who was quite suddenly diagnosed with a Stage 4 fast spreading cancer that appears to be concentrated in her omentum and right lung. Leslie has chosen to follow an alternate treatment path that will offer her a higher success rate of regaining her health and vitality. Due to the severity of this diagnosis, we have to act fast and have been forced to raise funds in order to save her life!On March 2nd of this year, my mother went to her doctor complaining of abdominal pain and a decreasing appetite. She was a supposedly healthy woman in her early 60's who devoted her life to the study of health, nutrition, yoga and sharing this knowledge and experience with family and many others connected to her life. On April 20th, a little over a month later, she was diagnosed with a Stage 4 "non-differentiated abno/carcinoma" apparent in her omentum from an undetermined source. The proposed treatment plan of chemotherapy, major surgery, followed by more chemotherapy only offers a 20% rate of success. She was also told she would have an approximate life expectancy of 6 months, should she decide to refuse treatment. The donated funds will go directly toward the diagnostic procedures and treatment of out of pocket expenses incurred so far(approx. $10,000), the 3 week cancer treatment protocol at CHIPSA Hospital in Playas Tijuana (approx. $33,427) and any extra needed to cover travel and a year's supply of therapy protocol necessary to continue her treatments at home. Leslie urges you to please go to the link under updates and listen to the documentary about the hospital where she will be receiving her cancer treatments. Leslie is determined to continue living a healthy vibrant life surrounded by grandchildren and those dear to her heart. She hopes to share her cancer story with many others who need to know that holistic, cutting edge cancer treatment therapies exist that are having impressive long term rates of success. Cancer patients need to view cancer as a divine tap on the shoulder that doesn't have to be a death sentence and with the proper support systems in place can lead to a life of deeper clarity and purpose.Leslie and all of her family members would like to express their sincere gratitude for every beautiful soul who has taken the time to express their love and support through prayers,kind thoughtful expression, donations and sharing this story with others who would like to join this healing partnership to fight for saving a cancer victim's life.

title: Help Ryan Baker Heal From Coma
text: Be part of Ryan Baker's MIRACLE.On February 26, 2018 Ryan was driving home from work and was in a head-on collision just outside of his neighborhood. The impact of the car accident caused Ryan's brain to sustain a severe injury known as diffuse axonal shearing. The injury left him in a coma and he was life flighted from the scene of the accident to the trauma ICU. After several weeks at the hospital, Ryan's insurance has transferred him to a hospital much farther away. Because family support has a major impact on your level of recovery, his wife has had to relocate near the hospital to continue to be by his side.  Without outside donations, Jennifer will be unable to stay by his side, unable to pay their mortgage, and unable to give him the best care. Even with great medical insurance, the costs of his injuries are devastating. He will be in long term care and rehab for many, many months. Ryan is the sole financial provider for his family because Jennifer was diagnosed with leukemia shortly into their marriage,  and they have already struggled to pay those medical bills and living expenses. When Ryan wakes up, we want him to worry about getting better and have as little financial stress as possible. We are continually grateful for the prayers on Ryan's behalf and see small miracles every day. While he is still in a coma, Ryan has begun to open his eyes and respond to simple commands. Despite the long road ahead, we have great hope for his recovery.Ryan has always been a giver and never expects handouts. Throughout his life, he has served his family and community in countless ways. He was an Eagle Scout by age 16, spent two years of his life as a missionary in Brazil, and at the time of his accident was serving as the Sunday School teacher for the 3- and 4-year-olds in his local church congregation. This is our chance to give back to the man who has given us so much.The funds raised will be used to cover medical and living expenses while Ryan is unable to work.Ryan and Jennifer are beyond appreciative of any donations you may be able to offer. And if you cannot contribute financially, please share this page and encourage others to read his story and donate what they can. Thank you, and above all else, please pray! We believe miracles are real, and we can all be part of this one.(The creator of this GoFundMe page is Ryan's sister, Katie Gulbrandsen. Ryan's father, Matthew Baker, will be helping manage the campaign's donations until Ryan is mindfully fit to do so himself.)

title: HALEY AND SETH  RAYMOND
text: Scarlett Kay Raymond was born Sunday, March 4th after a long labor for Haley and Seth. She weighed 7lbs 2 oz and was 20 1/2” long.  She and Haley were discharged from the hospital on Tuesday.  However, by Thursday afternoon, Haley wasn’t feeling well and ended up in the ER.  After tests, it was determined Haley had a kidney infection and sepsis. They found the right antibiotics for her and she was discharged Saturday. But Saturday morning, things took a turn for Scarlett.  While Haley was still in the hospital, Scarlett stopped breathing. Her grandparents, Brent and Le’Ann Downs,  called 911 and performed CPR ON her. She was taken to the ER and eventually transferred to Cook Childrens. This site was formed to keep everyone up to date on Scarlett. They covet your prayers through this difficult time.  We have set Le’Ann Downs up as the beneficiary to not burden Seth and Haley with having to manage this on top of all the other things going on in their lives. Le’Ann will be depositing this to their account. Thanks for understanding.

title: Love and Support for The McGlones
text: As as a new homeowner, and more importantly a new mom (again) of two beautiful girls, Josephine 3 and baby Cecily 2 months, the only thing Christine and her family should be worrying about is snuggling their bundles of joy and turning their newly purchased house into their dream home.But instead, as many of you now know, the last several weeks have been filled to the brim with doctors appointments, blood work and scans, to determine that our beloved mother of two has been diagnosed with Stage 3 B-Cell Non-Hodgkins Lymphoma.  Christine is an amazing mother, friend, sister, daughter, aunt, cousin and wife, and is one of the most positive and caring human beings I have ever met.   As her journey begins we must find ways within our means (no amount being to small) to support her fight.  With Christine's maternity leave coming to an end, now more than ever, it is so vital that this young family recieve not only our loving support but also our financial assistance. These funds will give Christine and her family the opportunity to focus on the most important things, loving their beautiful babies and healing.  As Christine and her family go through this process we will continue to update the site on how she is doing and and what else we can do to make a difference in the lives of this amazing family.
